headline: Nationals Player Tests Positive for Virus Before Opening Day
abstract: Because of contract-tracing rules, four other players and a staff member will be held out of Washington’s season opener against the Mets on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the last Major League Baseball game of 2020, the Los Angeles Dodgers were forced to remove third baseman Justin Turner from the final moments of the World Series after learning that he had tested positive for the coronavirus.

headline: Investment Firm’s Collapse Put Unseen Risks on Full Display
abstract: Archegos Capital Management’s use of swaps helped conceal its exposure to huge blocks of shares but showed once again how lightly regulated derivatives can shake the financial system.
lead_paragraph: After the implosion of a little-known investment firm saddled banks around the world with billions of dollars in losses last week, one big question is being asked all over Wall Street: How did they let this happen?

headline: Clerk Who Questioned $20 Bill Watched Floyd Arrest With ‘Disbelief and Guilt’
abstract: During the third day of Derek Chauvin’s trial, witness after witness agonized over whether they could have done anything to stop what would eventually happen to George Floyd.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — He chatted with a store clerk about playing football. He grabbed a banana off a shelf, flipped through a wad of cash, and hugged and exchanged pleasantries with a woman, laughing with his hand on her back.

headline: 40 Years After Reagan, a Bet Big Government Can Get Something Done
abstract: President Biden feels a burning sense of competition, his aides say, to prove that democratic capitalism can work.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It has been 40 years since President Ronald Reagan declared in his first inaugural address that “government is not the solution to our problems, government is the problem.”

headline: Investigators say a Trump aide took it upon himself to award hefty pandemic contracts.
abstract: Peter Navarro, frustrated by the snail’s pace response to Covid-19, gave contracts worth hundreds of millions of dollars to politically connected or novice companies, according to a House inquiry.
lead_paragraph: The Trump administration was so slow to prepare for the coronavirus pandemic that a top aide to President Donald J. Trump took matters into his own hands.

headline: Jill Biden, in California, Lends Support to Farmworkers Seeking Vaccinations
abstract: The first lady was in Delano, Calif., to mark the birthday of César Chávez, the labor organizer who formed the country’s first successful farmworkers’ union.
lead_paragraph: DELANO, Calif. — Jill Biden, the first lady, traveled to California on Wednesday to visit a pop-up vaccination site for farmworkers who have lobbied for priority access to shots during the pandemic.

headline: Man Is Charged With Smuggling in Crash That Killed 13 Migrants in California
abstract: More than two dozen people were crowded into an S.U.V. that collided with a tractor-trailer near the border. Jose Cruz Noguez was accused of coordinating the smuggling attempt.
lead_paragraph: Federal authorities in California charged a man on Tuesday with coordinating a smuggling attempt that resulted in the deaths of 13 Mexican and Guatemalan citizens in one of the deadliest border-related crashes in decades.

headline: For many college students, pandemic life is disappointing. For others, it is a financial crisis.
abstract: As campuses struggle under the shadow of the pandemic, many students report having trouble paying for food, housing and other basic needs.
lead_paragraph: Colleges around the country have been struggling under the shadow of the coronavirus, facing declining enrollment and major budget cuts. And students have mourned the loss of the traditional college experience, grappling with the disruption as campuses closed and many classes moved on line.

headline: Child Care in Crisis: Can Biden’s Plan Save It?
abstract: Child-care centers improvised during the pandemic, scrambling to stay open with razor-thin budgets and little government guidance. How long will the short-term solutions last?
lead_paragraph: In suburban Ohio, a decades-old child-care center that was thriving before the pandemic shut its doors for the final time in August.

headline: Quite a Job, You Have to Admit
abstract: Sam Ezersky wishes us all a happy April Fools’ Day.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — It doesn’t happen every year, but once in a while the puzzle editors like to throw solvers a curveball on April 1. The most notable one — at least while I’ve been here — was in 2016, when Peter Gordon made a puzzle containing the message, “DUE TO BUDGET CUTS, THE NEW YORK TIMES CROSSWORD PUZZLE WILL END TOMORROW.” I thought that this was a hilarious April Fools’ joke that no one would possibly take seriously, so the Wordplay column for that day played along.

headline: Corrections: April 1, 2021
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, April 1, 2021.
lead_paragraph: An article on Monday about the revival of hunting and trapping certain predators in Montana misstated how Gov. Greg Gianforte of Montana characterized his trapping experience. He said he had been trapping since he was a “tot,” not that he had been trapping wolves since that time. Because of editing errors, the article also described incorrectly the state and one of its senators. Montana is the third least dense state in the country, not the third least populous; and Steve Daines is the state’s junior senator, not its senior senator.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Euphoria and Sorrow as Nursing Homes Reopen a Year Later
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, April 1, 2021.
lead_paragraph: “I thought I would be so happy. And I just feel such grief because of the year of time I have lost and I will never get back.”

headline: Ray LaHood, Obama’s transportation secretary, failed to disclose a $50,000 check from an associate of a Lebanese-Nigerian billionaire.
abstract: Mr. LaHood did not disclose the check on two government ethics forms, federal prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: Ray LaHood, who served as transportation secretary for President Barack Obama from 2009 to 2013, took $50,000 from an associate of a Lebanese-Nigerian billionaire in 2012 and failed to disclose it, federal prosecutors announced Wednesday.

headline: Hong Kong Court Convicts Democracy Leaders Over Protest March
abstract: The defendants, including the media tycoon Jimmy Lai and the barristers Martin Lee and Margaret Ng, were some of the city’s most prominent activists.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Seven of Hong Kong’s veteran pro-democracy leaders were found guilty on Thursday of unauthorized assembly, a verdict seen by their supporters as a severe assault on the freedom of speech and other civil liberties that once were core to the city’s identity.

headline: A 9-Year-Old Boy Is Among 4 Killed in Southern California Shooting
abstract: The authorities said the boy died in the arms of a woman, believed to be his mother, who was trying to protect him. The woman was wounded and hospitalized.
lead_paragraph: ORANGE, Calif. — A gunman opened fire at a Southern California real estate office on Wednesday, killing four people, including a 9-year-old boy who the authorities said appeared to have died in his mother’s arms as she tried to shield him from the gunfire.

headline: Tiger Woods Update: Sheriff Says Crash Investigation Is Done
abstract: Alex Villanueva, the sheriff of Los Angeles County, said that the authorities would need Woods’s permission to release the results of the investigation.
lead_paragraph: The investigation into Tiger Woods’s single-vehicle crash in February is finished, but the results cannot be released publicly until Woods gives permission, the Los Angeles County sheriff said in a Facebook Livestream on Wednesday.

headline: What You Need to Know About Your Vaccine Card
abstract: For now, the best way to show that you’ve been inoculated against the coronavirus is a simple white card. Here, your key questions answered.
lead_paragraph: As vaccinations become more widely available for people in the United States and travel starts picking up, many people have started sharing their simple white vaccination cards on social media as prized new possessions.

headline: Twelve hours of baseball await.
abstract: Of four games being broadcast nationally on ESPN, the most interesting will probably be the Astros’ road opener at Oakland.
lead_paragraph: The expected highlights of opening day, which will stretch from 1:05 p.m. Eastern time until approximately 1 a.m., include the Hall of Famer Tony La Russa’s return to managing with the Chicago White Sox, Francisco Lindor’s debut with the Mets and the Los Angeles Dodgers beginning their title defense.But the most interesting game of the day is quite likely the Houston Astros’ road opener at Oakland, where they will face a hostile regular season crowd for the first time since their elaborate sign-stealing scheme (which helped the team win the 2017 World Series) was revealed. That game between the Astros and the Athletics is one of three opening day games that will be broadcast nationally on ESPN (the Mets-Nationals game, which was also set for ESPN, has been postponed). Here is the full opening day schedule.

headline: The Sabres’ Losing Streak Ends at 18
abstract: Buffalo had been on a dry spell, going 0-15-3 since late February, before beating Philadelphia on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The Buffalo Sabres started the year seeking to ignite their offense with new acquisitions, but instead they found ignominy with a historic losing streak.

headline: Women Are Calling Out ‘Rape Culture’ in U.K. Schools
abstract: Thousands of anonymous online accounts have shined a spotlight on sexual violence against young women and girls.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For weeks, the harrowing anonymous testimonies have poured in, one after another.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: ‘Rape culture’ in U.K. schools.
lead_paragraph: After weeks of harrowing anonymous accounts of sexual violence, sexism and misogyny at schools on a platform called Everyone’s Invited, local and national officials in Britain have begun investigations. On Wednesday, the government said an education body would conduct an immediate review of policies safeguarding students at both public and private schools.

headline: ‘Here We Go Baby’: Francisco Lindor Truly Commits to the Mets
abstract: The superstar shortstop will stay in Queens through 2031 thanks to a 10-year, $341 million contract extension.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Unable to contain his jubilation, Francisco Lindor unleashed a short celebratory scream in his hotel room late Wednesday when his agent informed him that the Mets had agreed to give him a franchise record 10-year, $341 million contract extension.

headline: Boris Johnson’s Government Is Built on Cruelty
abstract: Determined to make good on the nativist promise of Brexit, it has embraced anti-migrant authoritarianism.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Last week, as Britain focused on its gradual emergence from lockdown, the home secretary, Priti Patel, laid out the government’s “New Plan for Immigration.”

headline: New York Will End Long-Term Solitary Confinement in Prisons and Jails
abstract: Isolation for more than 15 consecutive days will be barred in prisons and jails starting next March after years of efforts to restrict the practice.
lead_paragraph: In a far-reaching move that will fundamentally change life behind bars in New York, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Wednesday signed into law a bill that will end the use of long-term solitary confinement in prisons and jails.

headline: Word of the Day: jeopardy
abstract: This word has appeared in 342 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?

headline: Biden Says He Would Support Moving All-Star Game Over Georgia Voting Law
abstract: In an interview on ESPN, President Biden discussed the restrictions passed by the state’s Republicans last week and encouraged baseball fans to abide by social-distancing protocols.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden said on Wednesday that he would “strongly support” Major League Baseball moving its All-Star Game from Atlanta after the executive director of the players’ union said he was open to discussing such a move after Georgia Republicans passed a law last week to restrict voting access in the state.

headline: Laura Wasser, She Who Will Cleave the Union of Kim and Kanye
abstract: A Hollywood divorce lawyer with lots of practice.
lead_paragraph: Among Laura Wasser’s singular gifts is her talent for spinning a tale. One of Hollywood’s premier divorce lawyers, she has cataloged her clients’ foibles, anxieties and misapprehensions in a book and on her social media platforms. There was the wife of a Hollywood producer who imagined that she would still be entitled, post-split, to fly on the movie studio’s private jet. Not a chance, Ms. Wasser told her crisply. “You are no longer Mrs. Producer.”

headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Amazon and Stan in Australia in April
abstract: Our streaming picks for April, including ‘Concrete Cowboy,’ ‘Made for Love’ and ‘Them’
lead_paragraph: Every month, streaming services in Australia add a new batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for April.

headline: Weekly Health Quiz: An Australian Mystery, Covid and the Teenage Brain
abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: It Takes Gumption to Work on a Novel For 10 Years. Ask Angeline Boulley.
abstract: “Firekeeper’s Daughter” is a runaway success, but the years leading to its publication consisted of a long series of quiet mornings.
lead_paragraph: EARLY BIRD Wunderkind novelists are fun to hoot and holler about, but late bloomers deserve a solemn moment of silence. Let’s offer one up for Angeline Boulley, a 55-year-old mother of three, who toiled over "Firekeeper’s Daughter” for 10 years — during her son’s hockey practices and in work meetings; through seasons of celebration (including her kids’ high school and college graduations); and periods of tumult (a move from Sault Ste. Marie, Mich., to Washington, D.C., a divorce).

headline: Poem: If I Should Come Upon Your House Lonely in the West Texas Desert
abstract: Natalie Diaz can be fiercely political, but, oh, my, can she also remind us to love.
lead_paragraph: These days, the sun lingers an hour longer. And with the coronavirus vaccines reaching more people every day, there is the hope that this pandemic is waning. And so I want to remember the love poem. The politics of holding someone close. I won’t pretend that the distance of these past months has reminded me of prison cells. But it has made me thankful for a little tenderness. Natalie Diaz can be fiercely political, but, oh, my, can she also remind us to love. As she says in “Grief Work,” the final poem of “Postcolonial Love Poem,” “Why not now go toward the things I love?” Selected by Reginald Dwayne Betts

headline: A Novel of the City, Alive to Its Hidden Connections
abstract: In “Ghosts of New York,” Jim Lewis introduces four characters and follows their intersecting paths.
lead_paragraph: GHOSTS OF NEW YORKBy Jim Lewis

headline: April Fools’
abstract: What story or memory does this day inspire for you?

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Running Out of Underwear
abstract: A married couple’s contention over a broken washer.
lead_paragraph: Kate writes: We were without a washer for a few weeks. Rather than buy new underwear, my husband, Steve, pulled out a pair of scissors and invented “short johns.” You take a pair of long johns, snip them off midthigh and then wear them like normal underpants. I say he’s ruining perfectly good clothing. But he still happily sings “short johns, short johns!” whenever he puts them on. I worry he’ll strike again.

headline: Dogs Can Have a Little Charcuterie, as a Treat
abstract: “Barkuterie” boards are a new way to spoil your beloved pets.
lead_paragraph: For well over a year now, elaborate charcuterie boards have been taking over the social feeds of food enthusiasts. There have been artful assemblages of the usual items, like cheese, meat and fruit, as well as plates topped with desserts and colorful candy.

headline: Elizabeth Acevedo Understands That ‘People Read Like They Eat’
abstract: “Sometimes we want comfort, sometimes we want to work to crack something open.”
lead_paragraph: “Sometimes we want comfort, sometimes we want to work to crack something open,” says the poet and young adult author, whose book “With the Fire on High” is new in paperback.

headline: Two Humans, Two Dogs and a Two-Bedroom in Brooklyn for Under $1.5 Million. Which Home Would You Choose?
abstract: For their first New York purchase, a couple scoured their beloved Williamsburg neighborhood for a quiet place with good light and more space for their growing household. Here’s what they found.
lead_paragraph: For their first New York purchase, a couple scoured their beloved Williamsburg neighborhood for a quiet place with good light and more space for their growing household. Here’s what they found.

headline: An Asian American Poet on Refusing to Take Up ‘Apologetic Space’
abstract: The writer and poet Cathy Park Hong discusses Asian outrage and why she’s seeking power, not assimilation.
lead_paragraph: This week, a Filipino woman was attacked in Midtown Manhattan during broad daylight. This assault came on the heels of the Atlanta-area shooting in which six women of Asian descent were killed and amid reports of rising crime against Asians. One group, Stop AAPI Hate, received nearly 3,800 accounts of incidents nationally between March 19, 2020, and Feb. 28.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘Rich Countries Signed Away a Chance to Vaccinate the World’
abstract: In this his lesson, students will learn about the stark inequalities in vaccine access across the globe, then consider what the United States should do to close the gap.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “Rich Countries Signed Away a Chance to Vaccinate the World” (PDF excerpt) by Selam Gebrekidan and Matt Apuzzo (You can read the full article here, but because it is quite long, our Questions for Writing and Discussion deal only with the information in the excerpt.)

headline: Are You Shopping for Obamacare? Tell Us About It.
abstract: We want to hear from people who enrolled for health insurance about their experiences signing up.
lead_paragraph: The stimulus bill that became law last month will spend billions to make health insurance more affordable. It will lower premiums for many who already buy their own coverage, and make millions newly eligible for financial help.

headline: Black Friendship, Broadcast
abstract: The hosts of the “OK Now Listen” podcast want to reflect the best parts of chatting with your buds. “I have a tribe of women that hold me down,” Deanii Scott said.
lead_paragraph: Every two weeks, Sylvia Obell and Deanii Scott get on Zoom from opposite coasts to record their podcast, “Okay, Now Listen,” which is produced by Netflix.

headline: The Push to Vaccinate 20,000 Holocaust Survivors in New York
abstract: One survivor who got her vaccine, Eva Rose, 96, said the last year has been “lousy,” but added: “I am still here, thank God.”
lead_paragraph: A year spent hiding at home from the coronavirus has given Anne Bertolino, 96, a lot of time to dwell on the past: the anti-Semitic abuse she suffered on the streets of Hamburg as a child; the grandparents who pushed for her and her sister to leave the country for their own safety; and her mother, a widow who was killed in Auschwitz.

headline: Cynthia Ozick Calls the New Philip Roth Biography a ‘Narrative Masterwork’
abstract: Blake Bailey’s comprehensive life of Roth features a parade of book after book, award after award, and lover after lover.
lead_paragraph: PHILIP ROTHThe BiographyBy Blake Bailey

headline: Billions in New Obamacare Subsidies Are Now Available on Healthcare.gov
abstract: Nearly everyone with a marketplace health plan can seek more financial help. Many uninsured Americans and people who buy their insurance elsewhere can also benefit.
lead_paragraph: Federal officials have reprogrammed Healthcare.gov, making new benefits available to tens of millions of Americans, weeks after Congress authorized spending billions on additional health law subsidies.

headline: How N.Y.C.’s Population Expert Says the City Will Bounce Back
abstract: Joseph J. Salvo, who is retiring after nearly 30 years as New York City’s chief demographer, is optimistic about New York City’s recovery after the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: In nearly three decades as New York City’s chief demographer at the Department of City Planning, Joseph J. Salvo has been the top expert on the city’s population, providing data and analysis of the city’s always-changing populace to help city officials, community organizers and journalists understand the most diverse city in the world.

headline: What if the Pain Never Ends?
abstract: I will still have to face it with dignity.
lead_paragraph: One morning a few years ago, my partner, Donika, rolled over in our bed, looked at me and sighed.

headline: Would You Buy an NFT?
abstract: Would you want to own an official version of a digital good like a video, an image or a song? How much would you be willing to pay?
lead_paragraph: Do you know what a nonfungible token, or NFT, is? Shira Ovide explains in the On Tech newsletter “NFTs Are Neither Miracles nor Scams”:

headline: The Freeing of the Ever Given
abstract: The stuck container ship became the butt of online jokes, but it was no minor crisis.
lead_paragraph: In the end, a full moon succeeded where puny machines could not, wrenching the mammoth barge out of the Egyptian mud in which it became wedged six days earlier. A spring tide finally set the Ever Given and its enormous stack of 18,300 shipping containers afloat again, drawing cheers from Egyptians on the shore and a virtual world beyond.

headline: Science Plays the Long Game. But People Have Mental Health Issues Now.
abstract: I’ve reported on behavior and mental health for 20 years. As I exit, I can’t help but wonder why researchers have placed so little emphasis on helping people in distress today.
lead_paragraph: When I joined the Science staff in 2004, reporters in the department had a saying, a reassuring mantra of sorts: “People will always come to the science section, if only to read about progress.”

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience virtually.
lead_paragraph: The Jazz Standard closed its location on East 27th Street in December, becoming the first major New York club to permanently shutter amid the coronavirus pandemic. But its leadership insists that’s not the end of the story: Simmering tensions with the landlord were largely to blame, and the club is on the hunt for a new, post-Covid location.

headline: The Real Reason for the Border Crisis
abstract: No one is holding American employers to account for their willingness to hire millions of unauthorized immigrants.
lead_paragraph: Once again, a humanitarian crisis is engulfing our southern border, as tens and potentially hundreds of thousands of migrants arrive from Mexico, Central America and around the world in the hope that the Biden administration will let them in and let them stay.

headline: Are We Much Too Timid in the Way We Fight Covid-19?
abstract: The debate among doctors, epidemiologists and economists is still going strong.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a question I’ve been mulling in recent months: Is Alex Tabarrok right? Are people dying because our coronavirus response is far too conservative?

headline: A Man Found 15,000 Bees in His Car After Grocery Shopping
abstract: An off-duty firefighter in Las Cruces, N.M., whose hobby is beekeeping, safely removed the swarm from the man’s car in an Albertsons supermarket parking lot.
lead_paragraph: He had just finished grocery shopping, but a New Mexico man got much more than he bargained for when he returned to his car in the store’s parking lot: A swarm of 15,000 honey bees had taken over the back seat.

headline: Britain Holds On to a Colony in Africa, With America’s Help
abstract: And together they are sabotaging their own efforts to curb China’s advances in the South China Sea.
lead_paragraph: President Biden, speaking at the State Department’s headquarters soon after his inauguration, called the “rule of law” one of America’s “most cherished democratic values.” The notion, a central part of his foreign policy and his faith in treaties and international institutions, is both a riposte to the Trump administration and a useful stick with which to beat China and Russia.

headline: They Are Giving Hemingway Another Look, So You Can, Too
abstract: Lynn Novick and Ken Burns consider the seminal writer in all his complexity and controversy in their new PBS documentary series.
lead_paragraph: Could there be anything more subversive than turning a spotlight, in this moment, on Ernest Hemingway?

headline: An Accidental Disclosure Exposes a $1 Billion Tax Fight With Bristol Myers
abstract: The I.R.S. believes the American drugmaker used an abusive offshore scheme to avoid federal taxes.
lead_paragraph: Almost nine years ago, Bristol Myers Squibb filed paperwork in Ireland to create a new offshore subsidiary. By moving Bristol Myers’s profits through the subsidiary, the American drugmaker could substantially reduce its U.S. tax bill.

headline: Air Travel Is Already Back to Normal in Some Places. Here’s Where.
abstract: While airports in major cities are still struggling, some smaller airports that are vacation destinations are busier than before the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: In Florida, Key West International Airport is busier than normal, while Miami International has half as many passengers as it did before the pandemic.

headline: ‘They Told Us Not to Resist’: Sexual Violence Pervades Ethiopia’s War
abstract: Rape is being used as a weapon as fighting rages in remote parts of Tigray region. “Even if we had shouted,” one woman said, “there was no one to listen.”
lead_paragraph: Mona Lisa lay on a hospital bed in Mekelle, the main city in war-torn northern Ethiopia, her body devastated but her defiance on display.

headline: Virus Surge in Michigan Is a ‘Gut Punch’ to Hopes of Pandemic’s End
abstract: The U.S. has entered a disconcerting phase: Vaccines are rolling out quickly, but upticks in cases raise the prospect of a new surge.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — In a rural stretch of Michigan along the shore of Lake Huron, coronavirus outbreaks are ripping through churches, schools and restaurants where the virus has infected line cooks and waitresses. For more than a week, ambulances have taken several hourlong trips each day to rush severely ill coronavirus patients to hospitals in Detroit, Saginaw or Port Huron, where beds in intensive-care units await.

headline: Turning Away From Nursing Homes, to What?
abstract: Covid-19 has driven down Americans’ demand for senior care facilities. Building support for more elders to remain at home requires systemic changes.
lead_paragraph: Regina Smith has dedicated her career to keeping seniors out of nursing homes. A geriatric social worker at an adult day care network in Indianapolis, she strives to provide services that can help people live independently.

headline: What the History of Pandemics Can Teach Us About Resilience
abstract: Widespread disease outbreaks have the potential to shock societies into new ways of living.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of a series on resilience in troubled times — what we can learn about it from history and personal experiences.

headline: Brandi Carlile Has Always Seen Herself Clearly. Now It’s Our Turn.
abstract: In her new memoir, “Broken Horses,” the singer-songwriter takes a deep look at how “a mean, scrappy little trailer girl with the wrong clothes” became a six-time Grammy winner.
lead_paragraph: Brandi Carlile was running late on account of a kitten emergency. She had arranged to pick up “this kitten thing” for her youngest daughter, Elijah’s, birthday, but then she was told she had to get it in the next 30 minutes, and the cat was an hour away. So now Carlile was sliding in front of her laptop screen for our interview with wet hair and a pink nose while also smoothly instructing an unseen collaborator in the details of deadline kitten extraction.

headline: Enter the Age of the Vaccine Selfie
abstract: From topless politicians to designers, it’s a thing. And it’s part of a longer tradition than you might expect.
lead_paragraph: Someday, when the history of the pandemic is written, it may be a narrative told partly in images: the despair of crowded hospitals and body bags, the fear and isolation of the masks. And then the balm of a smiling individual, one sleeve rolled up practically to the collarbone, with a medical worker poised to jab a needle into their upper arm. Log in to any social platform, and the picture — not to mention The Pose — is almost impossible to miss.

headline: ‘It Takes Time’: I.C.U. Workers Help Their Former Covid Patients Mend
abstract: They survived serious cases of Covid-19, sometimes spending weeks on a ventilator, but not without complications. Now, a special clinic at an L.A. hospital is helping them get back to their lives.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Three days after being released from Martin Luther King Jr. Community Hospital, Gilbert Torres returned on a stretcher, a clear tube snaking from his nose to an oxygen tank. It was the last place he wanted to be.

headline: That Spotty Wi-Fi? There’s $100 Billion to Fix It.
abstract: President Biden's infrastructure proposal aims to close the digital divide, which has existed since the Clinton administration.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Kimberly Vasquez, a high school senior in Baltimore, faced a tough problem when the pandemic began. She had no fast internet service in her home, but all her classes were online.

headline: Deals Designed to Lure Travelers Off Their Couches
abstract: For better or for worse, travel companies are trying hard to get people, especially those who are vaccinated, back on the road (or on a plane) again.
lead_paragraph: For a low-season trip to Honolulu in 2019, I scoured the internet for cheap, cheerful lodgings and the best I could come up with in Waikiki started around $300 a night. Looking ahead to this summer, 18 months and one pandemic later, the Ewa Hotel Waikiki has a condo suite with a kitchen and terrace for $129 a night, and the retro White Sands Hotel nearby has rooms from $179.

headline: Looking for Signs of Economic Hope
abstract: Unemployment claims increased slightly last week, but remained near pandemic lows. A manufacturing index rose sharply.
lead_paragraph: A year after they first rocketed upward, jobless claims may finally be returning to earth.

headline: What Will Legal Cannabis Look Like in New York?
abstract: The state will become one of the largest markets of the drug in the nation. Here's what you can do now, and what will take some time.

headline: 150,000 Painted Hearts, Each for a Life Lost to Covid-19 in Britain
abstract: The National Covid Memorial Wall in London aims to remember those who die during the pandemic. “It’s therapeutic,” said a volunteering painter who lost her grandmother to the disease.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Paula Smith couldn’t hold back her tears as she faced a sea of hand-painted red hearts covering a wall along the River Thames, each unique, each representing someone who died of Covid-19 in Britain.

headline: Setting the Stage Once Again for Shakespeare, and Live Theater
abstract: With coronavirus restrictions easing in England, several venues have plans to give classic plays new life.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Shakespeare is coming back, and I can’t be the only person who has missed him.

headline: A Union Drive at Amazon
abstract: How a small group of workers in Alabama are taking on one of the most powerful companies in the world.
lead_paragraph: Since its earliest days, Amazon has been anti-union, quashing any attempt by workers to organize.

headline: Biden Administration Announces Ad Campaign to Combat Vaccine Hesitancy
abstract: The public awareness push includes 275 participating organizations that will speak to communities where skepticism of the coronavirus vaccine remains high.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration on Thursday morning announced an ambitious advertising campaign intended to encourage as many Americans as possible to be vaccinated against the coronavirus.

headline: It Looks Like a Vespa, Rides Like a Vespa, but Doesn’t Smell Like a Vespa
abstract: An Irish mechanic in London has developed a kit to transform classic Italian scooters into clean-riding electric machines.
lead_paragraph: Among the iconic designs of Italy’s vibrant postwar period, few capture the essence of La Dolce Vita like Vespas and Lambrettas, the free-spirited motor scooters that brought mobility to the masses and became beloved across Italy, and subsequently, the world.

headline: OPEC and Its Allies Agree toGradual Increases in Oil Production
abstract: Some members wanted to take advantage of what they saw as a growing global thirst for oil as economies slowly expand after pandemic lockdowns.
lead_paragraph: OPEC and its allies, including Russia, announced on Thursday they would gradually increase oil production over the next three months.

headline: Biden’s Afghanistan Dilemma
abstract: The deadline for the U.S. to leave Afghanistan is a month away. Here’s where things stand.
lead_paragraph: Is America’s longest war finally coming to an end?

headline: Today's Headlines
abstract: A rundown of the most notable news. Listen now and you’re covered all day.
lead_paragraph: A rundown of the most notable news. Listen now and you’re covered all day.

headline: Fact, or Corporate Fiction?
abstract: Companies still can’t resist April Fools’ Day.
lead_paragraph: Announcing phony news on April Fools’ Day is one of corporate America’s favorite occasions for shameless publicity stunts. But when stonks, Dogecoin and $69 million JPG files are real things that warrant serious business coverage, the risk of jokes being taken seriously could hardly be higher. Some say that’s a good reason to skip them, not to mention the gravity that a pandemic has cast over things.

headline: ‘Amundsen: The Greatest Expedition’ Review: Ice, Ice, Baby
abstract: This overstuffed trek through the chilly life of the famed Norwegian explorer Roald Amundsen is a handsome snooze.
lead_paragraph: The subject of the sluggish Norwegian biopic “Amundsen: The Greatest Expedition” might be the polar explorer Roald Amundsen, but its star is frozen water. On clothing and facial hair, from North Pole to South, ice whitens the screen. There’s every indication Amundsen’s heart is carved from it, too.

headline: ‘This Is Not a Burial, It’s a Resurrection’ Review: Bringing Out the Dead
abstract: In this drama, a widow rises out of grief to protest a threat to her village.
lead_paragraph: The South African actress Mary Twala Mhlongo (who died last summer at 80) becomes an avatar of grief in “This Is Not a Burial, It’s a Resurrection.” With a gorgeously wizened face that feels weighted down by all that she has seen, Mhlongo plays a widow, Mantoa, whose miner son has just died. At first she sits at night by the radio, listening to obituaries and seemingly waiting for her own maker. But she surges into indignant action when a (true-to-life) dam project threatens her village with erasure, and desecration.

headline: ‘The Man Who Sold His Skin’ Review: The Artwork Has Legs
abstract: In this Oscar-nominated film, a Syrian refugee agrees to become a piece of art in exchange for passage to Europe.
lead_paragraph: Art satire meets immigration drama in the Tunisian director Kaouther Ben Hania’s “The Man Who Sold His Skin.” Ben Hania repurposes a real-life chapter from the annals of the art world, when the Belgian artist Wim Delvoye tattooed the back of a man, and then sold it as art. What sounds like a recipe for trouble — what about the human who’s the canvas? — is exactly where the movie lives, spinning a prickly cautionary tale of exploitation and commodification.

headline: ‘Malni — Towards the Ocean, Towards the Shore’ Review: Embracing Our Ghosts
abstract: This ethereal experimental documentary by Sky Hopinka is an essential portrait of contemporary Indigenous life.
lead_paragraph: An essential portrait of contemporary Indigenous life that resists the touristic gaze, “Małni — Towards the Ocean, Towards the Shore,” the debut feature from the Ho-Chunk artist and filmmaker Sky Hopinka, isn’t too concerned with whether we fully understand the traditions and rituals it entrancingly commits to screen. It refreshingly centers the Native perspective, and beckons audiences onto its wavelength by tapping into something more intuitive, the stuff of dreams.

headline: ‘Concrete Cowboy’ Review: Acquiring Horse Sense on the Philly Streets
abstract: Idris Elba leads us through the long-buried heritage of America’s Black cowboys, manifested in their modern-day urban descendants.
lead_paragraph: There’s a quote that’s been circulating for years and years, apocryphally attributed to Ronald Reagan, Winston Churchill and a few other white men: “There is nothing so good for the inside of a man than the outside of a horse.” In “Concrete Cowboy,” the improving aspects of horseback riding — and, yes, stable maintenance — are demonstrated in the tale of a troubled Black teenager, Cole (Caleb McLaughlin).

headline: ‘WeWork’ Review: The Sharing Economy or a Shared Delusion?
abstract: This documentary on the workspace start-up is a fast-paced, entertaining saga of relentless self-selling and a curious corporate culture.
lead_paragraph: Getting freelancers to split a workspace and convincing them that they’re part of an exclusive club is a neat trick, but it’s only the first flicker of gaslighting visible in “WeWork: Or the Making and Breaking of a $47 Billion Unicorn,” a documentary that suggests that WeWork — the tech start-up, or is it a real-estate start-up? — owed its growth less to the sharing economy than to shared delusion.

headline: In Tennis, Tough Decisions as Players Adjust to Shrunken Paydays
abstract: With less money to be won, many players are working harder than ever, especially those not lucky enough to have million-dollar endorsement portfolios.
lead_paragraph: Lloyd Harris has been on a bit of a roll this year.

headline: ‘The Human Voice’ Review: Almodóvar Meets Cocteau Meets Swinton
abstract: The first English-language film from the Spanish director Pedro Almodóvar stars Tilda Swinton and adapts Jean Cocteau to sublime results.
lead_paragraph: A woman is brought to the end of her rope by a recalcitrant former lover. In what could be their last exchange, she speaks to the man over the phone. She cajoles, she feigns composure, she sneers, she renounces — things get kind of crazy.

headline: ‘Every Breath You Take’ Review: The Therapist as Trauma Victim
abstract: Casey Affleck plays a vaunted psychiatrist whose life and career are derailed after he boasts about a miraculous new technique, which then fails tragically.
lead_paragraph: With chillingly minimal interiors, ominously crescendoing music, and a bluish-gray palette, “Every Breath You Take” announces itself as a thriller in predictable ways. Directed by Vaughn Stein and written by David K. Murray, the movie coasts on so many tropes that you almost expect it to subvert them, but the plot remains equally foreseeable.

headline: When Ian Desmond Opted Out, His Work Was Just Starting
abstract: Moved by tragedies to confront the complicated nature of being biracial, Desmond, a Colorado Rockies outfielder, is still away from the game, focusing on his family and his nonprofit.
lead_paragraph: In late July, as the 2020 Major League Baseball season started amid the pandemic, Colorado Rockies outfielder Ian Desmond found himself standing on his eight-acre property in Sarasota, Fla.

headline: The Fourth Floor: But Will Fans Fill Ballparks?
abstract: Stadiums will soon open to thousands across the country.  Our reporter, Jesus Jiménez, went to a game in Arlington, Texas, ​for our new culture and lifestyle show.
lead_paragraph: Stadiums will soon open to thousands across the country.  Our reporter, Jesus Jiménez, went to a game in Arlington, Texas, ​for our new culture and lifestyle show.

headline: The Title Race Is Over. The Fight for the Top Four Is On.
abstract: Everyone knows who will win the Premier League. Most can guess who will be relegated. All of the drama is in the race for a spot in the Champions League.
lead_paragraph: Here, then, is the home straight of the Premier League season, the final quarter of a campaign that was heralded as the most chaotic, and least predictable, of them all.

headline: Wall Street Hits Another Record, Lifted by Tech Rally and Economic Optimism
abstract: Gains were largely driven by technology shares, and the record close was the latest in a series of new highs for the S&P 500.
lead_paragraph: A rally in big technology stocks, a tailwind of optimism from the Biden administration’s latest spending plan and a jump in oil prices combined on Thursday to lift Wall Street to another record, this one punctuated by the S&P 500 index’s close above 4,000 for the first time.

headline: The pandemic showed how broken nursing homes are. But the alternatives aren’t easy.
abstract: The pandemic has intensified a spotlight on long-running questions about how communities can do a better job supporting seniors who need care but want to live outside a nursing home.
lead_paragraph: The pandemic has intensified a spotlight on long-running questions about how communities can do a better job supporting seniors who need care but want to live outside a nursing home.

headline: If You Build It, They Will Bike: Pop-Up Lanes Increased Cycling During Pandemic
abstract: A study of European cities adds to a growing body of evidence that investments in cycling infrastructure can encourage bike commuting, which helps cut greenhouse gas emissions.
lead_paragraph: Adding bike lanes to urban streets can increase the number of cyclists across an entire city, not just on the streets with new bike lanes, according to a new study. The finding adds to a growing body of research indicating that investments in cycling infrastructure can encourage more people to commute by bike, which helps reduce greenhouse gas emissions and improve health.

headline: 5 Classical Albums to Hear Right Now
abstract: A British rarity, experimental voices and a Beethoven quartet are among the highlights of recent releases.
lead_paragraph: Whether the cause is Brexit, or the coronavirus, or the rearranging of priorities that has arrived in their wake, there has been a small but significant recent exodus of musicians from Britain’s shores. The most-talked-about defector has been Simon Rattle, but perhaps the most heartbreaking is another conductor, Mirga Grazinyte-Tyla, 34, who announced in January that she will leave the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra in 2022, after six years as its music director.

headline: It’s Easy (and Legal) to Bet on Sports. Do Young Adults Know the Risks?
abstract: Americans wagered $13 billion on sports in 2019. With sports betting now legal in nearly half the states, experts fear the addiction danger is not being adequately addressed.
lead_paragraph: Saul Malek grew up surrounded by sports.

headline: In the Philippines, Attacks on Asian-Americans Threaten ‘Family’
abstract: The country’s foreign secretary responded forcefully to the recent assault on a Filipino immigrant in New York City. Some have called it hypocritical.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — When a Filipino immigrant was brutally attacked this week on a New York City sidewalk, the Philippine foreign secretary went on Twitter and advised his compatriots in the United States to fight back.

headline: Biden’s infrastructure plan proposes a formula for economic growth profoundly different from the G.O.P. one.
abstract: President Biden’s ambitious plan to increase corporate taxes does more than just reverse much of the overhaul pushed through by his predecessor. It also offers a profoundly different vision of how to make the United States more competitive and how to foot the bill.
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s ambitious plan to increase corporate taxes does more than just reverse much of the overhaul pushed through by his predecessor. It also offers a profoundly different vision of how to make the United States more competitive and how to foot the bill.

headline: How Diverse Are This Year’s Oscars?
abstract: Thursday: A year of many firsts for the Academy Awards could be a sign of progress in Hollywood. Also: More counties move to reopen.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Not Getting the Vaccine? Then You Won’t Be Seeing Your Grandkids.
abstract: A reader wonders what it will take to convince her mother to vaccinate herself against Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: My mom married a man 10 years ago and became a different person. She is still loving to us, but her politics changed drastically. Among other things, she is now adamantly opposed to vaccines. When my son was born a few years ago, it was a fight to have her get a flu shot before flying to visit us. Her husband refused and skipped our son’s bris. Now we’re arguing about the Covid vaccine. She wants to visit, but she and her husband refuse to take the vaccine. I told her until she does, she is not welcome to stay with us. She can’t believe I’m keeping her grandchildren from her. Where do I go from here? I want my kids to have more than a FaceTime relationship with her.

headline: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
abstract: An augmented reality app, Maggie Lee’s latest installation — and more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we share things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

abstract: This week’s properties are a five-bedroom in Bellmore, N.Y., and a four-bedroom in Watchung, N.J.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are a five-bedroom in Bellmore, N.Y., and a four-bedroom in Watchung, N.J.

headline: Unconditional Love
abstract: Can love be taught? A family uses a controversial therapy to train their son to love them. And other stories about the hard and sometimes painful work of loving other people.
lead_paragraph: Can love be taught? A family uses a controversial therapy to train their son to love them. And other stories about the hard and sometimes painful work of loving other people.

headline: Frontier Airlines I.P.O. Signals a Travel Industry Recovery
abstract: The discount airline became the second to sell shares in a public offering this year as more people begin traveling again.
lead_paragraph: The pandemic is far from over, but some airlines believe the travel business is already on an upswing.

headline: Tell Me I’m Fat
abstract: The way people talk about being fat is shifting. A show inspired by Lindy West’s book "Shrill."
lead_paragraph: The way people talk about being fat is shifting. A show inspired by Lindy West’s book "Shrill."

headline: The Brooklyn-Manhattan Rent Gap Is Shrinking Fast
abstract: During the pandemic, the difference between the median rent in the two boroughs nearly vanished.
lead_paragraph: Twenty or 30 years ago, you went to Brooklyn because you couldn’t afford Manhattan rents. By the early 2000s, the borough began catching up with its more expensive neighbor. A new generation of residents was moving in, a sports arena was in the works and lots of new development was rising — along with rents.

headline: The Lockdown Gave My Parents a Honeymoon Do-Over
abstract: No longer a willful preteen, she saw her stepfather in a new light: as a great fit for her mother.
lead_paragraph: This March, as the world marked one full year of the pandemic, my mother and stepfather celebrated their second go at a first wedding anniversary, 25 years after they divorced.

headline: Notes on Camp
abstract: Stories of summer camp, and an attempt to bridge the gap of misunderstanding between camp people and non-camp people.
lead_paragraph: Stories of summer camp, and an attempt to bridge the gap of misunderstanding between camp people and non-camp people.

headline: The Radio Drama Episode
abstract: This American Life pulled together a massive team of theater pros at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Opera House. The result? Journalism turned into a Broadway musical and opera.
lead_paragraph: This American Life pulled together a massive team of theater pros at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Opera House. The result? Journalism turned into a Broadway musical and opera.

headline: BBC Correspondent Leaves China, Citing Growing Risks
abstract: John Sudworth left with his family after a propaganda campaign against him that followed coverage of the origins of Covid-19 and of a crackdown on Muslim minorities.
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — A China correspondent for the BBC has left Beijing after coming under intense pressure and being threatened over the British public broadcaster’s coverage of subjects like the origins of Covid-19 and the government’s crackdown on Muslim minorities in the far western region of Xinjiang.

headline: Watch Live: Day 4 of the Derek Chauvin Trial
abstract: Watch live coverage of the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former police officer charged in the death of George Floyd. Note: The video may include graphic images.
lead_paragraph: Watch live coverage of the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former police officer charged in the death of George Floyd. Note: The video may include graphic images.

headline: April Vocabulary Challenge
abstract: How many of our recent Words of the Day can you use correctly in a 50-word story? Send us yours by April 15. And check out the winners of our March challenge!
lead_paragraph: Note: Outstanding entries to our March Vocabulary Challenge are recognized at the bottom of this post.

headline: With Open Ears, Indian Ragas and Western Melodies Merge
abstract: Amit Chaudhuri charts his musical journey in a new book, “Finding the Raga: An Improvisation on Indian Music.”
lead_paragraph: Amit Chaudhuri, an author and vocalist, blends memoir and music appreciation in “Finding the Raga: An Improvisation on Indian Music,” out now from New York Review Books. In it, Chaudhuri charts a personal journey that began with a Western-oriented love for the singer-songwriter tradition, followed by a headlong immersion into Indian classical music.

headline: How to Start Healing During a Season of Grief
abstract: There is no singular way to respond to heartache or sorrow. Find the strategy that works best for you.
lead_paragraph: We are all grieving right now.

headline: Myanmar Soldiers, Aiming to Silence Protests, Target Journalists
abstract: The security forces have arrested at least 56 reporters, outlawed online news outlets and crippled communications. Young people have stepped in with their phones to help document the brutality.
lead_paragraph: Ten days after seizing power in Myanmar, the generals issued their first command to journalists: Stop using the words “coup,” “regime” and “junta” to describe the military’s takeover of the government. Few reporters heeded the Orwellian directive, and the junta embraced a new goal — crushing all free expression.

headline: Looking Up
abstract: To envision how an ant might see its world, the Norwegian photographer Tine Poppe places her camera in the dirt of a meadow, lens pointing up.
lead_paragraph: To envision how an ant might see its world, the Norwegian photographer Tine Poppe places her camera in the dirt of a meadow, lens pointing up.

headline: What we know about Courteney Ross, George Floyd’s former girlfriend.
abstract: Ms. Ross was called on by the prosecution to testify on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Courteney Ross, a former girlfriend of George Floyd, was called on by the prosecution to testify on Thursday.

headline: Our Sad Souvenirs of the Pandemic
abstract: Americans can’t go anywhere, but we’re still buying the T-shirt.
lead_paragraph: Americans can’t go anywhere, but we’re still buying the T-shirt.

headline: Japan Is Finding It Harder to Stay Quiet on China’s Abuse of Uyghurs
abstract: Public awareness of the issue is growing in the country, spurred in part by the work of Uyghur activists, and that is increasing pressure on the government to take action.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Last summer, Halmat Rozi, a Uyghur Muslim living in Japan, received a video call from his brother in China’s western Xinjiang region. His brother said he had someone he wanted Mr. Rozi to meet: a Chinese security officer.

headline: ‘Roe v. Wade’ Review: A Physician’s Change of Heart
abstract: This hammy period drama tells the story of Dr. Bernard Nathanson, a pioneering abortion provider who later became an anti-abortion campaigner.
lead_paragraph: Directed by Nick Loeb and Cathy Allyn, “Roe v. Wade” tells the story of Dr. Bernard Nathanson, a pioneering abortion provider from the 1960s who later became an anti-abortion campaigner. Loeb has said that the movie doesn’t take sides and tries simply to “lay out the facts” surrounding the titular 1973 Supreme Court ruling.

headline: North Carolina Coach Roy Williams Retires After 3 National Titles
abstract: Williams won three N.C.A.A. men’s tournament championships in 18 seasons with the Tar Heels. At North Carolina and Kansas, he reached the Final Four nine times.
lead_paragraph: Roy Williams, who restored the sheen to North Carolina basketball — and cut a sideline figure as a dapper dresser with a folksy charm — announced his retirement on Thursday, saying that he felt like he was no longer “the right man for the job.”

headline: A key witness in the state’s case against Derek Chauvin will likely plead the fifth.
abstract: The witness, Morries Lester Hall, was seated in the passenger seat of Mr. Floyd’s car when Minneapolis police officers approached him.
lead_paragraph: A key witness in the state’s case against Derek Chauvin has filed a notice that he plans to exercise his Fifth Amendment rights, meaning he will most likely not testify during Derek Chauvin’s trial.

headline: How to Get Started With Tarot
abstract: Six — OK, seven — easy steps to ease your way into deeper introspection.
lead_paragraph: People have been finding meaning in tarot cards for centuries, and though there is a lot of ritual to the practice, there is no evidence that tarot cards actually … tell your future.

headline: What’s in Our Queue? ‘Gore’ and More
abstract: I'm an editor on the Culture desk. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: I'm an editor on the Culture desk. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and listening to lately.

headline: New Mexico Is Set to Legalize Recreational Marijuana
abstract: The governor is expected to sign the law, which would make New Mexico the 16th state to permit recreational use.
lead_paragraph: New Mexico was set to become the 16th state to legalize recreational marijuana after the Legislature passed a bill on Wednesday, joining a national movement to rethink antidrug laws that are increasingly seen as impediments to racial justice and the economy.

headline: American Jobs Plan: ‘My Generation’s New Deal’
abstract: Readers offer praise and criticism of the ambitious $1.9 trillion proposal to rebuild the country’s infrastructure.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: George Floyd’s girlfriend described their relationship: A shared struggle with addiction, their first kiss, a ‘dad selfie.’
abstract: Courteney Ross, 45, said she and Mr. Floyd had started taking opioids when they were prescribed for chronic pain.
lead_paragraph: Courteney Ross, who was dating George Floyd for nearly three years before his death in May, delivered tearful testimony on Thursday about their shared struggle with an opioid addiction.

headline: Do You Have Nafas, the Elusive Gift That Makes Food Taste Better?
abstract: The Arabic word refers to a mysterious factor that renders some people’s cooking exceptional. Whether it’s innate or acquired is up for debate.
lead_paragraph: The chef Mohamad Orfali remembers how his grandmother, whom everyone called Fatoum, spent her days in her kitchen in the Syrian city of Aleppo when he was a child there. If she wasn’t preparing feasts, she was preserving the season’s bounty to stock her pantry — everything from tomatoes and eggplants to peppers, pomegranates and grape leaves. Her cooking was so exceptional, her dining table was never without guests hankering for a meal.

headline: Maine will open Covid-19 vaccination to anyone 16 or older on Wednesday. Virginia will do so on April 19.
abstract: The states join dozens of others, heeding a call from the president, to rapidly expand eligibility.
lead_paragraph: Maine announced on Thursday that adults 16 years and older will be eligible for a vaccine on Wednesday, more than a week sooner than the April 19 deadline the state previously set. Virginia also announced it would allow residents 16 or older to begin getting vaccinated against Covid-19 on April 19, joining more than 40 states that have sped up efforts to open the process to all adults as federal health officials warn about a possible fourth surge of the coronavirus.

headline: His BBC Comedy Show Is Canceled. His Political Fight Continues.
abstract: Nish Kumar’s satirical late-night show “The Mash Report” ran for four years on the public broadcaster. Some believe it was a casualty of a “war on woke.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In the comedian Nish Kumar’s study hangs a poster of his face superimposed onto the famous “Guerrillero Heroico” photograph of Che Guevara, the communist revolutionary.

headline: ‘The Unholy’ Review: ‘There’s Something About Mary’
abstract: Miraculous acts or evil deeds? This tame, trite horror movie has a familiar answer.
lead_paragraph: Satan is at it again in “The Unholy,” the first feature from Evan Spiliotopoulos and what feels like the millionth recurrence of a plot that turns an innocent young woman into the plaything of a soul-sucking demon.

headline: Charlottesville Can Remove Confederate Statues, High Court Rules
abstract: Monuments to the Confederate generals Robert E. Lee and Stonewall Jackson are not protected by state law and can come down, the Virginia Supreme Court ruled on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Virginia’s Supreme Court ruled on Thursday that the city of Charlottesville can remove statues of two Confederate generals, including one of Robert E. Lee that was at the center of a deadly white nationalist rally in 2017.

headline: London Police Officer Convicted of Membership in Neo-Nazi Group
abstract: Benjamin Hannam, 22, is the first British police officer to be convicted of a terrorism offense, according to the local news media. He joined the neo-Nazi group National Action in 2016 and became a police officer in 2018.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — An officer in London’s main police force was convicted on Thursday of being a member of a banned neo-Nazi group, the police said. The conviction was the first time a British police officer had been convicted of a terrorism offense, the BBC and other British news organizations reported.

headline: Mets-Nationals game is postponed after positive tests.
abstract: Francisco Lindor’s Mets debut will have to wait after Washington had at least three positive coronavirus tests among its players, and several other players who had been in close contact.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Major League Baseball sailed through roughly six weeks of spring training without any major coronavirus disruptions, but just hours before first pitches were set to be thrown across the country, the problem lurched up again.

headline: Live Performing Arts Are Returning to N.Y.C., but Not All at Once
abstract: Starting on Friday, theaters, comedy clubs and other arts venues can open at 33-percent capacity. The formula doesn’t work for everyone.
lead_paragraph: This is the weekend New York City’s theaters, music venues and comedy clubs have been waiting for. The chance to start holding performances again for a live, flesh-and-blood audience.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Growing Zones
abstract: How are the growing zones in the United States shifting, and how do these changes affect which plants can grow successfully by region?

headline: A Crawfish Feast Where the South Meets Southeast Asia
abstract: Spring is turning into a comeback season at Crawfish & Noodles, a Houston restaurant famed for the Viet-Cajun style that has spread around the country.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — In early March, a delivery truck carrying dozens of bags of live Louisiana crawfish arrived at Crawfish & Noodles. The restaurant, in a district known as Asiatown, is arguably Houston’s best-known purveyor of Viet-Cajun crawfish. The style expands the flavor profile of traditional South Louisiana whole boiled crawfish, with modified spice blends and a twist developed by Vietnamese-American chefs: a generous bath in seasoned butter sauce.

headline: Esperanza Spalding’s Quest to Find Healing in Music
abstract: The bassist, vocalist and producer’s latest project is a therapeutic suite of songs sparked at an artists’ retreat she started during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Esperanza Spalding has never been one to sit idle. Her wandering spirit has brought this 36-year-old musician major achievements over the past decade and pushed her work in new directions. In 2017, Spalding, a bassist, vocalist and producer, spent 77 straight hours in the studio, writing and arranging songs. The resulting album, “Exposure,” was pressed directly to CD and vinyl for a limited release of just 7,777 copies. Her next project, “12 Little Spells,” explored the healing power of music; each song correlated with a different body part.

headline: Lawyers for George Floyd’s family say jurors should look past his drug use after hearing testimony about his addiction.
abstract: Many people who are addicted to drugs “are treated with dignity, respect and support, not brutality,” the lawyers said.
lead_paragraph: Two lawyers for the family of George Floyd said jurors in the trial of Derek Chauvin should look beyond Mr. Floyd’s drug use after his girlfriend testified on Thursday about their shared struggles with addiction.

headline: ‘The 2021 Oscar Nominated Short Films’ Review: Major Issues in Brief
abstract: From social justice themes to stories about grief and reckoning with the past, this year’s nominated shorts get serious.
lead_paragraph: This year, the Oscar-nominated short films are being presented in three programs: live action, animation and documentary. Each program is reviewed below by a separate critic.

headline: A Code to Live By: What Is Yours?
abstract: We invite readers to tell us the guiding philosophy of their lives.
lead_paragraph: We invite readers to step back from day-to-day events and consider: What is your guiding philosophy or the personal code you live by? How does it play out in your life? Feel free to mention if and how it has been affected by your experiences over the past year.

headline: 11 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: A couple of smart writers recently have put words to something that seems self-evident but bears keeping in mind for anybody who loves to read: “Literature is made of culture,” the critic Laura Miller wrote at Slate, while on Twitter the novelist Sheila Heti wrote, “Writers are their times.” (Or something to that effect, anyway: Heti, a dedicated self-deleter, removed her tweet not long after posting it.) The point is that books don’t exist in a vacuum, and even works of pure history or fantasy are shaped by the context of the writer’s own world.

headline: How to Spot Depression in Young Children
abstract: We tend to think of childhood as a time of innocence and joy, but as many as 2 to 3 percent of children from ages 6 to 12 can have serious depression.
lead_paragraph: When parents bring their children in for medical care these days, there is no such thing as a casual, “Hey, how’s it going?” We doctors walk into every exam room prepared to hear a story of sadness and stress, or at the very least, of coping and keeping it together in this very hard year, full of isolation, loss, tragedy and hardship, with routines disrupted and comfort hard to come by.

headline: Supreme Court Lets F.C.C. Relax Limits on Media Ownership
abstract: The justices said the commission had adequately considered whether easing rules on cross-ownership of radio and TV stations and newspapers would hurt female and minority ownership of media outlets.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court unanimously ruled on Thursday that the Federal Communications Commission could relax rules limiting the number of newspapers, radio stations and television stations that a single entity may own in a given market.

headline: Just tuning in to Day 4 of the Derek Chauvin trial? Here’s what happened this morning.
abstract: Testimony continued on the fourth day of the trial of Derek Chauvin, with appearances from George Floyd’s girlfriend and a paramedic who responded to the scene.
lead_paragraph: Testimony continued on the fourth day of the trial of Derek Chauvin, with appearances from George Floyd’s girlfriend and a paramedic who responded to the scene.

headline: Italy Bans Cruise Liners From Venice Lagoon, With a Catch
abstract: Though environmental groups praised the decision to detour big ships outside the fragile area, they are concerned about plans to temporarily dock them at Marghera, the lagoon’s industrial hub.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The coronavirus pandemic has kept most cruise ships docked. But the Italian government ruled this week that even when voyages resume, gigantic cruisers will no longer be permitted to pass Venice’s St. Mark’s Square and must find berthing outside its fragile lagoon.

headline: Amateur Hour
abstract: What happens when you get a gig with no experience? An episode on unqualified newbies.
lead_paragraph: What happens when you get a gig with no experience? An episode on unqualified newbies.

headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Amazon, HBO Max, Hulu and More in April
abstract: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of April’s most promising new titles.
lead_paragraph: (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our twice-weekly Watching newsletter here.)

headline: The Iran Nuclear Saga
abstract: Can the U.S. salvage a deal despite Israel’s sabotage?
lead_paragraph: Can the U.S. salvage a deal despite Israel’s sabotage?

headline: Solitary Confinement of Teenagers
abstract: The American Academy of Pediatrics says its use “remains common in juvenile detention facilities.” Also: Restoring the Everglades; better treatment of female athletes.
