headline: Why Did the Dean of the Most Diverse Law School in the Country Cancel Herself?
‘Malmkrog’ Review: Now You’re Talking
abstract: Welcome to a three-hour, multilingual 19th-century house party, organized by the Romanian filmmaker Cristi Puiu.
lead_paragraph: It’s winter, sometime in the late 19th century, somewhere in Russia or Eastern Europe. A small group has gathered at a country estate to discourse — over Champagne, tea, brandy, lunch and dinner, supplied by a squadron of silent maids and waiters — about matters of the utmost seriousness. How can we distinguish good from evil? Is killing ever justified? What is the future of Europe?

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Threats to pandemic progress everywhere.
lead_paragraph: Experts around the world are reminding people that despite hope from Covid-19 vaccinations and a clearer path forward, it is much too soon to let down our guard.

headline: Merkel’s Latest Pandemic Challenge: Leading as a Lame Duck
abstract: The German chancellor, known for her cool, solution-oriented response in the pandemic’s early stages, faces her greatest challenge yet as cases rise and patience plummets months before her final term ends.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — What a difference a year makes.

headline: The Interior Department’s chief of staff shifts jobs after ignoring coronavirus guidance and planning an indoor party.
abstract: Jennifer Van der Heide will remain at the department as a senior counselor to Interior Secretary Deb Haaland.
lead_paragraph: The White House has directed the Interior Department’s chief of staff, Jennifer Van der Heide, to step away from her position after she tried to plan an indoor party with roughly 50 attendees to celebrate the confirmation of Interior Secretary Deb Haaland, according to an administration official with knowledge of the matter.

headline: As Nation Speeds to Vaccinate All, Maryland’s Path Shows Challenges Ahead
abstract: The state is wrestling with most of the issues and trade-offs that come with such a giant undertaking.
lead_paragraph: UPPER MARLBORO, Md. — The path to quickly vaccinating the nation’s 250 million adults will be paved with pharmacy chains, hospitals and hulking stadiums where uniformed troops help inoculate thousands of people a day.

headline: George Floyd was dead by the time medical help arrived, a paramedic testified.
abstract: Derek Smith, the paramedic, said that he had first felt Mr. Floyd’s neck for a pulse while police officers were still on top of him and that he could not find one.
lead_paragraph: When a paramedic arrived at the scene of George Floyd’s arrest, he could not find a pulse and believed that Mr. Floyd was already dead, he testified in court on Thursday.

headline: It’s Time to Put Alice Neel in Her Rightful Place in the Pantheon
abstract: A large retrospective feels at home in the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s grandest galleries and should silence any doubt about the artist’s originality or her importance.
lead_paragraph: It is said that the future is female, and one can only hope. But it is important to remember that the past, through continuous excavation, is becoming more female all the time. The latest evidence is the gloriously relentless retrospective of Alice Neel (1900-1984), the radical realist painter of all things human, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: United Airlines restarts pilot hiring as ticket sales rebound.
abstract: United will start by hiring the roughly 300 pilots who either had a conditional job offer last year or whose start dates had been canceled because of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: United Airlines said it will start hiring pilots again, the latest sign that the travel industry is recovering from the pandemic.

headline: Man Arrested in Road Rage Attack on Couple That Killed Mother of 6
abstract: The police said a “road rage encounter unknowingly developed” after a couple’s S.U.V. came close to another car during a merge from one highway lane to another.
lead_paragraph: A North Carolina man was arrested in a “road rage encounter” that killed a mother of six who was on an anniversary trip with her husband, the authorities said Thursday.

headline: Toyota sales jump, but G.M. and Ford’s rebounds are weaker.
abstract: G.M. and Ford continue to be affected by a shortage of computer chips. Toyota’s big jump helped it outsell Ford.
lead_paragraph: General Motors reported a modest rise in car sales in North America for the first quarter, but its operations continue to be hampered by a shortage of computer chips.

headline: Delta and Coca-Cola face backlash from Republicans after opposing Georgia voting law.
abstract: Hours after the companies made their statements, Georgia’s governor took aim at the chief executive of Delta. And Republicans in the Georgia state legislature floated the idea of increasing taxes on Delta as retribution.
lead_paragraph: For two weeks, Delta Air Lines and Coca-Cola had been under pressure from activists and Black executives who wanted the companies to publicly oppose a new law in Georgia that makes it harder for people to vote. On Wednesday, six days after the law was passed, both companies stated their “crystal clear” opposition to it.

headline: Full Text: Georgia’s Voting Law
abstract: New legislation passed by state Republicans creates an array of new restrictions and limits on voting. Here’s the full document.
lead_paragraph: New legislation passed by state Republicans creates an array of new restrictions and limits on voting. Here’s the full document.

headline: A global aid program championed by Ivanka Trump has serious problems, a report finds.
abstract: So haphazard was management of the program that an independent watchdog was unable to determine whether it actually worked.
lead_paragraph: One of Ivanka Trump’s top initiatives — a legislative overhaul of programs assisting small businesses run by women around the world — was so haphazardly managed by a federal agency that an independent watchdog was unable to determine whether it actually worked.

headline: No Country for Any Men
abstract: “Promising Young Woman,” Emerald Fennell’s dark revenge fantasy, raises deep questions about sexual assault and justice.
lead_paragraph: “Promising Young Woman” is one of this year’s major Oscar contenders, clocking in with five nominations. It’s about a woman named Cassandra (Carey Mulligan), whose life is dedicated to avenging her best friend’s sexual assault. It’s a thriller, revenge fantasy, fairy tale and rom-com, all rolled into one. And at its core, it asks a sweeping question: What if there are no good men?

headline: Bibian Mentel, Champion Paralympic Snowboarder, Dies at 48
abstract: After losing part of a leg to cancer, she dominated the sport for nearly two decades, winning three Paralympic gold medals.
lead_paragraph: Bibian Mentel, a champion Dutch snowboarder who lost her lower right leg to cancer, then returned to the sport a few months later and dominated it for the next 16 years, died on Monday at her home in Loosdrecht, the Netherlands. She was 48.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Our TV critic recommends a sweet Japanese series of animated shorts, a warped new comedy about tech overreach and a 13-season classic.
lead_paragraph: Every Monday and Friday, Margaret offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.

headline: Doctors Accuse UnitedHealthcare of Stifling Competition
abstract: A multistate group of anesthesiologists filed cases in Texas and Colorado, accusing the insurance giant of squeezing them like a “boa constrictor.”
lead_paragraph: UnitedHealthcare, one of the nation’s largest health insurers, is being sued in two states by a large group of anesthesiologists who are accusing the company of stifling competition by forcing the doctors out of its network and by using its enormous clout to pressure hospitals and surgeons to stop referring patients to them.

headline: Paul Feinman, First Openly Gay Judge on N.Y. High Court, Dies at 61
abstract: “I hope I add to the diversity of perspectives that the court considers,” he said before being unanimously confirmed to the Court of Appeals in 2017.
lead_paragraph: Judge Paul G. Feinman, the first openly gay jurist to serve on New York State’s highest court, the Court of Appeals, died on Wednesday at a Manhattan hospital. He was 61.

headline: What You Need to Start an Urban Garden
abstract: Brighter and warmer days mean you might be thinking about starting a tiny garden on your fire escape (or balcony, or patio).
lead_paragraph: Brighter and warmer days mean you might be thinking about starting a tiny garden on your fire escape (or balcony, or patio).

headline: Scenes from Minneapolis on Day 4 of the Chauvin trial.
abstract: Outside the courthouse and beyond, protesters and signs called for police reform and justice for George Floyd.
lead_paragraph: Day 4 of the trial of Derek Chauvin drew protesters outside the Hennepin County courthouse and around the city of Minneapolis on Thursday.

headline: What Students Are Saying About Returning to Normalcy, Having Open-Minded Discussions and Representation in Acting
abstract: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts, and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to another roundup of student comments on our writing prompts. This week we asked students if they are nervous about returning to normal life after the pandemic; how they handle themselves in discussions with those who hold differing views; and how closely actors’ identities should reflect the roles they are hired to play.

headline: George Floyd Died Before Medics Arrived, Paramedic Says
abstract: Derek Smith, one of the paramedics called to the scene of George Floyd’s arrest, testified in court on Thursday that when he arrived it appeared that Mr. Floyd was already dead.
lead_paragraph: Derek Smith, one of the paramedics called to the scene of George Floyd’s arrest, testified in court on Thursday that when he arrived it appeared that Mr. Floyd was already dead.

headline: Can New York’s Marijuana Legalization Light Up a New Path?
abstract: Yes, it’s welcome news for cannabis connoisseurs. But for many advocates, the focus is on making amends for the war on drugs.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.

headline: Michigan, George Floyd, Baseball: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Why We Redesigned the Virus Trackers
abstract: Here’s what’s new on our coronavirus tracking pages.
lead_paragraph: In the coming days, we are rolling out major changes to the virus tracking pages that have been published multiple times a day for the past 13 months. These pages are a popular daily source of information for our readers, so we want to make sure everyone continues to find the information they need.

headline: Michael Friedlander, Urban Architect of Offbeat Designs, Dies at 63
abstract: He was best known for the Spring Street Salt Shed, a crystalline structure that appears, with a little imagination, to form a coarse grain of salt.
lead_paragraph: In the 1970s, Michael Friedlander was an architecture student at the Cooper Union, his head bursting with bodacious, unconventional designs. On graduating, he settled for a stopgap job with the City of New York, which had him working on prosaic assignments like drafting blueprints to renovate locker rooms for sanitation workers.

headline: Takeaways from Day 4 of the Derek Chauvin trial.
abstract: Paramedics who responded to the scene said they did not see any signs of life in George Floyd. “In lay terms, I thought he was dead,” one said.
lead_paragraph: The trial of Derek Chauvin, the former police officer charged with killing George Floyd in Minneapolis, entered a new phase on Thursday with the testimony of paramedics who responded to the scene, making it the first time that jurors heard about Mr. Floyd’s medical condition in the immediate aftermath of the arrest.

headline: Teenagers in The Times: March 2021
abstract: Our roundup of the news stories and features about young people that have recently appeared across sections of NYTimes.com.
lead_paragraph: Here is the March edition of Teenagers in The Times, a roundup of the news and feature stories about young people that have recently appeared across sections of NYTimes.com. We publish a new edition on the first Thursday of each month.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: Two states, Maryland and Michigan, offer microcosms of the issues facing the U.S.
lead_paragraph: The United States is in a perilous race between vaccinating residents as quickly as possible and succumbing to a new wave of infections driven by the faster-spreading variants.

headline: Film Club: ‘Inside the Battle Over George Floyd Square’
abstract: After almost a year of protests, the trial of the former officer accused of killing Floyd has begun. What does the debate over a memorial site tell us about the struggle for racial justice in one city, and for America?

headline: Texas lawmakers advance a bill that would make voting more difficult, drawing comparisons to Georgia.
abstract: The Texas measure comes on the heels of efforts in Iowa and Georgia, where lawmakers significantly tightened voting rules last month.
lead_paragraph: Lawmakers in Texas, a state that already claims the most onerous voting laws in the nation, on Thursday took a major step toward making it even tougher to cast a ballot, the latest in a bevy of Republican-backed efforts to restrict voting ahead of the 2022 midterm elections.

headline: The Yankees Start 2021 With Some Enthusiasm, and a Loss
abstract: Falling to Toronto in extra innings couldn’t dampen the spirits of a team buoyed by playing in front of a Yankee Stadium crowd for the first time in more than a year.
lead_paragraph: Twenty minutes before Gerrit Cole threw the first pitch of the 2021 Major League Baseball season on Thursday, his teammate, D.J. LeMahieu, emerged from the Yankees’ dugout and jogged to the outfield to stretch. He was met with something absent from Yankee Stadium since October 2019: applause and cheers from fans.

headline: To Build Support for Plan, Biden Offers His Own Take on ‘Bipartisan’
abstract: President Biden’s $2 trillion infrastructure proposal is a test of his belief that he can generate popular backing across the country as Republicans seek to block him on Capitol Hill.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s attempt to muscle through a $2 trillion plan to rebuild the country’s infrastructure — along with the tax increases to pay for it — will be a defining test of his belief that bipartisan support for his proposals can overwhelm traditional Republican objections in Congress.

headline: Biden Faces ‘a Very Precarious Point’ in the Coronavirus Response
abstract: With case counts rising, the president is in a complicated situation.
lead_paragraph: President Biden continues to receive high marks from the public for his handling of the coronavirus outbreak, and Americans are increasingly telling pollsters that they think the worst of the pandemic is behind us. On Thursday, the Consumer Confidence Index, a weekly measure of the public’s economic attitudes, hit its highest level since the start of the pandemic.

headline: Officers should have stopped restraining George Floyd sooner, a former supervisor of Derek Chauvin’s testified.
abstract: Mr. Chauvin said the officers had to restrain Mr. Floyd because he would not stay in the back of a police car. “He was going crazy,” he said.
lead_paragraph: A sergeant who supervised Derek Chauvin testified on Thursday that Mr. Chauvin and other police officers should have stopped holding George Floyd down once he became unresponsive.

headline: A decline in testing may be masking the spread of the virus in some U.S. states.
abstract: Efforts to speed up vaccinations have diverted resources from screening, and fewer people seem to seek out a test unless they are ill.
lead_paragraph: Declines in coronavirus testing in many states in the South and the Great Plains are making it harder to know just how widely the virus may be spreading in those states, even as restrictions are lifted and residents ease back into daily life, experts say.

headline: How Covid Can Change Your Personality
abstract: Distancing and isolation shaped who we are.
lead_paragraph: I don’t know about you, but I’ve found the latest stage of the pandemic hard in its own distinct way. The cumulative effect of a year of repetition, isolation and stress has induced a lassitude — a settling into the familiar, with feelings of vulnerability. The shock of a year ago has been replaced by a sluggish just-getting-to-the-end.

headline: Bidenomics Is as American as Apple Pie
abstract: Big spending on infrastructure goes back to the Erie Canal.
lead_paragraph: House Democrats are hoping to pass President Biden’s infrastructure bill by July 4, because of course they are. The Biden team is making a point of wrapping its economic initiatives firmly in the flag. First came the American Rescue Plan; now we have the American Jobs Plan paid for by the Made in America Tax Plan.

headline: Can Vaccinated People Spread the Virus? We Don’t Know, Scientists Say.
abstract: Researchers pushed back after the C.D.C. director asserted that vaccinated people “do not carry the virus.”
lead_paragraph: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Thursday walked back controversial comments made by its director, Dr. Rochelle P. Walensky, suggesting that people who are vaccinated against the coronavirus never become infected or transmit the virus to others.

headline: Baseball and Its Fans Are Back. Just Not Way, Way Back.
abstract: The crowds were still limited because of the coronavirus, but opening day of 2021 looked very different from the stark scenes at parks last summer.
lead_paragraph: They opened the gates at last on Thursday, six months after the end of a brief and surreal regular season played before no fans. Opening day for 2021 brought none of the usual standing-room-only crowds; with limited capacities, the games looked more like sleepy gatherings in mid-April. But the buzz was authentic, and there’s nothing like the real thing.

headline: Chauvin Trial: Day 4 Key Moments
abstract: As the murder trial of Derek Chauvin continued for a fourth day on Thursday, those who testified included George Floyd’s girlfriend and emergency responders who were on duty the day Mr. Floyd died.
lead_paragraph: As the murder trial of Derek Chauvin continued for a fourth day on Thursday, those who testified included George Floyd’s girlfriend and emergency responders who were on duty the day Mr. Floyd died.

headline: Daniel Laske, a ‘Social Justice Warrior,’ Dies at 21
abstract: He wanted to combine his passions for medicine and politics to make the world a better place. Then he tested positive for the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Biden Seeks to Use Infrastructure Plan to Address Racial Inequities
abstract: The president’s $2 trillion proposal allocates money to help communities of color, like a New Orleans neighborhood devastated by a highway project a half-century ago.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — America’s most celebrated infrastructure initiative, the interstate highway system, rammed an elevated freeway through the center of Claiborne Avenue in New Orleans in the late 1960s.

headline: George Floyd’s Girlfriend Says Opioid Addiction Was a Struggle They Shared
abstract: The testimony was partly an effort by the prosecution to show that Mr. Floyd had a high tolerance for fentanyl, which could undercut any argument that he died of a drug overdose.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — They met one evening four summers ago, and she was instantly drawn to his “great, deep, Southern voice.” She gave him her phone number that night, and they became close, exploring the city’s sculpture garden and its vibrant restaurant scene. Soon she was simply calling him “Floyd,” just like his friends did.

headline: It’s Not Too Early to Start Courting Latino Voters
abstract: Democrats will need their votes to keep control of the Senate and House after the midterms.
lead_paragraph: Latino voters helped deliver the presidency to Joe Biden by securing key victories in Arizona, Georgia, Nevada, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin. But Latino voters also moved an average of nine percentage points from Democrats to Republicans in the 2020 elections compared with 2016’s.

headline: Corrections: April 2, 2021
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, April 2, 2021.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about a citizen’s arrest bill approved in Georgia misstated the middle initial of a law professor at American University. He is Ira P. Robbins, not Ira R.

headline: Quotation of the Day: New York Arts Scene Inches Back to Life
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, April 2, 2021.
lead_paragraph: “That communion of audience and performer, which we’ve craved for a year, we can finally realize.”

headline: Justice Dept. Inquiry Into Matt Gaetz Said to Be Focused on Cash Paid to Women
abstract: The congressman and a former official in Florida sent money to the women using cash apps, receipts showed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A Justice Department investigation into Representative Matt Gaetz and an indicted Florida politician is focusing on their involvement with multiple women who were recruited online for sex and received cash payments, according to people close to the investigation and text messages and payment receipts reviewed by The New York Times.

headline: Grand Opening for a Casino
abstract: Kyra Wilson makes her New York Times Crossword debut, in collaboration with Sophia Maymudes.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — This is an excellent example of a themeless crossword puzzle, and it’s a half debut, to boot. By “half debut,” I mean that this collaboration was between Kyra Wilson — the debutante, sorry, I meant debutee — and Sophia Maymudes, who has had four puzzles in The Times.

headline: Taiwan Train Crash Kills Dozens in Deadliest Accident in Decades
abstract: The Taroko Express train derailed and crashed in a tunnel on the first day of a long holiday weekend.
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — The train, cruising in and out of mountain tunnels along Taiwan’s east coast, was packed with people rushing to see family and friends on the first day of a long holiday weekend.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: The challenging latest chapter of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Experts warn that despite hope from Covid-19 vaccinations and a clearer path forward, it is much too soon to let down our guard.

headline: 7 Texas Officers Are Fired in Death of Black Man Restrained in Jail
abstract: A 26-year-old man detained at the Collin County Jail on a misdemeanor marijuana charge died after being pepper-sprayed and placed in a spit hood.
lead_paragraph: Seven sheriff’s officers in Collin County, Texas, were fired on Thursday in connection with the death of Marvin D. Scott III, a 26-year-old Black man who died after being restrained at the county jail last month.

headline: My Choice Isn’t Marriage or Loneliness
abstract: I thought I had a classic fear of commitment, but it’s more complicated than that.
lead_paragraph: I broke up with my boyfriend of five years during quarantine, but not because we had fallen out of love.

headline: Manhattan Sales Market Is Poised for a Revival, Just a Year After It Collapsed
abstract: First-time buyers, significant price cuts and progress on vaccines in New York City helped boost first-quarter sales.
lead_paragraph: A year after Covid-19 cratered the Manhattan sales market, the borough is poised for a recovery, thanks to price cuts, renewed confidence in the city and a surge of first-time home buyers.

headline: What to Watch in the Women’s Final Four
abstract: Two No. 1 seeds, South Carolina and Stanford, face off in one semifinal. Another No. 1, UConn, takes on a No. 3 seed, Arizona, in the other game of the Final Four.
lead_paragraph: The last three games of the 2020-2021 women’s college basketball season will feature a few familiar teams, as well as one upset-ready newcomer.

headline: For Korea’s Golfers Eyeing the Olympics, More Than Four Is a Crowd
abstract: Each country can send only four women to Tokyo, and with six Korean golfers in the world’s top 15, just making the team can feel harder than winning gold.
lead_paragraph: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — So Yeon Ryu is a two-time major winner and a former world No. 1 who entered this week’s ANA Inspiration, the first L.P.G.A. major of the year, as a top 20 player. Ryu’s credentials for the Tokyo Olympics this summer are solid gold.

headline: Word of the Day: uncanny
abstract: This word has appeared in 237 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?

headline: Collage
abstract: What do you think this image is saying?

headline: Shut Out on Vaccines, Tiny San Marino Turns to Old Friend: Russia
abstract: A microstate surrounded by Italy, San Marino feared being left behind in Europe’s inoculation campaign. Now it has jumped ahead, with the Sputnik vaccine sent by an unlikely, faraway friend.
lead_paragraph: SAN MARINO — On the ground floor of the only hospital in San Marino, a tiny, independent republic perched high above the surrounding Italian countryside, nurses prepared Covid-19 vaccine doses from glass vials labeled in Cyrillic script, flicked needles and sought to put nervous residents at ease.

headline: Virginia, the Old Confederacy’s Heart, Becomes a Voting Rights Bastion
abstract: For nearly 50 years, the state was subject to Voting Rights Act rules meant to deter racial discrimination. Those federal guidelines are now shredded, but Virginia just recreated them on its own.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Va. — Georgia has sharply limited voting access, making drop boxes less available and forbidding anyone to hand out water to voters in line. Florida and Texas are poised to advance similar legislation. Alabama’s strict voter identification law is being used as a template elsewhere.

headline: Seven Infrastructure Problems in Urgent Need of Fixing
abstract: The Biden administration has pledged a $2 trillion investment in the nation’s infrastructure. With century-old water systems and schools vulnerable to earthquakes, there is no shortage of need.
lead_paragraph: Engineers say that when infrastructure works, most people do not even think about it. But they recognize it when they turn on a faucet and water does not come out, when they see levees eroding or when they inch through traffic, the driver’s awareness of the highway growing mile after creeping mile.

headline: Is the Fight Against Sexism in Australia’s Politics Different This Time?
abstract: Six weeks after Brittany Higgins spoke up with her allegation of rape in the defense minister’s office, some things have changed and some things have not.
lead_paragraph: For most of the past week, I’ve been interviewing current and former members of Parliament about the mistreatment of women in Australian politics. I’ve spoken mainly to those with direct experience inside the system, and I found myself starting off with the same question: Does what’s happening now feel different?

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘Losing a Loved One Twice: First to Prison, Then to Covid’
abstract: In this lesson, students will learn about the unique risks the coronavirus pandemic poses to correctional facilities and consider the disease’s effects on incarcerated people and their families.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “Losing a Loved One Twice: First to Prison, Then to Covid” by Jacey Fortin

headline: Vaccine ‘Fiasco’ Damages Europe’s Credibility
abstract: The European Union’s failure to secure adequate vaccine supplies, followed by an export ban, has dented the reputation of the bloc’s leaders. It may also hurt their ability to act in other areas.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Alain Walravens, 63, is waiting to be invited for a first coronavirus vaccination. So are Marion Pochet, 71, a retired translator, and her husband, Jean-Marc. At least, Ms. Pochet said, they both have had Covid-19, “so we have some immunity, at least for the moment.”

headline: A Rapper, Hitting His 30s, Reinvents Himself as a Scion of Spanish Pop
abstract: C. Tangana was a provocative star of trap music. Now, his songs are played in supermarkets and praised by 50- and 60-somethings on YouTube.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — C. Tangana, one of Spain’s biggest rap stars, two years ago hit “a little bit of a crisis.”

headline: Strong U.S. Job Growth in March Fuels Optimism on Recovery
abstract: The gain of 916,000 was the biggest since August, and unemployment fell to 6 percent. Barring a setback in fighting the virus, the outlook is bullish.
lead_paragraph: The American job market roared back to life in March — and with vaccinations accelerating, businesses reopening and federal aid flowing, the rebound should only get stronger from here.

headline: New in Paperback: ‘How Much of These Hills Is Gold’ and ‘Coffeeland’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: HOW MUCH OF THESE HILLS IS GOLD, by C Pam Zhang. (Riverhead, 336 pp., $16.) Our reviewer, Martha Southgate, compared this “arresting” debut novel, about the long journey of two Chinese-American siblings to bury their failed gold-rush-prospector father in the sweepingly beautiful and barren American West, to, yes, Faulkner’s “As I Lay Dying” and Steinbeck’s “The Grapes of Wrath.”

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, April 2, 2021
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

abstract: In “A Little Devil in America,” Abdurraqib moves from Master Juba to Josephine Baker to Sun Ra to Patti LaBelle to “The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air.”
lead_paragraph: A LITTLE DEVIL IN AMERICANotes in Praise of Black PerformanceBy Hanif Abdurraqib

abstract: Readers respond to recent issues of the Sunday Book Review.

headline: What Children’s Books Have Had the Biggest Impact on You?
abstract: In a recent Times article, an author wrote a heartfelt tribute to a beloved children’s author. What authors and books from childhood have made a mark on your life?
lead_paragraph: What books or authors stand out from childhood? Did any unlock the magic and joys of reading for you? Did any inspire, shape or guide the person you are today or hope to be?

headline: Lack of Covid Rules Fuel the Return of Big Weddings
abstract: Weddings that face scrutiny for their long guest lists are not exclusive to Texas, but they may be more common there because of the lack of regulations.
lead_paragraph: When Nessa Egwuatu and Jordan Onuoha held a 350-person wedding in Houston on March 6, it was a sign of how large weddings are returning to Texas — and beyond — amid the loosening of Covid-19 restrictions.

headline: Looking Forward to Your 170th Birthday
abstract: In “Ageless,” Andrew Steele explores the science of aging and the advances that might let humans prolong their lives by decades.
lead_paragraph: AGELESS The New Science of Getting Older Without Getting Old By Andrew Steele

headline: Let’s Stay Angry About Jan. 6
abstract: Rather than taking things in stride, I’m still saying, “How dare you?”
lead_paragraph: The events of Jan. 6 taste as bitter in my mouth as they did the day they took place. Nearly three months later, the simmering bad feeling isn’t boiling over anymore, but it’s still hot to the touch.

headline: Why We Romanticize the Past
abstract: Ah, the good old days. Were they really that good?
lead_paragraph: A year into the pandemic, it’s easy to find yourself reminiscing about the past: bustling restaurants, sweaty spin classes, grocery shopping unburdened by face masks and cascades of adrenaline. You may even miss things you never thought you would, like your annoying co-workers or your long commute.

headline: She Met a Pilot on a Plane to London
abstract: Sonia Brozak and Matthieu Autret struck up a conversation as seatmates on a flight to London from Paris.
lead_paragraph: If not for a one-hour flight to London from Paris, Sonia Brozak and Matthieu Autret probably would never have landed an opportunity to live together in New York.

headline: Humanity’s Awesome, Terrifying Takeover of Evolution
abstract: Walter Isaacson and Ezra Klein discuss the implications of humanity’s awesome, terrifying takeover of evolution.
lead_paragraph: For years now, I’ve had the same recurring worry: Am I focusing on the trivial? When future generations look back on this moment in history, will they remember the daily political fights — or will everything just look like a sideshow compared to humans being able to edit genetic code?

headline: What Georgia’s Voting Law Really Does
abstract: The New York Times analyzed the state’s new 98-page voting law and identified 16 key provisions that will limit ballot access, potentially confuse voters and give more power to Republican lawmakers.
lead_paragraph: Go page by page through Georgia’s new voting law, and one takeaway stands above all others: The Republican legislature and governor have made a breathtaking assertion of partisan power in elections, making absentee voting harder and creating restrictions and complications in the wake of narrow losses to Democrats.

headline: How the Pandemic Has Made the Creative Class Feel Free
abstract: Hardcore business travelers have no intention of going back to the old ways. The workers who cater to their needs don’t have as many choices.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, I served on my building’s co-op board with someone whose daily logistical demands made me realize I was just coasting.

headline: The Manager Sent Her a Shot and His Card. Weirdly, It Worked.
abstract: Brian Skogen and Jennifer Valdes met more than seven years ago at the restaurant he managed. He couldn’t keep his eyes off her.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Valdes had a feeling someone was watching her while she was at a birthday dinner in October 2013 at Café Martorano, a restaurant in Oakland Park, Fla.

headline: Yes, There Are Nice Landlords in New York
abstract: Building owners are making deals with struggling businesses. As one put it: “A half a loaf of bread is better than no loaf.”
lead_paragraph: In the early 1970s, Margo Margolis was part of a movement to transform Manhattan’s SoHo from an industrial wasteland to an affordable haven for artists. A young painter, she rented a cheap loft there and converted it into a studio and living space. When her landlord went bankrupt, she and her fellow artist tenants pooled money and bought their building to run as a co-op. Around them, galleries and scrappy businesses began springing up. One of her favorites was Pearl River Mart.

headline: I Used to Think the Remedy for Bad Speech Was More Speech. Not Anymore.
abstract: How kids, lawsuits and legislation can save democracy.
lead_paragraph: I used to believe that the remedy for bad speech is more speech. Now that seems archaic. Just as the founders never envisioned how the right of a well-regulated militia to own slow-loading muskets could apply to mass murderers with bullet-spewing military-style semiautomatic rifles, they could not have foreseen speech so twisted to malevolent intent as it is now.

headline: For New York City, Glimmers of Hope and Signs of Revival
abstract: Yankee Stadium welcomed fans on Thursday, and some high-end hotels are opening their doors. But a widespread rebound from Covid-19 could take years.
lead_paragraph: For New York City’s economy, the last 12 months have amounted to one long, brutal winter. The pandemic forced the shutdown of most of the city’s businesses, wiped out hundreds of thousands of jobs and kept away tens of millions of tourists.

headline: Biden Wants to Spend Billions to Fight Climate Change. It’s Not Enough.
abstract: His plan is too big to pass, and too small to work.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: She Had a ‘Million’ Questions. He Had One for Her.
abstract: Nina Umont and Ondrej Antos, who are rarely at a loss of words with each other, were married in Carmel-by-the-Sea, Calif.
lead_paragraph: After going on a first date in August 2018 with Ondrej Antos, Nina Umont told a friend that she was going to marry him.

headline: This Summer, Get Invigorated With a Live Cultural Performance
abstract: Breathe in some culture and the great outdoors — just from behind a mask.
lead_paragraph: Pandemic willing, live shows will be back across the United States this spring and summer. (A patchwork of them, anyway.) Scores of festivals, benefits and theatrical events are playing it safe with digital editions or postponements, but some impresarios are forging ahead, adhering to safety protocols, capping audience size and keeping it outside, mindful of all the artists and fans left bruised last year by cancellations.

headline: Where Are the Least Fortunate Americans Supposed to Live?
abstract: Biden’s new $2 trillion-plus jobs plan recognizes that homes are part of the nation’s infrastructure.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, President Biden announced and outlined the next priority on his legislative agenda: a climate-centered infrastructure bill.

headline: The Perpetual Crisis at the Border — and What We Can Do About It
abstract: The U.S. immigration system doesn't reflect its own needs or those of its southern neighbors.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The U.S.-Mexico border is a “bleeding scar.” That is how Mexican author Carlos Fuentes described it in 1997. According to the Pew Research Center, 1.2 million immigrants, authorized and unauthorized, entered the United States that year. Back then, just like now, there was talk of an overwhelming crisis at the border.

headline: Two Brothers Posed for a Portrait. One Lived to See It in the Met.
abstract: Alice Neel painted two neighborhood boys in her studio in the 1960s. Fifty years later, the mystery of what happened to the picture has been solved.
lead_paragraph: When Jeff Neal was 8 or 9 years old, an older friend would take him and his brother Toby on trips around the city. They’d go to the Empire State Building or the parks, and one day they went to a large apartment on the Upper West Side that was filled with paintings.

headline: Can We Really Picture Auschwitz?
abstract: As memories of the Holocaust fade, one survivor’s images remain vivid.
lead_paragraph: When Buba Weisz Sajovits and her sister Icu arrived in Veracruz in 1946, their eldest sister, Bella, was waiting for them by the dock. Bella, who had been in Mexico with her husband from the 1930s, insisted that they were not to speak of what had happened to them in the war. Life was meant to be lived facing the future, not the past.

headline: Coca-Cola C.E.O.: Voting Rights Advocate?
abstract: A company with Southern roots and global reach tries to find its voice on an issue that disproportionately affects Black voters.
lead_paragraph: When James Quincey became chief executive of Coca-Cola in 2017, it’s fair to say he wasn’t focused on how to articulate the company’s position on the issue of voting rights. Instead, Mr. Quincey, who grew up in Birmingham, England, and has spent most of his career outside the United States, was consumed with the usual C.E.O. fare — expanding the business, keeping the share price up and not damaging the brand.

headline: They Got Lost in the Woods, Then Eloped in the Snow
abstract: Dr. Anais Ovalle and Emily Black learned a lot about each other when they got lost in the woods on their second date. Three years later, they had a snowy wedding day in Vermont.
lead_paragraph: On their second date, Dr. Anais Ovalle and Emily Black got lost hiking at the Moose Hill Wildlife Sanctuary in Sharon, Mass. Snow fell and then it got dark. Even though they lost cellphone service for a while and eventually had to call an Uber to get to their cars, both kept their cool.

headline: The Unsettling Power of Easter
abstract: The holiday is about much more than a celebration of spring.
lead_paragraph: I grew up in the Southern Black church tradition, where Easter was the opportunity to don your best outfit. The yellow and red dresses and dark suits set against the Black and brown bodies of my church were a thing to behold. The hats of grandmothers and deacon’s wives jostled with one another for attention. The choir had its best music rehearsed and ready to go. Getting to sing the solo on Easter was like getting a prime spot at the Apollo.

headline: Hurrah for Live Performances
abstract: How Nacho Figueras, Indya Moore and Alex Poots have navigated the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: With the New York charity circuit on hiatus, here is how some philanthropists and society figures are spending their time and resources during the pandemic.

headline: The Pandemic Hit the Working Class Hard. The Colleges That Serve Them Are Hurting, Too.
abstract: The community colleges largely serving low-income, Black and Latino students are reeling, and experts worry that inequality in education will increase.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic has been uniquely hard on America’s working class, causing higher unemployment among people without college degrees and eliminating low-wage jobs by the millions. Now, the education system created to help those very workers also is in jeopardy.

headline: Up on the Met Roof, an Artist Is Taking Big Bird to New Heights
abstract: Alex Da Corte, known for provocative, brightly colored installations, will showcase the beloved “Sesame Street’” character at the top of the Met this spring — but with a twist.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Among the characters that the artist Alex Da Corte has transformed himself into for his video work and installations are Eminem, Mister Rogers and the Wicked Witch of the West. In his Technicolor universe, American cultural icons share screen time with mascots from famous commercials, and even slasher-movie psychopaths are lovingly brought to life, with hours of prosthetics and tender, surgical-like observation. It’s a big-tent worldview that he shares, curiously, with “Sesame Street,” in which monsters, kids and grouches coexist — and in which he has discovered the subject for his latest artwork.

headline: The Unmitigated Chaos of America’s Attempt at Color-Coded Covid Guidance
abstract: Many states use color-coded tiers to signal coronavirus restrictions. Why are they all wildly different?
lead_paragraph: In California, the color of suffering is the juicy purple of seedless grapes. In Alabama and Alaska, it’s blood-colored. Blue signifies safety in many states, unless the blue is navy and you’re in Utah, in which case it communicates total catastrophe — the worst conditions possible. In New Mexico, nothing is better than green except for a color the governor’s office used to call “green-plus,” before it was changed to turquoise.

headline: Boomers Are Vaccinated and Down to Party
abstract: The Roaring Twenties are back in Southern Florida and other spots where older Americans gather.
lead_paragraph: In a glimpse of our post-pandemic world, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recently set forth guidelines for vaccinated people. Among other things, they can hang out indoors and mask-free with small groups of other inoculated people.

headline: How a Radio Host, Broadcasting Live From Home, Spends Sundays
abstract: It’s been a year — and many pots of beans — since Kai Wright abandoned his on-air studio in Manhattan. But the show has gone on.
lead_paragraph: “The United States of Anxiety” seems like the perfect title for a radio program these days. Since the shutdown, Kai Wright has led the WNYC show — which takes on hot-button social issues, from racism to gun control, often providing a historical perspective — live from his home in Cypress Hills, Brooklyn.

headline: Literature’s Most Ubiquitous Hat
abstract: The bowler, beloved by Jeeves, Leopold Bloom and Babar.

headline: The Ghosts of Brooks Brothers
abstract: After the retailer filed for bankruptcy one couple was left with a warehouse full of abandoned mannequins and a hefty price tag to dispose of it.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: ‘Mommy, I Have Bad News’: For Young Migrants, Mexico Can Be the End of the Road
abstract: Thousands of young migrants, most from Central America, are making their way to the border, many hoping to meet parents in the United States. But for those caught in Mexico, there is only near-certain deportation.
lead_paragraph: CIUDAD JUÁREZ, Mexico — The children tumbled out of a white van, dazed and tired, rubbing sleep from their eyes.

headline: Your ‘Maskne’ Might Not Be Acne at All
abstract: Perioral dermatitis, a complex facial rash that is often mistaken for acne, is becoming more common, some experts say. Here’s how to spot, treat and prevent this irritating condition.
lead_paragraph: It started as a mini constellation of red dots near the right corner of my lips. Probably just “maskne,” I figured. I slathered on some acne cream and tried to forget about it.

headline: Following the Pandemic-Era Deals in New Development
abstract: Sales are increasing in Manhattan, but so are the discounts.
lead_paragraph: Sales are increasing in Manhattan, but so are the discounts.

headline: A Home Buyers’ Bonanza in Manhattan
abstract: Housing sales in New York City are finally picking up — along with deep discounts.
lead_paragraph: Anyone rooting for the recovery of New York City’s housing market has probably been heartened by the data trickling out of brokerages in the past few months.

headline: A Major Change to Life in New York’s Prisons and Jails
abstract: A  ban on long-term solitary confinement follows concerns about its effect on Black people and minors, and links to mental health problems.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: China Puts Limits on Foreign Banks, Worrying Businesses
abstract: New rules, aimed at taming big money flows and possibly controlling the Chinese currency, could give domestic rivals a competitive edge and make international firms more dependent on local lenders.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — To defend against accusations by Washington and others that it doesn’t play fair on trade, Beijing could point to the banks. Chinese leaders have been steadily lowering the barriers they had erected around the country’s vast financial system, giving Wall Street and European lenders a greater shot at winning business in the world’s second-largest economy.

headline: Queens Man Is Charged in 1976 Killing of Pregnant Teenager
abstract: Luis Sierra, 63, of Ozone Park, was arrested this week in the killing of Evelyn Colon, a Jersey City 15-year-old whose dismembered remains were found along a riverbank in Pennsylvania, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: For more than 40 years, investigators were confounded by the circumstances surrounding the disappearance of a pregnant New Jersey teenager whose unidentified remains were found in several suitcases along a riverbank in Pennsylvania, along with a nearly full-term fetus.

headline: How Do I Define My Gender if No One Is Watching Me?
abstract: Without a public eye, who are we?
lead_paragraph: When the world went into lockdown five months after I started taking testosterone, I thought it would be easier not to see people for a while. Maybe they wouldn’t hear my voice go scratchy or see up close the hormonal acne splattered across my face. Alone in my apartment, I imagined that all my difficulties in being seen and recognized as transgender-nonbinary would evaporate. No one would gender me except myself; my pronouns would be right there in the text box on my Zoom screen.

headline: Inside the Biden Infrastructure Plan
abstract: A look at how the multitrillion-dollar package is a blueprint for sweeping social and economic change.
lead_paragraph: President Biden is pushing the boundaries of how most Americans think of infrastructure.

headline: Why the Markets Need a Strong Government Hand
abstract: Individually rational actions often yield bad outcomes, an economist says. That incontestable fact is the central rationale for government involvement in economic life.
lead_paragraph: Milton Friedman, the Nobel laureate, is said to have joked that if the federal government were put in charge of the Sahara, in five years there would be a shortage of sand.

headline: No Federal Taxes for Dozens of Big, Profitable Companies
abstract: FedEx and Nike are among those found to have avoided U.S. tax liability for three straight years.
lead_paragraph: Just as the Biden administration is pushing to raise taxes on corporations, a new study finds that at least 55 of America’s largest paid no taxes last year on billions of dollars in profits.

headline: The State of Summer Vacation
abstract: Travel is ticking back up, and “vaccine passports” could play a big role.
lead_paragraph: With Covid vaccinations underway, many people are wondering about travel.

headline: With New Wrinkle, N.H.L. Division Races Heat Up
abstract: The exclusively intradivisional play means teams can climb the standings or fall faster than in the past.
lead_paragraph: There’s a lot that is different about the N.H.L. schedule this season.

headline: Georgia’s Voting Law Puts Sports and Sponsors on the Spot
abstract: Major League Baseball said it was reviewing whether to play this summer’s All-Star Game in Atlanta. But many others in sports were silent about their next move.
lead_paragraph: Major League Baseball said it was reviewing its decision to hold this summer’s All-Star Game in Atlanta amid an outcry over a restrictive voting law, and President Biden said this week that he would support such a move. But the sport’s commissioner said he would go no further than that for now.

headline: An Equine Virus Alarms Europe’s Equestrian Community
abstract: In Europe, a deadly form of a common virus has killed nearly 20 horses and shut down competitions in 10 countries.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after arriving from abroad last month, Dr. Kent Allen’s new patient spiked a low fever. The doctor inserted a sterile swab into his patient’s nostril, a P.C.R. test to determine if this was yet another case of a potentially deadly virus sweeping the globe.

headline: Scientists say they still don’t know whether vaccinated people can spread the virus.
abstract: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Thursday walked back contentious comments made in a TV interview by its director, Dr. Rochelle P. Walensky, suggesting that people vaccinated against the coronavirus never become infected or transmit the virus to others.
lead_paragraph: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Thursday walked back contentious comments made in a TV interview by its director, Dr. Rochelle P. Walensky, suggesting that people vaccinated against the coronavirus never become infected or transmit the virus to others.

headline: Turning to Russia, San Marino gave its vaccination campaign a jump start.
abstract: San Marino, a tiny, independent republic within northern Italy, is perhaps best known — to the extent it is known at all — as one of the smallest countries on earth.
lead_paragraph: San Marino, a tiny, independent republic within northern Italy, is perhaps best known — to the extent it is known at all — as one of the smallest countries on earth.

headline: Baseball’s back, and it’s ‘good to hear humans in the stands.’
abstract: They opened the gates on Thursday, six months after the end of a brief and surreal regular season played before cardboard cutouts and empty stands. Opening day for 2021 brought none of the usual standing-room-only crowds; with limited capacities, the games looked more like sleepy gatherings in mid-April. But the buzz was authentic, and there’s nothing like the real thing.
lead_paragraph: They opened the gates on Thursday, six months after the end of a brief and surreal regular season played before cardboard cutouts and empty stands. Opening day for 2021 brought none of the usual standing-room-only crowds; with limited capacities, the games looked more like sleepy gatherings in mid-April. headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Walter Isaacson
abstract: The April 2 episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Walter Isaacson. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: The U.K. reports more blood-clotting cases in people who received the AstraZeneca shot.
abstract: Some countries, including Germany, have restricted use over the issue, but British and European regulators say that incidences are rare and that the vaccine should continue to be given.
lead_paragraph: Britain reported 30 cases of extremely rare blood clots in people who had received the AstraZeneca-Oxford vaccine, the same sort of events that have prompted some European countries to restrict use of the shot in certain at-risk age groups.

headline: Experts Grade California’s Vaccine Rollout
abstract: Friday: We asked experts to assign a letter grade to the state’s vaccine rollout. Here’s what they said.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Key Moments on Day 5 of the Derek Chauvin Trial
abstract: The longest-serving officer in the Minneapolis Police Department said Mr. Chauvin had violated policy by failing to move George Floyd off of his stomach as he knelt on him for more than nine minutes.

headline: Americans have saved a lot of cash, and they are ready to spend it.
abstract: The primary factor holding back spending has been the pandemic. But with the vaccine rollout accelerating, that could soon change.
lead_paragraph: Economists think the big job gains reported on Friday are just the beginning. One reason:  U.S. households had $2.4 trillion in savings in February, $1 trillion more than a year earlier. And that was before the latest wave of $1,400 relief checks started going out in March.

headline: How Veterans of #Vanlife Feel About All the Newbies
abstract: Once a niche movement, the nomadic lifestyle is going mainstream. For longtime vanlifers, that means fewer parking spaces and more trash, but the potential for positive changes.
lead_paragraph: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo. — If you search for “van life” on YouTube, one of the first results is a video by Christian Schaffer, a photographer who started living in a Ram ProMaster in 2019, titled “10 Tips for Getting Started.”

headline: Bible Study Brought Them to the Altar, Where They Shared Their First Kiss
abstract: One night, a voice told him what should become of these college students’ friendship.
lead_paragraph: If Nessa Egwuatu and Jordan Onuoha got more sympathy than most couples who have had weddings fall through recently, it may be because they had more people sympathizing.

headline: Pandemic Helps Stir Interest in Teaching Financial Literacy
abstract: Two dozen states are considering bills on the subject. Proponents say student debt and heightened interest in economic inequality are behind the efforts.
lead_paragraph: Two dozen state legislatures are considering bills on financial literacy education, an unusually high number, proponents say.

headline: An Argument for Investing Where the Return Is Social Change
abstract: A new report makes the case for investments that consider impact first and financial return second. But critics say such investments are mainly for the wealthy.
lead_paragraph: Advocates for impact investments have long made the case that investments can do social good without sacrificing returns.

headline: Maryland’s vaccine rollout shows the hurdles that other states could face.
abstract: As states ramp up vaccinations and expand eligibility, health officials can look to one state in particular to better understand the challenges ahead: Maryland has encountered nearly all the geographic, demographic and human behavioral challenges that come with a public health task of this scale.
lead_paragraph: As states ramp up vaccinations and expand eligibility, health officials can look to one state in particular to better understand the challenges ahead: Maryland has encountered nearly all the geographic, demographic and human behavioral challenges that come with a public health task of this scale.

headline: ‘Can’t Wait to Be Able to Hold Them’: Players’ Parents in an N.C.A.A. Bubble
abstract: The Stanford women’s basketball team has reached the Final Four after a long stretch as nomads, without familiar faces in the stands. Now in San Antonio, the Cardinal’s family and friends are making their presence known.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — Michelle Bain-Brink took books and a container of macaroons to her daughter, Cameron, a freshman forward for Stanford, the morning after the team rallied against Louisville on Tuesday to advance to the Final Four in the N.C.A.A. women’s basketball tournament. Bain-Brink fully expected to leave the packages with a security guard who would send them to her daughter’s room in the team hotel.

headline: Tesla delivered 185,000 cars in the first quarter, twice as many as a year ago.
abstract: The sales numbers, which cover the entire world, came a day after General Motors and Ford Motor reported that their U.S. sales were up modestly.
lead_paragraph: Tesla said on Friday that it more than doubled the number of cars it delivered in the first quarter, bouncing back after the pandemic slowed sales in the same period a year ago.

headline: Saudis keep control of the oil market despite a production increase.
abstract: Analysts said Saudi Arabia’s oil minister appeared to be calculating that by appeasing other oil producers, he can remain in control over the longer term.
lead_paragraph: For months, Saudi Arabia’s oil minister, Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman, arguably the most powerful individual in the oil business, has urged his fellow producers to keep a tight rein on output, fearing additional crude could flood the world’s markets and cause prices to drop. At the same time, some producers, notably Russia, have been chafing to open the spigot a bit more.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: How is Amsterdam preparing for a post-pandemic tourism boom? Also in this edition: the otherworldly tiny fish in the depths of our oceans and why an ideal college athlete decided to quit.
lead_paragraph: How is Amsterdam preparing for a post-pandemic tourism boom? Also in this edition: the otherworldly tiny fish in the depths of our oceans and why an ideal college athlete decided to quit.

headline: On the Upper East Side, Two Grand Mansions Sell at Steep Discounts
abstract: One of them was the longtime residence of the accused sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. It sold for $51 million.
lead_paragraph: Two stately limestone mansions just a couple of blocks apart on the Upper East Side topped the list of closings in New York City during March, with each selling at a significant discount.

headline: The Terrifying Genius of Restaurant Letter Grades
abstract: A first-person essay by the restaurant owner Demian Repucci about dealing with the New York City Health Department’s decade-old initiative — and why it isn’t what it seems.
lead_paragraph: A first-person essay by the restaurant owner Demian Repucci about dealing with the New York City Health Department’s decade-old initiative — and why it isn’t what it seems.

headline: When reporters try to speak with Floyd’s family outside the courtroom, sheriff’s deputies step in.
abstract: The chief judge of Hennepin County has set strict rules prohibiting the Floyd family from speaking to the news media outside the courtroom.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday afternoon, when Charles McMillian, a witness to the death of George Floyd, broke down while recounting what he saw last May, Judge Peter Cahill called a short recess to allow Mr. McMillian to compose himself.

headline: Hate Superheroes? Maybe You Just Haven’t Met the Right One
abstract: Even if Avengers and Justice Leagues leave you cold, there’s probably some superpowered champion out there for you. Here’s a guide to the best nontraditional superhero stories available to stream.
lead_paragraph: We get it: Superheroes have overrun pop culture.

headline: Justice Dept. inquiry into Matt Gaetz is said to be focused on cash paid to women.
abstract: A Justice Department investigation into Representative Matt Gaetz and an indicted Florida politician is focusing on their involvement with multiple women who were recruited online for sex and received cash payments, according to people close to the investigation and text messages and payment receipts reviewed by The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: A Justice Department investigation into Representative Matt Gaetz and an indicted Florida politician is focusing on their involvement with multiple women who were recruited online for sex and received cash payments, according to people close to the investigation and text messages and payment receipts reviewed by The New York Times.

abstract: Watch live coverage of the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former police officer charged in the death of George Floyd. Warning: The video may include graphic images.
lead_paragraph: Watch live coverage of the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former police officer charged in the death of George Floyd. Warning: The video may include graphic images.

headline: U.S. and Iran Agree to Indirect Talks on Returning to Nuclear Deal
abstract: The countries will negotiate next week through intermediaries in Vienna to try to bring both back into compliance with the 2015 nuclear agreement.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After weeks of failed starts and back-channel exchanges, Iran and the United States will, next week in Vienna, begin exchanging ideas about how to restore the 2015 nuclear deal. Initially, though, there will be no direct talks between the two countries, officials in Europe and the United States said on Friday.

headline: Taiwan Train Crash Kills Dozens
abstract: A train traveling along Taiwan’s east coast flew off the rails and slammed into the walls of a tunnel. Dozens of people were killed in the crash, the deadliest train accident in Taiwan in decades.
lead_paragraph: A train traveling along Taiwan’s east coast flew off the rails and slammed into the walls of a tunnel. Dozens of people were killed in the crash, the deadliest train accident in Taiwan in decades.

headline: A Stand-Up Set at the Swipe of a MetroCard
abstract: For about three months, an Upper West Side comedy club has been organizing Saturday-night shows on the 1 train.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Lander, a Brooklyn stand-up comedian, was in the middle of a joke about the 2020 presidential election — her audience’s ears perked for the punchline — when the train reached its final stop.

headline: In ‘Chad,’ Nasim Pedrad Embraces Her Inner Teen Boy
abstract: Pedrad, a “Saturday Night Live” alumna, plays the title character in her TBS comedy about an awkward 14-year-old trying to fit in.
lead_paragraph: For almost everyone, adolescence is a unique and personal caldron of anxiety. When Nasim Pedrad was growing up in Orange County, Calif., in the 1990s, she was simultaneously contending with a general, pubescent sense of mortification and the specific uncertainty of being a teenage immigrant who’d come to the United States from Iran at age 3.

headline: A French Soccer Team Clings to First Place as the Bottom Falls Out
abstract: Lille will play its deep-pocketed rival Paris St.-Germain for the league lead on Saturday. But not even a title may spare it from a financial reckoning.
lead_paragraph: On the surface, the pitch was a convincing one. Last year, the owners of Lille O.S.C. commissioned a graphic designer to produce a glossy prospectus, one intended to entice an investor into buying out their stake in the French soccer club.

headline: Myanmar’s Bloodshed Reveals a World That Has Changed, and Hasn’t
abstract: How the country became primed for a sort of violence, and a sort of dictatorship, that had grown rare.
lead_paragraph: Myanmar’s rulers this week crossed a threshold few governments breach anymore: They have killed, by most estimates, more than 500 unarmed citizens of their own country.

headline: 5 Books to Celebrate Baseball’s Return
abstract: To help ring in the 2021 baseball season, here are five books that celebrate the many quirks in the game’s history.
lead_paragraph: To help ring in the 2021 baseball season, here are five books that celebrate the many quirks in the game’s history.

headline: How the Yankees’ Luckiest Batboy Ended Up in an Unmarked Grave
abstract: Eddie Bennett earned fame in the dugouts of the Major Leagues. He had almost slipped from memory when New Yorkers teamed up to honor his short, dramatic life.
lead_paragraph: For 85 years, visitors to St. John’s Cemetery in Queens skipped past an unmarked grave in Section 34, Row DD. This is where Edward Bennett, a batboy for the New York Yankees — maybe the most famous batboy in the Major Leagues — was buried and forgotten.

headline: California’s Governor Was Tested by the Pandemic. Now a Recall Looms.
abstract: In California, both Republicans and Democrats say the threat of a recall election has shaped Gov. Gavin Newsom’s recent responses to the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — Things have been looking up in California. Vaccines will soon be available to everyone over 16. Los Angeles schools are about to bring hundreds of thousands of students back to classrooms. Disneyland, dark for a year, will throw open its gates in just a few weeks.

headline: Review: ‘Hemingway’ Is a Big Two-Hearted Reconsideration
abstract: Ken Burns’s latest documentary, premiering Monday on PBS, traces the complicated connections between the person, the persona and the stories
lead_paragraph: One of the more unsettling moments in “Hemingway,” the latest documentary from Ken Burns and Lynn Novick, finds Ernest Hemingway, big-game hunter, chronicler of violence and seeker of danger, doing one thing that terrified him: speaking on television.

lead_paragraph: The film’s director Adam Wingard narrates the scene where Godzilla and Kong first spar.

lead_paragraph: Good morning. Dorie Greenspan is about the only person on the planet who could persuade me to make a baked alaska (above) over the Easter weekend. Persuade me she did, with a delightful column about the dessert that not only taught me that the dish is known in France as omelette norvégienne — Norwegian omelet — but also managed to include the most charmingly complicated sentence I’ve read in at least a year:

headline: Watch an Underwater Brawl in ‘Godzilla vs. Kong’
abstract: The director Adam Wingard narrates the sequence where the big ape and the giant lizard first spar in the film.
