headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Debate in France over its student union.
lead_paragraph: To its critics, France’s 114-year-old university student union, Unef, is the incarnation of American-inspired ideas that threaten France’s founding principles, including the use of “safe space” forums that critics note exclude white people. Its leaders say it is the future.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Hemingway’ and ‘The People v. the Klan’
abstract: Lynn Novick and Ken Burns revisit the life of Ernest Hemingway on PBS. And a documentary about a civil suit against the Ku Klux Klan airs on CNN.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, April 5-11. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: A Soccer Official Proved Her Discrimination Case. No One Was Punished.
abstract: A court confirmed claims about a tainted election for a FIFA post, but while the woman who filed the case was vindicated, there have been no consequences for the men involved.
lead_paragraph: The ruling, when it eventually came, could not have been more clear.

headline: White Evangelical Resistance Is Obstacle in Vaccination Effort
abstract: Millions of white evangelical adults in the U.S. do not intend to get vaccinated against Covid-19. Tenets of faith and mistrust of science play a role; so does politics.
lead_paragraph: Stephanie Nana, an evangelical Christian in Edmond, Okla., refused to get a Covid-19 vaccine because she believed it contained “aborted cell tissue.”

headline: Inside Corporate America’s Frantic Response to the Georgia Voting Law
abstract: Companies like Delta are caught between Democrats focused on social justice and populist Republicans. They face major political consequences no matter what they do.
lead_paragraph: On March 11, Delta Air Lines dedicated a building at its Atlanta headquarters to Andrew Young, the civil rights leader and former mayor. At the ceremony, Mr. Young spoke of the restrictive voting rights bill that Republicans were rushing through the Georgia state legislature. Then, after the speeches, Mr. Young’s daughter, Andrea, a prominent activist herself, cornered Delta’s chief executive, Ed Bastian.

headline: Yang Drives the Bus, Republicans Joust: 5 Takeaways From N.Y.C. Mayor’s Race
abstract: The Democratic candidates vowed to stop Zooming and get out more, and a rap video earned mixed reviews.
lead_paragraph: With less than three months before Primary Day in New York City, most of the Democratic candidates for mayor appear to be quickly tiring of two things: mayoral forums on Zoom, and Andrew Yang’s presumptive role as front-runner.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘A Union Drive at Amazon’
abstract: In this lesson, students will listen to an episode of “The Daily” to learn about Amazon warehouse workers trying to organize a union.
lead_paragraph: Featured Podcast: “A Union Drive at Amazon”

headline: Israel offers a hint of what post-pandemic life may look like.
abstract: Israel’s vaccination program has been remarkably swift and successful. In recent weeks, new coronavirus infections have dropped significantly, from a peak of 10,000 a day in January to a few hundred by late March. The economy has almost fully reopened.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s vaccination program has been remarkably swift and successful. In recent weeks, new coronavirus infections have dropped significantly, from a peak of 10,000 a day in January to a few hundred by late March. The economy has almost fully reopened.

headline: Rachel Kushner’s Essays Cover a Lot of Ground, Driven by Powerful Engines
abstract: In “The Hard Crowd,” Kushner writes about two of her pet subjects — motorcycles and cars — as well as art, literature, politics and her formative years in San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: “America was a V-8 country, gas-driven and water-cooled,” Harry Crews wrote in “Car,” his 1972 novel. In her first book of essays, “The Hard Crowd,” the novelist Rachel Kushner reminds us that she writes as well as any writer alive about the pleasure of a good motor doing what it was designed to do.

headline: Should Corporations Take Political Stands?
abstract: What role, if any, do you think companies should play in political discourse in the United States?

headline: Gary Panter’s Jagged, Shape-Shifting Antihero Was Made for Our Moment
abstract: In his Graphic Content column, Ed Park looks at the work of Panter, a living legend for comics fans, and his singular creation, the character Jimbo.
lead_paragraph: “MEET GARY PANTER,” reads a 1988 ad in The Village Voice for a bookstore appearance in support of JIMBO: ADVENTURES IN PARADISE. The buff title character, cross-eyed and crew-cut, resembles an unhinged Billy Idol about to take the rugby pitch. “It’s an avant-garde adult comic book, about the adventures of a punk Everyman, who defines his generation,” the text claims. “Come by for a signed copy and meet a real comic book hero.”

headline: When an Estranged Relative Dies, Some Face Grief, Regret and Relief
abstract: Some have regrets over unfinished business. For others, the end of an unhappy and complicated relationship just comes as a relief.
lead_paragraph: When the phone call came from my mother’s nursing home, I knew there could be only one reason. She had died at 85, sitting in her armchair watching television.

headline: Apple’s C.E.O. Is Making Very Different Choices From Mark Zuckerberg
abstract: Tim Cook views privacy as ‘one of the top issues of the 21st century.’ Other tech leaders don’t seem to agree.
lead_paragraph: It’s a dismal world when two tech giants are embroiled in a fight over your privacy. Yet here we are as updates from Apple that give users more power over their data and make third-party tracking more transparent have sent Facebook into a fury. The social media giant took out a full-page ad last year claiming it was “standing up to Apple.” Or perhaps Facebook was standing up for its bottom line, as tracking is a critical component of the company’s targeted ad business.

headline: Thank God for the Poets
abstract: Their words remind us that suffering is not our only birthright. Life is also our birthright — life and love and beauty.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — When the poet Amanda Gorman stepped to the lectern at President Biden’s inauguration, she faced a much-diminished crowd of masked people on the National Mall, but she was speaking directly to the heart of a bruised nation:

headline: This Peeler Did Not Need to Be Wrapped in So Much Plastic
abstract: Amazon must become a leader in reducing single-use packaging.
lead_paragraph: The year 2020 may have been heartbreaking for most humans, but it was a good one for Jeff Bezos and Amazon. His company’s worldwide sales grew 38 percent from 2019, and Amazon sold more than 1.5 billion products during the 2020 holiday season alone.

headline: Matt Gaetz Is in Deep Trouble
abstract: But at the task of epitomizing the Trumpified Republican Party, he has excelled.
lead_paragraph: Bret: My intuition tells me that the name Matt Gaetz is going to make an appearance in a future Gail Collins column. Want to preview your thoughts?

headline: No Address, No ID, and Struggling to Get Their Stimulus Checks
abstract: Many people living in homeless shelters and on the street have not received the federal stimulus checks they’re entitled to, stymied by misinformation and bureaucracy.
lead_paragraph: For most Americans, the third stimulus payment, like the first two, arrived as if by magic, landing unprompted in the bank or in the mail.

headline: When Patients Choose to End Their Lives
abstract: For some, the decision to die is more complicated than a wish to reduce pain.
lead_paragraph: At a time when so many are dying against their will, it may seem out of sync to discuss the option of having a doctor help people end their lives when they face intolerable suffering that no treatment can relieve.

headline: Amazon Illegally Fired Activist Workers, Labor Board Finds
abstract: The two employees had publicly pushed the company to reduce its impact on climate change and address concerns about its warehouse workers.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Amazon illegally retaliated against two of its most prominent internal critics when it fired them last year, the National Labor Relations Board has determined.

headline: Amazon’s Clashes With Labor: Days of Conflict and Control
abstract: Amazon was built on an underdog philosophy, but its workers are finding a voice. That presents a problem for the company that goes far beyond the union vote in Alabama.
lead_paragraph: It has been Day 1 at Amazon ever since the company began more than a quarter-century ago. Day 1 is Amazon shorthand for staying hungry, making bold decisions and never forgetting about the customer. This start-up mentality — underdogs against the world — has been extremely good for Amazon’s shoppers and shareholders.

headline: An Extraordinary Winning Streak for Religion at the Supreme Court
abstract: More broadly, one new study found, “the politicization of religious freedom has infiltrated every level of the federal judiciary.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — “For many today, religious liberty is not a cherished freedom,” Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. told the Federalist Society, the conservative legal group, in November. “It pains me to say this, but, in certain quarters, religious liberty is fast becoming a disfavored right.”

headline: Lena Dunham and the Spanx Liberation Movement
abstract: The actor-writer-director-controversy creator is back with a new project: a plus-size clothing line. The whole body positivity thing? She has thoughts.
lead_paragraph: In the 10 or so years since she first became famous, Lena Dunham has been many things. She has been a wunderkind, a writer-director-actor-producer of both feature films and television series, voice of her generation, David Remnick mentee, Golden Globe winner and representative of liberal white privilege. She has been a Vogue cover girl, newsletter maven and subject of social media shaming. Also head of her own book imprint at Random House, endometriosis and hysterectomy survivor, and oversharer.

headline: Shopping for Kitchen Range Hoods
abstract: Whether you choose a showstopper or one that’s virtually invisible, a range hood is essential. Otherwise, you’ll be smelling that fish for days.
lead_paragraph: Every range hood vacuums up steam, smoke and odors from the kitchen. But when it comes to style, designs vary widely: Some are kitchen-defining statement pieces, while others almost disappear.

headline: Researchers Are Hatching a Low-Cost Coronavirus Vaccine
abstract: A new formulation entering clinical trials in Brazil, Mexico, Thailand and Vietnam could change how the world fights the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: A new vaccine for Covid-19 that is entering clinical trials in Brazil, Mexico, Thailand and Vietnam could change how the world fights the pandemic. The vaccine, called NDV-HXP-S, is the first in clinical trials to use a new molecular design that is widely expected to create more potent antibodies than the current generation of vaccines. And the new vaccine could be far easier to make.

headline: Let Us Now Praise Tiny Ants
abstract: Even in the densest human habitations, there are orders of magnitude more ants than there are of us, doing the hard work of making our crumbs disappear.
lead_paragraph: It is telling, the entomologist Eleanor Spicer Rice writes in her introduction to a new book of ant photography by Eduard Florin Niga, that humans looking downward on each other from great heights like to describe the miniaturized people we see below us as looking “like ants.” By this we mean faceless, tiny, swarming: an indecipherable mass stripped of individuality or interest.

headline: A Cyclist on the English Landscape
abstract: Grounded by the pandemic, a travel photographer spent the year pedaling the roads around his home, resulting in a series of poetic self-portraits.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, as a travel photographer grounded by the pandemic, I started bringing a camera and tripod with me on my morning bicycle rides, shooting them as though they were magazine assignments.

headline: One-Third of New Yorkers Have Received a Vaccine Shot
abstract: The spread of highly contagious coronavirus variants has dampened optimism about ending the pandemic even as vaccinations spread.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: How Much Do You Know About Belarus?
abstract: Can you find Belarus on a map? What else do you know about this Eastern European nation with 9.5 million people?
lead_paragraph: Can you find Belarus on a map? What else do you know about this Eastern European nation with 9.5 million people?

headline: Millions of white evangelicals do not intend to get vaccinated.
abstract: Across white evangelical America, reasons not to get vaccinated have spread quickly.
lead_paragraph: Across white evangelical America, reasons not to get vaccinated have spread quickly.

headline: A Military That Murders Its Own People
abstract: Following a coup in Myanmar, security forces have cracked down brutally on civilians. We ask why soldiers have so readily turned against the population.
lead_paragraph: Two months ago, Myanmar’s military carried out a coup, deposing the country’s elected civilian leader, Aung San Suu Kyi, and closing the curtains on a five-year experiment with democracy.

headline: Biden’s Judge Push
abstract: Donald Trump reshaped the courts. Today we’re looking at how President Biden is trying to leave his own mark.
lead_paragraph: President Biden last week named 11 people he plans to nominate to serve on federal courts, more than any recent president this early in his term. Nine are women, three are Black women and one would become the country’s first Muslim federal judge.

headline: In ‘Exterminate All the Brutes,’ Raoul Peck Takes Aim at White Supremacy
abstract: After the success of “I Am Not Your Negro,” HBO gave Peck carte blanche for his next big project. What resulted is a sweeping meditation on colonialism and the nature of truth itself.
lead_paragraph: After completing his 2016 documentary “I Am Not Your Negro,” the director Raoul Peck felt he’d had his say on the topic of U.S. race relations. Or at least his subject, the writer James Baldwin, had.

headline: The plan for post-pandemic life in England includes free testing and Covid certificates.
abstract: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain offered a first detailed glimpse of what a post-pandemic society in England might look like on Monday, announcing free twice-weekly coronavirus tests and Covid status certificates that would allow people with immunity into crowded nightclubs and sporting events.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain offered a first detailed glimpse of what a post-pandemic society in England might look like on Monday, announcing free twice-weekly coronavirus tests and Covid status certificates that would allow people with immunity into crowded nightclubs and sporting events.

headline: Ohtani Throws 101 M.P.H. Fastball and Hits 451-Foot Homer
abstract: The Angels star was the first starting pitcher to homer in an American League game since 1972, but left after a collision at home plate.
lead_paragraph: Shohei Ohtani had tantalized as a pitcher and as a hitter in the past, but he had never done both in the same game until Sunday night. Finally putting his full arsenal on display in prime time, Ohtani, the Los Angeles Angels’ Japanese star, dazzled with 100 mile-per-hour fastballs and also hit the hardest home run of any batter so far this season.

headline: Companies Can’t Stay on the Political Sidelines
abstract: The fight over voting rights shows corporate leaders face pressure to speak out even in the post-Trump era.
lead_paragraph: Corporations have increasingly taken social and political stands, often spurred by the policies of former President Donald Trump. But the dispute over voting rights is different, presenting a “head-spinning new landscape for big companies,” The Times’s David Gelles writes. Both political parties consider the issue a priority, so companies face potentially steep consequences no matter what they do.

headline: Minority business owners struggled to get Paycheck Protection Program loans.
abstract: The government’s central small business relief effort, the Paycheck Protection Program, has made $734 billion in forgivable loans to nearly seven million businesses. But minority-owned businesses were disproportionately underserved by the program, a New York Times analysis found.
lead_paragraph: The government’s central small business relief effort, the Paycheck Protection Program, has made $734 billion in forgivable loans to nearly seven million businesses. But minority-owned businesses were disproportionately underserved by the program, a New York Times analysis found.

headline: American buyers are fueling demand that could propel the global economy.
abstract: The United States and its record-setting stimulus spending could help haul a weakened Europe and struggling developing countries out of their own economic morass.
lead_paragraph: The United States and its record-setting stimulus spending could help haul a weakened Europe and struggling developing countries out of their own economic morass.

headline: Brexit is tormenting British chocolate makers.
abstract: Small British chocolate makers emphasizing ethically sourced ingredients and bespoke batches became big sellers in Europe in recent years but have been nearly impossible to find there since January, David Segal reports for The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Small British chocolate makers emphasizing ethically sourced ingredients and bespoke batches became big sellers in Europe in recent years but have been nearly impossible to find there since January, David Segal reports for The New York Times.

headline: When will office workers go back? Here’s what companies are saying.
abstract: Companies are wary of setting hard deadlines but increasingly are spelling out their plans for bringing employees back to the office.
lead_paragraph: At one point the target was the start of 2021. Then it was bumped to July. Now September is the new goal that many companies have marked on the calendar for bringing back office workers who have been working remotely for the past year.

headline: Key Moments on Day 6 of the Derek Chauvin Trial
abstract: The chief of the Minneapolis Police Department testified on Monday that Mr. Chauvin had “absolutely” violated department policies when he knelt on George Floyd for more than nine minutes.
lead_paragraph: After a week of often emotional and occasionally explosive testimony, the trial of Derek Chauvin resumed on Monday, with the prosecution continuing to present witnesses that they hope will support the charges of murder in the death of George Floyd.

headline: Climbers return to Mount Everest, with social distancing and Covid-19 insurance.
abstract: Local officials have instituted testing, mask and social-distancing requirements, stationed medical personnel at the Mount Everest Base Camp, and made plans to swoop in and pick up infected climbers.
lead_paragraph: After Nepal was forced to close its mountain trails last year, dealing its economy a devastating blow, the tiny Himalayan country has reopened Mount Everest and its seven other 26,200-foot-plus peaks in the hope of a rebound.

headline: Pair of Early Morning Earthquakes Jolt Los Angeles Area
abstract: The United States Geological Survey said two quakes with preliminary magnitudes of 3.3 and 4.0 were felt about 30 minutes apart.
lead_paragraph: A 4.0-magnitude earthquake jolted people awake in the Los Angeles area early Monday, according to the United States Geological Survey and the reactions on social media.

headline: How California Stands to Benefit From the $2.2 Trillion Infrastructure Proposal
abstract: Monday: If the plan passes, the state will have big plans for the federal money.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Tribune Publishing Considers New Offer From Surprise Bidders
abstract: Two months after agreeing to sell itself to the hedge fund Alden Global Capital, the company behind The Chicago Tribune and The Baltimore Sun may shift course.
lead_paragraph: Tribune Publishing, the newspaper chain that includes The Chicago Tribune, The Daily News and The Baltimore Sun, said on Monday that it had begun serious discussions about a sale of the company to a pair of bidders who came through with an offer nearly two months after it agreed to sell itself to Alden Global Capital, a New York hedge fund.

headline: What You Get for $2.4 Million in California
abstract: A renovated Victorian in San Francisco, a modern beach house in Newport Beach and a 1963 home near Santa Barbara.
lead_paragraph: A renovated Victorian in San Francisco, a modern beach house in Newport Beach and a 1963 home near Santa Barbara.

headline: $2.4 Million Homes in California
abstract: A renovated Victorian in San Francisco, a modern beach house in Newport Beach and a 1963 home near Santa Barbara.
lead_paragraph: A petite version of the traditional San Francisco Victorian, this house was built in the early 1900s and has been updated, although the sellers, who bought it in 2015, have retained some original details.

headline: 27 Killed as Cargo Ship Collides With Ferry in Bangladesh
abstract: The country has a grim history of deadly disasters on its heavily trafficked rivers.
lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — A collision between a cargo ship and a small ferry killed 27 people and left more than a dozen others swimming for their lives in Bangladesh late on Sunday, the latest in a long history of disasters on the country’s heavily trafficked waterways.

headline: Defendant No. 1 or Next Prime Minister? Netanyahu Divides Israel
abstract: With Benjamin Netanyahu on trial on corruption charges, even as he tries to cobble together a new government, Israel’s democratic system is drawing closer to a constitutional crisis.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — It was a split-screen spectacle that encapsulated the confounding condition of Israel and its democracy.

headline: Rift in Jordan’s Royal Leadership Is Soothed, Palace Says
abstract: The royal house said King Abdullah II and his estranged half brother, Prince Hamzah, had agreed to mediation measures, easing worries about a destabilizing family feud.
lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — A rare public rift within the Jordanian ruling family seemed to edge toward resolution late Monday, as the royal house first announced that King Abdullah II and his estranged half brother, Prince Hamzah, had agreed to mediation measures, and then released a statement in which the prince was quoted as pledging loyalty to the king.

headline: Here’s what we know about the man behind Friday’s attack on Capitol Hill.
abstract: Noah Green, the knife-wielding man killed after ramming his car into a checkpoint at the U.S. Capitol on Friday, was a troubled former college athlete whose life was disintegrating in the months leading up to a violent outburst that left one officer dead and another injured.
lead_paragraph: Noah Green, the knife-wielding man killed after ramming his car into a checkpoint at the U.S. Capitol on Friday, was a troubled former college athlete whose life was disintegrating in the months leading up to a violent outburst that left one officer dead and another injured.

headline: Why SpaceX Wants a Tiny Texas Neighborhood So Badly
abstract: The residents of Boca Chica didn’t ask Elon Musk to move in, but now his company is taking over.
lead_paragraph: The residents of Boca Chica didn’t ask Elon Musk to move in, but now his company is taking over.

headline: Yellen calls for a global minimum corporate tax rate.
abstract: The pitch comes as the Biden administration looks for ways to pay for a multi-trillion dollar infrastructure package.
lead_paragraph: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen made the case on Monday for a global minimum tax, kicking off the Biden administration’s effort to help raise revenue in the United States and prevent companies from shifting profits overseas to evade taxes.

headline: Cruise ships won’t have to require vaccinations when they resume sailing, the C.D.C. says.
abstract: Long-awaited guidance from the C.D.C. brings cruise lines one step closer to sailing again in United States waters.
lead_paragraph: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention issued long-awaited technical guidance for cruise lines on Friday, bringing them one step closer to sailing again in United States waters.

headline: New York Times Names James Dao Metro Editor
abstract: A veteran of the paper is appointed to lead its local coverage as candidates line up to succeed Mayor Bill de Blasio, and New York City looks beyond the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times on Monday named Jim Dao, a deputy editor on the national desk who has worked in a wide range of roles at the paper since 1992, as its new metropolitan editor.

headline: New York City Schools Have Been Closing a Lot. That’s About to Change.
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio is easing the two-case rule about positive virus cases that had been forcing many schools to temporarily shut this year.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio will change a rule that has, for months, created a paradox in New York City’s school reopening plan: Classrooms that had been reopened to students often closed again because school buildings had to shut temporarily whenever two unrelated virus cases were detected.

headline: Walgreens Not Following U.S. Guidance on Pfizer Vaccine Spacing
abstract: After complaints from customers and the C.D.C., the pharmacy chain will start scheduling doses three weeks apart.
lead_paragraph: Walgreens has inoculated hundreds of thousands of Americans against Covid-19 this year using the vaccine developed by Pfizer and Germany’s BioNTech. But the pharmacy chain has not been following guidance from federal health officials about the timing of second doses.

headline: We Are the Eggmen
abstract: Whether you like your egg salad tucked into a sandwich, curried, or paired with briny olives, we have the recipes for you.
lead_paragraph: Egg salad season follows Easter as surely as some will find a Peep under the couch some time in May. You can repurpose decorated eggs for the egg salad sandwich Eli Zabar developed for his appetizing shop in Manhattan, or make them into this fancy egg salad. You could use them in this asparagus salad with hard-boiled eggs, or in a sauce gribiche that you can use to adorn a platter of braised leeks — or braised tongue, if you prefer.

headline: China Tries to Counter Xinjiang Backlash With … a Musical?
abstract: The movie is part of Beijing’s wide-ranging new propaganda campaign to push back on sanctions and criticism of its oppression of the Uyghurs.
lead_paragraph: In one scene, Uyghur women are seen dancing in a rousing Bollywood style face-off with a group of Uyghur men. In another, a Kazakh man serenades a group of friends with a traditional two-stringed lute while sitting in a yurt.

headline: As Vaccines Abound, So Do the Questions
abstract: Readers discuss vaccine passports, requiring health care workers to get vaccinated and the “‘Hunger Games’ competition to actually get an appointment.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Biden thanks immigrants for ‘choosing us’ as he struggles with a surge at the border.
abstract: His statement comes at a time of increased pressure at the border and growing criticism from Republicans.
lead_paragraph: President Biden, navigating the perilous politics resulting from the influx of migrants at the border with Mexico, on Monday released a video thanking newly naturalized citizens for having the “courage” to come to the United States.

headline: The Supreme Court vacates ruling that Trump violated the First Amendment by blocking people on Twitter.
abstract: The Supreme Court’s move was expected, as Mr. Trump is no longer president and Twitter has permanently suspended his account.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Monday vacated an appeals court ruling that President Donald J. Trump had violated the First Amendment by blocking people from his Twitter account after they posted critical comments.

headline: A Pandemic Opportunity: Geffen Hall’s Overhaul Accelerates
abstract: Dark since March 2020, the New York Philharmonic’s home will reopen in fall 2022, a year and a half ahead of schedule.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic has dealt a devastating blow to performing arts institutions nationwide, closing their theaters and robbing them of ticket revenue. But for the New York Philharmonic and Lincoln Center, it has also offered a silver lining: the opportunity to accelerate the long-delayed renovation of David Geffen Hall.

headline: The Easter Parade That Could Not Be Stopped
abstract: Officially, the Fifth Avenue ceremony was virtual. In reality, some could not resist the spring weather and chance to peacock.
lead_paragraph: A lingering pandemic may have put a halt to the traditional New York Easter parade, the gaudy cavalcade that, in other years, winds ribbonlike along Fifth Avenue from 49th Street to 57th Street. But little blunted the spirits of visitors gathered outside St. Patrick’s Cathedral in Midtown to celebrate a ritual that is to many minds the most festive and joyous of the year.

headline: What we know about Medaria Arradondo, the Minneapolis police chief.
abstract: Mr. Arradondo was expected to testify that Derek Chauvin’s use of force was contrary to department policy and training.
lead_paragraph: The prosecution called Medaria Arradondo, the Minneapolis police chief, to testify on Monday. He was expected to testify that Derek Chauvin’s use of force was contrary to department policy and training.

headline: Warhol a Lame Copier? The Judges Who Said So Are Sadly Mistaken.
abstract: An appeals court ruled that Andy Warhol violated a photographer’s copyright by appropriating her image for a silk-screen he did in 1984. Our critic disagrees.
lead_paragraph: A few years back, a bevy of art critics declared that Marcel Duchamp’s 1917 sculpture called “Fountain” — a store-bought urinal he had presented, unchanged, as art — was the most influential work of the 20th century.  Andy Warhol’s 1964 Brillo Boxes — copies of scouring-pad cartons presented as art — could easily have come a close second. The philosopher Arthur Danto built an illustrious career, and a whole school of thought, around the importance of those boxes to understanding the very nature of artworks.

headline: The doctor who pronounced George Floyd dead says a lack of oxygen was the likely cause.
abstract: Dr. Bradford Wankhede Langenfeld testified that he had tried to save Mr. Floyd for 30 minutes but had never been able to restart his heart.
lead_paragraph: An emergency room doctor who tried to save George Floyd’s life for 30 minutes before pronouncing him dead testified on Monday that he believed Mr. Floyd had most likely died of a lack of oxygen, bolstering a central argument of the prosecution.

headline: Off Hong Kong’s Shores, Threatened Pink Dolphins Enjoy Brief Respite
abstract: A cut in ferry service because of the pandemic means the animals, a Hong Kong icon, are getting a little peace and quiet in a favored habitat. But the break is temporary and the future not bright.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The most popular reward for hiking to the top of Fu Shan, a hill near Hong Kong’s westernmost point, is a selfie backed by the setting sun, the gleaming new bridge across the Pearl River or a flight landing at the nearby airport.

headline: Harvey Weinstein Appeals Sex Crimes Conviction Over Accusers’ Testimony
abstract: The filing marks the beginning of what is likely to be a lengthy effort by Mr. Weinstein, who was accused of sexual assault or misconduct by dozens of women, to overturn his conviction.
lead_paragraph: Harvey Weinstein, the Hollywood producer found guilty of two felony sex crimes last year, appealed his conviction on Monday, saying several women who had accused him of sexual assault should never have been allowed to testify.

headline: Biden and Democrats Detail Plans to Raise Taxes on Multinational Firms
abstract: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said the U.S. would support a global minimum tax, while top Democrats unveiled their own plan to raise taxes on multinational firms.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration and top Democrats in Congress began detailing plans for significant changes to how the United States and other countries tax multinational corporations as they look for ways to raise revenues and finance President Biden’s $2 trillion infrastructure proposal.

headline: What’s Good About Tech Bubbles
abstract: We’re seeing a mania for wacky tech ideas. But tech bubbles aren’t necessarily the worst thing.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: How to Protect Sex Workers
abstract: A human-rights activist says they should not be prosecuted, only those who profit from them. Also: For a constitutional amendment to abolish capital punishment.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Gloria Henry, ‘Dennis the Menace’ Mother, Dies at 98
abstract: She was a prolific B-movie actress early in her career, but she became best known for her role as Alice Mitchell, the gentle mother of Dennis, on the CBS show.
lead_paragraph: Gloria Henry, a B-movie actress of the 1940s and ’50s who became best known as the sunny, preternaturally patient mom on the television series “Dennis the Menace,” died on Saturday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 98.

headline: Want the Final Four Court? You Have to Win on It First.
abstract: Championship teams have the option to buy the Final Four’s custom-made floors, which have gone on to second lives in practice gyms, locker rooms and lobbies.

headline: Gianluigi Colalucci, Who Showed Michelangelo’s True Colors, Dies at 91
abstract: The chief restorer of the Vatican Museums, he led the cleaning of the Sistine Chapel, a 14-year effort that revealed a new vision of Michelangelo’s complex work.
lead_paragraph: Gianluigi Colalucci, who led what was known as the restoration of the century — the cleaning of the Sistine Chapel — and in so doing revealed a new vision of Michelangelo’s storied, complex masterpieces there, died on March 28 in Rome. He was 91.

headline: New York State Is Set to Raise Taxes on Those Earning Over $1 Million
abstract: The deal, a sign of Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s weakened influence, would mean wealthy New York City residents would pay the highest combined local tax rate in the nation.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and New York State legislative leaders were nearing a budget agreement on Monday that would make New York City’s millionaires pay the highest personal income taxes in the nation, a stark result of the pandemic’s economic fallout.

headline: Boris Johnson Announces Free Coronavirus Tests and Status Certificates for England
abstract: The British leader’s plans are the next step in a cautious reopening after a lockdown that began in January.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson offered Britons their first detailed glimpse of what a post-pandemic society might look like on Monday, announcing free twice-weekly coronavirus tests in England and Covid status certificates that would allow people with immunity into crowded nightclubs and sporting events.

headline: Cookie Tins Straight From Brooklyn
abstract: The baker Melissa Funk Weller will sell cookies and bars for pickup and delivery under the name Funk Foods Bakery.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Funk Weller, a baker whose résumé includes Per Se, Bouchon Bakery, High Street on Hudson, Roberta’s and, most notably, Sadelle’s, where she made bagels, is starting a brand of her own: Funk Foods Bakery. She doesn’t have a location yet; for now she’s baking in a restaurant kitchen in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Starting Thursday she will sell boxes of assorted cookies and bars, 13 for $38. For now, a new assortment will make its debut on the first of each month, including one with Mother's Day in mind on May 1. They’re available only on Tuesdays for pickup from 10 a.m. until 2 p.m., and for national shipping on those days; a shop is on the horizon. April’s tins include peanut butter-layered brownies, raspberry-fig whole wheat bars that echo Fig Newtons, and salt-dusted shortbreads.

headline: An Auction to Raise Money for Restaurants
abstract: The Conscious Collection includes lots of wine and spirits, as well as extravagant experiences like truffle hunting in Italy.
lead_paragraph: The Conscious Collection, an auction to raise money for restaurants and bars in need, will be held by Zachys on Friday. It includes more than 100 lots of exceptional wines, spirits and over-the-top experiences like dinner for eight at Château Margaux, another with Christian Moueix at Dominus, three bottles of 2016 Screaming Eagle, and truffle hunting for four in Piedmont, Italy, with a stay at the Ceretto estate. Sponsored by Southern Glazer’s Wine & Spirits and Wine Spectator, the auction will donate the money to the Barstool Fund for hospitality-industry applicants, administered by the nonprofit 30-Day Fund, which has been raising money nationwide. Online bidding is open, and the live (virtual) auction will begin on Friday at 6 p.m. Eastern time. Absentee bids must be submitted by 5:45 p.m. on Friday. For most of the lots that involve travel, winners will have a year to fulfill the experience, unless specified otherwise. So far, bidding has started at about $500. To participate, bidders must first register.

headline: Gayle Smith, who helped lead the U.S. response to Ebola, will run Biden’s vaccine diplomacy.
abstract: Ms. Smith will try to corral wealthier nations into distributing Covid-19 vaccines more evenly around the globe.
lead_paragraph: An ardent advocate of protecting some of the world’s poorest countries from Covid-19 has been selected to lead the Biden administration’s vaccine diplomacy in an effort to corral wealthier nations into distributing immunizations more evenly around the globe.

headline: Atlantic Salmon With a Smaller Carbon Footprint
abstract: The company Atlantic Sapphire opened a facility in Homestead, Fla., to supply the United States.
lead_paragraph: Norway put farmed Atlantic salmon (salmo salar) on the map about 50 years ago. Today Atlantic salmon is raised around the globe. The company Atlantic Sapphire even has them swimming in Florida. Two Norwegians, Johan Andreassen and his cousin Bjorn-Vegard Lovik, joined with a Danish aquaculture expert, Thue Holm, to create the company in 2010, in Denmark. They were mindful of the carbon footprint of transporting the fish by air to other countries, notably the United States, so in 2017 they opened a facility and installed their fish farm in Homestead, Fla., south of Miami. The salmon are raised in big indoor saltwater pools fed from the area’s extensive aquifer. The fish, each about 12 pounds and raised without hormones or other additives, were harvested for the first time a few months ago, and were rated “best choice” by the Monterey Bay Aquarium Seafood Watch; they are now being sold as fillets, under the label Bluehouse Salmon. The fish has good texture and a very mild flavor. Many chains, including Publix, Wegmans and Safeway carry it. It’s also available shipped  from Allen Brothers in eight-ounce fillets, six for $99.95.

headline: An Illustrated Ode to the Restaurants of Paris
abstract: The artist John Donohue’s sketches are paired with loving descriptions by Francophile writers.
lead_paragraph: This is exactly the right moment to dream and thumb the pages of “A Table in Paris,” the artist John Donohue’s sketched love letter to that city’s restaurants. It echoes his work for his book “All the Restaurants In New York.” The new book is armed with a raft of Francophile contributors, including Michael Ruhlman, Richard Linklater, Peter Kaminsky, Lauren Collins, Alexander F. Lobrano, Christine Muhlke and Dana Cowin. They recommend and lovingly describe the restaurants, and Mr. Donohue has drawn many of them, mainly their exteriors. It’s organized according to neighborhood and has an index of the restaurants. Mr. Donohue is also donating half of the profits from online sales of his signed limited-edition prints to the Emergency Relief Fund of the Restaurant Workers’ Community Foundation.

headline: A New Pasta Shape for Your Pantry
abstract: Cascatelli was invented after three years of research and development by Sfoglini and the podcast host Dan Pashman.
lead_paragraph: Add cascatelli — inspired by the Italian word for waterfall, cascata — to your pasta vocabulary and your pantry. This new pasta shape was invented after three years of research and development by Dan Pashman, the host of the podcast The Sporkful, with the expertise of Sfoglini, a pasta company based in West Coxsackie, N.Y., in the Hudson Valley. The creation story has been documented on Mr. Pashman’s podcast as “Mission: Impastable.” He insisted on a shape that could be speared with a fork, and that would hold sauce well and have a proper bite. Traditionally extruded pasta shapes are made by forcing the dough through a die; a new, high-quality bronze die was made for cascatelli. The shape is a bit larger than most short pastas, but it’s very good, especially for simpler, less ingredient-heavy sauces like marinara, carbonara, pesto and arrabbiata.

headline: Supreme Court Backs Google in Copyright Fight With Oracle
abstract: The 6-to-2 ruling ended a decade-long battle over whether Google had improperly used Java code in its Android operating system.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Monday sided with Google in a long-running copyright dispute with Oracle over software used to run most of the world’s smartphones. The 6-to-2 ruling, which resolved what Google had called “the copyright case of the decade,” spared the company from having to face claims from Oracle for billions of dollars in damages.

headline: The Iran Nuclear Talks, Explained
abstract: Talks in Vienna to try to bring both the United States and Iran back into compliance with the 2015 nuclear deal were never going to be easy. They might have just gotten even harder.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — In Vienna last week, the signers of the 2015 Iran nuclear deal came together with what would appear to be a simple task. They wanted to restore compliance with an agreement that puts strict controls on Iran’s nuclear enrichment, to ensure that it cannot build a nuclear weapon, in return for the lifting of punishing economic sanctions.

headline: Transgender Childhood Is Not a ‘Trend’
abstract: As far back as historians have found evidence of transgender people, they’ve found transgender children.
lead_paragraph: There’s a story I know of a young transgender girl from rural Wisconsin, who before the age of 5 made it clear enough to her parents that she was a girl, not a boy, that they changed her name and dressed her in girl’s clothes. When the time came for her to go to school, her parents arranged with school administrators for her to attend as a girl. She used the girls’ bathroom and participated in the girls’ 4-H Club. All in all, she was treated with respect, not bullied or shunned.

headline: Robert A. Mundell, a Father of the Euro and Reaganomics, Dies at 88

He was 88.

headline: Why You Should Adopt a Seasonal Mind-Set
abstract: Our lives are cyclical. So why not think of them that way?
lead_paragraph: MISSOULA, Mont. — Early spring in this part of the Northern Rockies is cruel. When I was on a hike one recent afternoon, the clouds parted and bathed the hills in glorious 65-degree warmth. One day later, I stood in a field bracing against frigid winds and pelting hail. It snowed two inches that evening. Charles Dickens had it right in his description of March: “When it is summer in the light, and winter in the shade.”

headline: ‘It’s Déjà Vu’: Credit Suisse Faces a Big Loss From Familiar Troubles
abstract: The Swiss bank is in turmoil after a series of financial disasters that have battered its reputation and are likely to diminish its global clout.
lead_paragraph: Credit Suisse’s disclosure on Tuesday that it will lose almost $5 billion and remove two top executives after its involvement with Archegos Capital Management, the collapsed investment fund, has a familiar ring to anyone who lived through the last big financial crisis more than a decade ago.

headline: Starbucks will stop using disposable cups in South Korea by 2025.
abstract: The coffeehouse chain plans to introduce program in which customers will pay a deposit for reusable cups, part of an effort to reduce the company’s carbon footprint.
lead_paragraph: Starbucks says it plans to eliminate all single-use cups from its South Korean stores by 2025, the chain’s first move of this sort as it seeks to reduce its carbon footprint.

headline: What Is Your Gender Identity?
abstract: Tell us how you’ve come to understand your gender identity, and what it means to you.
lead_paragraph: Note to teachers and students: To prepare to answer these questions, you might visit our recent lesson plan on transgender athletes that began with the definitions of some relevant terms as well as a “temperature check” exercise with questions about talking about gender in general.

headline: Jan Morris Is Sending Us Missives From Beyond the Grave
abstract: “Allegorizings,” a posthumous essay collection from the British historian and travel writer, ranges from playful skits to alternative histories.
lead_paragraph: ALLEGORIZINGSBy Jan Morris

headline: How to Apologize to a Child
abstract: Even if it’s difficult, admit you were wrong and share only your remorse.
lead_paragraph: “We tell children, ‘Go apologize to your brother,’ but they can learn more by experiencing you apologizing to them,” says Jeremy Ruckstaetter, a professor of counseling at Covenant Theological Seminary in St. Louis, Mo. When Ruckstaetter started researching apologies in graduate school, he found perplexingly few studies focusing on apologies from parents to children. For his doctoral dissertation, he surveyed 327 parents and found that those who regularly apologized to their children reported stronger attachment bonds.

headline: Did the Boomers Ruin America? A Debate.
abstract: The conservative writer Helen Andrews and the liberal journalist Jill Filipovic discuss why millennials are so mad at their parents’ generation.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump was the fourth member of the baby boomer generation to be elected president, after Barack Obama, George W. Bush and Bill Clinton. The Senate majority leader, Chuck Schumer, is a boomer. Chief Justice John Roberts is a boomer. The Federal Reserve chair, Jerome Powell, is a boomer. President Joe Biden and Speaker Nancy Pelosi and the Senate minority leader, Mitch McConnell, were born a few years too early to officially qualify as boomers, but they’re close. We’re living in the world the boomers and nearly boomers built, and are still building.

headline: Devoted to the Deaf, Did Alexander Graham Bell Do More Harm Than Good?
abstract: Katie Booth‘s new biography, “The Invention of Miracles,” argues that the inventor’s view of deafness as a deficit to be cured by oralism has had a long, destructive influence on deaf culture.

headline: Here Is Fiction as an Escape Room, Packed With Mysteries
abstract: J. Robert Lennon’s new novel, “Subdivision,” and story collection, “Let Me Think,” offer puzzle-box narratives and alternate realities.
lead_paragraph: SUBDIVISIONBy J. Robert Lennon

headline: In James Merrill’s Letters, a Workshop and a Stage for the Poet’s Wit
abstract: “A Whole World: Letters From James Merrill,” edited by Langdon Hammer and Stephen Yenser, casts light on a generous soul with an active social life.
lead_paragraph: A WHOLE WORLDLetters From James MerrillEdited by Langdon Hammer and Stephen Yenser

headline: After Genetic Testing, I Took a Chance on an ‘Imperfect’ Pregnancy
abstract: “It was like rolling the dice, except for someone you’ve never met.”
lead_paragraph: My husband and I were sitting in an Upper East Side office with deep-toned velvet couches and fluffy throw pillows, surrounded by photos of smiling babies, as the fertility doctor gave his spiel. He told us that after age 35, a woman’s chances of getting pregnant drop. Older women produce few normal embryos even with fertility treatment. But we’d have a healthy baby in our arms within a year — if we tested the embryos.

headline: A Chronicle of Mexico City and Its Multitudes
abstract: In “Horizontal Vertigo,” the Mexican novelist Juan Villoro writes with affection and wonderment about Mexico City, the vast and complex megalopolis.
lead_paragraph: HORIZONTAL VERTIGOA City Called MexicoBy Juan Villoro

headline: The ‘Ghetto Girls’ Who Fought the Nazis With Weapons and Wiles
abstract: In “The Light of Days,” Judy Batalion recounts the stories of dozens of young Jewish women who bribed executioners, smuggled pistols and fought on the front lines of the resistance.
lead_paragraph: THE LIGHT OF DAYSThe Untold Story of Women Resistance Fighters in Hitler’s GhettosBy Judy Batalion

headline: No Longer Homeless or Hiking, Raynor Winn Is Still in Thrall to Nature
abstract: In “The Wild Silence,” a sequel to her best-selling memoir “The Salt Path,” the British author contends with the illness and death of loved ones but finds solace outdoors.
lead_paragraph: THE WILD SILENCE By Raynor Winn

headline: Cynthia D’Aprix Sweeney Read Hemingway at Marcia Brady’s Urging
abstract: “Who wouldn’t take a book recommendation from Marcia Brady?”
lead_paragraph: “I brought a copy of ‘A Farewell to Arms’ to school to impress my seventh-grade teacher,” the author of “Good Company” says. “But I never told him that my sudden interest in Hemingway came from a ‘Brady Bunch’ book.”

headline: Who Can Actually Afford to Live in Portland?
abstract: Willy Vlautin’s “The Night Always Comes” follows a young woman determined to hold her impoverished family together.
lead_paragraph: THE NIGHT ALWAYS COMES By Willy Vlautin

headline: Even on Her Best Days, Brandi Carlile Cleans Up Vomit

lead_paragraph: FIRST PERSON SINGULARStoriesBy Haruki MurakamiTranslated by Philip Gabriel

headline: How Many Is a Trillion?
abstract: We hear about trillions all the time now, but the number is beyond human comprehension.
lead_paragraph: Last year, as the rich grew richer while the poor grew only in number, speculation began about who would become the first trillionaire. (Jeff Bezos was the clear front-runner.)

headline: You Can Be a Different Person After the Pandemic
abstract: Our personalities are not set in stone. They are more like sand dunes.
lead_paragraph: When the pandemic lockdowns began, Catherine Steffel, a medical physicist and science writer in Madison, Wis., noticed that her daily routine didn’t change very much. It unsettled her that her regular life so closely resembled quarantine.

headline: As Variants Have Spread, Progress Against the Virus in U.S. Has Stalled
abstract: Vaccinations have topped three million per day, but cases have risen again amid the presence of more-contagious variants, restriction rollbacks and more travel.
lead_paragraph: Vaccinations have topped three million per day, but cases have risen again amid the presence of more-contagious variants, restriction rollbacks and more travel.

headline: The Hazards of American Justice
abstract: Three new books analyze the shortcomings of the nation’s criminal justice system.
lead_paragraph: HALFWAY HOME

headline: My Child’s Egg Donor Is Latin American. Does That Make Him Latino?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on what forms our identity and the importance of informed consent to medical procedures.
lead_paragraph: I am the parent of a child who was conceived via in vitro fertilization and surrogacy using the sperm of a Caucasian man and a donor egg from someone who is half Colombian and half Central American. My spouse and I are professionals and both Caucasian, so (knock on wood) our son will most likely not encounter financial hardships. May we in good conscience check “Latino/Hispanic” on his college application?

headline: Covid Closed Theaters. But It Also Made Them Accessible.
abstract: Before 2020, theater often felt inaccessible to me, a luxury for those who were more able-bodied or lived in certain cities. Now I’m obsessed.
lead_paragraph: I have never lived in either London or New York, and thus have next to no experience with the hotbeds of English-speaking theater. Though I frequently travel to those cities, and social media posts of friends with their Broadway Playbills tantalize me, I live with an illness that makes it difficult to remain upright. That makes theater a tough experience: The first time I saw “Hamilton,” after I left the Richard Rodgers Theater I was too sick to remember most of what had happened. It was only through luck that I was well enough to see the musical a second time while on book tour, as well as Andrew Scott’s award-winning London performance in “Present Laughter.” Each was exhilarating, but I was always painfully aware of my body. On other occasions, a sudden flare of symptoms could force me to leave or to forfeit a pricey ticket on the week of a performance.

headline: New & Noteworthy, From Nancy Reagan to the God Equation
abstract: A selection of recent titles of interest; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
lead_paragraph: LADY JOKER, VOL. 1, by Kaoru Takamura. Translated by Allison Markin Powell and Marie Iida. (Soho Crime, $28.95.) Hinging on a kidnapping plot, Takamura’s prismatic heist novel (published in Japan in 1997) offers a broad indictment of capitalist society.

headline: From Digging for Gold to Drinking It, in a Novel of American Striving
abstract: The hero of Sanjena Sathian’s “Gold Diggers,” a son of Indian immigrants, finds a magical elixir to help him succeed.
lead_paragraph: GOLD DIGGERS By Sanjena Sathian

headline: If It’s Not Jim Crow, What Is It?
abstract: Georgia’s new voting law has to be understood in its own peculiar historical context.
lead_paragraph: The laws that disenfranchised Black Americans in the South and established Jim Crow did not actually say they were disenfranchising Black Americans and creating a one-party racist state.

headline: I’m Incarcerated. This Is My Covid Lockdown Story.
abstract: As one blockmate after another fell ill, we tried to stay safe and care for one another. It wasn’t always enough.
lead_paragraph: I was in my prison cell in upstate New York one afternoon in mid-​January when someone called out, “Suits walking!” The Sullivan Correctional Facility superintendent, a gray-haired man in his 60s named William Keyser, had come into the cell block with a mask strapped to his face, accompanied by a pair of deputies. Now he stood in the belly of the block in his suit and tie, pulled down his mask and announced that he was putting us under quarantine.

headline: He Was Charged in an Anti-Asian Attack. It Was His 33rd Arrest.
abstract: Many people arrested in assaults on Asian residents in New York have had a history of mental health episodes, arrests and homelessness, complicating the city’s search for an effective response.
lead_paragraph: Tommy Lau, a Chinese-American bus driver in New York City, was walking last month during his lunch break in Brooklyn when he noticed a man harassing an older Asian couple.

headline: Is This the Future of Face Masks?
abstract: Will.i.am and Honeywell introduce the first connected mask. Think sneakers meet smartphones.
lead_paragraph: The story begins with Marc Benioff, the chief executive of the cloud computing company Salesforce, watching the MTV Video Music Awards last summer.

headline: Georgia’s New Law, and the Risk of Election Subversion
abstract: A reminder from a January phone call that the reform bill by congressional Democrats may not have the proper protections.
lead_paragraph: What would have happened if the Georgia secretary of state, Brad Raffensperger, had responded, “OK, I’ll try,” in a January phone call after President Trump asked him to “find” 11,000 votes?

headline: The Robots Are Coming … to Mow Your Lawn
abstract: Gas-power yard equipment spews noise and pollutants. Newer models, using batteries or electricity, are quieter and greener, and might even manage themselves.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our new series, Currents, which examines how rapid advances in technology are transforming our lives.

abstract: Chinese rivals to Western names have improved quality and marketing. Now the country’s defiance could give them an edge with young patriots.
lead_paragraph: Tim Min once drove BMWs. He considered buying a Tesla.

headline: Imagining the Timeless Childhood of Beverly Cleary’s Portland
abstract: In the winter of 2019, a family traveled on a literary pilgrimage to the Oregon city that left its mark on the celebrated author’s imagination.
lead_paragraph: Fifteen months ago I traveled to Portland, Ore., to visit the childhood haunts and homes of Beverly Cleary, the beloved and award-winning author of more than 40 books for children and young adults. I was accompanied by my husband and our daughter, all three of us aficionados of Ramona Quimby, us parents having read all the books as children, before rereading them aloud to our kid.

headline: An Updated Take on Greek Revival Style in Brooklyn
abstract: The 1834 townhouse, once home to the Franciscan Sisters of the Poor, needed more than just a simple renovation to function in the 21st century.
lead_paragraph: The 1834 townhouse, once home to the Franciscan Sisters of the Poor, needed more than just a simple renovation to function in the 21st century.

lead_paragraph: When Steven Holley found his 1834 Greek Revival townhouse in Brooklyn Heights, it seemed almost like divine intervention.

headline: Garment Workers Who Lost Jobs in Pandemic Still Wait for Severance Pay
abstract: A new report says millions of dollars in wages have been withheld from garment workers around the world by factories contracted by major fashion brands.
lead_paragraph: Over a crackling phone line, Ashraf Ali, a 35-year-old father in Bangladesh, described feeling suicidal and desperate to feed his family. Sokunthea Yi, in Cambodia,  said she spends sleepless nights worrying about how she will pay off loans she took out to build her house. And at only 23, Dina Arviah in Indonesia said she was hopeless about her future as there were no longer any jobs in her district.

lead_paragraph: The Carliles are nail-biters. I started biting my nails at three years old. Everyone told me that if I didn’t keep my hands out of my mouth, I’d get sick.

headline: What We Learned From 15 Million Guesses About a Neighborhood’s Politics

headline: Netanyahu Gets First Crack at Forming a New Government in Israel
abstract: After a fourth inconclusive election in two years, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu now has a possible path to stay in office even as he stands trial on corruption charges.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel was asked by the president on Tuesday to try to form a new coalition government, offering a possible path for him to remain in office even as he stands trial on corruption charges.

headline: The ‘Joy and Envy’ of Seeing All Your Friends Get Vaccinated
abstract: As some people start to shake off coronavirus precautions, those who are waiting their turn for a vaccine say the FOMO is real. “It’s like when every friend is getting engaged before you.”
lead_paragraph: At the start of the year, Shay Fan felt relief: Vaccinations were on their way. Her relief turned to joy when her parents and in-laws got their shots.

abstract: How one woman with a grudge was able to slander an entire family online, while the sites she used avoided blame.

headline: How Will China Vaccinate 560 Million People? Start With Free Ice Cream.
abstract: China’s Covid-19 vaccination campaign got off to a slow start. It is now trying to catch up, through a mixture of freebies and the occasional threat.
lead_paragraph: In Beijing, the vaccinated qualify for buy-one-get-one-free ice cream cones. In northern Gansu Province, a county government published a 20-stanza poem extolling the virtues of the jab. In the southern town of Wancheng, officials warned parents that if they refused to get vaccinated, their children’s schooling and future employment and housing were all at risk.

headline: Three Million Daily Shots, Achieved
abstract: And now? Four million is the new benchmark for the U.S.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after President Biden took office, I began asking his aides why their publicly announced goal for Covid-19 vaccine distribution — an average of one million shots a day — was so unambitious. The pace wasn’t much faster than what the Trump administration had achieved in its final days, and it was far short of the rate at which vaccine makers would be delivering doses to the government. Based on that delivery schedule, a reasonable goal seemed to be three million shots a day.

headline: Is Big Business the Democrats’ New Best Friend?
abstract: When C.E.O.s speak out against Republican priorities, it isn’t the flip-flop of alliances it appears to be.
lead_paragraph: “Parts of the private sector keep dabbling in behaving like a woke parallel government.”

headline: Without Tiger Woods, the Masters Leaderboard Is a Blank Slate
abstract: As Augusta National faces life without Woods, possibly even beyond this year, several young golfers look ready to usher in a new era.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The Masters Tournament, after an aberrant autumn appearance five months ago, returns this week to its customary place as a ritual of spring, and golf fans will find familiar the sight of vibrant azalea bushes and blooming magnolia trees. But beyond aesthetics at the Augusta National Golf Club, this year’s Masters may be at a crossroads, when golf’s most tradition-bound event turns a new page.

headline: Corporate America’s Not-So-New Allies
abstract: Democrats are coming to business’ political aid over social issues. That’s not as big a shift as it might seem.
lead_paragraph: For decades, corporate America was seen as a natural ally of the Republican Party. But as companies increasingly use their clout to speak out on social issues, a rift has emerged. “Parts of the private sector keep dabbling in behaving like a woke parallel government,” Senator Mitch McConnell said yesterday after a series of statements from big businesses about restrictions to voting rights in Georgia and elsewhere. At the same time, liberal Democrats who made their careers bashing big business may have reason to rethink who their friends are, Andrew writes in his latest column.

headline: As Jordan Seeks to Quell Royal Feud, Allies of Prince Remain in Detention
abstract: The country’s royal family said Prince Hamzah had now pledged his loyalty to King Abdullah II. The government banned news outlets and social media users from discussing the rare public show of conflict.
lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — Employees and associates of a Jordanian prince accused of plotting to undermine the government were still being held incommunicado by security forces on Tuesday, their relatives said, casting doubt on earlier claims by the royal court that it had resolved an unusually public and bitter rift.

headline: United Airlines pledges to train a diverse group of pilots in a new program.
abstract: The airline said it planned to train 5,000 pilots at the school by 2030, with a goal of half of those students being women or people of color.
lead_paragraph: United Airlines said on Tuesday that it had started accepting applications to its new pilot school, promising to use scholarships, loans and partnerships to help diversify a profession that is overwhelmingly white and male.

headline: San Francisco and Other Cities Try to Give Artists Steady Income
abstract: Through pilot programs, cities are giving checks to artists in hopes of allowing them to focus on their creative output instead of having a second job.
lead_paragraph: In San Francisco, public officials have announced a pilot program that will provide a monthly stipend to artists. The mayor’s office recently unveiled the initiative, city payments that were approved by the  arts commission, which will provide a guaranteed monthly income of $1,000 over six months to 130 eligible artists.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Helen Andrews and Jill Filipovic
abstract: The April 6 episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”

headline: The I.M.F. sees a faster economic recovery as vaccines are deployed.
abstract: The global economy is expected to expand by 6 percent this year, up from a previous projection of 5.5 percent, after a contraction of 3.3 percent in 2020.
lead_paragraph: The global economy is recovering from the coronavirus pandemic faster than previously expected, largely thanks to the strength of the United States, but the International Monetary Fund warned on Tuesday that major challenges remained as the uneven rollout of vaccines threatens to leave developing countries behind.

headline: ‘Kung Fu’ Rights the Wrongs of Its Ancestor
abstract: This gender-flipped martial-arts reboot departs from its 1970s predecessor by having a predominantly Asian-American cast.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 50 years after David Carradine rose to fame as an enigmatic, half-Chinese Shaolin monk in the Wild West, “Kung Fu” is returning to network television in a new iteration on the CW.

abstract: Tuesday: The conclusion of a fight between a little town and a big timber company over who owned the rights to a pristine spring.

headline: U.K. Community Leaders Step In to Aid Vaccination in Ethnically Diverse Areas
abstract: Local initiatives across the country are working to dispel misinformation and encourage Covid-19 vaccination in communities that have been disproportionately hurt by the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Minority communities in Britain have long felt estranged from the government and medical establishment, but their sense of alienation is suddenly proving more costly than ever amid a coronavirus vaccination campaign that depends heavily on trust.

headline: Key Moments From Day 7 of the Derek Chauvin Trial
abstract: Lawyers for both the prosecution and the defense continued to argue over whether Mr. Chauvin violated police policy when he knelt on George Floyd for more than nine minutes.
lead_paragraph: Several members of the Minneapolis Police Department testified in the trial of former officer Derek Chauvin on Tuesday, providing key support for prosecutors’ arguments that his actions last May killed George Floyd.

headline: In a Syrian Rebel Bastion, Millions Are Trapped in Murky, Violent Limbo
abstract: Millions of people displaced during Syria’s 10-year war are impoverished, insecure and crowded into an area of the country’s northwest controlled by a rebel group once linked to Al Qaeda.
lead_paragraph: IDLIB, Syria — Among the millions of Syrians who fled as the government bombed their towns, destroyed their homes and killed their loved ones are 150 families squatting in a soccer stadium in the northwestern city of Idlib, sheltering in rickety tents under the stands or in the rocky courtyard.

headline: Nets’ Harden Will Miss at Least 10 Days
abstract: Kyrie Irving scored 40 points in a win over the Knicks, then learned he will play without his co-star James Harden for a little longer.
lead_paragraph: The injured Nets star Kevin Durant has been missing since mid-February, but his team got some good news on Monday with the return of James Harden, who had missed Brooklyn’s last two games with a hamstring injury.

headline: Morries Hall, a friend of George Floyd’s who was with him when he was arrested, is trying to avoid testifying.

headline: Biden will offer a virus update as the pace of vaccination accelerates.

lead_paragraph: The Northern Irish actress Laura Donnelly doesn’t love the “strong female character” label. “I always exchange the word ‘strong’ for ‘complex’ because that’s what we’re looking for,” she said on a video call in late March. “We’re after complexity. We’re after fully rounded, well-drawn characters to get our teeth into.”

headline: Damon Locks and the Black Monument Ensemble’s Spiritual, Funky Escape
