headline: Wisconsin’s Barry Alvarez Says He Will Retire
abstract: No coach won more football games at Wisconsin, but Alvarez’s final act was an even longer stint as the athletic director in Madison.
lead_paragraph: Barry Alvarez, the University of Wisconsin’s winningest football coach, will retire from his longtime post as the school’s athletic director at the end of June, he said Tuesday.

headline: Her Dad Came to Her Birthday Party. Then He Killed Her Family.
abstract: A frightened girl called 911 after her father killed her mother and sisters at her birthday party in Brooklyn before turning a gun on himself, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A man attending his daughter’s birthday party in Brooklyn on Monday night turned the joyful celebration into a scene of carnage when he shot and killed her mother and two sisters, the police said.

headline: Chocolate Doughnuts Inspired by Global Flavors
abstract: Fany Gerson of La Newyorkina will sell them at Fan-Fan Doughnuts in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Fany Gerson of La Newyorkina, which sells Mexican sweets, prepared foods and groceries, will hold a chocolate doughnut celebration at her Brooklyn shop, Fan-Fan Doughnuts, from April 13 through 15. With travel so restricted because of the pandemic, her thought was to evoke faraway destinations through flavors like rooibos (South Africa), sticky toffee (the United Kingdom), blue corn (Mexico) and pistachios (Iran). The company Guittard is supplying the chocolate for this tasty little event. The doughnuts are $3.50 to $5 each and will be sold from 9 a.m. until 4 p.m., or whenever they sell out. They can be reserved between noon and 4 p.m. a day in advance.

headline: Biden’s $2.3 trillion plan spurs a fight over what ‘infrastructure’ really means.
abstract: The early political and economic debate over President Biden’s $2 trillion American Jobs Plan is being dominated by a philosophical question: What does infrastructure really mean?
lead_paragraph: The early political and economic debate over President Biden’s $2 trillion American Jobs Plan is being dominated by a philosophical question: What does infrastructure really mean?

headline: Relationship Podcasts Reveal the Truth About Marriage
abstract: Married hosts offer honest conversations about their personal issues and the challenges that can arise in any partnership.
lead_paragraph: Gambling, infidelity, moving away from a shared religious faith. These topics, once hidden behind closed doors, are now discussed openly as couples choose to broadcast their relationships on podcasts.

headline: Kyle Abraham’s Second Act at City Ballet: Spare, Wintry, Abstract
abstract: For “When We Fell,” a filmed dance, the choreographer took cues from a snowy bubble residency — and from Prince’s “Under the Cherry Moon.”
lead_paragraph: Few ballets in recent years have caused as much of a sensation as Kyle Abraham’s “The Runaway” at New York City Ballet in 2018. In it, Abraham fused elements of classical ballet with street and contemporary dance to thrilling effect — and rapturous reviews — amplified by his equally eclectic musical choices (Kanye West and Nico Muhly, Jay-Z and James Blake) and fantastical costumes by Giles Deacon.

headline: Family Holds Nightly Jail Protests Over the Death of Marvin Scott
abstract: Mr. Scott, 26, died last month after being restrained at the county jail in McKinney, Texas. His family members have been calling for the arrests of his detention officers.
lead_paragraph: A few days after Marvin D. Scott III died in the custody of detention officers in Collin County, Texas, members of his family and community gathered outside the county jail on the northern outskirts of McKinney, a suburb of Dallas.

headline: The Biden administration will seek the public’s input on a Title IX overhaul.
abstract: The Department of Education will hold a public hearing for students, educators, and other stakeholders to share “important insights” on sexual harassment and gender-based discrimination.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration announced Tuesday that the public’s input will be included in an expansive effort to review all existing policies on sex and gender discrimination and violence in schools.

headline: Modern Crime-Solving Methods vs. the Mystery of World War II Deaths
abstract: DNA-based techniques that have successfully tracked down elusive serial killers may soon be used to help identify thousands of American service members “known but to God.”
lead_paragraph: South of Rome, an American military cemetery has a grave that is thought to contain the remains of a young Army private named Melton Futch. But the white marble marker reads only, “Here rests in honored glory a comrade in arms known but to God.”

headline: Neil Diamond Bio-Musical Sets Sights on Broadway
abstract: “A Beautiful Noise,” featuring songs from the hit-maker's deep catalog, will play a monthlong run in Boston in 2022, with New York planned next.
lead_paragraph: A musical featuring the songs — and telling the life story — of Neil Diamond now has a title, a choreographer and scheduled performance dates in Boston, with Broadway plans next.

headline: How Well Did You Predict March Madness?
abstract: We asked readers to make their picks for the N.C.A.A. basketball tournaments — beyond just choosing winners.
lead_paragraph: We asked readers to make their picks for the N.C.A.A. basketball tournaments — beyond just choosing winners.

headline: Fears of White People Losing Out Permeate Capitol Rioters’ Towns, Study Finds
abstract: Counties with the most significant declines in the non-Hispanic white population were the most likely to be homes to people who stormed the Capitol.
lead_paragraph: When the political scientist Robert Pape began studying the issues that motivated the 380 or so people arrested in connection with the attack against the Capitol on Jan. 6, he expected to find that the rioters were driven to violence by the lingering effects of the 2008 Great Recession.

headline: How Will We Remember the Pandemic?
abstract: The science of how our memories form — and how they shape our future.
lead_paragraph: The science of how our memories form — and how they shape our future.

headline: Man Suspected in Museum Thefts of a Van Gogh and a Hals Is Arrested
abstract: The paintings were stolen separately in the last year from two different, smaller museums in the Netherlands.
lead_paragraph: They are two paintings by two major Dutch artists, Vincent van Gogh and Frans Hals, and both were taken last year, within months of each other, leaving gaping holes on the walls of two small museums in the Netherlands.

headline: High Bills for Covid Tests at a Hospital E.R.
abstract: A former hospital medical director and a former economics professor criticize excessive costs under our current health care system, while a Lenox Health administrator defends its fees.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Many Children With Serious Inflammatory Syndrome Had No Covid Symptoms
abstract: Pediatricians should be vigilant, experts said, after the release of the largest U.S. study of the syndrome, MIS-C, that can strike young people weeks after their coronavirus infection.
lead_paragraph: Many children and teenagers who developed the mysterious inflammatory syndrome that can emerge several weeks after contracting the coronavirus never had classic Covid-19 symptoms at the time of their infection, according to the largest study so far of cases in the United States.

headline: A Minneapolis police sergeant and crisis intervention trainer testifies that officers often have time to ‘slow things down.’
abstract: Prosecutors called Sgt. Ker Yang to the stand and walked through the various decisions that officers are expected to make while on the job.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for both the prosecution and the defense continued to argue on Tuesday over whether Derek Chauvin violated police policy when he knelt on George Floyd, asking a range of questions to the day’s first witness, a crisis intervention coordinator with the Minneapolis Police Department.

headline: No, Really, Are We Rome?
abstract: While the sack of the Capitol was thwarted,  history suggests that corrosive change can be hard to see while it’s happening.
lead_paragraph: While the sack of the Capitol was thwarted,  history suggests that corrosive change can be hard to see while it’s happening.

headline: Vaccine passports are becoming the next coronavirus divide. The White House is skittish; Texas’ governor opposes them.
abstract: A wide range of businesses in general, including cruise lines and airlines, have been eager for people to be issued some kind of credential, often called a vaccine passport.
lead_paragraph: Under a new executive order issued by Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas this week, government agencies, private businesses and institutions that receive state funding cannot require people to show proof that they have been vaccinated against the coronavirus.

headline: U.S. Bet Big on Covid Vaccine Manufacturer Even as Problems Mounted
abstract: The Baltimore plant that recently had to scrap up to 15 million ruined doses had flouted rules and downplayed errors, according to internal audits, ex-employees and clients. Other doses had to be scrapped last year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — More than eight years ago, the federal government invested in an insurance policy against vaccine shortages during a pandemic. It paid Emergent BioSolutions, a Maryland biotech firm known for producing anthrax vaccines, to have a factory in Baltimore always at the ready.

headline: YouTube discloses the percentage of views going to videos that break its rules.
abstract: Before their removal, so-called violative videos accounted for 0.16 to 0.18 percent of all views on the platform in the last quarter of 2020.
lead_paragraph: It is the never-ending battle for YouTube.

headline: Navalny Is Moved to Infirmary as His Health Declines
abstract: Aleksei A. Navalny, the jailed Russian opposition leader who is nearly a week into a hunger strike at a penal colony, showed signs of respiratory illness, prison doctors said.
lead_paragraph: POKROV, Russia — The coarse medical treatment that Aleksei A. Navalny, a Russian opposition leader, is receiving in prison poses a lethal risk to his health, his personal doctor told journalists on Tuesday. The doctor was subsequently arrested, along with several reporters.

headline: From China’s Far North, a Paradoxical Noodle Lands in Queens
abstract: The roasted cold noodles at Followsoshi in Flushing aren’t cold and don’t look much like other noodles.
lead_paragraph: The first thing you notice about roasted cold noodles, a favorite street food in the far northeastern Chinese province of Heilongjiang, is that they are not cold.

headline: Doormen Who Stood By After Brutal Attack on Asian Woman Are Fired
abstract: One was seen on video closing the door to the Midtown Manhattan building after the attack, as the victim, a Filipino-American woman, lay on the street outside.
lead_paragraph: The lobby staff members who closed the door to a Manhattan apartment building last week without taking immediate action after a Filipino-American woman was brutally attacked on the street outside have been fired, the building’s owners told residents in an email on Tuesday.

headline: How to Make Stunning Croissants at Home
abstract: Get those perfectly burnished, flaky pastries straight from your oven with this expert advice.
lead_paragraph: Does anything in the baking realm rival a fresh croissant, the way its burnished shell shatters, then yields to the silky, bready, layered interior?

headline: New Study Finds Covid Spikes After N.F.L. Games With Fans
abstract: As the N.F.L. makes plans to return to stadiums at full capacity this season, researchers published findings that “fan attendance at N.F.L. games led to episodic spikes” in the number of Covid-19 cases.
lead_paragraph: Major League Baseball, the N.B.A. and other sports leagues have started to let fans back into their stadiums and arenas, with most teams limiting attendance to 10 to 20 percent of capacity, but some allowing more. The N.F.L. has even grander plans. Last week, Commissioner Roger Goodell said the league hoped to open all of its stadiums at full capacity when the season kicked off in September.

headline: N.Y.C. public school students can opt back in to standardized testing this year.
abstract: The pandemic will have disrupted at least two years of state testing.
lead_paragraph: Students in New York City’s public school system, the largest district in the United States, will be able to take standardized tests this year, a process that has been drastically disrupted because of the pandemic. For the first time, New York City will ask families to opt in to state math and English exams, which all students in grades three through eight are typically asked to take during the spring. Last year, those exams were canceled altogether when city schools were shuttered as New York became a global center of the pandemic.

headline: Review: ‘Exterminate All the Brutes’ Rewrites a Brutal History
abstract: Raoul Peck’s four-hour documentary for HBO is a dizzying retelling of the course of colonialism, slavery and genocide.
lead_paragraph: “The very existence of this film is a miracle,” Raoul Peck says in “Exterminate All the Brutes,” a documentary he wrote, directed and narrated. He’s referring to the existence of a film that retells the history of colonialism and slavery from a nonwhite, non-Western viewpoint, though in 2021 that may seem less like a miracle than an expectation.

headline: The Sentry Flatiron, Atop the Hotel Henri, Opens in the Flatiron District
abstract: Fried chicken on the Upper West Side, a new wine shop from Bâtard and Tribeca Grill alumni, and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: A well-appointed rooftop is about as good as it gets when it comes to complying with pandemic protocols while dining out. At this new 18th-floor perch atop the Hotel Henri, the Midtown views are an added bonus. The Sentry is the work of Parched Hospitality, founded by Barry Dry with Tom Rowse and the chef Brent Hudson as partners; the three also own the Hole in the Wall restaurants. Mr. Rowse said the space could be divided to accommodate smaller groups, up to 10, in semiprivate areas. During the day, it’s a club for hotel guests. After 5 p.m., the general public is admitted for drinks and small plates of Impossible sausages, crispy pork with chile paste and fish sauce caramel, and salt-and-pepper squid with fried curry leaves and Kewpie mayonnaise. Drinks are the responsibility of Gates Otsuji and Jeremy Ortiz, who own Controlled Substances, a bar consulting company. (Opens Thursday)

headline: Google Won. So Did Tech.
abstract: In siding with Google, the Supreme Court gave software experts some love.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: Breast Cancer Centers Urge Early, Annual Scans, Countering U.S. Guidelines
abstract: A panel recommends biennial screenings, starting at 50, but a new study took issue with the way hundreds of centers are telling women 40 and up to come in yearly. Some experts contend that frequent mammograms can “do more harm than good.”
lead_paragraph: My last breast cancer screening was “b.c.” — before Covid — just a few weeks before the mysterious new disease was detected in China. The timing was perfect: Everything was normal, and by the time we went into lockdown, my to-do list no longer included a mammogram.

headline: What Happened to Jordan Peterson?
abstract: The mysterious disappearance, and resurrection, of an adored guru and reviled provocateur.
lead_paragraph: The mysterious disappearance, and resurrection, of an adored guru and reviled provocateur.

headline: Electric Aircraft Start-Up Accuses Rival of Stealing Its Secrets
abstract: A lawsuit by Wisk, partly owned by the Google co-founder Larry Page, says two engineers took sensitive files before joining Archer.
lead_paragraph: The age of electric planes may still be years away, but the fight for that market is already heating up.

headline: Iran and U.S. Agree on Path Back to Nuclear Deal
abstract: In indirect talks in Vienna, the U.S. and Iran agreed to try to synchronize Washington’s lifting of sanctions and Iran’s limiting of uranium enrichment.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The United States and Iran agreed through intermediaries on Tuesday to establish two working groups to try to get both countries back into compliance with the 2015 Iran nuclear deal.

headline: ‘Giants Being Lonely’ Review: Indie Filmmaking Being Twee
abstract: The feature-directing debut of the artist Grear Patterson paints a hazy picture of adolescence.
lead_paragraph: Starting with its title, appropriated from a Carl Sandburg poem, “Giants Being Lonely” aims to capture something precious about adolescence and American beauty. (Unlike in Sandburg, the “Giants” in question are a high school baseball team.) But nothing concrete emerges from this haze of oblique editing and barely written scenes, acted by cast members who are not up to making the dialogue sound convincing or filling the voids left in place of their characters.

headline: Ex-Trump Official Fined and Barred From Government Over R.N.C. Video
abstract: Lynne Patton recruited and interviewed public housing tenants in New York City for a pro-Trump re-election video. The residents accused her of tricking them into participating.
lead_paragraph: The video aired on the final night of the Republican National Convention in August, a two-minute clip featuring four New York City public housing tenants praising President Donald J. Trump’s record and bashing the city’s mayor.

headline: The Tokyo Olympics, Explained
abstract: After a year’s delay, the Tokyo Summer Olympics look set to proceed. But the circumstances will be most unusual. Here's what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: After a year’s delay, the Tokyo Summer Olympics appear set to proceed. The world’s best athletes will once again compete in the pool, on the track, around the velodrome and high above the trampoline. But the circumstances will be most unusual.

headline: ‘We Are Doomed’: Devastation From Storms Fuels Migration in Honduras
abstract: Honduras has barely begun to recover from two hurricanes that hit late last year. With relatively little disaster relief from the U.S., many are heading for the border.
lead_paragraph: SAN PEDRO SULA, Honduras — Children pry at the dirt with sticks, trying to dig out parts of homes that have sunk below ground. Their parents, unable to feed them, scavenge the rubble for remnants of roofs to sell for scrap metal. They live on top of the mud that swallowed fridges, stoves, beds — their entire lives buried beneath them.

headline: The Teenager Who Hacked Twitter
abstract: The New York Times Presents explores the case of a teenager from Florida who is accused of breaching one of the most high-profile internet platforms in the world. Watch how Twitter was hacked in an episode of our documentary TV series.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Presents explores the case of a teenager from Florida who is accused of breaching one of the most high-profile internet platforms in the world. Watch how Twitter was hacked in an episode of our documentary TV series.

headline: Yahoo Answers, a Haven for the Confused, Is Shutting Down
abstract: People used Yahoo Answers to ask weird questions, seek help and make jokes. But the service offered “real human reaction, for better or for worse,” one longtime observer said.
lead_paragraph: At times on Yahoo Answers, the people asking questions of strangers lunged for the hallucinatory limits of human curiosity: What would a heaven for elephants be like? Should scientists give octopi bones?

headline: How Weeksville, a Center of Black History, Fought to Survive
abstract: A slice of Brooklyn that was home to one of the largest free Black communities in pre-Civil War America sought the promise of steady financial help from the city.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, Weeksville Heritage Center in Brooklyn, which is dedicated to preserving the remnants of a thriving village established by Black New Yorkers in the years after the state abolished slavery in 1827, was at risk of disappearing.

headline: More Than 1,800 Prisoners Are Broken Out of Jail in Nigeria
abstract: Gunmen bearing machine guns and grenades stormed a prison in a restive part of southeast Nigeria many refer to as Biafra, letting loose any inmate who wanted out.
lead_paragraph: LAGOS, Nigeria — The Nigerian authorities say they are searching for about 1,800 inmates who escaped from a prison aided by heavily armed gunmen in the southeastern corner of the country, where anti-government separatists have long been active.

headline: A police use-of-force instructor faced questions about Derek Chauvin’s use of neck restraints.
abstract: Lt. Johnny Mercil, the second witness of the day, is a veteran of the Minneapolis Police Department, a practitioner of Brazilian jiu-jitsu and a use-of-force instructor who has trained hundreds of police officers.
lead_paragraph: Lt. Johnny Mercil, the second witness of the day, is a veteran of the Minneapolis Police Department, a practitioner of Brazilian jiu-jitsu and a use-of-force instructor who has trained hundreds of police officers.

headline: Testing an Opaque Security Power, Michigan Man Challenges ‘No-Fly List’
abstract: The plaintiff, a Lebanese-American, says he was barred from flying after refusing to become an F.B.I. informant.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A Michigan man challenged the constitutionality of the government’s so-called no-fly list in a lawsuit on Tuesday, accusing the F.B.I. of violating his due process rights by barring him from air travel and giving him no meaningful opportunity to challenge their decision.

headline: California plans to lift virus restrictions in June if certain benchmarks are met.
abstract: Other states have already eased health restrictions at a time when the Biden administration is pleading with them not to make those changes just yet.
lead_paragraph: California plans to lift all its coronavirus restrictions on June 15, provided there are enough Covid-19 vaccines available for anyone age 16 or older and hospitalizations remain low and stable, state officials announced on Tuesday.

headline: Florida Crisis Highlights a Nationwide Risk From Toxic Ponds
abstract: Thousands of open-air waste pools near power plants, mines and industrial farms can pose safety dangers from poor management and, increasingly, the effects of climate change.
lead_paragraph: They are ponds the size of city blocks: Wastewater pits that hold the hazardous byproducts of coal. Lagoons brimming with diluted pig excrement. Vast pools atop stacks of radioactive tailings.

headline: Report of Secret Dinner Parties for the Elite Sets Off Outrage in France
abstract: A television channel said the dinner parties were being held in defiance of coronavirus restrictions. One organizer initially said that government ministers had participated, setting off outrage online.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Champagne, foie gras and a “potato soup glazed with truffles” were on the menu at one of many secret elite dinner parties being held across Paris in violation of nationwide coronavirus restrictions, according to a French television report.

headline: ‘We Cannot Picture Auschwitz’
abstract: A Holocaust researcher says art can bring us closer to the terror. Also: Figure skating for Black girls; remote work; transgender children and sports.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Al Sharpton and the Floyd family pray for ‘justice’ outside of the courthouse.
abstract: Relatives of George Floyd prayed outside the courthouse with the Rev. Al Sharpton on Tuesday, asking God for “justice” from the jury and for strength to continue closely watching the trial taking place on the 18th floor of the building behind them.
lead_paragraph: Relatives of George Floyd prayed outside the courthouse with the Rev. Al Sharpton on Tuesday, asking God for “justice” from the jury and for strength to continue closely watching the trial taking place on the 18th floor of the building behind them.

headline: Hans Küng, Catholic Theologian Critical of the Church, Dies at 93
abstract: A prolific writer and a prominent speaker, he promoted dialogue among religions and challenged Vatican doctrine on many fronts, provoking its censure.
lead_paragraph: Hans Küng, a Roman Catholic theologian and priest whose brilliantly disputatious, lucidly expressed thoughts in more than 50 books and countless speeches advanced ecumenism and provoked the Vatican to censure him, died on Tuesday at his home in Tübingen, Germany. He was 93.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Freebies and warnings in China’s vaccine push.
lead_paragraph: In Beijing, a Covid-19 vaccine will qualify you for a buy-one-get-one-free deal on ice cream cones. But in the town of Wancheng, officials warned parents that if they refused to get vaccinated, their children’s schooling, and future employment and housing were all at risk.

headline: Democrats Push Biden to Take Harder Line on Saudi Arabia
abstract: Lawmakers have continued to press for harsher action and a wholesale rethinking of the American stance toward the kingdom.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Joseph R. Biden Jr. pledged during his campaign to make Saudi Arabia a “pariah” should he become president, congressional Democrats who had been pushing for months to impose sanctions on the kingdom for increasingly brazen, violent behavior breathed a sigh of relief.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘So Relieved About a Friend’s Failure’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words
lead_paragraph: My boss at the Design Industries Foundation Fighting AIDS wanted me to meet Susan. He said that she, a hardworking designer, needed to get out more. Imagining that meant “couldn’t get a date,” I felt more resigned than happy. “How will I know you?” she asked over the phone. “I’ll be the 5-foot-9 woman who looks like I’m looking for someone.” She replied, “I’ll be the 6-footer looking for you.” Susan entered the Noho Star, now permanently closed, in a cloud of colorful fabric. I was agog, thinking, “I’m not introducing her to anyone.” I’m still agog. — Rosemary Kuropat

headline: McConnell, long a defender of corporate speech, now suggests executives ‘stay out of politics.’
abstract: Senator Mitch McConnell has lashed out at executives with Major League Baseball, Delta and other corporations for criticizing Republican-led efforts in some states to impose restrictions on voting access.
lead_paragraph: Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky, has long argued that corporate campaign donations are a protected, nearly sacred, form of political communication. On Tuesday he made the case that business executives might be better off limiting their free speech to writing checks.

headline: Shamed Over Sex, a Generation of Evangelicals Confronts the Past | Retro Report
abstract: A Christian “purity” movement in the 90s promoted a biblical view of abstinence before marriage. But two decades later, followers are grappling with unforeseen aftershocks.
lead_paragraph: A Christian “purity” movement in the 90s promoted a biblical view of abstinence before marriage. But two decades later, followers are grappling with unforeseen aftershocks.

headline: How an Abstinence Pledge in the ’90s Shamed a Generation of Evangelicals
abstract: The Christian “purity” movement promoted a strict view of abstinence before marriage. But two decades later, some followers are grappling with unforeseen aftershocks.
lead_paragraph: To the uninitiated, Christianity’s evangelical movement can seem like a monolith that brooks no dissent on certain core issues: Same-sex relationships are sinful, men’s spiritual dominance over women is divinely ordained and, on the political front, Donald J. Trump was an improbable but nonetheless valued protector of the faith.

headline: Lois Sasson, Quiet Force in Gay and Women’s Rights, Dies at 80
abstract: Ms. Sasson, a jewelry designer and the partner of the singer Lesley Gore, was an advocate for feminism, gay rights and more. She died of Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Senate Ruling Gives Democrats a Back Door Around the Filibuster
abstract: A surprise decision by a top Senate official gives Democrats multiple chances to skirt Republican opposition, but it could sap momentum for weakening the filibuster.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Democrats might not have the votes to gut the filibuster, but they were just handed the procedural keys to a backdoor assault on the Senate’s famous obstruction tactic.

headline: How to Create an At-Home Forest Bathing Ritual
abstract: With a little know-how, aspects of shinrin-yoku, the calming Japanese practice of spending time among trees, can be approximated indoors.
lead_paragraph: Forests have been imbued with magical, spiritual powers in folklore and fairy tales for centuries. But it’s their therapeutic properties that have captivated modern scientists. In Japan, shinrin-yoku, or forest bathing — defined as spending time among trees — has been considered a form of preventive medicine since the 1980s, when researchers in Nagano found that the practice lessens stress, boosts immunity and lowers blood pressure. Subsequent studies showed that soaking up the forest environment — the still atmosphere, the verdant scenery, the gentle crunching of twigs underfoot — reduces cortisol (the body’s primary stress hormone) and activates the parasympathetic (self-healing) nervous system. These findings paved the way for other holistic disciplines, including today’s forest medicine (the study of how wooded environments improve health) and ecotherapy (which considers the curative potential of natural settings).

headline: Why Stanford Should Clone Itself
abstract: If elite colleges are serious about diversity of class and race, there’s a simple solution.
lead_paragraph: Stanford University’s faculty members may have convinced themselves that they struck a blow for egalitarianism when they voted for a policy meant to de-emphasize wealth in admitting undergraduates. But those professors should hold off on breaking out the champagne.

headline: ‘Blindness’ Review: Listening to the Sound of Theater Again
abstract: Stimulating and immersive — yet actor-free — this audio adaptation of the Saramago novel brings the terror of an epidemic into your ears.
lead_paragraph: As I sat down in the dark of the Daryl Roth Theater in my oversized high school sweatpants, Slytherin T-shirt and mercilessly beaten down pair of Chuck Taylors, one arm freshly numb from a Pfizer shot and an N95 mask desperately clinging to me like a facehugger, I had a single thought: This is not how I imagined my grand return to theater.

headline: Biden Keeps Trump’s Policy Retaining Land Mines in U.S. Arsenal, for Now
abstract: On the campaign trail, Joseph R. Biden Jr. had pledged to reverse his predecessor’s land mine policy. A Pentagon spokesman said the matter was under review.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Defense Department announced Tuesday that it would retain the Trump administration’s policy and keep antipersonnel land mines in its arsenal, reserving the right to use them in war.

headline: Possible Side Effects of AstraZeneca Vaccine Come Into Sharper Focus
abstract: Regulators may soon issue their first formal warnings about rare blood clots, threatening to cloud the global rollout of a cheap and easy-to-store vaccine.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For months, European countries have seesawed between craving and rebuffing AstraZeneca’s vaccine, with the shot’s fortunes rising and falling on spats over supply and on questions over the efficacy of the vaccine itself.

headline: Training vs. experience on the streets becomes a focal point of the Chauvin trial.
abstract: Law enforcement officials and criminal justice experts have said that while officers may learn things like de-escalation and community engagement in training, they can be influenced by training on the job.
lead_paragraph: Much of Tuesday’s testimony has highlighted the training that the former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin received. But one longtime issue in policing in Minneapolis and elsewhere is the difference between what officers learn in the academy and what they learn on the streets.

headline: Likely Legal, ‘Vaccine Passports’ Emerge as the Next Coronavirus Divide
abstract: Businesses and universities want fast, easy ways to see if students and customers are vaccinated, but conservative politicians have turned “vaccine passports” into a cultural flash point.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Cathay Pacific airlines, convinced that digital proof of coronavirus vaccination will bring about the return of safe international travel, asked its pilots and crew to try out a new mobile app that showed their vaccination status on a recent flight from Hong Kong to Los Angeles.

headline: New York Reaches Deal on $212 Billion Budget to Jump-Start Recovery
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and the Legislature have agreed to raise taxes on the wealthy and give aid to renters, businesses and undocumented immigrants.
lead_paragraph: New York State leaders announced they had reached an agreement on Tuesday on a $212 billion state budget that includes tax increases on the wealthy as well as substantial relief for renters, undocumented immigrants and business owners hit hardest by the coronavirus.

headline: Down Nine Players, the Nationals Rally to Shock Atlanta
abstract: A coronavirus outbreak had Washington severely short-handed for its long-delayed opener, but the Nats walked off with a win.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Lucroy has played for eight teams in 12 seasons and knows his place in the game. His All-Star years are over, and he has been released by a different team in each of the last three years. But for a team seeking a capable veteran to ease a sudden roster crunch, Lucroy is a perfect fit.

headline: The Many Selves of Alfred Hitchcock, Phobias, Fetishes and All
abstract: In showing several different sides of the filmmaker, some of them contradictory, Edward White’s “The Twelve Lives of Alfred Hitchcock” captures him in full.
lead_paragraph: In the world of Alfred Hitchcock, resemblance is fatal. It is the story of “Vertigo,” of Charlie, in “Shadow of a Doubt,” named for a beloved uncle who turns out to be a notorious murderer of wealthy widows. Think of the falsely accused men in “The Lodger,” “The Wrong Man,” “The Thirty-Nine Steps,” “I Confess,” “North by Northwest” and “Frenzy.”

headline: Utah Will Require Fathers to Help With Pregnancy Bills
abstract: The law, set to take effect in May, requires any father whose paternity has been confirmed to pay half of a mother’s insurance premiums while she is pregnant, and any related medical costs.
lead_paragraph: A new law in Utah will require biological fathers to pay half of the medical expenses for any pregnancy and birth, stirring debate about the state’s abortion and maternal health care policies.

headline: Isamu Akasaki, 92, Dies; Nobel Winner Lit Up the World With LEDs
abstract: A physicist, he shared the prize with two others for their breakthrough in creating blue light-emitting diodes, succeeding “where everyone else had failed.”
lead_paragraph: Isamu Akasaki, a Japanese physicist who helped develop blue light-emitting diodes, a breakthrough in the development of LEDs that earned him a Nobel Prize and transformed the way the world is illuminated, died on Thursday in a hospital in Nagoya, Japan. He was 92.

headline: Champions Crowned, N.C.A.A. Returns to Its Pre-Covid Problems
abstract: If anything, the coronavirus pandemic only deferred, highlighted or exacerbated the issues confronting college sports.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — In the early hours of Tuesday morning, as the task of disassembling this year’s N.C.A.A. men’s basketball championship game stage was underway — folding up tables, lowering the baskets, removing the cardboard cutouts of fans — a worker with a wide dry mop was sweeping confetti into a pile.

headline: Capitol Rioters Face the Consequences of Their Selfie Sabotage

New York State law mandates that private and religious schools provide a curriculum equivalent to that of public schools, and a 2019 report by New York City’s Department of Education found that only two of the 28 yeshivas it investigated met these requirements. This is especially problematic, considering that the city’s yeshivas receive over $100 million in state funds annually.

abstract: President Biden wants to change the paradigm. That may be easier than changing the Pentagon.
lead_paragraph: President Biden loves spending money. Last month, he signed the $1.9 trillion American Rescue Plan to stimulate the economy. Now he’s pushing the $2 trillion American Jobs Plan to rebuild the nation’s infrastructure. He vows to follow that with the American Families Plan to improve health care, child care and education, which could cost billions or trillions more.

headline: Will Shortz Edits His 10,000th Crossword
abstract: If Malcolm Gladwell is correct, Will Shortz is finally an expert.
lead_paragraph: There may be only a handful of people in the puzzle community keeping track of such things, but on April 7, Will Shortz will have edited 10,000 puzzles since joining The New York Times as crossword editor in November 1993. That, of course, is an approximate number, counting from his start date. There are also the Variety puzzles.

headline: Targeting Overseas Tax Shelters
abstract: How one U.S. multinational used overseas shelters to slash its tax bill — and how the Biden administration plans to crack down on such practices.
lead_paragraph: For decades, U.S. multinationals have been stowing trillions of dollars overseas as a way to slash their tax bills.

headline: What’s Up With Those Weird-Looking Mushrooms?
abstract: You may not expect to see them in your yard, but that doesn’t mean you’ve got trouble. The opposite, in fact.
lead_paragraph: They appear spontaneously, or so it seems, popping up out of the mulch, rising in a single spot on the lawn or bursting from between the pathway pavers like little marshmallows. But there is an intricate master plan at work, just not one to which most gardeners are privy.

headline: The Main Reason for Your Pandemic Boredom
abstract: It comes down to lack of control.
lead_paragraph: Before the pandemic, I found comfort in the routine of my life and the rhythms of my family — what Nora Ephron once called the “peanut-butter-and-jellyness” of days with children. I liked the morning thunderdome of getting the children dressed and fed and breaking up some fights along the way, dropping them at school and taking the 20-minute walk to the subway. When I got off the subway, I had an array of coffee shops to choose from, which at the time did not seem exciting, but after a year of pandemic isolation would probably feel like bungee jumping.

headline: The Georgia Voting Fight
abstract: Sorting through the heated debate over Georgia’s new voting law.
lead_paragraph: Georgia’s new voting law has inspired a heated national debate, involving President Biden, top Republicans and major companies. It has led to a furious exchange of charges and countercharges, sometimes about basic facts.

headline: JPMorgan’s Chief Sees a Boom Coming
abstract: Jamie Dimon tells the bank’s investors to prepare for an economic upswell.
lead_paragraph: The annual letter to shareholders by JPMorgan Chase’s chief Jamie Dimon was just published. The widely read letter is not just an overview of the bank’s business but also covers Mr. Dimon’s thoughts on everything from leadership lessons to public policy prescriptions.

headline: Headlines Today
abstract: What you need to know when you can only spare a little time.
lead_paragraph: What you need to know when you can only spare a little time.

headline: Target says it will spend more than $2 billion with Black-owned businesses.
abstract: The company joins a growing list of retailers that have pledged to increase their economic support of companies owned by Black entrepreneurs.
lead_paragraph: Target will spend more than $2 billion with Black-owned businesses by 2025, it announced on Wednesday, joining a growing list of retailers that have promised to increase their economic support of such companies in a bid to advance racial equity in the United States.

headline: A Brooklyn Artist Wants Sports Fans to Wear Their Names
abstract: A Brooklyn artist uses sports iconography to commemorate Trayvon Martin, George Floyd and other Black victims of violence.
lead_paragraph: The irony has always troubled Raafi Rivero. “People love Black athletes,” he said. “But they don’t love Black people.”

headline: Jamie Dimon predicts an economic boom that ‘could easily run into 2023.’
abstract: In his annual letter to shareholders, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase weighed in on the nation’s economy, climate change and tax loopholes.
lead_paragraph: The annual letter to shareholders by JPMorgan Chase’s chief executive, Jamie Dimon, was published early Wednesday. The letter, which is widely read on Wall Street, is not just an overview of the bank’s business but also covers Mr. Dimon’s thoughts on everything from leadership lessons to public policy prescriptions.

headline: Cosmic Questions
abstract: What is time? Do we have free will? Our cosmic affairs correspondent Dennis Overbye tries to answer the big ones on our culture and lifestyle show.
lead_paragraph: What is time? Do we have free will? Our cosmic affairs correspondent Dennis Overbye tries to answer the big ones on our culture and lifestyle show.

headline: St. Louis Elects Its First Black Woman as Mayor
abstract: Tishaura Jones, the city’s treasurer, promised on Tuesday night not to stay silent on racial injustices and vowed to bring “fresh air” to the city.
lead_paragraph: Tishaura Jones became the first Black woman to be elected mayor of St. Louis on Tuesday and later this month will begin leading a city confronting a high homicide rate, disturbances at the city jail and challenges related to the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: A nonprofit group is spreading a model in which training programs get paid if students get hired.
abstract: American Diesel Training, a school in Ohio that prepares people for careers as diesel mechanics, is part of a new model of work force training — one that bases pay for training programs partly on whether students get hired.
lead_paragraph: American Diesel Training, a school in Ohio that prepares people for careers as diesel mechanics, is part of a new model of work force training — one that bases pay for training programs partly on whether students get hired.

headline: What’s Wrong With the Los Angeles Lakers
abstract: Repeating as N.B.A. champion is difficult — but the Lakers didn’t expect it to be this hard.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles Lakers braced for a season of strain after the shortest off-season in league history.

headline: Georgia’s voting law’s effects ripple in Washington.
abstract: Georgia is still caught up in a political riptide, less than a week after Major League Baseball pulled its summer All-Star game out of suburban Atlanta in a rebuke to the state’s new election rules that restrict access to voting.
lead_paragraph: Georgia is still caught up in a political riptide, less than a week after Major League Baseball pulled its summer All-Star game out of suburban Atlanta in a rebuke to the state’s new election rules that restrict access to voting.

headline: In his new book, Boehner asserts Trump ‘incited that bloody insurrection.’
abstract: John Boehner, the Republican former House speaker, issued a stinging denunciation in his new book of Donald J. Trump, saying that the former president “incited that bloody insurrection” by his supporters at the Capitol on Jan. 6 and that the Republican Party had been taken over by “whack jobs.”
lead_paragraph: John Boehner, the Republican former House speaker, issued a stinging denunciation in his new book of Donald J. Trump, saying that the former president “incited that bloody insurrection” by his supporters at the Capitol on Jan. 6 and that the Republican Party had been taken over by “whack jobs.”

headline: The End of California’s Lockdowns
abstract: Wednesday: State officials said they planned to lift all pandemic restrictions except the mask mandate on June 15.
lead_paragraph: (This article is part of the California Today newsletter. Sign up to get it delivered to your inbox.)

headline: Here’s how a Senate ruling could help push Biden’s agenda through Congress.
abstract: Hours after a top Senate official informed Democrats that they could potentially have more chances to use a complex budget maneuver to push through their agenda without any Republican votes, Senator Bernie Sanders, the Vermont independent, was on television outlining the breadth of liberal ambitions.
lead_paragraph: Hours after a top Senate official informed Democrats that they could potentially have more chances to use a complex budget maneuver to push through their agenda without any Republican votes, Senator Bernie Sanders, the Vermont independent, was on television outlining the breadth of liberal ambitions.

headline: At 91, John Cullum Is Ready to Try Something New
abstract: The Tony-winning musical theater actor and TV star planned to debut a cabaret show in 2019. Illness hit, then the pandemic. But he hasn’t been stopped.
lead_paragraph: On a sunshiny August afternoon in 2019, the actor John Cullum stood singing and storytelling beside an upright piano in a rehearsal space off Columbus Circle, inside a building that no longer exists. Hopscotching through reminiscences of his six-decade stage career, tweaking the script as he went along, he was readying for a cabaret show in September that would never come to be.

headline: 5 Ways to Tap Into Your Smartphone’s Audio Powers
abstract: A virtual assistant is just one tool that lets you use your voice to share your thoughts, capture a moment or just get things done.
lead_paragraph: It has been a decade since Apple integrated Siri right into its iPhone software and mainstreamed the voice-activated assistant. But the assistant is just one of the voice-powered tools in your smartphone’s ever-growing audio toolbox. Your device can also be a digital recorder, a dictation machine, a podcast production studio and more. Here’s how to get things done with more talking and less typing.

headline: What You Get for $300,000
abstract: An 1876 clapboard cottage in New Bedford, a two-bedroom condo in Cincinnati and a Cape Cod-style house in Winston-Salem.
lead_paragraph: An 1876 clapboard cottage in New Bedford, a two-bedroom condo in Cincinnati and a Cape Cod-style house in Winston-Salem.

headline: $300,000 Homes in Massachusetts, Ohio and North Carolina
abstract: An 1876 clapboard cottage in New Bedford, a two-bedroom condo in Cincinnati and a Cape Cod-style house in Winston-Salem.
lead_paragraph: New Bedford is a coastal city of about 95,000 that was a 19th-century whaling capital. This house, in the downtown County Street Historic District, has easy access to stores, restaurants, bars, tea shops and bakeries. The New Bedford Whaling National Historical Park, a 13-block district that commemorates the area’s maritime heritage, is less than a mile east. Just beyond that is the Acushnet River, where ferry terminals provide service to Nantucket and other destinations. Buttonwood Park, a 97-acre park with a zoo, is less than a mile west.

headline: Watch Live: Day 8 of the Derek Chauvin Trial
abstract: Watch live video of the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former police officer charged in the death of George Floyd. Warning: The video may include graphic images.
lead_paragraph: Watch live video of the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former police officer charged in the death of George Floyd. Warning: The video may include graphic images.

headline: The Therapy-App Fantasy
abstract: An overwhelming demand for counseling has spawned slickly marketed companies promising a service they cannot possibly provide.
lead_paragraph: An overwhelming demand for counseling has spawned slickly marketed companies promising a service they cannot possibly provide.

headline: Minneapolis’s Native American community is closely watching the trial.
abstract: The American Indian Center was near areas that were damaged in protests after George Floyd’s death, and residents are preparing for possible unrest again after a verdict.
lead_paragraph: The regular updates that Johnny Crow’s girlfriend gives him about the former officer Derek Chauvin’s trial trigger reminders of how the Native American community in Minneapolis rallied to support one another in the months after George Floyd died.

headline: Key Moments in Day 8 of the Derek Chauvin Trial
abstract: The effect of bystanders and the Minneapolis Police Department’s use-of-force protocols have been key topics in recent testimony.
lead_paragraph: The trial of the former officer Derek Chauvin resumed on Wednesday with testimony from Sgt. Jody Stiger of the Los Angeles Police Department, who is expected to be the only outside expert to testify for the state about police training and use of force.

headline: Towering Above the Suburbs of Stockholm
abstract: This four-bedroom home — a converted seven-level water tower on an island outside Stockholm, Sweden — is on the market for $2.2 million.
lead_paragraph: This four-bedroom home — a converted seven-level water tower on an island outside Stockholm, Sweden — is on the market for $2.2 million.

headline: House Hunting in Sweden: A Sauna-Topped Water Tower Near Stockholm
abstract: After a slump in 2017 and 2018, Sweden’s housing prices are soaring again thanks to growing consumer confidence and evolving demand for larger homes.
lead_paragraph: This four-bedroom home is a converted, 108-foot water tower on Vaxon, an island in the Stockholm Archipelago, about 35 minutes east of central Stockholm, Sweden’s capital. The brick tower was built in 1923 on one of the highest points in the area to supply drinking water, and was being used as a reserve as late as 1989, said Jan Tivenius, an agent with Residence-Christie’s International Real Estate, which has the listing.

headline: Democratic lawmakers join a lawsuit that accuses Trump and Giuliani of conspiring to incite the Jan. 6 riot.
abstract: The suit accuses the former president and his lawyer of violating the Ku Klux Klan Act, an 1871 statute that includes protections against violent conspiracies that interfered with Congress’s constitutional duties.
lead_paragraph: A group of 10 Democratic members of Congress on Wednesday joined a federal lawsuit against former President Donald J. Trump and his personal lawyer Rudolph W. Giuliani, claiming that they violated a 19th-century statute when they tried to prevent the certification of the presidential election on Jan. 6.

headline: San Francisco Schools Will Keep Jefferson, Lincoln and Washington Names
abstract: The school board rescinded its January decision to rename 44 schools that honor historical figures such as Jefferson, Lincoln and Washington after an outcry from parents and the mayor.
lead_paragraph: San Francisco’s Board of Education voted to suspend a plan to rename a third of the city’s public schools, including ones honoring Washington, Jefferson and Lincoln, after the plan drew a scathing response from parents and the city’s mayor.

headline: Harris moves into her renovated residence, with new floors and Pence’s old beehive.
abstract: Number One Observatory Circle is finally ready for its newest resident. After months spent living in temporary quarters at Blair House, Vice President Kamala Harris moved into her 33-room official residence on Tuesday evening following the completion of renovations, an administration official said.
lead_paragraph: Number One Observatory Circle is finally ready for its newest resident. After months spent living in temporary quarters at Blair House, Vice President Kamala Harris moved into her 33-room official residence on Tuesday evening following the completion of renovations, an administration official said.

headline: Biden Can Go Bigger and Not ‘Pay for It’ the Old Way
abstract: By focusing on how much revenue they hope to raise from tax increases on the well-off, Democrats risk limiting the scope of their ambitions.
lead_paragraph: Last week, President Biden introduced a $2.2 trillion infrastructure plan in a speech, calling it “a once-in-a-generation investment in America.” And on Wednesday, he and the Treasury Department outlined many of the package’s details, including how to “pay for” it. A close look at those so-called pay-fors, however, shows Democrats are thinking about fiscal responsibility the wrong way. They could be on the verge of sparking some unpleasant short-term overheating of the economy, in which price increases accelerate and the purchasing power of our dollars falls somewhat. If the final legislation were to grow much larger — toward the $10 trillion level many progressives in Congress are pushing — it could send such inflation soaring.

headline: What It Means to Become ‘America’s Favorite Dancers’
abstract: “So You Think You Can Dance” may be on pandemic hiatus, but the show’s alums can be found on screens of all sizes.
lead_paragraph: At the beginning, “So You Think You Can Dance” seemed unstoppable. The “American Idol”-style reality competition found a devoted audience when it premiered in the summer of 2005. In the late 2000s, at the height of the show’s popularity, the names of “So You Think” dancers were familiar enough to pepper casual viewers’ dinner-table conversation. Did you call in to vote for Benji or Sabra or tWitch?

headline: Couple Who Defaced $400,000 Painting Thought It Was a Public Art Project
abstract: The vandalism of a piece by the graffiti artist JonOne at a gallery in South Korea has prompted a debate about contemporary art.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL — The couple saw brushes and paint cans in front of a paint-splattered canvas at a gallery in a Seoul shopping mall. So they added a few brush strokes, assuming it was a participatory mural.

headline: Calls for Further Inquiries Into Coronavirus Origins
abstract: In addition to outside calls for new inquiries, the W.H.O. team of scientists also suggested pursuit of other avenues including reviews of samples from blood banks.
lead_paragraph: In addition to outside calls for new inquiries, the W.H.O. team of scientists also suggested pursuit of other avenues including reviews of samples from blood banks.

headline: Justice Breyer says expanding the Supreme Court could undermine its authority.
abstract: Justice Stephen G. Breyer’s talk, on the nature of the court’s authority, had a valedictory quality.
lead_paragraph: Justice Stephen G. Breyer warned on Tuesday that expanding the size of the Supreme Court could erode public trust in it by sending the message that it is at its core a political institution.

headline: Two Presidents Visited Turkey. Only the Man Was Offered a Chair.
abstract: A protocol mishap involving Ursula von der Leyen, the European Commission president, was cited by critics as symbolic of Turkey’s treatment of women. It also underlined divisions within the European Union.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — If diplomacy is part theater, acted out on meticulously crafted sets, then a protocol blunder this week turned a top-level visit by European Union leaders to Turkey into high drama.

headline: The Courtroom Sketch: A Piece of History, and Art
abstract: The Library of Congress recently added more than 200 sketches of the Rodney King police brutality trial to its collection. “We are drawing history in the making,” one sketch artist said.
lead_paragraph: Sitting in a Manhattan courtroom in 1993, Marilyn Church unpacked her crayons and paper and patiently waited for the right moment to illustrate. As a courtroom sketch artist, she was used to jockeying for a good vantage point. This time, she was lucky to be seated in an empty jury box, giving her a clear view of both Mia Farrow and Woody Allen during a hearing in their child custody dispute.

headline: Why Immigrants Risk Their Lives Coming to the U.S.
abstract: Readers react to an Op-Ed that argued that they are lured by the willingness of employers to hire unauthorized immigrants.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: U.K. says under-30s should get a non-AstraZeneca option; E.U. finds a ‘possible link’ to rare clots.
abstract: Britain said on Wednesday that it would offer alternatives to the AstraZeneca vaccine for adults under 30 as European regulators described a “possible link” with rare blood clots, a setback for the world’s most widely used vaccine and a blow to the more than 100 countries relying on it to save lives amid a global surge in coronavirus cases.
lead_paragraph: Britain said on Wednesday that it would offer alternatives to the AstraZeneca vaccine for adults under 30 as European regulators described a “possible link” with rare blood clots, a setback for the world’s most widely used vaccine and a blow to the more than 100 countries relying on it to save lives amid a global surge in coronavirus cases.

headline: Why Kentucky Just Became the Only Red State to Expand Voting Rights
abstract: Republican lawmakers and the state’s Democratic governor backed a new law that proved the exception to the trend of G.O.P.-led legislatures moving to restrict ballot access.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Decker has solid conservative credentials. A first-term Republican state lawmaker in Kentucky who used to work for Senator Rand Paul, she represents a county that voted for Donald J. Trump last year by nearly 30 percentage points.

headline: New enrollees in Obamacare exceed half a million.
abstract: The number rose sharply from previous years, probably a result of more outreach, less stringent criteria for signing up, and the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: More than a half-million Americans have signed up for Affordable Care Act coverage during the first six weeks of a special open enrollment period that the Biden administration started in February.

headline: What to Cook Tonight
abstract: Set yourself up to eat well this evening, whether you make a tofu scramble, or an improvisational spicy pasta with tomatoes, olives and capers.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I mostly traffic in recipes in this space — in no-recipe recipes, too, as you will see below. These are mostly singular events: chicken paprikash, say, or a tofu scramble. What I love about my colleague David Tanis is, he stands for menus, for a full slate of recipes that result in a marvelous meal. Last week, for instance, he brought us instructions for a spring dinner of remarkable elegance and deliciousness, something to delight on all fronts: an herb-filled salad with egg and walnuts (above), with pan-fried breaded pork chops to follow, and baba au rhum for dessert. I hope you’ll give that a try this weekend.

headline: A Fierce Election Tests Modi’s Campaign to Remake India
abstract: The prime minister’s party is vying to dethrone a powerful politician in West Bengal. Even a close race could demonstrate the growing reach of his Hindu nationalist movement.
lead_paragraph: NANDIGRAM, India — The challenger arrived with police vehicles, a band of drummers and the backing of the country’s powerful prime minister. The crowd joined him in full-throated chants of glory to the Hindu god Ram: “Jai Shree Ram!” He brought a warning: If Hindus did not unite around him, even their most basic religious practices would be in danger in the face of Muslim appeasement.

headline: Richard Thompson on Fairport Convention, Linda Thompson and London in the Late ’60s
abstract: In “Beeswing,” one of the great pioneers of folk-rock looks back on his early years.
lead_paragraph: BEESWINGLosing My Way and Finding My Voice, 1967-1975By Richard Thompson with Scott Timberg

headline: A Tiny Particle’s Wobble Could Upend the Known Laws of Physics
abstract: Experiments with particles known as muons suggest that there are forms of matter and energy vital to the nature and evolution of the cosmos that are not yet known to science.
lead_paragraph: Evidence is mounting that a tiny subatomic particle seems to be disobeying the known laws of physics, scientists announced on Wednesday, a finding that would open a vast and tantalizing hole in our understanding of the universe.

headline: America’s Toxic Disasters-in-Waiting
abstract: A giant pool of industrial waste almost burst in Florida this week. There are thousands more around the country.
lead_paragraph: You may never have seen them, but vast open-air pools of toxic water, from hazardous mining byproducts to diluted pig waste, are a common feature at thousands of industrial and agricultural sites across the country.

headline: Tiger Woods Was Driving About 85 M.P.H. in a 45 M.P.H. Zone When He Crashed
abstract: The stretch of road where Woods crashed in February is known for speeding and crashes.
lead_paragraph: Tiger Woods was speeding when he crashed his sport-utility vehicle in February, reaching speeds of more than 80 m.p.h. in a 45 m.p.h. zone on winding road near Los Angeles, according to Los Angeles County Sheriff Alex Villanueva.

headline: What is proportional force?
abstract: Proportional force is the idea that the force that an officer is supposed to use on a suspect, including the use of chokeholds or other neck restraints, should not be more intense than necessary.
lead_paragraph: The phrase “proportional force” or “proportional use of force” has been mentioned several times during the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis officer who has been charged with the death of George Floyd.

headline: Kentucky becomes the only red state to expand voting rights this year, as others enact restrictions.
abstract: Kentucky on Wednesday became the only state in the country with a Republican-controlled legislature to expand voting rights this year, as Gov. Andy Beshear, a Democrat, signed a bipartisan law that cut against the push in many G.O.P.-led states nationwide to put up barriers to voting.
lead_paragraph: Kentucky on Wednesday became the only state in the country with a Republican-controlled legislature to expand voting rights this year, as Gov. Andy Beshear, a Democrat, signed a bipartisan law that cut against the push in many G.O.P.-led states nationwide to put up barriers to voting.

headline: A Lifetime of Reading Taught Min Jin Lee How to Write About Her Immigrant World
abstract: As a child, the novelist found consolation in books that embraced American rugged individualism and the Korean quest for knowledge. Those same books showed her how to honor the stories of the people she grew up with.
lead_paragraph: This past year, I’ve spent most of my time in my drafty office in Harlem, where the water leak from the lintel above the south-facing window has reappeared after some bad weather. The elementary school across the street has been closed. I miss the happy laughter of the children. I’ve had some troubling news, and had to gather myself and remember how to solve knotty problems. I turn to my shelves again.

headline: FEMA will offer more financial aid for Covid funeral expenses starting next week.
abstract: Billions of dollars from two Covid relief measures will be used to soften the financial blow for grieving families by reimbursing funeral and related expenses.
lead_paragraph: People who paid for the funeral and burial expenses of someone who died from Covid-19 will be offered expanded federal financial support starting on Monday, according to an announcement by the Federal Emergency Management Agency.

headline: The 17 Best Recipes Our Food Staff Cooked Last Month
abstract: In March, the staff of the Food section and NYT Cooking made the most of early spring produce, while leaning in to easy and hearty favorites.
lead_paragraph: March is a strange time of year. It heralds the arrival of spring, but some of us are not out of winter’s icy grip just yet. The New York Times Food team cooked accordingly. While we still turned to hearty meals — seafood stews, a big pot of beans and birthday baked ziti — we also dipped our toes into the pool of spring produce. (A full-throated hello to our dear friend asparagus.) Here are our favorite recipes we cooked last month.

headline: The Biden administration seeks to raise $2.5 trillion through corporate tax increases.
abstract: The tax plan would raise the corporate rate to 28 percent from 21 percent to help fund the president’s economic agenda.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration unveiled its plan to overhaul the corporate tax code on Wednesday, offering an array of proposals that would require large companies to pay higher taxes to help fund the White House’s economic agenda.

headline: Millions of delayed stimulus payments have arrived. Veterans are next.
abstract: More than 25 million lower-income Americans received their stimulus payments on Wednesday. Certain veterans could get theirs next week.
lead_paragraph: More than 25 million lower-income Americans whose stimulus payments were delayed finally received them on Wednesday. And one group still waiting — certain veterans and their beneficiaries — can expect their payments to arrive next week, the Internal Revenue Service said.

headline: With Virus Origins Still Obscure, W.H.O. and Critics Look to Next Steps
abstract: A scientific mission to China proposed further study for a number of topics. Critics and the director of the W.H.O. have weighed in as well.
lead_paragraph: The joint international and Chinese mission organized by the World Health Organization on the origins of Covid released its report last week suggesting that for almost every topic it covered, more study was needed. What kind of study and who will do it is the question.

headline: Lippold’s Soaring Lincoln Center Sculpture Lands at La Guardia
abstract: Richard Lippold’s “Orpheus and Apollo,” removed from an atrium in 2014, will be seen on a grand scale at La Guardia Airport.
lead_paragraph: Richard Lippold’s soaring sculpture “Orpheus and Apollo,” which had been removed from Lincoln Center’s Philharmonic Hall (now David Geffen Hall) in 2014, will be suspended in flight once again: as the centerpiece of La Guardia Airport’s Central Hall.

headline: Biden says he’s willing to compromise on his infrastructure plan, but will not tolerate ‘doing nothing.’
abstract: President Biden on Wednesday signaled his openness to “good faith negotiations” on his $2.3 trillion infrastructure proposal — but bluntly warned Republican opponents of the plan that he would “not be open to doing nothing.”
lead_paragraph: President Biden on Wednesday signaled his openness to “good faith negotiations” on his $2.3 trillion infrastructure proposal — but bluntly warned Republican opponents of the plan that he would “not be open to doing nothing.”

headline: Can Colleges Require Covid-19 Vaccines?
abstract: It’s shaping up to be yet another political debate.
lead_paragraph: Most U.S. colleges and universities already require on-campus students to show proof of vaccines for illnesses, like bacterial meningitis, that can spread rapidly in close quarters. But Covid-19 is a much more complicated story.

headline: Nemam Ghafouri, Doctor Who Aided Yazidis in Iraq, Dies at 52
abstract: Dr. Ghafouri helped survivors of an ISIS genocide and reunited formerly enslaved women with children taken from them. She died of Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: That Nemam Ghafouri was born in a cave might be one of the least remarkable things about her. It was the 1960s, and her mother went into labor in the mountains of what is now the Kurdistan region of Iraq as she was fleeing with her other children from Iraqi government forces.

headline: Unions at The Ringer and Gimlet Media announce their first contracts.
abstract: The agreements at the two companies, owned by the audio giant Spotify, are a milestone for the podcasting industry.
lead_paragraph: Unions representing employees at two prominent podcasting companies owned by Spotify, the audiostreaming giant, announced Wednesday that they had ratified their first labor contracts.

headline: A police force expert says Derek Chauvin used ‘deadly force’ on George Floyd when he should have used none.
abstract: Sgt. Jody Stiger, who works for the Los Angeles Police Department, said Mr. Chauvin had put Mr. Floyd at risk of positional asphyxia, a key point for prosecutors who have argued that Mr. Floyd died of asphyxia.
lead_paragraph: A use-of-force expert with the Los Angeles Police Department testified on Wednesday that Derek Chauvin had used “deadly force” on George Floyd at a time when it was not appropriate to use any force.

headline: Watch Live: Biden Speaks on Infrastructure Plan
abstract: President Biden delivers remarks on his $2 trillion American Jobs Plan, which aims to overhaul the nation’s infrastructure.
lead_paragraph: President Biden delivers remarks on his $2 trillion American Jobs Plan, which aims to overhaul the nation’s infrastructure.

headline: Breaking Silence, Jordan’s King Says Royal Family Rift Is Over
abstract: The government has accused King Abdullah II’s half brother, Prince Hamzah, of undermining national security, and arrested several of his associates.
lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — King Abdullah II of Jordan broke his silence Wednesday night over the unusually public rift with his half brother, Prince Hamzah, justifying the steps he had taken to curb his brother’s contact with the outside world, while asserting that the prince’s “sedition has been nipped in the bud.”

headline: How Integration Came to the American League, in Cleveland’s Glory Days
abstract: Luke Epplin talks about “Our Team,” which recounts the Cleveland Indians’ seasons of 1947 and 1948, including Larry Doby becoming the first Black player in the American League.
lead_paragraph: Whether or not you care about baseball, you know the name Jackie Robinson. But even baseball fans of a certain age might not know Larry Doby, who made his major-league debut with the Cleveland Indians on July 5, 1947, integrating the American League just three months after Robinson had courageously done the same for the National League. Doby’s experience as the second Black player to break baseball’s 20th-century color barrier is one strand of Luke Epplin’s first book, “Our Team.” Epplin recounts the Indians’ seasons of 1947 and 1948 through the stories of four iconic figures: Doby; Satchel Paige, the Negro leagues pitching legend who joined the Indians in 1948, at 42 years old; Bill Veeck, the team’s maverick owner; and Bob Feller, the Hall of Fame pitcher who had debuted in Cleveland in 1936, when he was just 17. Below, Epplin talks about the origins of his interest in the team, how Doby’s experience differed from Robinson’s and more.

headline: Lois Kirschenbaum, the Ultimate Opera Superfan, Dies at 88
abstract: In New York opera circles, an autograph request from her, the mezzo-soprano Frederica von Stade said, was considered “a special type of approval.”
lead_paragraph: For more than a half-century, nearly every prominent singer to perform at the Metropolitan Opera could expect to be approached backstage afterward by a wispy woman in thick glasses, who held piles of memorabilia to be autographed while she praised the performance in a raspy Brooklyn accent.

headline: What is the Minnesota Bureau of Criminal Apprehension, the agency that investigated George Floyd’s death?
abstract: A special agent from the bureau testified at the Derek Chauvin trial on Wednesday. The agency has a range of responsibilities, including investigating all Minneapolis police killings.
lead_paragraph: The second witness to take the stand in the trial of Derek Chauvin on Wednesday was a special agent with the Minnesota Bureau of Criminal Apprehension. Other employees of the agency are also expected to testify. So, what is it?

headline: Most U.S. infections are now caused by a contagious virus variant, the C.D.C. says.

headline: Mario Schifano’s Excellent New York Adventure
abstract: A new exhibition in SoHo explores the Italian artist’s connections to the midcentury American art scene.
lead_paragraph: For much of the 19th and early 20th centuries, American artists believed they lived in a cultural backwater. They yearned to sail to Europe to study painting and crane their necks at the Sistine Ceiling. But at a certain point, the direction of travel was reversed. New York became the imperial art capital, and European artists considered it obligatory to come here and meet the gang. When did that moment occur? Perhaps on Dec. 3, 1963, when Mario Schifano, a 29-year-old Italian artist enamored of novelty, arrived in New York.
