headline: Jordan Spieth Had a Very Good Day at the Masters
abstract: A crowd favorite, all eyes were on Spieth as he charged up the leaderboard and put himself in contention with a confident second round.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Jordan Spieth was walking down the 17th hole at Augusta National Golf Club on Friday when a voice from the crowd lining the fairway cried out, “Welcome back!”

headline: Fans Mourn the Death of DMX
abstract: Fans created a small memorial in White Plains, N.Y., to remember the rapper and actor Earl Simmons, also known as DMX, who died on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Fans created a small memorial in White Plains, N.Y., to remember the rapper and actor Earl Simmons, also known as DMX, who died on Friday.

headline: Will Biden ‘Pack’ the Supreme Court?
abstract: The president has not explicitly endorsed calls to expand the court, but he just ordered a study exploring possible reforms.
lead_paragraph: For many liberals, the state of the nation’s courts system has reached a crisis point. For President Donald Trump and Senator Mitch McConnell, reshaping the judiciary branch was a top priority throughout Trump’s term — and they largely succeeded.

headline: Martina Batan, New York Art Dealer Consumed by a Cold Case, Dies at 62
abstract: Finding answers to the unsolved murder of her 14-year-old brother became a lifelong quest, ultimately chronicled in a documentary film.
lead_paragraph: One winter night in 1978, a 14-year-old boy named Jeffrey Batan was killed in Rego Park, Queens. His body was found with 20 stab wounds in a snowy yard the next morning. Though the violent crime received media attention, it was never solved.

headline: Despite Other Factors, Police Caused Floyd’s Death, Medical Examiner Says
abstract: Dr. Andrew Baker, who performed the official autopsy of George Floyd, said that fentanyl and heart disease had contributed to his death, but that the officers’ actions were the main cause.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — In a trial where many key figures have spent hours on the stand, the prosecution whipped through one of their most anticipated witnesses, the doctor who performed George Floyd’s official autopsy, in a mere 50 minutes on Friday.

headline: World Leaders Remember Prince Philip
abstract: Leaders from around the world paid tribute to the life and service of Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh, who died on Friday, and offered condolences to Queen Elizabeth II and the royal family.
lead_paragraph: Leaders from around the world paid tribute to the life and service of Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh, who died on Friday, and offered condolences to Queen Elizabeth II and the royal family.

headline: Rose Holds Slim Masters Lead as Johnson Misses the Cut
abstract: After shooting a 75 on Friday, Dustin Johnson, who won the Masters in November, became the latest defending champion not to advance into the weekend.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — To most every player at the Masters Tournament, the 530-yard, water-guarded hole called Firethorn is a back-nine destination for earning back a stroke. To Bernd Wiesberger, that hole, No. 15 at Augusta National Golf Club, can teeter toward the nightmarish.

headline: China Fines Alibaba $2.8 Billion in Landmark Antitrust Case
abstract: The penalty is the biggest move to date in China’s campaign to tighten supervision of its internet Goliaths.
lead_paragraph: By hitting the e-commerce titan Alibaba with a record $2.8 billion antitrust fine on Saturday, Chinese officials sent a message to the country’s high-flying internet industry: We’ve got our eyes on you.

headline: Matt Gaetz Says He Is a Victim of ‘the Leaks and the Lies’ of Critics
abstract: The congressman defended himself in his first major public appearance since a Justice Department inquiry came to light last week.
lead_paragraph: Representative Matt Gaetz, the Florida Republican who is the focus of a Justice Department inquiry over whether he broke sex trafficking laws, maintained his innocence on Friday and insisted he was the victim of “the leaks and the lies” of his critics.

headline: Not So Intense, Say
abstract: Evans Clinchy throws a highly cultured Saturday brunch.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This kind of grid is my bread and butter, not just because so many of its entries make me think of a nice meal out, but because so many of its entries are completely unknown, absent from my knowledge. That makes for great column fodder, true, but it’s also so satisfying to suss out a little pileup of trivia like we see in the northeast corner, and I found the difficult cluing very likable and fresh.

headline: Focus on Wellness and Take a Gardening Class
abstract: This week, spend story time with the National Postal Museum, listen to a lecture from the artist Lorraine O’Grady or take a Syrian cooking class.
lead_paragraph: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.

headline: Quotation of the Day: To Speed Up, Some Call for Delaying Second Shots
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, April 10, 2021.
lead_paragraph: “Relying on one dose of Moderna or Pfizer to stop variants like B.1.351 is like using a BB gun to stop a charging rhino.”

headline: Corrections: April 10, 2021
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, April 10, 2021.
lead_paragraph: An article on Monday about an elite high school’s efforts to implement a coronavirus testing program, relying on outdated information from the Illinois Department of Public Health, misstated the status of its investigation into SafeGuard Screening. After publication, The Times was told that the investigation had ended in March, after SafeGuard received federal certification.

headline: Woman Who Coughed on Pier 1 Shopper’s Face Is Sentenced to 30 Days
abstract: Debra Hunter, 53, was seen in a widely circulated video last year coughing on a customer who was recording her dispute with employees at a home-goods store in Jacksonville, Fla.
lead_paragraph: A Florida woman who was seen in a widely watched video intentionally coughing on a shopper at a Pier 1 home-goods store last summer, as fears about the pandemic raged, was sentenced on Thursday to 30 days in jail, court records show.

headline: A ‘San Diego Kid’ Gives the Padres Their First No-Hitter
abstract: Joe Musgrove allowed only one base runner, on a hit-by-pitch. San Diego had been the last team without a no-hitter.
lead_paragraph: Maybe it was fate, Joe Musgrove guessed late Friday night. How else to explain his sudden status as the first pitcher to throw a no-hitter in the history of his hometown team? Musgrove was drafted by Toronto, won a World Series with Houston and made an opening-day start for Pittsburgh. But his inner compass always pointed home.

headline: Incarcerated and Infected: How the Virus Tore Through the U.S. Prison System
abstract: Since March 2020, New York Times reporters have tracked every known coronavirus case in every correctional setting in the nation. More than 2,700 inmates have died.
lead_paragraph: Since March 2020, New York Times reporters have tracked every known coronavirus case in every correctional setting in the nation. More than 2,700 inmates have died.

headline: By 5-4 Vote, Supreme Court Lifts Restrictions on Prayer Meetings in Homes
abstract: The court shifted direction in cases on Covid-related limits on religious services after Justice Amy Coney Barrett replaced Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court late Friday night lifted California’s restrictions on religious gatherings in private homes, saying they could not be enforced to bar prayer meetings, Bible study classes and the like. The court’s brief, unsigned order followed earlier ones striking down limits on attendance at houses of worship meant to combat the coronavirus.

headline: We Asked Congress’s Freshmen to Give Up Stock Trading. Few Were Willing.
abstract: Playing individual stocks is a losing strategy more often than not, and it poses political risk. But only a handful of newly minted lawmakers saw it that way.
lead_paragraph: It’s easy to forget that just a year ago, senators from both parties were under Justice Department scrutiny for potentially profiteering from the coronavirus with well-timed stock trades.

headline: ‘Sense of Disappointment’ on the Left as the N.Y.C. Mayor’s Race Unfolds
abstract: Even as New York has veered toward the left, two more-moderate candidates, Andrew Yang and Eric Adams, lead the mayoral race.
lead_paragraph: Over the last year, New York politics have appeared to lurch ever leftward. First came the primary victories last summer in a series of House and state legislative races, then the legalization of recreational marijuana, and just this week, a state budget agreement that would raise taxes on the wealthy and create a $2.1 billion fund to aid undocumented workers.

headline: Police Say an Antifa Activist Likely Shot at Officers. His Gun Suggests Otherwise.
abstract: Investigators said that Michael Reinoehl probably opened fire before officers killed him last year. But some key evidence raises questions about that conclusion.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — When a U.S. Marshals task force killed a self-described antifa activist in Washington State in September, the Trump administration applauded the removal of a “violent agitator” who was suspected of murder. Last week, local investigators concluded a monthslong homicide inquiry with the announcement that the activist, Michael Reinoehl, had most likely fired at authorities first, effectively justifying the shooting.

headline: The New Cancel Culture Capitalism
abstract: For Republicans, cancel culture is good for business.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your wrap-up of the week in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

headline: YungBBQ Can Be Almost Anyone. Just Watch.
abstract: Alexis Feacher, 21, built a following by creating freestyle dance routines emulating a specific era of pop culture.
lead_paragraph: Alexis Feacher, 21, has built a following with her freestyle dance impersonations of pop cultural figures and fictional characters. Her improvised movements and elaborate costumes have helped her convey the essence of Tina Turner, Jimmy Neutron, Missy Elliott and so many more.

headline: This Heroin-Using Professor Wants to Change How We Think About Drugs
abstract: Prof. Carl Hart saw drugs as destroyers of communities. Then he saw the positive side. “We have miseducated the public,” he said.
lead_paragraph: Carl L. Hart, a neuroscientist at Columbia University, fielded questions the other day about his new book, which makes an unconventional case for drug use.

headline: Inside the Fight for the Future of The Wall Street Journal
abstract: A special team led by a high-level manager says Rupert Murdoch’s paper must evolve to survive. But a rivalry between editor and publisher stands in the way.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Trump Lashes His Enemies Anew as G.O.P. Dances Around His Presence
abstract: A gathering of Republican leaders and top donors in Florida this weekend is less a reset of priorities and more a reminder of the tensions that Donald J. Trump instills in his party.
lead_paragraph: The first spring donor retreat after a defeat for a political party is typically a moment of reflection and renewal as officials chart a new direction forward.

headline: Royal Rivalry Bares Social Tensions Behind Jordan’s Stable Veneer
abstract: The standoff between King Abdullah II and his half brother, Prince Hamzah, wasn’t just palace intrigue. It hinted at Saudi meddling and highlighted wider tensions within Jordan’s complex society.
lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — The prince and the general paced the garden outside the prince’s palace, locked in a deep argument. The prince was shouting, the general was barely audible. But the general made the threat.

headline: At Last, Aid for Senior Nutrition That Offers More Than Crumbs
abstract: Meal programs for older adults have long been underfunded. The new economic recovery plan will help.
lead_paragraph: Long before the coronavirus hit, nutrition programs that served the nation’s older adults struggled to keep up with a growing demand. Often, they could not.

headline: Could Ron DeSantis Be Trump’s G.O.P. Heir? He’s Certainly Trying.
abstract: Florida’s governor has elbowed his way to the front of the line of 2024 Republican hopefuls by leveraging a brand of “competent Trumpism” (as one ally put it) and hitting back at critics of his pandemic leadership.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — No one had to tell Ron DeSantis that his mock debates had bordered on disastrous. His answers rambled. He seemed uninspired.

headline: She Gets Paid Just to Humiliate Her Fans
abstract: The high-priced hustle of financial domination, where “pay pigs” send tributes to their cash masters.
lead_paragraph: To celebrate her 27th birthday, Mistress Marley, a professional dominatrix from Harlem, flew to Tulum, Mexico, where she rented a modern four-bedroom villa with a limestone pool, private beach and personal chef.

headline: Why Buy a Yacht When You Can Buy a Newspaper?
abstract: Billionaires aren’t usually cast as saviors of democracy. But one way they are winning plaudits for civic-minded endeavors is by funding the Fourth Estate.
lead_paragraph: Billionaires have had a pretty good pandemic. There are more of them than there were a year ago, even as the crisis has exacerbated inequality. But scrutiny has followed these ballooning fortunes. Policymakers are debating new taxes on corporations and wealthy individuals. Even their philanthropy has come under increasing criticism as an exercise of power as much as generosity.

headline: Michigan’s Virus Cases Are Out of Control, Putting Gov. Gretchen Whitmer in a Bind
abstract: Ms. Whitmer, a Democrat, locked down her state over the din of protests last year. Now she is trying a different approach, appealing to personal responsibility.
lead_paragraph: Nowhere in America is the coronavirus pandemic more out of control than in Michigan.

headline: A Teacher Marched to the Capitol. When She Got Home, the Fight Began.
abstract: Kristine Hostetter was a beloved fourth-grade teacher. Then came the pandemic, the election and the Jan. 6 riot in Washington.
lead_paragraph: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif. — Word got around when Kristine Hostetter was spotted at a public mask-burning at the San Clemente pier, and when she appeared in a video sitting onstage as her husband spoke at a QAnon convention. People talked when she angrily accosted a family wearing masks near a local surfing spot, her granddaughter in tow.

headline: Harry Will Attend Philip’s Funeral, Raising Hope Royal Rift Will Heal
abstract: Although Harry  will come home to mourn with the family, his pregnant wife Meghan will not. The patriarch’s death opens an uncertain chapter for the House of Windsor.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Buckingham Palace said on Saturday that Prince Harry would be returning to Britain for Prince Philip’s funeral next weekend, setting in motion fevered speculation about whether the reunion would mend fences in the royal family or sow deeper discord.

headline: Staying afloat as interest rates rise.
abstract: The low rates that propelled the stock market’s boom are starting to rise, putting investors in a precarious position.
lead_paragraph: The stock market’s rally during the pandemic has been nothing short of amazing. But rising interest rates are raising the question of how long this bull market can last.

headline: ‘You Can’t Trust Anyone’: Russia’s Hidden Covid Toll Is an Open Secret
abstract: The country’s official coronavirus death toll is 102,649. But at least 300,000 more people died last year during the pandemic than were reported in Russia’s most widely cited official statistics.
lead_paragraph: SAMARA, Russia — She burst into the hospital morgue and the bodies were everywhere, about a dozen of them in black bags on stretchers. She headed straight for the autopsy room, pleading with the guard in a black jacket: “Can I speak to the doctor who opened up my father?”

headline: The Oddities That Make the Masters Unique
abstract: The Masters Tournament, played annually at Augusta National Golf Club in Georgia, is one of the South’s grandest spring traditions. It also has its quirks.
lead_paragraph: The Masters Tournament, played annually at Augusta National Golf Club in Georgia, is one of the South’s grandest spring traditions. It also has its quirks.

headline: Scenes From the First Rounds of the Masters
abstract: Our staff photographer Doug Mills brings us an inside look at Augusta National.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Maybe it is the Masters tournament’s place as an annual rite of spring or its rich history, revisited this week for an 85th time. Perhaps it is because the tournament is the only major golf championship contested on the same golf course every year, which breeds a comforting familiarity. But the Masters stands out among sporting events — for its colorful grounds, for its gentle mix of old and new champions, and for the generations of attending families renewing traditions on the site. It is the rare athletic arena in the spotlight for only four days a year, but then maybe that is its ultimate charm.

headline: Companies Can’t Stop Overworking
abstract: Excess work isn’t good for anyone, employers included. So why are we still doing it?
lead_paragraph: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.

headline: A Soviet ‘Lord of the Rings’ Is Unearthed, Epic in Its Own Way
abstract: Tolkien fans received an unexpected gift with the rediscovery of an all-but-forgotten 1991 production. They were also left with questions, like “why is Gollum wearing a lettuce on his head?”
lead_paragraph: The hobbits and elves are familiar, if the Soviet folk-rock is not. One man is clearly a wizard, though the special effects are, at their best, not very good. And the growl of an actor painted green does sound — sort of — like he might be saying “gollum.”

headline: Turn the Lights Out. Here Come the Birds.
abstract: Buildings, landmarks and monuments are turning off lights to prevent fatal impacts as birds set off on spring migration.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of American cities are being transformed this spring, enveloped in darkness as the lights that usually brighten up their skylines are turned off at night to prevent birds from fatal impacts during their annual migrations.

headline: A Love Letter to Black Women
abstract: A first solo exhibition by the Bahamian artist Gio Swaby aims to redefine the often politicized Black body.
lead_paragraph: For many, art provides a voice for the unheard. It can capture moments of positivity that might otherwise be unrepresented.

headline: 5 Takeaways From the Second Week of the Derek Chauvin Trial
abstract: Witnesses addressed two key issues: What caused George Floyd’s death, and whether Mr. Chauvin violated police policies on the use of force.
lead_paragraph: The first week of the Derek Chauvin trial was marked by emotional accounts from bystanders who witnessed the nine and a half minutes that the police pinned George Floyd to the ground. But the second week struck a different chord, highlighting testimony from medical and law enforcement experts that centered on the conduct of Mr. Chauvin and the cause of Mr. Floyd’s death.

headline: Afghan President in ‘Desperate Situation’ as His Power Is Undermined
abstract: Ashraf Ghani has few remaining allies, the Taliban are gaining militarily and his international supporters are impatient with him and the stumbling peace process.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — He attends international conferences, meets with diplomats, recently inaugurated a dam and delivers patriotic speeches vowing to defend his country against the Taliban.

headline: Man Who Boasted He Was at Capitol Riot Is Charged in Bomb Plot
abstract: Seth Aaron Pendley was arrested on Thursday and charged with plotting to blow up an Amazon data center in Virginia, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: A Texas man who boasted that he was at the United States Capitol when a pro-Trump mob stormed the building in January has been charged with plotting to blow up an Amazon data center in Virginia, the Justice Department said on Friday.

headline: Do You Have to Pay Your Building’s Covid-19 Cleaning Fee?
abstract: It depends on how your contract is worded, but there is often room for negotiation in any case.
lead_paragraph: Q: I am moving out of the Yorkville apartment that I’ve been renting in a condo. The management company says the condo board has mandated a $1,250 Covid-19 cleaning fee, on top of the standard move-out fee. My lease included a rider stating that it was subject to the provisions and bylaws of the condo, but $1,250 seems like an absurd amount of money to clean a 650-square-foot apartment, and unnecessary when it’s been shown that surfaces are not high-risk. Do I have to pay this?

headline: The Essence of Spring
abstract: Make an herby salad, a bright pasta or a fresh one-pan meal to conjure flavors of the season.
lead_paragraph: Looking for a bright and zesty dish that conjures the essence of spring? This herby, crunchy salad with egg and walnuts from David Tanis (above) fits the bill, and it was our most popular recipe of the week. Kay Chun’s pasta Bolognese with lamb and peas is equally springy, as are Melissa Clark’s one-pan pork chops with feta, snap peas and mint. Or try your hand at some classic French baking: David Tanis’s baba au rhum and Claire Saffitz’s croissants caught New York Times Cooking readers’ attention.

headline: What DMX’s Poetry of Death Did for Hip-Hop
abstract: In life and art, death was never far from Earl Simmons.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve ever attended a DMX concert, it’s more than likely that you’ve seen him cry. As the adrenaline of the night would cool, the rapper born as Earl Simmons would pray, acting as the intercessor for the holy spirit on behalf of the audience, through a sheet of sweat and tears.

headline: ‘To Leave the World a Bit Better,’ and Other Codes to Live By
abstract: We asked readers what philosophies they live by. Their inspirations include Emerson, Niebuhr, deceased family members, a sign at a boat dock and a pet.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Sliding in the Polls, Erdogan Kicks Up a New Storm Over the Bosporus
abstract: As part of a push to carve a canal alongside the waterway, Turkey’s president signaled that he could scrap a treaty that has kept peace in the region for decades.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The unpredictable roller coaster that has become Turkish politics was on full display this past week after 104 retired admirals publicly challenged President Recep Tayyip Erdogan in an open letter — and 10 of them ended up in jail, accused of plotting a coup.

headline: ‘Maximum Pressure’ on Iran Has Failed
abstract: A return to the nuclear deal is the first step out of the morass.
lead_paragraph: There exists now a brief window of time for Iran and the United States to return to the principles of the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action, known to supporters and critics alike as the Iran nuclear deal.

headline: The Force That Can Help Amazon’s Workers? Amazon’s Shoppers.
abstract: Customers can start telling Jeff Bezos to treat his workers like human beings.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the ways that people who have worked inside Amazon’s warehouses describe the experience: “The job crushed my spirit and crippled my body.” “The lowest point in my life.” An “isolating colony of hell.” “They’re killing people mentally and physically.” “I began to hate my day-to-day life.” “The way Amazon pushes people is not moral.” “I had whole days where I didn’t talk to anyone.” “The systematic devaluing of human bodies.”

headline: Republicans Have Found Their Cruel New Culture War
abstract: Arkansas lawmakers’ move against trans people reflects a larger strategy.
lead_paragraph: Straight people have often asked me what I, a gay man, have in common with someone who’s trans. Gay people have often put that question to themselves. There are many answers. Here’s one: I know what it’s like to have my identity, my dignity — my very hold on happiness — pressed into partisan battle and fashioned into a political weapon.

headline: A Once-in-a-Century Crisis Can Help Educate Doctors
abstract: The horrors of Covid-19 may give proponents of the liberal arts an unexpected opening.
lead_paragraph: Over the past year, ordinary medical research nearly ground to a halt as researchers focused on coronavirus vaccine trials and treatments. Single-mindedness paid off. Drugmakers developed lifesaving vaccines in record time, and now a third of Americans are at least partially vaccinated.

headline: AstraZeneca Vaccine and Blood Clots: What Is Known So Far
abstract: In rare cases, an immune reaction has led to antibodies that caused a serious clotting disorder. But public health experts maintain the vaccine’s benefits far outweigh the risks for most people.
lead_paragraph: The AstraZeneca-Oxford vaccine has been deployed against Covid-19 in at least 115 countries, some of them for several months now. But it wasn’t until a few cases of a rare blood-clotting disorder — some fatal — emerged within the past month or so that many European nations began to rethink its use across all age groups.

headline: Saudi Aramco sells oil pipeline stake for $12.4 billion
abstract: Aramco is under pressure from its main owner, the Saudi government, to generate cash to finance state operations as well as new investments.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Aramco, the national oil company of Saudi Arabia, has reached a deal to raise $12.4 billion from the sale of a 49 percent stake in a pipeline-rights company.

headline: Seeing Hate, 28 Asian and Asian-American Photographers Focus on Love
abstract: In a special project by the Culture desk, artists respond to a climate of fear and racism with images and reflections from the heart.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Ramsey Clark, Attorney General and Rebel With a Cause, Dies at 93
abstract: Mr. Clark oversaw the drafting of the Fair Housing Act in 1968 and went on to defend both the disadvantaged and the unpopular.
lead_paragraph: Ramsey Clark, who championed civil rights and liberties as attorney general in the Johnson administration, then devoted much of the rest of his life to defending unpopular causes and infamous people, including Saddam Hussein and others accused of war crimes, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 93.

headline: Life Has Moved On, but Fans in Atlanta Mourn the All-Star Game
abstract: Friday’s home opener offered some prepandemic-like excitement, but even fans who support M.L.B.’s choice to move the signature event are sad to see it go.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — In and around Truist Park in suburban Atlanta on Friday, there were scant clues that Major League Baseball’s 2021 All-Star Game, as of roughly a week ago, was supposed to be held here on July 13.

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon remind us about what’s really important before we all go interstellar.
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — Today’s passage concerns something that humanity has fixated on since its discovery by Galileo in the 17th century, yet it’s also very timely — Mars, the red planet, is hosting an elaborate group of mechanical explorers from Earth right now, in preparation for our imminent mass migration. That’s a stretch, but if you read the book excerpted in today’s puzzle, Kate Greene’s “Once Upon a Time I Lived on Mars,” you might feel a bit better about the possibility of visiting, maybe for a dinner out. Keep in mind that snacking on the way will present a logistical challenge.

headline: Young Migrants Crowd Shelters, Posing Test for Biden
abstract: The administration is under intensifying pressure to expand its capacity to care for as many as 35,000 unaccompanied minors, part of a wave of people crossing the border.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The desperate plea landed this week in the email inboxes of employees in government agencies like the Department of Homeland Security and NASA: Will you consider taking a four-month paid leave from your job to help care for migrant children in government-run shelters packed with new arrivals at the border?

headline: The Wall Street Journal’s Internal Audit
abstract: A look at what the newsroom’s internal study — The Content Review — concluded about the paper’s faults.
lead_paragraph: For over a year, a special team of editors within The Wall Street Journal analyzed the state of the newsroom and produced a detailed, lengthy report on what the paper is doing right, and, more important, what the paper is doing wrong.

headline: After Going ‘Free of L.G.B.T.,’ a Polish Town Pays a Price
abstract: Krasnik voted to be “free of L.G.B.T.” two years ago to satisfy conservative voters. Now, the mayor regrets the move, which has led to censure from other European countries and put funding at risk.
lead_paragraph: KRASNIK, Poland — When local councilors adopted a resolution two years ago declaring their small town in southeastern Poland “free of L.G.B.T.,” the mayor didn’t see much harm in what appeared to be a symbolic and legally pointless gesture.

headline: Marshall D. Sahlins, Groundbreaking Anthropologist, Dies at 90
abstract: His work focused on the way cultures shape, and are shaped by, individuals — a framework he demonstrated through his passionate political activism.
lead_paragraph: Marshall D. Sahlins, a brilliant and witty anthropologist who, starting in the 1970s, explored how individuals shape and are shaped by their cultures — a point he had already put in practice a decade earlier as the inventor of the “teach-in” against the Vietnam War — died on April 5 at his home in Chicago. He was 90.

headline: Can the Meritocracy Find God?
abstract: The secularization of America probably won’t reverse unless the intelligentsia gets religion.
lead_paragraph: As is now traditional on the Easter holiday, I spent last Sunday hunting for eggs with my children, attending Mass, hiding more eggs at an aunt’s house so the children could hunt yet again, and reading elegiac essays about American Christianity’s decline.

headline: They Overcame Mutual Loathing, and Saved a Town
abstract: Environmentalists and loggers thought they had nothing in common, until they started talking.
lead_paragraph: JOHN DAY, Ore. — One of the most venomous battles in our polarized nation is the one that has unfolded between loggers and environmentalists in timber towns like this one in the snow-capped Blue Mountains of Eastern Oregon.

headline: New Hampshire and Oklahoma are the latest states to open vaccinations to outside residents.
abstract: The moves come as President Biden pushed up the deadline to make all adults eligible for a vaccine and as the pace of inoculations is accelerating in the country.
lead_paragraph: New Hampshire and Oklahoma announced plans this week to open up vaccine eligibility to outside residents as supply grows and more states expand eligibility.

headline: Black Army Officer Pepper-Sprayed in Traffic Stop Accuses Officers of Assault
abstract: Second Lt. Caron Nazario was in uniform when two Windsor, Va., police officers ordered him to stop his car, pointed their weapons at him and doused him with pepper spray.
lead_paragraph: Caron Nazario, a lieutenant in the U.S. Army Medical Corps, was driving to Petersburg, Va., from a drill weekend the night of Dec. 5 when he saw police lights flashing behind him.

headline: 2 Salt Lake County Deputies Shot Outside Sheriff’s Office, Officials Say
abstract: The gunman was dead, Sheriff Rosie Rivera said, adding that the shooting happened after “some type of altercation.”
lead_paragraph: Two deputies were wounded — one shot in an eye and the other in the face — after “some type of altercation” outside the Salt Lake County Sheriff’s Office, the sheriff said.

headline: Video Shows Police Pepper-Spraying Black Army Medic at Traffic Stop
abstract: Caron Nazario, an Army lieutenant, was driving through Windsor, Va., on Dec. 5, 2020, when two officers drew guns and doused him with pepper spray, according to a lawsuit filed this month.
lead_paragraph: Caron Nazario, an Army lieutenant, was driving through Windsor, Va., on Dec. 5, 2020, when two officers drew guns and doused him with pepper spray, according to a lawsuit filed this month.

headline: John Topping, 77, Dies; Early Advocate for Climate Action
abstract: A former official of the Environmental Protection Agency, he was a Republican activist on global warming when it was an issue with bipartisan support
lead_paragraph: John Topping, whose work to warn the world of the risks of climate change stretched back to the 1980s, and who helped spur the international effort to limit warming, died on March 9 at a hospital in Bethesda, Md. He was 77.

headline: After Snatching One Crown, Mrs. World Gives Up Her Own
abstract: Last year’s winner of a pageant for married women grabbed a crown from the 2021 Mrs. Sri Lanka winner, who she claimed was divorced, in violation of pageant rules.
lead_paragraph: Last year’s winner of Mrs. World, a beauty pageant for married women, said she would return her crown after she snatched one off the head of the 2021 winner of Mrs. Sri Lanka World, claiming that she was divorced — a violation of pageant rules.

headline: His Fence Says ‘Black Lives Matter.’ His City Says Paint Over It.
abstract: West St. Paul, Minn., says the nearly 75-foot message violates multiple portions of city code. The conflict is brewing as the Twin Cities region uneasily awaits a verdict in the Derek Chauvin trial.
lead_paragraph: The colorful mural, adorned with hearts, a portrait of a local activist and the words “Black Lives Matter,” stands out at a busy intersection in West St. Paul, a community nestled against the Twin Cities. It is a cherished symbol for many Black residents, a site of reflection and pride.

headline: Merger Mania
abstract: Dick Shlakman and Will Nediger join forces in a friendly takeover.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This is a really neat, busy grid by a couple of wags: Will Nediger, a familiar name, constructs professionally, and Dick Shlakman, who had a couple of puzzles some years ago (including a Sunday), is a retired lawyer and corporate executive. Mr. Shlakman is somewhat the senior of the two (by five decades, give or take) and came up with the business-y theme, probably from all those years of watching every company in our frenetic capitalist society try to beat or join every other company. Perhaps, then, Mr. Nediger is to blame for the cascade of interesting fill, some of which I incorrectly attributed to the theme. All in all, a good challenge that deals with the acquisitive and rewards the inquisitive (as always, forgive me).

headline: A Hole in One Pushes Corey Conners Up the Masters Leaderboard
abstract: The shot by the Canadian golfer was the sixth hole in one on No. 6 in tournament history.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The old man working near No. 2 knew. He had to have known, because everyone knew.

headline: Mother in Custody After 3 Children Are Found Dead, Police Say
abstract: The children, who appeared to be under 5 years old, were found on Saturday morning in a Los Angeles apartment, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A mother was taken into custody in California on Saturday after her three children were found dead in a Los Angeles apartment, the authorities said.

headline: Alex Rodriguez Near Deal to Purchase the Minnesota Timberwolves
abstract: Rodriguez and Marc Lore, an e-commerce billionaire, intend to keep the team in Minnesota, the current owner said.
lead_paragraph: Alex Rodriguez, the former Yankees star and three-time American League most valuable player, and Marc Lore, an e-commerce billionaire who is close to Rodriguez, signed a letter of intent on Saturday to purchase the N.B.A.’s Minnesota Timberwolves and the W.N.B.A.’s Minnesota Lynx, parties on both sides of the deal announced.

headline: Maryland Passes Sweeping Police Reform Legislation
abstract: The measures, enacted over the objections of Gov. Larry Hogan, placed the state at the forefront of a national debate over police brutality and officers’ excessive use of force.
lead_paragraph: Maryland lawmakers voted on Saturday to limit police officers’ use of force, restrict the use of no-knock warrants and repeal the nation’s first Bill of Rights for law enforcement, taking sweeping action to address police violence after nationwide demonstrations following the death of George Floyd.

headline: Hideki Matsuyama Charges Into the Lead at the Masters
abstract: After a 78-minute rain delay, the golf course was far more forgiving with significantly slower greens, and Matsuyama will head into Sunday’s final round with a four-stroke lead.
lead_paragraph: [Follow live coverage of the 2021 Masters final round.]

headline: Chloé Zhao Becomes Second Woman to Win Top Directors Guild Award
abstract: The “Nomadland” filmmaker is  the first woman of color to take the feature-film directing prize. She’s now the prohibitive front-runner for the Oscar.
lead_paragraph: The Directors Guild of America made history Saturday night, giving the group’s top prize for feature-film directing to Chloé Zhao (“Nomadland”), the first woman of color to receive the award and only the second woman ever to win in the category, after Kathryn Bigelow (“The Hurt Locker”).

headline: Take a Flying Leap, but Bring Your Paper Parachute
abstract: With a little ingenuity, your sheet of newsprint can float safely to the ground.
lead_paragraph: From Leonardo da Vinci’s pyramid design in the 15th century to the  supersonic version that helped land the Perseverance rover safely on Mars, the parachute, a device that catches air to control an object’s speed, has played an essential role in land, air, water and space travel. For all of the technology and resources that go into launching a spacecraft out of Earth’s atmosphere, it is the simple parachute that is key to safely landing it. A parachute’s canopy creates drag or air resistance, which means that the air below is pushed up against the underside of the canopy and slows its rate of descent.

headline: Corrections: April 11, 2021
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, April 11, 2021.
lead_paragraph: An article this weekend on Page 7 about the impact of the pandemic on food pantries misstates the role of the National Guard in helping the Rev. Emaeyak Ekanem run a food pantry in the Bronx. Last year, the National Guard helped Mr. Ekanem set up his pantry for increased demand. It did not provide Mr. Ekanem with training before the pandemic, as he was never part of the National Guard.

headline: Quotation of the Day: For This Surge, Whitmer Takes Hands-Off Tack
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, April 11, 2021.
lead_paragraph: “Policy change alone won’t change the tide. We need everyone to step up and to take personal responsibility here.”

headline: Schedule an Appointment With Those Clothes You Haven’t Worn in a Year
abstract: Is it possible that a sense of style is one more thing we lost during  the pandemic? Here’s why dressing to be seen in public seems so much harder now.
lead_paragraph: Get-togethers are being planned without Zoom links. Restaurant diners are venturing back inside. As the vaccine rollout continues to gain speed, more companies are reopening their offices. We’re officially heading into new times. From a wardrobe perspective, these developments have generally meant one thing: putting on non-stretchy pants again.

headline: Review Your Social Media Etiquette
abstract: Despite your best efforts, you may cause someone pain with that Tweet or Facebook post. Here’s a refresher on social media best practices, along with advice for some pandemic-only dilemmas.
lead_paragraph: In an ideal world, your followers would think every photo, video or thought you post on social media is like a little gift to them. In reality, it’s hard to predict how posts on Instagram, Facebook and other social media will land, especially during the pandemic. After so much loss and isolation over the past year, people are on edge. That vaccine selfie may feel joyous and hopeful to you, but it could be a digital slap in the face to someone who hasn’t received a vaccine shot or who has suffered a grave loss.

headline: Don’t Take Your Head Out of the Clouds!
abstract: Far from a waste of time, daydreaming might be one of the best things you can do with your free time.
lead_paragraph: Like many people, Namita Kulkarni has felt trapped during the pandemic. When this travel blogger’s typically intrepid life suddenly became stuck in place, she sought her next adventure in her imagination.

headline: The Nets Could Have Had It All With Dr. J
abstract: As great as today’s Nets look with their starry threesome, they could have dominated the N.B.A. much, much sooner — in the 1970s, behind Julius Erving.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Loughery and Julius Erving share a city, Atlanta, a golf club and an emotional connection to a basketball allegory told inharmoniously in three distinct parts — what was, what might have been and what now has become.

headline: He Sought Refuge in Online Poker: ‘This Is Never About the Cards’
abstract: The author is not good at the game. But games played online while meeting on a video call with strangers provided connection at the right time.
lead_paragraph: One of my closest friends is Myki Bajaj, a 30-year-old film and television producer in Los Angeles. We see each other every week, and we usually speak multiple times. Our conversations span from the mundane — sports and culture and the like — to more serious topics, like family and being brown in America. We mull traveling together and frequently talk about projects on which to collaborate.

headline: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Reacts to the Derek Chauvin Trial
abstract: In an episode hosted by Carey Mulligan, “S.N.L.” looked at the American justice system through the lens of a fictional midday news program.
lead_paragraph: After two weeks of testimony, the murder trial of Derek Chauvin, the former officer charged in the death of George Floyd, has gripped viewers — including the hosts of a fictional news program on “Saturday Night Live,” who drew very different conclusions from what they’d seen.

headline: That’s So Cringe!
abstract: Why is everyone suddenly so embarrassed for everyone else?
lead_paragraph: Well, that was awkward. A few weeks ago, a relationship guru named Derrick Jaxn attracted millions of views with an Instagram video — now deleted — detailing numerous relationships with women other than his wife. “All of it,” he said in the video, “falls under the umbrella of inappropriate, cheating, affairs, stepping out.” Meanwhile, his wife, Da’Naia Jackson, sat beside him in support.

headline: ‘My Friends and I Knew Every Neighbor, and They Knew Us’
abstract: On the old block, another Thursday at the bodega and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: The Traveling Work Diary of a Master Distiller
abstract: Marianne Eaves has traded the distillery life for travels with her partner’s circus, connecting to clients in the spirits business from all over the globe.
lead_paragraph: Marianne Eaves, a whiskey expert and entrepreneur, is all about “the journey.” She calls Eaves Blind, her new subscription-based blind-tasting kit, a “yearlong journey through eight different bourbons.” And she says the key to a good bourbon blend is not just its warm finish, but the journey through different flavor profiles that leads you there.

headline: My Family’s Global Vaccine Journey
abstract: We were spread across three continents, at the mercy of vaccine geopolitics. Which of us would be inoculated last?
lead_paragraph: In early February, my sister posted a video in our family’s WhatsApp group.

headline: ‘Tell Us if He’s Dead’: Abductions and Torture Rattle Uganda
abstract: Hundreds have been detained, many brutalized, after a bloody, contested election. The government of Yoweri Museveni appears intent on breaking the back of the opposition.
lead_paragraph: KAMPALA, Uganda — Armed men in white minivans without license plates picked up people off the streets or from their homes.

headline: ‘Everything Is Worth Freedom’: Uganda’s Opposition Leader Faces the Future
abstract: Bobi Wine, the pop star who became a presidential candidate, considers rebuilding his anti-government movement after a violent election season that left many aides and supporters imprisoned.
lead_paragraph: KAMPALA, Uganda — Bobi Wine’s eyes were bloodshot from little sleep. When he spoke, his thoughts trailed off, and his sentences sometimes lacked the precision and eloquence he employed while running for president. At times, he forgot to sip his coffee, even after bringing the mug to his lips.

headline: Conservative Ex-Banker Headed to Victory in Presidential Election in Ecuador
abstract: Guillermo Lasso was ahead of Andrés Arauz late Sunday night in an election that saw the emergence of the country’s long marginalized Indigenous movement as a key driver of the political conversation.
lead_paragraph: QUITO, Ecuador — Guillermo Lasso, a 66-year-old conservative former banker, was set to win Ecuador’s presidential election and beat out Andrés Arauz, a 36-year-old leftist handpicked by former President Rafael Correa.

lead_paragraph: Good morning. Here are the top stories in business and tech to know for the week ahead. — Charlotte Cowles

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | April 12, 2021
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.

headline: In Peru’s Presidential Election, the Most Popular Choice Is No One
abstract: Peruvians head to the polls at a moment that many are calling one of the lowest points in the country’s young democracy, and many plan to cast empty ballots.
lead_paragraph: LIMA, Peru — Vicenta Escobar, 62, sells fruit from a stand on the streets in Peru’s capital, Lima. In every presidential election over the last four decades, she has chosen a candidate she believed in, in the hope that he or she would deliver change.

headline: ‘Younger’ Departs a Covid-Free New York, a Fantasy to the End
abstract: The show’s final season was delayed by the pandemic and shot on the streets of a still-recovering New York, but its enchanting vision of the city remains intact.
lead_paragraph: “Younger” has always been escapism at its fantastical best: A New York of dazzling Manhattan skyscrapers and tastefully grungy Brooklyn lofts. A 40-ish divorced woman battling workplace ageism by passing as a 20-something, with enticing romantic possibilities in each age group. A publishing industry where even an assistant can afford designer threads she doesn’t need to wear twice.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘The Ghost Writer’
abstract: Philip Roth was his own favorite subject. What’s left for a biographer?
lead_paragraph: The author Philip Roth, who died in 2018, was not sure whether he wanted to be the subject of a biography. In the end, he decided that he wanted to be known and understood.

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $440,000
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: Breonna Taylor Show Puts Art Museums on a Faster Track
abstract: Assembled in a mere four months, pivoting off an important national event, the Speed Museum offers a new, relevant model for aging institutions.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — People talk a lot about getting back to pre-Covid normal. But our traditional art museums can forget about that. After a year of intense racial justice reckoning, a paralyzing pandemic and crippling economic shortfalls, aging hidebound institutions are scrambling just to stay afloat. And the only way for them to do so is to change. Strategies for forward motion are needed. One is in play here at the Speed Art Museum, in the form of a quietly passionate show called “Promise, Witness, Remembrance,” which might, with profit, be studied by other institutions in survivalist mode.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Yewande Komolafe has a fine recipe for kunun gyada, a warmly spiced West African porridge of rice and peanuts that’s also a versatile meal.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Yewande Komolafe has a fine new recipe for kunun gyada (above) this week, a warmly spiced West African porridge of rice and peanuts that, she pointed out in her article about the dish, is an excellent addition to iftar, the daily breaking of the Ramadan fast that begins next week and runs for a month.

headline: Benita Raphan, Maker of Lyrical Short Films, Is Dead at 58
abstract: Her dreamlike “genius” films about figures like Emily Dickinson and Buckminster Fuller hovered between documentary and experimental cinema.
lead_paragraph: Benita Raphan made short experimental films about eccentric and unusual minds — like John Nash, the mathematician; Buckminster Fuller, the utopian architect; and Edwin Land, who invented Polaroid film. Her “genius” films, as they were known, are dreamlike, lyrical and suggestive. Not quite biography, they hover between documentary and experimental filmmaking. Ms. Raphan described herself as a cinematic diarist and an experimental biographer.

headline: Chinese official acknowledges low effectiveness of the country’s Covid vaccines.
abstract: A senior Chinese official said that the country’s vaccines may need to be administered in greater doses or in concert with other shots because of their low overall effectiveness.
lead_paragraph: A senior Chinese official said that the country’s vaccines may need to be administered in greater doses or in concert with other shots because of their low overall effectiveness.

headline: Drained by a Year of Covid, Many Mayors Head for the Exit
abstract: Local officials nationwide are announcing plans to step back from elected office. Many offer the same explanation: Covid burnout.
lead_paragraph: NEWBURYPORT, Mass. — Donna Holaday is the kind of mayor who does not say no to an invitation.

headline: Blackout Hits Iran Nuclear Site in What Appears to Be Israeli Sabotage
abstract: The power failure was described by Iran as “nuclear terrorism” as talks were underway in Vienna to restore the 2015 nuclear deal.
lead_paragraph: A power failure that appeared to have been caused by a deliberately planned explosion struck Iran’s Natanz uranium enrichment site on Sunday, in what Iranian officials called an act of sabotage that they suggested had been carried out by Israel.

headline: Need New Skills? How About a Hug? The Women’s Shed Welcomes You.
abstract: In Australia, men’s sheds became a global model for helping “old boys” continue living meaningful lives. Now, women are starting their own.
lead_paragraph: DAVOREN PARK, Australia — No one really knows when backyard sheds became meaningful to men, as a retreat and a place to tinker. But in the late 1990s, Australia made them communal. Hundreds of men’s sheds, as they came to be known, popped up across the country — where retirees or the out of work could stave off loneliness and depression by working on creative projects, gaining new skills and socializing.

headline: After Threats to Turn It Into a Toilet, a Confederate Monument Is Recovered
abstract: A stone chair dedicated to Jefferson Davis has been returned to the United Daughters of the Confederacy after a group calling itself White Lies Matter claimed to have stolen it.
lead_paragraph: As ransom demands go, this one was a bit different.

headline: More Bloodshed in Myanmar as Crackdown on Coup Protests Continues
abstract: The death toll has passed 700, with more than 80 killed on Friday in one city alone, a rights group said.
lead_paragraph: The Myanmar military’s bloody crackdown on the nationwide resistance to its rule showed no sign of easing on Sunday, with a human rights group reporting that the death toll across the country had passed 700.

headline: How to Help Your Adolescent Think About the Last Year
abstract: Hint: It’s not a “lost year.” Also, the screen time with friends? It’s good for their mental health.
lead_paragraph: They’re calling it a “lost year.”

headline: U.S. secretary of state calls for more thorough investigation of Covid origins in China.
abstract: “We need to get to the bottom of this,” Antony J. Blinken said of the origins of Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken on Sunday criticized the Chinese government for a lack of transparency during the pandemic, particularly during “the early stages of Covid,” and he called for a more thorough investigation of the origins of the coronavirus.

headline: 2 Korean Battery Makers Settle Dispute That Threatened Biden’s Green Agenda
abstract: The settlement between LG Energy Solution and SK Innovation ensures that a battery plant in Georgia will go forward without hampering electric vehicle production.
lead_paragraph: Two South Korean manufacturers of electric vehicle batteries that are building plants in the United States said on Sunday that they had reached a $1.8 billion settlement in a trade secrets dispute that threatened the domestic battery supply and, with it, the Biden administration’s green agenda.

headline: Here’s how to watch the Masters.
abstract: Coverage is split across a number of different networks and platforms. Here’s a guide to streaming the final round.
lead_paragraph: Coverage of the Masters Tournament is split across a number of television networks, streaming platforms and websites, making it confusing to understand how to watch. The good news is that there are a number of viewing options, some of them free, for golf fans.

headline: Storms Cause Tornadoes and Softball-Size Hail in the South
abstract: Powerful storms moved through the South late Friday into Saturday, killing two people in Louisiana, bringing hail the size of softballs and baseballs to parts of Alabama, and leaving damage in the Florida Panhandle.
lead_paragraph: Powerful storms moved through the South late Friday into Saturday, killing two people in Louisiana, bringing hail the size of softballs and baseballs to parts of Alabama, and leaving damage in the Florida Panhandle.

headline: N.R.A. Chief Takes the Stand, With Cracks in His Armor
abstract: Wayne LaPierre has led the National Rifle Association for 30 years, but his implacable image looked threadbare in bankruptcy court.
lead_paragraph: For three decades, Wayne LaPierre has been the implacable face of the gun lobby, a scourge of the left who argued that giving ground on gun control was akin to giving up on America. So it was remarkable to see the shambolic turn his tenure atop the National Rifle Association has taken showcased last week in federal bankruptcy court in Dallas.

headline: Has Texas achieved herd immunity? “There is no way on God’s green earth,” an expert says.
abstract: When asked why his state wasn’t seeing higher reported cases after removing restrictions, the Texas governor speculated that the population had reached herd immunity.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas may have been overly optimistic on Sunday when he said on Fox News that his state could be “very close” to herd immunity — the point where so much of the population is immune to Covid-19, either from being vaccinated or previously infected, that the virus can no longer spread.

headline: For a second day, Billy Horschel took off his socks and shoes at No. 13.
abstract: Billy Horschel just made it through No. 13 without slipping down a slope.
lead_paragraph: Billy Horschel just made it through No. 13 without slipping down a slope.

headline: Howard Weitzman, Defense Lawyer for the Famous, Dies at 81
abstract: A master practitioner of the courthouse-steps news conference, he often made his case in the court of public opinion. He also made lawsuits disappear.
lead_paragraph: Howard Weitzman, an entertainment lawyer whose client list bristled with the names of some of the nation’s most famous, and infamous, celebrities — including Michael Jackson, Justin Bieber and, for two days, O.J. Simpson — died on Wednesday  at his home in the Pacific Palisades section of Los Angeles. He was 81.

headline: Del Posto, the Lauded Italian Restaurant, Will Permanently Close
abstract: Its executive chef, Melissa J. Rodriguez, has purchased the restaurant with a group of investors, with plans to open a similarly ambitious Italian restaurant.
lead_paragraph: Del Posto, the elegant Italian restaurant in Manhattan that received a rare four-star review from The New York Times in 2010, will permanently close following its sale, said Jeff Katz, the restaurant’s longtime general manager.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Russia’s hidden coronavirus toll.
lead_paragraph: At least 300,000 more people died last year during the coronavirus pandemic than were reported in Russia’s most widely cited official statistics.

headline: ‘Nomadland’ Wins Big at Diverse BAFTAs
abstract: Four awards went to Chloé Zhao’s tale of itinerant Americans, living in vans and rolling through gorgeous landscapes, seeking temporary jobs to eke out an existence.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — “Nomadland,” Chloé Zhao’s film about a woman forced to join the rising numbers of Americans living out of vans as they search for work, was the big winner at the EE British Academy Film Awards in London on Sunday.

headline: Biden’s Infrastructure Push Spurs a Flurry of Lobbying in Congress
abstract: Lawmakers in both parties are lining up to get their pet projects and policy priorities included in the expansive package.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Members of Congress have begun a frenzy of lobbying to ensure that their pet projects and policy priorities are included in President Biden’s $2 trillion infrastructure and jobs plan, eager to shape what could be one of the most substantial public works investments in a generation.

headline: The Telling of DMX’s Life Story
abstract: A conversation about the intense potency of the rapper’s music and religious fervor, and what it was like to interview him.
lead_paragraph: At the end of the 1990s, there was no rapper more popular than DMX, who rode a series of energized and earnest hits to the top of the Billboard album chart with each of his first five albums.

headline: As the Finish Line Gets Closer, New York’s Mayoral Race Heats Up
abstract: With the primary weeks away, candidates are sharpening their attacks, ramping up in-person events and preparing to spend the millions of dollars that they have stockpiled.
lead_paragraph: It was opening day for Coney Island’s famed amusement parks, long shuttered during the pandemic, and Andrew Yang — the 2020 presidential candidate who has shifted his personality-driven campaign to the New York City mayoral race — was in his element.

headline: ‘Like the Tiger King Got Elected Tax Collector’: Inside the Case That Ensnared Matt Gaetz
abstract: Joel Greenberg, a onetime local official in Florida, is accused of an array of crimes, including bribery, stalking and corruption.
lead_paragraph: LAKE MARY, Fla. — Long before the F.B.I. began to scrutinize a tax collector in Florida named Joel Greenberg — and long before his trail led them to Representative Matt Gaetz — he amassed an outlandish record in the mundane local public office he had turned into a personal fief of power.

headline: Purr-son Who Loves Her Pets
abstract: Ella Dershowitz and Aimee Lucido have a perfect pitch for spring.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Ella Dershowitz made her New York Times Crossword debut in the cold winter month of January with her friend and constructing partner, Aimee Lucido.

headline: Why We’re Freaking Out About Substack
abstract: A company that makes it easy to charge for newsletters has captivated an anxious industry because it embodies larger forces and contradictions.
lead_paragraph: Danny Lavery had just agreed to a two-year, $430,000 contract with the newsletter platform Substack when I met him for coffee last week in Brooklyn, and he was deciding what to do with the money.

headline: You Can Hear the Whistle Blow a Hundred Miles
abstract: Just the possibility of riding trains again has me humming folk songs.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Walter Mondale had no chance of beating Ronald Reagan in 1984, and everyone knew it. I went to a Mondale rally at Philadelphia’s Love Park anyway. The musical guests that day included Stephen Stills; Peter, Paul and Mary; and the immortal B.B. King, but the song I’ve carried with me ever afterward is not “Teach Your Children” or “The Thrill Is Gone.” It’s “500 Miles.”

headline: Canadian Basketball Hopes a New Floor Will Raise Its Ceiling
abstract: Canada hasn’t made the Olympics in men’s basketball in two decades, but its sports officials hope a memento from the Toronto Raptors’ championship run will bring good luck.
lead_paragraph: What worked for Wayne Gretzky and Canadian hockey at the 2002 Winter Olympics never quite fit the karmic ambitions of Canadian basketball officials nearly two decades later.

headline: You’ve Heard About Gerrymandering. What Happens When It Involves Prisons?
abstract: Counting people where they’re imprisoned takes political power away from cities and transfers it to rural areas.
lead_paragraph: Where do you live? For most people, that’s an easy question to answer when the census comes around. It’s much harder for those locked up in a state or federal prison, often hundreds or even thousands of miles from the place they last called home.

headline: Online Schools Are Here to Stay, Even After the Pandemic
abstract: Some families have come to prefer stand-alone virtual schools and districts are rushing to accommodate them — though questions about remote learning persist.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: A Clash of Wills Keeps a Leonardo Masterpiece Hidden
abstract: The Louvre inspected the “Salvator Mundi” and certified it as the work of Leonardo da Vinci. But it kept those findings secret after a squabble with the painting’s owners.
lead_paragraph: French curators had worked for a decade to prepare a major exhibition marking the 500th anniversary of the death of Leonardo da Vinci. When it opened, though, the most talked-about painting they had planned to show — “Salvator Mundi,” the most expensive work ever sold at auction — was nowhere to be seen.

headline: Tucker Carlson and White Replacement
abstract: This racist theory is rooted in white supremacist panic.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, Fox News host Tucker Carlson caused an uproar by promoting the racist, anti-Semitic, patriarchal and conspiratorial “white replacement theory.” Also known as the “great replacement theory,” it stands on the premise that nonwhite immigrants are being imported (sometimes the Jewish community is accused of orchestrating this) to replace white people and white voters. The theory is also an inherent chastisement of white women for having a lower birthrate than nonwhite women.

headline: Hideki Matsuyama Wins the Masters With a Groundbreaking Performance
abstract: Matsuyama led the final round from start to finish at Augusta National, becoming the first Asian-born man to win the Masters.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Hideki Matsuyama’s first swing in the final round of the 85th Masters was an unsightly banana-shaped slice that would have looked familiar on the nerve-racking first tee of any golf course in the world.

headline: Fed Chief Says U.S. Economy Is at an ‘Inflection Point’ as Risks Remain
abstract: “It’s going to be smart if people can continue to socially distance and wear masks,” Jerome Powell said on “60 Minutes.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The economy is at an “inflection point” and on the cusp of growing more quickly, the Federal Reserve chair, Jerome H. Powell, said in an interview broadcast on Sunday night. But he warned that the crisis was not yet over.

headline: High Finishes at the Masters Are Becoming Familiar to First-Year Players
abstract: Will Zalatoris, who finished second at the Masters, one stroke behind the winner, is only the latest first-year player to contend for a green jacket.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — As an undergraduate at Wake Forest, Will Zalatoris received an invitation familiar to members of the golf team: Come play at Augusta National Golf Club. When he did in 2017, he recalled recently, he stood on the bridge straddling Rae’s Creek and gazed around Amen Corner.

abstract: China’s $2.8 billion antitrust penalty against Alibaba far exceeds its previous fines for anticompetitive business practices.
lead_paragraph: Two days after Chinese regulators fined the e-commerce giant Alibaba $2.8 billion for placing illegal restrictions on the vendors on its shopping sites, the company said it would lower the fees it charges such merchants and invest in new services for them.

abstract: A snapshot of Europe’s lockdowns.

headline: It Doesn’t Take Genius to Understand Basketball. But It Helps.
abstract: For his book, “How to Watch Basketball Like a Genius,” Nick Greene spoke to the best in ballet, magic and astrophysics for a fresh perspective on the sport.
lead_paragraph: When James Naismith invented the concept of basketball, the object of which was to throw a ball into peach baskets, the early games had too much roughhousing for his liking. So he scribbled down 13 rules. Among them: The ball may be batted — yes, batted — in any direction, just not with your fist. A player cannot run with the ball. No shouldering, tripping or holding.

headline: It’s Time to Rethink the Olympics
abstract: Displacements, human rights violations, health concerns and overspending have dogged the Games in recent years. The Olympic mission is a mess in need of long-term fixing.
lead_paragraph: The time has come to press pause and reimagine the Olympics. It might even be time, I’ve come to believe, for the entire endeavor to close down for good.

headline: M.L.B. Pushes Incentives to Encourage Players to Get Vaccine
abstract: Teams can have numerous restrictions lifted when they are 85 percent vaccinated. A few teams have reached that total so far.
lead_paragraph: A few days after going to a grocery store over the winter, Milwaukee Brewers reliever Brent Suter woke up feeling off. As the day went on, he grew tired and achy, and his back stiffened. He tested positive for the coronavirus the next day, and so did his wife soon after. Suter, 31, said his lungs were inflamed, and he lost his sense of smell and taste for two weeks. He paused his off-season throwing.

headline: Officer Who Pepper-Sprayed a Black Army Officer Is Fired
abstract: Joe Gutierrez, who is accused of using excessive force during a traffic stop in Windsor, Va., has been dismissed, the town said.
lead_paragraph: A police officer in Virginia who confronted a uniformed Black Army lieutenant at gunpoint and doused him with pepper spray during a traffic stop, an exchange captured on video, has been fired, officials said on Sunday.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Our Towns’ and ‘Beethoven in Beijing’
abstract: A documentary on HBO looks at small towns across America. And PBS’s “Great Performances” revisits a pivotal 1973 classical music tour.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, April 12-18. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Who Will ‘Vax Daddy’ Endorse? 5 Takeaways From N.Y.C. Mayor’s Race.
abstract: Candidates vied for the backing of the influential teachers’ union and other players, and one contender made a journey to Minneapolis.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s mayoral contest is indeed beginning to pick up steam.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘How Teachers Are Exploring the Derek Chauvin Trial With Students’
abstract: In this lesson, students will learn how schools across the country are addressing the trial of the former police officer charged with the murder of George Floyd.
lead_paragraph: Teachers: Have you talked about the Derek Chauvin trial in your classroom already? How are you incorporating the trial and upcoming verdict into your curriculum, if at all? What are you weighing as you decide if, when and how to address it? Let us know us know what lessons and activities you have used.

headline: Don’t Mistake Silent Endurance for Resilience
abstract: In powering through discomfort, I became inured to it — until I figured out how to acknowledge what I actually wanted.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of a series on resilience in troubled times — what we can learn about it from history and personal experiences.

headline: Partners, Now Friends
abstract: Two artists who've stayed close, even as the terms of their relationship have evolved.
lead_paragraph: Jessica Rankin: We met in 2000 in a bar, and got married in 2008. From the start, we were in sync in terms of the way we look at art: the way we think about it and the way it weaves itself through our lives. It’s a conversation that started and never really stopped. When you spend time watching someone work, you get a sense of what they’re striving for, and you trust that they feel that in your work, too. When relationships change, as ours did in 2014 when we separated, you inevitably have to take some space, but it didn’t last that long for us. Julie is one of the people I trust most to talk about my work with, so it was impossible to maintain any kind of distance.

headline: Work Friends
abstract: Jared Blake: About four years ago, I’d gotten some gray Eames shell chairs on eBay — and then my dad bought me a single yellow one, but I didn’t want it, so I put it on Craigslist and Ed came to buy it. When we met, he was wearing something I would wear: a fitted Mets cap with a blue oxford, black pants and checkered Vans, the ultimate business-casual, casual-business outfit. It was like a hidden language. He told me he was stockpiling furniture to open a brick-and-mortar store. And I’d been thinking about dealing furniture online.
lead_paragraph: Jared Blake: About four years ago, I’d gotten some gray Eames shell chairs on eBay — and then my dad bought me a single yellow one, but I didn’t want it, so I put it on Craigslist and Ed came to buy it. headline: The Language of Friends
abstract: A group of Deaf and hearing creatives in Berlin, brought together by the artist Christine Sun Kim, sign, type, dance and collaborate — and serve as a reminder that every one of us is a vessel for communication.
lead_paragraph: A group of Deaf and hearing creatives in Berlin, brought together by the artist Christine Sun Kim, sign, type, dance and collaborate — and serve as a reminder that every one of us is a vessel for communication.

headline: Best Friends
abstract: Chloë Sevigny: We first met in the backyard of the actor Michael Rapaport’s apartment on 21st Street in New York in 1997. I was in between boyfriends and places, and living in the guest room for free, which was very generous of him. And Natasha had been staying in his apartment in Los Angeles. I think Mike match-made us: “You’re my girls. I want you to meet each other, yada yada.”
lead_paragraph: Chloë Sevigny: We first met in the backyard of the actor Michael Rapaport’s apartment on 21st Street in New York in 1997. I was in between boyfriends and places, and living in the guest room for free, which was very generous of him. And Natasha had been staying in his apartment in Los Angeles. I think Mike match-made us: “You’re my girls. I want you to meet each other, yada yada.”

headline: How F.D.R.’s Heir Is Changing the Country
abstract: It’s all about jobs and infrastructure, and President Biden is off to a good start.
lead_paragraph: “History doesn’t repeat itself, but it sometimes rhymes,” Mark Twain (supposedly) said. If so, Franklin Delano Roosevelt and Joseph Robinette Biden Jr. could be a couplet. With a few breaks and the skillful execution of what seems to be a smart legislative strategy, President Biden is poised to match F.D.R.’s stunning debut in office.

headline: Friends Who Share a Language
abstract: Christine Sun Kim: Growing up, I struggled to communicate and develop friendships with hearing peers, but then I went to college and became more comfortable with my signing and myself. Then I went to grad school, and my A.S.L. bubble popped. I learned I had a skill with strangers. I realized that small talk with hearing strangers was an opportunity for them to see me. And if I saw that they weren’t interested in me, I knew they weren’t worth my time, and it didn’t hurt my feelings — it was the filter I needed. Now when my friends and I are together, we communicate using a combination of American Sign Language (A.S.L.), German Sign Language (D.G.S.), international signs and [the messaging app] Cardzilla.
lead_paragraph: Christine Sun Kim: Growing up, I struggled to communicate and develop friendships with hearing peers, but then I went to college and became more comfortable with my signing and myself. Then I went to grad school, and my A.S.L. bubble popped. I learned I had a skill with strangers. I realized that small talk with hearing strangers was an opportunity for them to see me.
