lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. on Tuesday sent a memo to all 32 teams effectively mandating that support personnel including coaches and trainers be vaccinated against Covid-19, with an exception made for staff who have a “bona fide medical or religious ground” for not doing so.

headline: Top Bidder for Tribune Newspapers Is an Influential Liberal Donor
abstract: The Swiss billionaire Hansjörg Wyss helped build a sophisticated behind-the-scenes operation that attacked Republicans and promoted Democratic causes.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Long before he emerged as a potential champion of journalism with his bid for Tribune Publishing, the Swiss billionaire Hansjörg Wyss quietly created a sophisticated political operation to advance progressive policy initiatives and the Democrats who support them.

headline: Takeaways from Day 12 of the Derek Chauvin trial.
abstract: An expert testifying for the defense said Mr. Chauvin was justified in pinning George Floyd under his knee. He contradicted numerous experts called by prosecutors, including the police chief of Minneapolis.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in the trial of the former police officer Derek Chauvin, a witness explicitly defended his actions when he knelt on George Floyd for nine and a half minutes.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: What to know about the pause on the Johnson & Johnson vaccine.
lead_paragraph: Federal health agencies in the United States called for a temporary halt in the use of Johnson & Johnson’s Covid-19 vaccine over concerns that the vaccine may be linked to a rare disorder involving blood clots.

headline: Johnson & Johnson, Minnesota, Big Ben: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Twin Cities set overnight curfew for Tuesday as more protests are expected.
abstract: Movement will be restricted in Minneapolis and St. Paul from 10 p.m. to 6 a.m., the third night after the police shot Daunte Wright.
lead_paragraph: The cities of Minneapolis and St. Paul set another overnight curfew on Tuesday as local officials anticipated a third night of protests demanding justice after Daunte Wright, a 20-year-old Black man, was shot by the police on Sunday during a traffic stop.

headline: Mourning Another Fallen Officer, Capitol Police Face Deepening Crisis
abstract: Officer William F. Evans was the second Capitol Police officer to lie in honor in the Rotunda this year, the latest blow to a department reeling after the Jan. 6 attack.
lead_paragraph: For the second time in just over two months, members of the United States Capitol Police slipped on black mourning bands on Tuesday and watched as the flag-draped remains of a fellow officer were hoisted up the steps of the Capitol to lie in honor inside the building he died protecting.

headline: Biden plans to name Robert Santos to lead the Census Bureau, which is racing to complete its 2020 count.
abstract: If confirmed by the Senate, Mr. Santos would be the first person of color to serve as permanent head of the beleaguered agency.
lead_paragraph: President Biden on Tuesday announced plans to nominate statistician Robert L. Santos to serve as director of the Census Bureau, according to a memo from the White House.

headline: China Poses Biggest Threat to U.S., Intelligence Report Says
abstract: The annual assessment does not predict a military confrontation with either Russia or China, but it suggests that intelligence operations, cyberattacks and global drives for influence will intensify.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — China’s effort to expand its growing influence represents one of the largest threats to the United States, according to a major annual intelligence report released on Tuesday, which also warned of the broad national security challenges posed by Moscow and Beijing.

headline: Jeffrey Paley, Journalist, Gallerist and Investor, Dies at 82
abstract: A son of the CBS founder, he wrote for newspapers from Europe, championed young artists in SoHo and became an investor. He died of complications of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Indicted Gaetz Associate Is Said to Be Cooperating With Justice Dept.
abstract: Joel Greenberg, a former elected official in Florida, has been talking to federal investigators since last year about the conduct of Representative Matt Gaetz and others.
lead_paragraph: A former local official in Florida indicted in the Justice Department investigation that is also focused on Representative Matt Gaetz has been providing investigators with information since last year about an array of topics, including Mr. Gaetz’s activities, according to two people briefed on the matter.

headline: You’re Vaccinated. Your Kids Are Not. What Now?
abstract: We asked public health experts to help answer some of your most pressing questions.
lead_paragraph: As more parents get vaccinated ahead of their children, some families are finding themselves with questions that seem to have no clear answers: Is it finally OK to have indoor play dates? Can we take summer vacations, or fly on airplanes? What if my kids are high risk?

headline: Daunte Wright Spent Final Moments Talking With His Mother
abstract: “I just seen and heard the fear in his voice,” she said. Mr. Wright was a young father who loved basketball and, in the tightknit world of Minneapolis, had a connection to George Floyd.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Daunte Wright called his mother. The tremble in his voice told her something was wrong. The police had stopped him, he told her nervously.

headline: Can These Democratic Pollsters Figure Out What Went Wrong?
abstract: Five competing Democratic polling firms put their heads (and their data) together about 2020.
lead_paragraph: Everybody agrees the polls missed the mark in 2020, as they had four years earlier. But nobody’s certain why.

headline: Use-of Force Expert Says Chauvin’s Actions Were Justified
abstract: Barry Brodd, a former police officer and use-of-force expert, testified on Tuesday that Derek Chauvin’s actions during the arrest of George Floyd were justified by Mr. Floyd’s resistance.
lead_paragraph: Barry Brodd, a former police officer and use-of-force expert, testified on Tuesday that Derek Chauvin’s actions during the arrest of George Floyd were justified by Mr. Floyd’s resistance.

headline: Pause in Vaccinations Leads to Canceled Appointments Across States
abstract: Health departments scrambled to postpone vaccine clinics and rebook patients after the one-dose offering from Johnson & Johnson was sidelined.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The student union had been converted into a vaccination center. The doses had arrived on campus. The first appointments were minutes away. Then, at 7:23 a.m. on Tuesday, news of the pause in Johnson & Johnson vaccinations reached Youngstown State University.

headline: After Another Police Shooting, Biden Urges Calm. Activists Want Answers.
abstract: The police shooting of Daunte Wright in Minnesota has renewed questions about what the administration will be able to accomplish on policing.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After President Biden abandoned a campaign promise to establish a police oversight commission during his first 100 days in office, administration officials have provided few details about how far he will go to combat racism in policing.

headline: Some Children With Covid-Related Syndrome Develop Neurological Symptoms
abstract: New research found that half of young patients with the inflammatory condition, MIS-C, in a London hospital experienced confusion, hallucinations and other issues, in addition to physical symptoms.
lead_paragraph: Reports about the mysterious Covid-related inflammatory syndrome that afflicts some children and teenagers have mostly focused on physical symptoms: rash, abdominal pain, red eyes and, most seriously, heart problems like low blood pressure, shock and difficulty pumping.

headline: These Ants Shrink Their Brains for a Chance to Become Queen
abstract: If their bids at motherhood fail, they can then regrow their brains.
lead_paragraph: The Indian jumping ant, Harpegnathos saltator, has many talents. This inch-long arthropod, found in flood plains across India, has a four-inch vertical leap and the ability to take down prey nearly twice its size. If that wasn’t enough, these amazing ants can also adjust the size of their own brains.

headline: We Need a High Wall With a Big Gate on the Southern Border
abstract: Immigration is America’s lifeblood, so we can’t risk losing it.
lead_paragraph: After reading as much as I can about the latest surge in illegal immigration along our southern border, I’m still not clear how much is seasonal, how much is triggered by President Biden’s announcement that he was halting construction of Donald Trump’s border wall and reviewing Trump’s asylum policies, and how much is just the lure of jobs in a rapidly vaccinating United States.

headline: Amazon’s Big Win Over the Little Guy
abstract: Corporate America keeps squeezing the humanity out of the workplace.
lead_paragraph: It is easy to imagine that Amazon executives popped champagne corks over the weekend after quashing the union drive in Bessemer, Ala. After a bruising fight, workers at the warehouse, in a suburb of Birmingham, rejected joining a union by more than a two-to-one ratio, chilling future union organizing efforts at the nation’s second-largest private employer.

headline: Biden to Withdraw All Combat Troops From Afghanistan by Sept. 11
abstract: After years of arguing against an extended military presence in Afghanistan, President Biden is doing things his way, with the deadline for withdrawal set for the 20th anniversary of the terrorist attacks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden will withdraw American combat troops from Afghanistan by Sept. 11, declaring an end to the nation’s longest war and overruling warnings from his military advisers that the departure could prompt a resurgence of the same terrorist threats that sent hundreds of thousands of troops into combat over the past 20 years.

headline: Did Spotlighting a Rare Potential Vaccine Side Effect Put More at Risk?
abstract: Some public health officials fear that the pause on the Johnson & Johnson vaccine may fuel vaccine hesitancy and expose more Americans to a bigger danger: the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: To federal health officials, asking states on Tuesday to suspend use of the Johnson & Johnson coronavirus vaccine until they can investigate six extremely rare but troubling cases of blood clots was an obvious and perhaps unavoidable move.

headline: With Afghan Decision, Biden Seeks to Focus U.S. on New Challenges
abstract: The president’s choice to set a firm date for a full withdrawal reflected a belief that the priorities of 2021 require moving on from policies set in 2001.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s decision to pull all American troops from Afghanistan by Sept. 11 was rooted in his belief that there is no room for continuing 20 years of failed efforts to remake that country, especially at a moment when he wants the United States focused on a transformational economic and social agenda at home and other fast-evolving threats from abroad.

headline: Will Afghanistan Become a Terrorism Safe Haven Once Again?
abstract: Not likely, at least in the short term, intelligence officials assess. But stopping terrorism groups over the long term could be more difficult.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Sept. 11 attacks led American troops into Afghanistan in 2001 for what became a two-decade war. Now President Biden’s decision to withdraw military forces has prompted a central question: Will the threat of terrorism against America re-emerge from Afghanistan?

headline: Make Sense of the News: Johnson & Johnson Vaccine

lead_paragraph: David Leonhardt’s popular morning briefing newsletter, exclusively for NYT Audio.

headline: Hank Aaron’s Name Will Replace a Confederate General’s on an Atlanta School
abstract: Forrest Hill Academy, named for Nathan Bedford Forrest, also an early leader of the Ku Klux Klan, will become Hank Aaron New Beginnings Academy.
lead_paragraph: A public school in Atlanta carrying the name of a Confederate general who was an original grand wizard of the Ku Klux Klan will be renamed for Hank Aaron, the baseball legend who broke racial barriers and the career home run record.

headline: Police Officer Who Shot and Killed Daunte Wright Was Training Others
abstract: Kimberly A. Potter was a 26-year veteran of the force in a Minneapolis suburb and president of a police union.
lead_paragraph: BROOKLYN CENTER, Minn. — Officer Kimberly A. Potter was in the midst of a routine training day on Sunday, demonstrating her decades of policing know-how to less experienced officers in the Brooklyn Center Police Department.

headline: Capitol Police Told to Hold Back on Riot Response on Jan. 6, Report Finds
abstract: Despite being tipped that “Congress itself is the target” on Jan. 6, Capitol Police were ordered not to use their most powerful crowd-control weapons, according to a scathing new watchdog report.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Capitol Police had clearer advance warnings about the Jan. 6 attack than were previously known, including the potential for violence in which “Congress itself is the target.” But officers were instructed by their leaders not to use their most aggressive tactics to hold off the mob, according to a scathing new report by the agency’s internal investigator.

headline: Harris Commemorates Black Maternal Health Week
abstract: As part of the first presidential proclamation for Black Maternal Health Week, Vice President Kamala Harris hosted a round table focused on racial disparities in child care and pregnancy-related deaths.
lead_paragraph: As part of the first presidential proclamation for Black Maternal Health Week, Vice President Kamala Harris hosted a round table focused on racial disparities in child care and pregnancy-related deaths.

headline: In Early Testimony for Defense, Witness Says Chauvin’s Force Was ‘Justified’
abstract: The defense also presented body camera video from a previous arrest of George Floyd, part of its strategy to shift the jurors’ focus to his use of illicit drugs.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — A police officer approached a car with George Floyd in the front seat, and Mr. Floyd started to panic. While officers ordered him to spit out a pill he was trying to swallow, he repeatedly begged them not to shoot him.

headline: Key Findings of the Inspector General’s Report on the Capitol Riot
abstract: Intelligence failures, orders to use less aggressive measures and equipment breakdowns contributed to the Capitol Police’s botched response, a watchdog found.
lead_paragraph: A new report by the Capitol Police’s internal watchdog found that department leaders overlooked key intelligence in the run-up to the riot on Jan. 6, including a warning that “Congress itself is the target,” and barred the force’s riot response unit from using its most powerful crowd-control measures.

headline: Pausing the Johnson & Johnson Vaccine Makes Sense
abstract: There might have been better ways to handle the situation, but officials did what they had to do.
lead_paragraph: This editorial has been updated to reflect news developments.

lead_paragraph: The Muldrow Glacier, on the north side of Denali, is undergoing a rare surge.

lead_paragraph: Republican Party officials in two deeply conservative counties voted to censure Gov. Brian Kemp and two other top party leaders in recent days, a sign that the Georgia governor continues to face grass-roots opposition from loyalists to former President Donald J. Trump, and the possibility of a primary challenge next year.

abstract: A potential deluge of millions of gallons of water from a former phosphate mine had threatened homes south of Tampa.
lead_paragraph: Florida officials on Tuesday announced their intention to permanently shut down a leaking wastewater reservoir south of Tampa that had forced hundreds of residents to evacuate their homes under the threat of a catastrophic collapse.

lead_paragraph: An overdue obituary for the fashion influencer of New York's punk scene, who dressed musicians like Debbie Harry of Blondie and James Chance.

headline: Corrections: April 14, 2021
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, April 14, 2021.
lead_paragraph: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about the causes of India’s most recent wave of coronavirus infections misstated India’s Covid-19 mortality rate. The country recorded 0.04 deaths per 100,000 people for the past seven days as of April 9. The figure did not represent a rate for total deaths since the pandemic began.

headline: Court Vindicates Black Officer Fired for Stopping Colleague’s Chokehold
abstract: Cariol Horne acted to keep a white officer from using what she saw as excessive force. Fifteen years later, a judge said her firing was wrong.
lead_paragraph: It was a cold November day in Buffalo when Officer Cariol Horne responded to a call for a colleague in need of help. What she encountered was a white officer who appeared to be “in a rage” punching a handcuffed Black man in the face repeatedly as other officers stood by.

headline: Hundreds of Companies Unite to Oppose Voting Limits, but Others Abstain
abstract: Amazon, Google, G.M. and Starbucks were among those joining the biggest show of solidarity by businesses over legislation in numerous states.
lead_paragraph: Amazon, BlackRock, Google, Warren Buffett and hundreds of other companies and executives signed on to a new statement released on Wednesday opposing “any discriminatory legislation” that would make it harder for people to vote.

headline: National Endowment for the Humanities Announces New Grants
abstract: The first round of funding for the year totals $24 million and will support 225 projects across the country.
lead_paragraph: The New York Botanical Garden, the Children’s Museum of Indianapolis and the Judd Foundation in Marfa, Texas, are among 225 beneficiaries of new grants from the National Endowment for the Humanities that were announced on Wednesday.

headline: A Ban on Bottle Tossing Disrupts a Tradition in Cycling
abstract: Riders’ water bottles are treasured souvenirs among cycling fans. Cyclists are unhappy with a new rule that outlaws tossing them into the crowd.
lead_paragraph: Alex Howes, an American cyclist on the EF Education-Nippo team, heard a familiar sound from roadside fans at the Itzulia Basque Country race in Spain last week.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: A fresh blow to Europe’s vaccination efforts.
lead_paragraph: Revelations that both the AstraZeneca and Johnson & Johnson coronavirus vaccines may, in extremely rare circumstances, cause blood clots have dealt a fresh blow to Europe’s already beleaguered vaccination push.

headline: 15 Favorite Episodes as the Book Review Podcast Turns 15
abstract: Pamela Paul, the editor of the Book Review, highlights memorable episodes from her eight years hosting the show, including conversations with Robert Caro, Isabel Wilkerson, James McBride and others.
lead_paragraph: This was a near impossible task. Actually, it was an impossible task, as I assigned myself a top 10 list but was unable to stick to it. Instead, going through the eight years of weekly episodes in which I’ve hosted the Book Review’s podcast (my predecessor, Sam Tanenhaus, was the founding host), I came up with what I thought was a strict culling of favorites. That initial list was 35 episodes long.

headline: Injuries Are Raining on the N.B.A.’s Championship Parade
abstract: Pick a big-name N.B.A. star, and he’s probably been injured this season: LeBron, Giannis, LaMelo, A.D., K.D. and, now, Jamal Murray. What’s going on?
lead_paragraph: Three-fourths of the N.B.A.’s regular season will be complete after Wednesday’s play, making this a natural time for you to press your favorite newsletter curator to pick a title favorite.

lead_paragraph: Ghalia al-Asseh had just begun studying chemistry and biotechnology at the Technical University of Denmark when the country’s immigration services summoned her for an interview.

lead_paragraph: Organizers marked 100 days until the start of the Tokyo Olympics on Wednesday with a subdued ceremony amid tougher restrictions and growing questions over the event as Japan endures another surge of coronavirus infections.

headline: Should People Be Required to Show Proof of Vaccination?
abstract: Businesses, schools and politicians are considering “vaccine passports” as a path to reopening the country. Do you think sharing vaccine status should be mandatory to go to school, take a vacation or enter a movie theater?
lead_paragraph: As more and more people across the United States get vaccinated against the coronavirus, you may have seen friends, family and celebrities sharing photos of their vaccine cards to show proof of their vaccinations. But do you think sharing one’s vaccine status should become mandatory to go to school, enter a movie theater, eat in a restaurant or travel?

headline: The Long History of Those Who Fought to Save the Animals
abstract: In “Beloved Beasts,” Michelle Nijhuis tells the stories of the men and women who have fought to rescue endangered animals from extinction.
lead_paragraph: BELOVED BEASTSFighting for Life in an Age of ExtinctionBy Michelle Nijhuis

headline: Why the Anti-Abortion Side Will Lose, Even if It Wins
abstract: Ross Douthat and Michelle Goldberg return to the podcast to debate the future of abortion in America.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court — and its post-Donald Trump conservative majority — is currently deciding whether to take up a case that could be the final blow to Roe v. Wade. Overturning Roe, the 48-year-old decision protecting the right to an abortion in America, would leave abortion regulation up to the states. But some abortion opponents think that’s not far enough and are pushing the movement to change its focus to securing a 14th Amendment declaration of fetal personhood.

headline: Don’t Fear Cryptocurrencies. Manage Them.
abstract: The idea that regulation chills activity in new markets is intuitive, but not always accurate. Sometimes the opposite is true.
lead_paragraph: Since last fall, cryptocurrencies — digital tokens that represent monetary value, stored on completely decentralized networks of public digital ledgers — have boomed. It’s led to a bullish frenzy among those who see them as a generational wealth-creation opportunity or view themselves as the eventual survivors of an inflation-driven collapse of traditional currencies like the U.S. dollar.

headline: I’m in a Police Union That Holds Bad Cops Accountable
abstract: The Ethical Society of Police isn’t afraid to speak out against police misconduct.
lead_paragraph: This week, a veteran officer in Brooklyn Center, Minn., killed an unarmed man, claiming to have mistaken her gun for her Taser. The Ethical Society of Police, a St. Louis group consisting mostly of Black officers, was quick to comment on the shooting, calling out the negligence of the officer.

headline: Show Us Your Pandemic Baby Family Reunions
abstract: The Times wants to see families finally welcoming new babies that they couldn’t see in person during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: An overjoyed grandmother cradling the baby she’s only seen over FaceTime. An uncle crying openly with relief when he finally meets his new nephew. The cluster of sweet young cousins greeting the smallest member of their family for the first time.

headline: A Classic Venetian Dish That Doesn’t Need Improvement
abstract: With some trepidation, Gabrielle Hamilton puts her own spin on risi e bisi — rice and peas.
lead_paragraph: There is a joke going around that divorce lawyers are limbering up for the post-​pandemic onslaught of work headed their way. If you’ve ever had your marriage fall apart, it’s not the funniest joke, especially when there are kids involved. But here’s a really funny one in the opposite direction: The pandemic dissolved all residual rancor and friction between me and my ex-husband as soon as New York City shut down. Our situation created the urgent, nonnegotiable necessity for smooth cooperation: We have two children, and they had to go back and forth between our homes. No one could be harmed in the shuffle.

headline: Nothing Could Make Her Body Stop Itching. Would It Ever End?
abstract: It felt like the itch was coming from somehow under her skin. The cause ended up being even deeper.
lead_paragraph: It was dark by the time the 41-year-old woman was able to start the long drive from her father’s apartment in Washington, D.C., to her home in Westchester County, N.Y. She was eager to get back to her husband and three children. Somewhere after she crossed the border into Maryland, the woman suddenly developed a terrible itch all over her body. She’d been a little itchy for the past couple of weeks but attributed that to dry skin from her now-faded summertime tan. This seemed very different: much stronger, much deeper. And absolutely everywhere, all at the same time.

headline: Why Tucker Carlson Is Obsessed With Kristen Clarke
abstract: She’s a fighter for civil rights. Of course Fox News is trying to smear her.
lead_paragraph: There are few people in the country today who have more experience fighting in the judicial trenches to preserve civil rights than Kristen Clarke, President Biden’s nominee to head the civil rights division of the Department of Justice.

headline: Latin America’s Former Presidents Have Way Too Much Power
abstract: It’s time to take them down from their pedestals.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, voters elected Guillermo Lasso, a former banker and a supporter of free-market policies, as president of Ecuador over Andrés Arauz, a left-wing populist. Some analysts are decrying the end of progressivism, but what we are really seeing is a welcome setback for a strange form of strongman politics: the phenomenon of former presidents seeking to extend their control and influence by choosing and backing their protégés in national elections.

headline: Why Settle for Boring Glassware?
abstract: Stephanie Hall, the founder of Estelle Colored Glass, wants to brighten up your cabinet of coupes and wine glasses.
lead_paragraph: In Stephanie Hall’s youth, afternoons spent treasure hunting with her grandmother in Holly Hill, S.C., often yielded sparkling hauls of vintage glassware in colors like emerald green and amber.

headline: The Marriage Between Republicans and Big Business Is on the Rocks
abstract: But the internal contradictions of “woke capitalism” are a mixed blessing for the Democratic Party.
lead_paragraph: “Woke capitalism” has been a steadily growing phenomenon over the past decade. The muscle of the movement was evident as early as 2015 in Indiana and 2016 in North Carolina, when corporate opposition forced Republicans to back off anti-gay and anti-transgender legislation.

headline: The Triumph of the Celebrity Endorsement
abstract: Shilling stars used to be accused of “selling out.” Now they’re hailed as savvy investors and giving the performances of their careers.
lead_paragraph: When I learned that Catherine Zeta-Jones would be appearing on a website called TalkShopLive to launch a new product line under her Casa Zeta-Jones label, I was not sold. I loved watching Zeta-Jones ooze charisma across a movie screen, in “Chicago,” in “High Fidelity,” even in “America’s Sweethearts.” But recently I had mostly seen her featured in gross clickbait slide shows stuck to the bottoms of articles — the kind with dire headlines like “What Happened to Catherine Zeta-Jones?” — and I wasn’t sure I wanted to know the answer.

headline: These People Should Be Required to Get Vaccinated
abstract: Cases are surging. We need to maximize the number of inoculated frontline workers and students.
lead_paragraph: The next coronavirus surge seems to be underway. Maryland, Michigan, Minnesota and Wisconsin are among the states with rising cases, hospitalizations and intensive care occupancy, and hospitalization rates among younger people are increasing nationally. The causes of this pronounced rush of cases — the spread of a more infectious B.1.1.7 variant and lockdown fatigue — are not going away.

headline: Living In ... West Hartford, Conn.
abstract: This densely developed town abutting Connecticut’s capital city is a ‘little bit of a liberal enclave,’ equidistant from Boston and New York.
lead_paragraph: This densely developed town abutting Connecticut’s capital city is a ‘little bit of a liberal enclave,’ equidistant from Boston and New York.

headline: Democrats Were Lukewarm on Campaign Biden. They Love President Biden.
abstract: Joe Biden never captured the hearts of Democratic voters in the way Barack Obama once did. But now that he is in office, he is drawing nearly universal approval from his party.
lead_paragraph: The old cliché has it that when it comes to picking their presidential candidates, Democrats fall in love. But the party’s primary race last year was hardly a great political romance: Joseph R. Biden Jr. drew less than 21 percent of the Democratic vote in the Iowa and Nevada caucuses and a dismal 8.4 percent in the New Hampshire primary.

headline: West Hartford, Conn.: A Suburb With an Urban Aesthetic
abstract: This densely developed town abutting Connecticut’s capital city is a ‘little bit of a liberal enclave,’ equidistant from Boston and New York.
lead_paragraph: When Jonathan and Sarah Hammer began looking for a house in West Hartford, a bustling suburb abutting Connecticut’s capital city, it was immediately clear that they were in a fiercely competitive market. Early in March, they submitted an offer for $16,000 above the asking price for a five-bedroom colonial. Their offer was rejected, and the property later sold for closer to $90,000 above list.

headline: Make Way for the Travel Agents. Again.
abstract: After a devastating year, the travel industry is hoping for a rager of a rebirth this summer. Travel agents are planning the festivities.
lead_paragraph: With more people getting vaccinated and the C.D.C. largely giving the greenlight to travel for those who have had all their shots, a real-deal vacation this summer may be a reality for millions of Americans.

headline: What Are the Roadblocks to a ‘Vaccine Passport’?
abstract: Creating a digital certificate of vaccination against the coronavirus is one of the hottest debates right now. What’s keeping it from happening, and why are some people opposed?
lead_paragraph: With all American adults soon to be eligible for Covid-19 vaccines and businesses and international borders reopening, a fierce debate has kicked off across the United States over whether a digital health certificate (often and somewhat misleadingly called a “vaccine passport”) should be required to prove immunization status.

headline: Put Down Your Book. It’s Time to Act Out.
abstract: With playhouses closed, theater fans have taken drama into their own hands and mouths, forming play reading groups online and off.
lead_paragraph: When England began its first lockdown about a year ago, a production of “Coriolanus” at the Crucible in Sheffield locked down, too. Suddenly at liberty, the actress Alex Young hung up her Junius Brutus costume and returned to London. She panicked, she grieved and then on March 18, she opened Twitter. “Who’d be up for a Zoom/Skype play reading group?” she wrote. “Like a book group but we chose a script each time.”

headline: Coinbase’s Public Listing Is a Cryptocurrency Coming-Out Party
abstract: With acceptance from traditional investors, a profitable start-up that eases transactions is offering proof of the industry’s staying power.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Digital currency, once mocked as a tool for criminals and reckless speculators, is sliding into the mainstream.

headline: Regular Exercise May Help Protect Against Severe Covid
abstract: People who tended to be sedentary were far more likely to be hospitalized, and to die, from Covid than those who exercised regularly.
lead_paragraph: More exercise means less risk of developing severe Covid, according to a compelling new study of physical activity and coronavirus hospitalizations. The study, which involved almost 50,000 Californians who developed Covid, found that those who had been the most active before falling ill were the least likely to be hospitalized or die as a result of their illness.

headline: A Key Tool in Covid Tracking: The Freedom of Information Act
abstract: Through open-records laws, Times reporters have acquired data on coronavirus cases that revealed racial inequalities, pinpointed hot spots and uncovered other critical facts.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: It’s Not Just You: Many Are Placing Bets on Summer Travel
abstract: Airfare, typically purchased well in advance, can be a barometer of how the public is feeling about the pace of recovery, and summer fares are surging.
lead_paragraph: On March 11, President Biden gave the country a preliminary timetable for returning to normalcy. In a prime-time address, he directed states to make all adults eligible for vaccination by May 1.

headline: 5 Health Care Jobs on the Rise
abstract: Occupations in the industry are increasingly in demand because of an aging population and longer life spans.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our new series on the Future of Health Care, which examines changes in the medical field.

headline: New Target for New York’s Ascendant Left: Rep. Carolyn Maloney
abstract: Justice Democrats, a left-wing group that fueled the rise of Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, is backing Rana Abdelhamid’s primary bid.
lead_paragraph: Nearly three years ago, a little-known left-wing organization helped engineer Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez’s shock victory over Representative Joseph Crowley in a House primary. Last year, the group, Justice Democrats, aided Jamaal Bowman’s ouster of Representative Eliot Engel in another House primary.

headline: How to Use Tech to Prepare for Travel in a Pandemic
abstract: Even as vaccines make it safer to travel, planning a trip is becoming increasingly complicated.
lead_paragraph: With coronavirus vaccines now readily available, you might have ambitions to venture far from home. Government officials, after all, say traveling is a low-risk activity for the inoculated.

headline: Decades After His Death, Richard Wright Has a New Book Out
abstract: “The Man Who Lived Underground,” a novel publishers rejected in the 1940s, is about an innocent Black man forced to confess to the murder of a white couple.
lead_paragraph: In 1941, Richard Wright, fresh off the success of his novel “Native Son,” sent his editor the draft of a new book called “The Man Who Lived Underground.”

headline: At Least 15 Officers Mistook Guns for Tasers. Three Were Convicted.
abstract: Prosecuting police in cases of so-called weapon confusion has happened before, but the legal landscape is complex.
lead_paragraph: It happened in a flash.

headline: The Woman Who Made van Gogh
abstract: Neglected by art history for decades, Jo van Gogh-Bonger, the painter’s sister-in-law, is finally being recognized as the force who opened the world’s eyes to his genius.
lead_paragraph: In 1885, a 22-year-old Dutch woman named Johanna Bonger met Theo van Gogh, the younger brother of the artist, who was then making a name for himself as an art dealer in Paris. History knows Theo as the steadier of the van Gogh brothers, the archetypal emotional anchor, who selflessly managed Vincent’s erratic path through life, but he had his share of impetuosity. He asked her to marry him after only two meetings.

headline: Their London Pub Was Reduced to Rubble. They Fought to Bring It Back.
abstract: Developers knocked down the Carlton Tavern six years ago to make way for luxury apartments. After a legal fight, they were ordered to rebuild it, brick by brick.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — “Your local pub, it’s a bit like your favorite pair of shoes or jeans, something you just completely take for granted,” Rob Cope said, sitting outside the Carlton Tavern in North London on Monday.

headline: In My Hometown, Opioids Are Still Stealing Lives
abstract: A decade ago, it was already a crisis. But it feels as if it’s getting worse.
lead_paragraph: HATBORO, Pa. — I’d almost lost my capacity to be shocked by drug overdose. At 28, I’m of Generation Opioid. During high school, prescription pills were as easy to abuse as a learner’s permit. Our reunions take place coffin-side and often.

headline: Who Made My Crossword?
abstract: This month’s spotlight shines on Brendan Emmett Quigley.
lead_paragraph: I’m currently a resident of Brookline, Mass. Living the dream.

headline: A Legal Winning Streak for Religion
abstract: A series of victories in the Supreme Court has fueled claims that the justices are giving preference to faith groups.
lead_paragraph: In a ruling a few days ago, the Supreme Court lifted coronavirus restrictions imposed by California on religious services held in private homes. The decision gave religious Americans another win against government rules that they say infringe on their freedom to worship.

headline: Why Diversity Is an Advantage in a Vegetable Plot
abstract: Forget whatever you’ve heard about which plants “love” which other plants. This isn’t Match.com for vegetables: There’s a science to it.
lead_paragraph: Before pushing that cart of vegetable seedlings to the checkout line, consider a stop in the seed aisle. On offer: potential organic pest control.

headline: Can Medical Alexas Make Us Healthier?
abstract: America’s health care system needs help. But don’t expect technology to be a silver bullet.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: Serious and Rare
abstract: Will the Johnson & Johnson pause do more harm or good?
lead_paragraph: The apparent problem with Johnson & Johnson’s Covid-19 vaccine is both serious and rare, which makes it a thorny issue for policymakers to address and for the rest of us to think through.

headline: Other People’s Kids Are Annoying
abstract: How to enforce house rules when you’ve got company.
lead_paragraph: Because I am a parenting columnist, fellow moms and dads will often whisper off-the-record complaints to me. A recurring issue in the pandemic era has been how much they really do not enjoy their children’s friends. I have heard elementary school kids called names that are unprintable in this fine family newspaper. That’s because parents are beyond frustrated with the second-graders in their home who would, for example, prefer to lie down on the floor, shouting, rather than sit attentively during distance learning.

headline: Afghans Wonder ‘What About Us?’ as U.S. Troops Prepare to Withdraw
abstract: Many Afghans fear that without the umbrella of American protection, the country will be unable to preserve its modest gains toward democracy and women’s rights.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A female high school student in Kabul, Afghanistan’s war-scarred capital, is worried that she won’t be allowed to graduate. A pomegranate farmer in Kandahar wonders if his orchards will ever be clear of Taliban land mines. A government soldier in Ghazni fears he will never stop fighting.

headline: Theater to Stream: ‘Assassins’ and ‘Romeo and Juliet’
abstract: Highlights include a virtual production of Adam Rapp’s “The Sound Inside” and a new reading series by Roundabout Theater Company.
lead_paragraph: In March of last year, Classic Stage Company announced that its revival of the Stephen Sondheim musical “Assassins” was postponed. “The production was to begin performances on April 2,” the email said. “C.S.C. intends to resume rehearsals and present ‘Assassins’ in the coming months.”

headline: The C.E.O.s Who Didn’t Sign a Big Defense of Voting Rights
abstract: Hundreds of leaders and companies signed a letter opposing strict limits. They did not.
lead_paragraph: Amazon, BlackRock, Google, Warren Buffett and hundreds of other companies and executives have signed a new statement opposing “any discriminatory legislation” that would make it harder for people to vote. The statement, which ran as a two-page ad in The Times, comes amid a flurry of voting-related proposals from Republicans that have generated competing calls for corporations to take a stand and to stay out of politics lest lawmakers retaliate, David Gelles and Andrew write in The Times. And just as notable as the names who signed the statement are those that didn’t.

headline: Toshiba’s top executive resigns amid company turmoil.
abstract: The leader of the Japanese conglomerate stepped down as the company faces a buyout offer and an inquiry into management practices.
lead_paragraph: Toshiba announced on Wednesday the resignation of its top executive, Nobuaki Kurumatani, a move that comes as the Japanese conglomerate faces a potential buyout and a shareholder-initiated investigation into its management practices.

headline: Here is what happened in markets today.
Some companies are focusing on wooing individual investors, who are becoming a market force.
abstract: Dozens of companies are suddenly paying more attention to individual investors.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of companies are suddenly paying more attention to individual investors.

headline: Insurers are trying to pass on costs of the Texas storm by blaming power companies.
abstract: Two months after the storm crippled large swaths of Texas, insurers are sketching out a legal strategy to pin the costs on utilities and power companies that they say failed to adequately prepare for bitterly cold weather.
lead_paragraph: Two months after the storm crippled large swaths of Texas, insurers are sketching out a legal strategy to pin the costs on utilities and power companies that they say failed to adequately prepare for bitterly cold weather.

headline: NATO Confirms Its Troop Withdrawal From Afghanistan
abstract: The alliance’s mantra has always been “in together and out together,” so with the U.S. leaving, the pullout did not come as a surprise.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Following the news that the United States was pulling all its troops from Afghanistan by Sept. 11, NATO’s foreign and defense ministers agreed on Wednesday to begin withdrawing NATO forces on May 1 and finish “within a few months,” the alliance said in a statement.

headline: Biden announces a withdrawal from Afghanistan after two decades of frustration in the ‘Forever War.’
abstract: President Biden, frustrated in his efforts to end America’s “Forever War” a decade ago,  announced on Wednesday a Sept. 11 deadline for withdrawal of U.S. troops from Afghanistan after 20 years, a move that immediately triggered similar action among the country’s NATO allies.
lead_paragraph: President Biden, frustrated in his efforts to end America’s “Forever War” a decade ago,  announced on Wednesday a Sept. 11 deadline for withdrawal of U.S. troops from Afghanistan after 20 years, a move that immediately triggered similar action among the country’s NATO allies.

headline: The E.U.’s vaccination campaign gets a lift from Pfizer as it promises a big switch in strategy.
abstract: The bloc will receive an extra 50 million doses from the manufacturer this month as it moves away from relying on vaccines from AstraZeneca and Johnson & Johnson.
lead_paragraph: The European Union will receive an extra 50 million doses this month of the coronavirus vaccine developed by Pfizer and BioNTech, a lift in its effort to speed up inoculations in the face of difficulties with vaccines developed by AstraZeneca and Johnson & Johnson.

headline: What to Know About Johnson & Johnson Vaccines in California
abstract: Wednesday: How will a pause in the use of Johnson & Johnson vaccines affect the Golden State’s rollout?
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Here are the takeaways of a scathing inspector general’s report on the Capitol riot.
abstract: A new report by the Capitol Police’s internal watchdog found that department leaders overlooked key intelligence in the run-up to the riot on Jan. 6, including a warning that “Congress itself is the target,” and barred the force’s riot response unit from using its most powerful crowd-control measures.
lead_paragraph: A new report by the Capitol Police’s internal watchdog found that department leaders overlooked key intelligence in the run-up to the riot on Jan. 6, including a warning that “Congress itself is the target,” and barred the force’s riot response unit from using its most powerful crowd-control measures.

headline: 25 Free Performances Come to Bryant Park Starting in June
abstract: The park will host events for live audiences of 200 with institutions including the New York Philharmonic, Jazz at Lincoln Center, Joe’s Pub and the Classical Theater of Harlem.
lead_paragraph: With arts performances in New York slowly starting up again, one city tradition is finally set to return: free outdoor events in marquee locations.

headline: With a Drone on the High Line, an Artist Re-emerges From Controversy
abstract: Sam Durant reveals his first large-scale sculpture in the public sphere since the “Scaffold” controversy in Minneapolis.
lead_paragraph: In May, a sleek white fiberglass sculpture in the shape of a Predator drone will be installed atop a 25-foot-tall pole and rotate in the wind on the High Line at 30th Street in New York. With a wingspan of 48 feet — almost the actual size of the remote-controlled military aircraft but stripped of its cameras, weapons and landing gear — the kinetic artwork could appear as a modernist bird hovering in the sky, reminiscent of the biomorphic sculptures of Constantin Brancusi or Barbara Hepworth.

headline: A Laid-Back Villa Near the Coast of Portugal
abstract: This linear contemporary home in Sintra, Portugal, a few miles from the Atlantic Ocean, is on the market for $3.6 million.
lead_paragraph: This linear contemporary home in Sintra, Portugal, a few miles from the Atlantic Ocean, is on the market for $3.6 million.

headline: House Hunting in Portugal: A Light-Filled Retreat Near the Atlantic Coast
abstract: In Lisbon and other high-density areas, foreign buyers are scrambling to make investments before the country’s Golden Visa program is cut back.
lead_paragraph: This contemporary villa sits on nearly three acres in the tourist-friendly town of Sintra, about three miles from Portugal’s southwestern coastline and about 25 miles west of Lisbon. Built in 2008 from concrete and glass, the approximately 10,700-square-foot house has five bedrooms and five and a half baths, with natural light pouring in through floor-to-ceiling windows and doors throughout.

headline: What You Get for $2 Million
abstract: A 1910 Tudor Revival house in Evanston, Ill.; a home near the beach on Maui, Hawaii; and a steel-and-glass showplace in Dallas.
lead_paragraph: A 1910 Tudor Revival house in Evanston, Ill.; a home near the beach on Maui, Hawaii; and a steel-and-glass showplace in Dallas.

headline: $2 Million Homes in Illinois, Hawaii and Texas
abstract: A 1910 Tudor Revival house in Evanston, a home near the beach on Maui and a steel-and-glass showplace in Dallas.
lead_paragraph: Walter Burley Griffin, who worked as an architect in Frank Lloyd Wright’s Oak Park studio before developing his own international practice, designed this suburban Chicago house with the strong horizontal planes and overhanging eaves of the Prairie Style, combined with a Tudor-esque front gable and half-timbering. Known as the Frederick B. Carter Jr. House, after its original owners, and listed on the National Register of Historic Places, the house is in southeast Evanston, about half a mile north of the border with Chicago and about 12 miles north of Millennium Park and the Loop. It is about a mile south of the downtown business district, three blocks east of the commercial establishments along Chicago Avenue and within walking distance of a public beach and park on Lake Michigan.

headline: Her Boss Sent Harassing Texts. So She Beat Him With a Mop.
abstract: A government worker in China became an internet sensation after a video emerged of her striking back at a boss she had accused of harassment.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — It was a thrashing to behold.

headline: A Choreographer Diving Into Grief Looks to Whales
abstract: In a haunting new digital work, “Whale Fall,” Mayfield Brooks mourns Black bodies.
lead_paragraph: Light is important in any dance, but in Mayfield Brooks’s latest, the right lighting is everything. “The light at 1 p.m. is when we want it,” said the choreographer, bathed in a morning glow during a recent video interview.

headline: The Queen of Fractured Fairy Tales
abstract: Helen Oyeyemi writes magical, unsettling novels in which nothing remains fixed. She’s lived her life that way, too.
lead_paragraph: Helen Oyeyemi writes magical, unsettling novels in which nothing remains fixed. She’s lived her life that way, too.

headline: Key Moments on Day 13 of the Derek Chauvin Trial
abstract: A forensic pathologist called to testify by the defense said it was his medical opinion that George Floyd died from cardiac arrhythmia.
lead_paragraph: The lawyer for the former officer Derek Chauvin began calling witnesses to the stand this week, including an associate of George Floyd’s who was in the car with him when the police arrived, and a Minneapolis Park Police officer on the scene. The defense is trying to build a case that Mr. Floyd was affected by drugs he had taken, and that the bystanders were a threat to the officers who pinned Mr. Floyd to the ground.

headline: Watch Live: Day 13 of the Derek Chauvin Trial
abstract: Watch live video of the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former police officer charged in the death of George Floyd. Warning: The video may include graphic images.
lead_paragraph: Watch live video of the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former police officer charged in the death of George Floyd. Warning: The video may include graphic images.

headline: With Earnings Soaring, Wall Street Banks See Economic Boom Ahead
abstract: The banks said they released large chunks of money that had been set aside to cushion themselves from losses caused by the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The mood on Wall Street is decidedly jubilant.

headline: ‘Justice for Daunte Wright’
abstract: What do you think this image is saying? What is your opinion of its message?

headline: Bernard Madoff, Architect of Largest Ponzi Scheme in History, Is Dead at 82
abstract: His enormous fraud left behind a devastating human toll and paper losses totaling $64.8 billion.
lead_paragraph: Bernard L. Madoff, the onetime senior statesman of Wall Street who in 2008 became the human face of an era of financial misdeeds and missteps for running the largest and possibly most devastating Ponzi scheme in financial history, died on Wednesday in a federal prison hospital in Butner, N.C. He was 82.

headline: Every Film in This Oscar Category Is an Underdog You Can Root for
abstract: Live-action shorts were once as mainstream as best picture. Now they’re treated as afterthoughts. Their history reflects the evolution of Hollywood.
lead_paragraph: In an era when TikTok, YouTube, and other bite-size videos are compulsively viewed by millions, you’d think short films might get a little more attention. The academy bestows awards on shorts in no less than three categories, but they’re sometimes treated as an afterthought, even a place to streamline a lengthy ceremony. Yet the short film endures as a valuable art form, with hundreds produced every year.

headline: Screamers, a Missing Link of Los Angeles Punk, Is Missing No More
abstract: An archival release marks the technical debut of a band that helped build a scene, 44 years later.
lead_paragraph: K.K. Barrett hadn’t spoken to Tommy Gear in two decades when he reached out about releasing a secret stash of their old music. There were no hard feelings — the two had simply grown apart over the years — but it was tricky business, regardless. Their band, Screamers, was something of a phantom in the history of Los Angeles punk rock.

headline: With George Floyd, a Raging Debate Over Bias in the Science of Death
abstract: Critics say the profession of forensic pathology has been slow to acknowledge how big a role bias may play in decisions such as whether to classify a death in police custody as a homicide.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — From the beginning, the death of George Floyd disrupted the field of forensic pathology in much of the way it challenged policing.

headline: Morries Hall, who was with George Floyd before his arrest, will not be compelled to take the stand.
abstract: Mr. Hall invoked his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination. He was with Mr. Floyd moments before police officers pulled him out of a car and later pinned him to the ground for more than nine minutes.
lead_paragraph: Morries Lester Hall, who was in a car with George Floyd outside of Cup Foods in Minneapolis moments before the police pulled Mr. Floyd out of the car and later pinned him to the ground for more than nine minutes, invoked his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination when he was called to testify on Wednesday.

headline: Colton Underwood, ‘Bachelor’ Star, Comes Out as Gay
abstract: The 29-year-old former football player had written about questioning his sexuality in a memoir, published in 2020.
lead_paragraph: Colton Underwood, a star of “The Bachelor” and a former football player, came out as gay in an interview with Robin Roberts that aired Wednesday on “Good Morning America.”

headline: David Fowler, former chief medical examiner of Maryland, says he believes George Floyd died from cardiac arrhythmia.
abstract: Dr. Fowler, who retired as the state’s chief medical examiner in 2019, has a history of involvement with high-profile police use-of-force cases.
lead_paragraph: Derek Chauvin’s defense called on Dr. David Fowler, who retired as Maryland’s chief medical examiner in 2019 and has a history of involvement with high-profile police use-of-force cases, to testify on Wednesday as an expert witness.

headline: Risi e Bisi Time!
abstract: Gabrielle Hamilton’s lovely take on the dish favors vegetables over the rice, green and vibrant against its creamy, cheesy background.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. If there’s anything we’ve learned from a pandemic spent watching people make quesabirria tacos and soondubu jjigae on TikTok, it’s that culinary authenticity is a slippery concept: internet fame, as Tejal Rao told us recently, both broadens demand for particular dishes and flattens our perception of them. Suddenly there’s only one way to make a dish.

headline: A panel of independent experts to the C.D.C. says it needs more time to assess data and risks during the Johnson & Johnson vaccine pause.
abstract: The emergency meeting on Wednesday came after federal health authorities said they were studying rare blood clots in a small number of vaccine recipients and injections of the vaccine were halted across the country.
lead_paragraph: An advisory committee for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention met on Wednesday to discuss the decision made on Tuesday to pause use of the Johnson & Johnson Covid-19 vaccine because of its possible link to extremely rare blood clots. After a robust afternoon discussion, the panel decided they needed more time to assess the data and risks, and would not vote on a recommendation until they meet again in a week or 10 days.

headline: A Long-Awaited Return to Eating at Beloved New York Restaurants
abstract: As the city’s sense of optimism grows, one author stops by her favorite Manhattan institutions, and orders a dish or two at each.
lead_paragraph: In this series for T, the author Reggie Nadelson revisits New York institutions that have defined cool for decades, from time-honored restaurants to unsung dives. For this installment, which coincides with the release of her book “Marvelous Manhattan,” she checks in on some of her favorite places.

headline: Somalia’s President Extends Term by Two Years, Drawing Condemnation
abstract: His four-year term expired, President Mohamed Abdullahi Mohamed signed a contentious law that critics fear could plunge the fragile country into renewed, possibly violent, turmoil.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — In a highly contentious move, Somalia’s president has extended his own term in office by two years, drawing condemnation from the United States and other allies who viewed it as a naked power grab that could upend faltering efforts to establish a functioning state in Somalia and defeat the insurgency by the extremist group Al Shabab.

headline: Witness With George Floyd Before His Arrest Will Not Take the Stand
abstract: Morries Lester Hall, who was in a car with George Floyd before his arrest, invoked his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination when he was called to testify on Wednesday in Derek Chauvin’s murder trial.
lead_paragraph: Morries Lester Hall, who was in a car with George Floyd before his arrest, invoked his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination when he was called to testify on Wednesday in Derek Chauvin’s murder trial.

headline: How the Largest Animals That Could Ever Fly Supported Giraffe-Like Necks
abstract: These pterosaurs had wingspans as long as 33 feet, and scans of fossilized remains reveal a surprise in their anatomy.
lead_paragraph: If you were to gaze skyward in the late Cretaceous, you might catch a glimpse of surreal flying giants with wingspans that rival small planes. This supersized group of pterosaurs, known as azhdarchids, included species that measured 33 feet between wingtips, which made them the largest animals that ever took to the air.

headline: In India, Second Wave of Covid-19 Prompts a New Exodus
abstract: Low-paid workers are starting to flee the cities en masse, just like a year ago. Their hometowns, often in far-flung places, may once again be ill prepared to test arrivals and treat the sick.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — As dawn broke over Mumbai, India, on Wednesday, Kaleem Ansari sat among a crowd of thousands outside the central rail station waiting for his train to pull in. Mr. Ansari, a factory worker, carried old clothes in his backpack and 200 rupees — not quite $3 — in his pocket.

headline: 16 Asparagus Recipes That Positively Scream Spring
abstract: After a particularly long winter, these bright, fresh recipes will have you clamoring to eat greens.
lead_paragraph: Asparagus performs at its best with little effort: It retains its bright-green hue, delicate flavor and crisp-tender crunch when cooked quickly. Raw or roasted, blanched or sautéed, it pops up in a number of dishes that involve minimal labor, allowing the stalks to shine. When it comes to spring asparagus — and, perhaps, cooking in general at this stage of the pandemic — less is more.

headline: What Women Need to Know About the Covid Vaccine
abstract: Can it affect mammograms or the timing of fertility treatments? What side effects should you look out for? Experts weigh in.
lead_paragraph: News that seven women developed a rare blood clotting disorder after receiving Johnson & Johnson’s Covid-19 vaccine has prompted new questions about whether vaccines affect women differently than men, and whether there are special considerations that women should take into account when getting vaccinated.

headline: Read excerpts from Biden’s prepared remarks on Afghanistan, to be delivered at the White House this afternoon.
abstract: Immediately after the speech at the White House, Mr. Biden is scheduled to travel to Arlington National Cemetery, where he will visit Section 60, where service members who died in Iraq and Afghanistan are buried.
lead_paragraph: President Biden will deliver a speech Wednesday afternoon in which he will lay out his plans for withdrawing all troops from Afghanistan, ending American involvement in a war that began 20 years ago.

headline: The Israel Prize Is Meant to Unify. More Often, It’s Mired in Controversy.
abstract: This year’s rumpus involves a scientist who opposes the occupation of the West Bank.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The annual Israel Prize ceremony is supposed to be an august and unifying event, a beloved highlight of the Independence Day celebrations that fall on Thursday this year.

headline: The Strange, Lovely ‘Infinity Train’ Reaches the End of the Line
abstract: The fantastical animated series is part surreal adventure and part spiritual parable. Its fourth and final season arrives Thursday on HBO Max.
lead_paragraph: Whatever the state of public transportation in the real world, pop culture does not lack for metaphorical trains that promise to solve our problems. Glide on the peace train. Start a love train. People get ready, there’s a train a-comin’.

headline: Rep. Kevin Brady of Texas announces that he’ll retire from Congress at the end of his term.
abstract: Mr. Brady, who first won his seat in the state’s Eighth Congressional district in 1996, is the latest seasoned lawmaker to announce his retirement in recent months.
lead_paragraph: Representative Kevin Brady of Texas, the top Republican on the House Ways and Means Committee, announced on Wednesday that he would retire from Congress at the end of this term after more than two decades in the House.

headline: In a historic vote, a House panel advances a bill to form a reparations commission.
abstract: The bill — labeled H.R. 40 after the unfulfilled Civil War-era promise to give former slaves “40 acres and a mule” — faces an uphill path amid opposition from Republicans and many Democrats.
lead_paragraph: A House committee voted on Wednesday to recommend for the first time the creation of a commission to consider providing Black Americans with reparations for slavery in the United States and a “national apology” for centuries of discrimination. It comes three decades after the measure was first introduced and a century and a half after the end of slavery.

headline: Denmark says it’s permanently stopping use of the AstraZeneca vaccine.
abstract: The country hasn’t used it since last month, after concerns arose about a possible rare, dangerous side effect. Officials say they have adequate supplies of other vaccines to use instead.
lead_paragraph: Denmark on Wednesday became the first country to plan to permanently stop administering the AstraZeneca vaccine, a month after suspending its use following reports that a small number of recipients had developed a rare but serious blood-clotting disorder.

headline: Overdose Deaths Have Surged During the Pandemic, C.D.C. Data Shows
abstract: The latest numbers surpass even the yearly tolls during the height of the opioid epidemic and mark a reversal of progress against addiction in recent years.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — More than 87,000 Americans died of drug overdoses over the 12-month period that ended in September, according to preliminary federal data, eclipsing the toll from any year since the opioid epidemic began in the 1990s.

headline: 4 Art Gallery Shows to See Right Now
abstract: Arthur Jafa remixes Robert Mapplethorpe; Sanou Oumar leaps forward; Ray Johnson makes connections; TR Ericsson processes grief.
lead_paragraph: Arthur Jafa’s most conspicuous skill is for editing; the force of his videos (such as “Love Is the Message, the Message Is Death,” on view at the New Museum in the show “Grief and Grievance”) comes from a jagged, poetic soldering of high- and low-resolution found footage. Those smash-cut techniques persist here, at Gladstone, where he has arranged in breezy counterpoint 108 icy photographs of flowers and fornicators by Robert Mapplethorpe. He freely mixes Mapplethorpe’s portraiture, still lifes, nudes and sadomasochistic pictures; omits many well-known images (none of the bodybuilder Lisa Lyon); and accentuates his early color Polaroids, such as three shots from 1972 of Mapplethorpe’s lover, Sam Wagstaff, hard at work.

headline: Burt Pugach, Protagonist of a Strange Tabloid Love Story, Dies at 93
abstract: In 1959, he had his lover blinded. When he got out of prison, he married her. He called their relationship “a storybook romance.”
lead_paragraph: In an incongruously serene finale to a half-century of making lurid headlines — he hired thugs to blind the lover who had spurned him, served 14 years in prison for arranging the assault, married her after he was released, cheated on her with a younger mistress and was forgiven yet again — Burt Pugach died inconspicuously four months ago in Queens.

headline: The Minnesota officer who killed Daunte Wright was charged with manslaughter.
abstract: Kimberly A. Potter, who resigned from the Brooklyn Center Police Department, was arrested on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: BROOKLYN CENTER, Minn. — The Minnesota police officer who fatally shot Daunte Wright, a 20-year-old Black man, after appearing to mistake her handgun for her Taser was arrested on Wednesday and charged with second-degree manslaughter following three nights of protests over the killing.

headline: The Crucial Questions for Afghanistan
abstract: What will happen to women and minorities? Can the Afghan president hold on to power? These and other pressing questions face a fearful country as the United States military withdraws.
lead_paragraph: The reality of an imminent American withdrawal from Afghanistan differs from its long-anticipated likelihood. Already the anxiety engendered by this new certainty in the capital, Kabul, and other urban centers is making itself felt.

headline: We Don’t Need Tech Infomercials
abstract: Technology has moved beyond staged product events. We should, too.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: A Man Who Shipped Himself in a Crate Wants to Find the Men Who Helped
abstract: Over 50 years after Brian Robson mailed himself out of Australia, emerging almost 8,000 miles away, he is looking for two friends who assisted.
lead_paragraph: With no email or social media in 1965, Brian Robson lost touch with two friends who took part in a reckless scheme: They nailed him into a crate to ship him across the planet.

headline: The Eco–Yogi Slumlords of Brooklyn
abstract: How did a couple who built an empire of yoga studios and homes with “living walls” end up as pandemic villains?
lead_paragraph: How did a couple who built an empire of yoga studios and homes with “living walls” end up as pandemic villains?

headline: Fowler Says He Would Classify Floyd’s Death as ‘Undetermined’
abstract: Dr. David Fowler, former Maryland chief medical examiner, testified on Wednesday that he would classify George Floyd’s death as “undetermined,” with a primary cause of cardiac arrhythmia during police restraint.
lead_paragraph: Dr. David Fowler, former Maryland chief medical examiner, testified on Wednesday that he would classify George Floyd’s death as “undetermined,” with a primary cause of cardiac arrhythmia during police restraint.

headline: When will there be a verdict in the Derek Chauvin trial?
abstract: The defense began presenting its case, then the trial will move into closing arguments and jury deliberation.
lead_paragraph: The defense began presenting its witnesses on Monday, after more than 30 witnesses took the stand for the state during the first two weeks of the trial of Derek Chauvin.

headline: The Johnson & Johnson Pause Slows College Vaccinations
abstract: Schools are looking for alternatives to the one-shot vaccine before the end of the semester.
lead_paragraph: As summer break looms, colleges are racing to inoculate students before they leave campus. Many schools and states had banked on the Johnson & Johnson vaccine — the only one-shot Covid-19 inoculation approved for use in the U.S. — to achieve that goal.

headline: Hundreds of companies and executives sign a statement opposing laws to limit voting.
abstract: Amazon, BlackRock, Google, Warren Buffett and hundreds of other companies and executives signed on to a new statement released on Wednesday opposing “any discriminatory legislation” that would make it harder for people to vote.
lead_paragraph: Amazon, BlackRock, Google, Warren Buffett and hundreds of other companies and executives signed on to a new statement released on Wednesday opposing “any discriminatory legislation” that would make it harder for people to vote.

headline: Fraternity Members Pay Off Mortgage of Longtime House Cook
abstract: For 14 years, Jessie Hamilton cooked for the Phi Gamma Delta fraternity at Louisiana State University. Years later, 90 former members took up a collection to pay her mortgage.
lead_paragraph: For years, Jessie Hamilton cooked red beans and rice, hamburgers, and fried chicken with mashed potatoes for the members of the Phi Gamma Delta fraternity at Louisiana State University.

headline: Miami Outdoor Theater Hit Announces a New York Arrival
abstract: “The Seven Deadly Sins,” a theatrical anthology series, will start off on June 23 at a series of storefront windows in the Meatpacking District.
lead_paragraph: After enjoying a successful run in Miami Beach from late November through January, “The Seven Deadly Sins,” an outdoor theatrical anthology series that explores humanity’s basest impulses, will come to New York. Performances are scheduled to begin on June 23 and will take place in storefront windows in Manhattan’s Meatpacking District.

headline: Your Child Says She’s Trans
abstract: Hormones? Surgery? The choices are fraught — and there are no easy answers.
lead_paragraph: Hormones? Surgery? The choices are fraught — and there are no easy answers.

headline: ‘Snabba Cash’ Depicts a Sweden Flowing with Money and Blood
abstract: Netflix’s gender-flipped update of Jens Lapidus’s Stockholm Noir Trilogy probes the hustle for riches among drug dealers and tech billionaires alike.
lead_paragraph: Not wanting to talk oneself up is a traditionally Swedish trait. There is even a Nordic term for it: jantelagen. But there is precious little room for such decorum in “Snabba Cash,” which depicts a Stockholm pulsing with pushy entrepreneurs, blinged-out cocaine dealers and a tech billionaire (Olle Sarri) who tells a radio interviewer, “I am the system.”

headline: The WeWork Guy’s Guide to Striking it Rich
abstract: Adam Neumann may be out of a job, but his wild rise is standard operating procedure in Silicon Valley.
lead_paragraph: Adam Neumann may be out of a job, but his wild rise is standard operating procedure in Silicon Valley.

headline: Review: Close Quarters and Distant Love in ‘The Last Five Years’
abstract: Casting Black actors and filming in a claustrophobic New York apartment revitalizes Jason Robert Brown’s popular two-character musical.
lead_paragraph: Breakups, hookups, divorces, engagements: Even if you haven’t been afflicted yourself, you’ve surely heard stories of the dramatic changes Covid-19 has wrought on relationships, as though Cupid himself got feverish and went rogue.

headline: NFTs Have a Climate Problem
abstract: Making the digital artworks requires colossal amounts of computing power, and that means greenhouse gases.
lead_paragraph: You’ve probably noticed a lot of buzz over the past few weeks about nonfungible tokens, or NFTs, the digital artworks that are stamped with unique codes. Last month, one of them sold for more than $69 million at a Christie’s online auction.

headline: Once again, South Africa finds itself halting use, at least temporarily, of a Covid-19 vaccine it had bet on.
abstract: The change comes after concerns of rare blood clots that emerged in a handful of people in the United States who had received the shot.
lead_paragraph: South Africa has faced blow after blow to its pandemic-control efforts: A worrisome variant swept across the country, driving a devastating second wave of coronavirus cases. Then officials had to scramble for an alternative when the vaccine it had bet on, from AstraZeneca, proved ineffective against the variant, which can partially dodge the body’s immune system response.

headline: Coinbase’s valuation soars in first public listing of a major cryptocurrency company.
abstract: The listing is a sign of how cryptocurrencies have become mainstream.
lead_paragraph: Shares in Coinbase, the first major cryptocurrency company to list its shares on a U.S. stock exchange, jumped in their market debut on Wednesday, showing that investors are hungry to get a piece of the hot market for digital currencies.

headline: How New Mexico Became the State With the Highest Rate of Full Vaccinations
abstract: New Mexico, which has one of the highest poverty rates in the U.S., is a vaccination pacesetter thanks to decisive political decisions, homegrown technology and cooperation.
lead_paragraph: ALBUQUERQUE — Despite having one of the highest poverty rates in the country, New Mexico is surging past states with far more resources in the race to achieve herd immunity against the coronavirus.

headline: Televisa will sell its content and media business to Univision.
abstract: More than a decade ago, Grupo Televisa of Mexico and Univision of the United States, giants in the world of Spanish-language media, set aside years of hostility to strike an alliance. Now, the two companies are deepening their bonds to better compete in the streaming era.
lead_paragraph: More than a decade ago, Grupo Televisa of Mexico and Univision of the United States, giants in the world of Spanish-language media, set aside years of hostility to strike an alliance. Now, the two companies are deepening their bonds to better compete in the streaming era.

headline: Western Warnings Tarnish Covid Vaccines the World Badly Needs
abstract: Amid a deep residue of mistrust, American and European cautions on the AstraZeneca and Johnson & Johnson vaccines risk igniting anti-vaccine fervor in countries that can’t afford to be particular.
lead_paragraph: Safety worries about the AstraZeneca and Johnson & Johnson Covid-19 vaccines have jeopardized inoculation campaigns far beyond the United States, undercutting faith in two sorely needed shots and threatening to prolong the coronavirus pandemic in countries that can ill afford to be choosy about vaccines.

headline: Donald P. Ryder, Architect of Black Heritage Sites, Dies at 94
abstract: His firm, which he formed with J. Max Bond Jr., designed public works commemorating the civil rights movement as well as the Schomburg Center in Harlem.
lead_paragraph: Donald P. Ryder, whose firm designed important repositories of Black culture and social history in becoming one of the nation’s most prominent partnerships of Black architects, died on Feb. 17 at his home in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 94.

headline: The 6 Best Speeches of Awards Season So Far

lead_paragraph: Even at the best of times, making an award acceptance speech isn’t easy. It’s the most scrutinized moment of your career, you’re bound to forget the name of somebody you love, and you’re five feet from a trigger-happy orchestra that is trained to turn on you like a firing squad.

headline: A Capitol Police lieutenant won’t face charges in the Jan. 6 shooting death of a rioter.

lead_paragraph: A former editor at Vanity Fair has been working for several years to create a digital publication with a business twist: Its writers will share in subscription revenue.

headline: ‘We have already boarded’: Businesses in Minneapolis brace for protests, like the ones last year.
abstract: Shop owners hope they don’t experience destruction similar to that of last summer as a verdict draws closer in the Derek Chauvin trial and tensions flare over a police shooting.
lead_paragraph: Carl Mitchell spent Sunday nailing wood to the windows of the Amstar convenience shop he manages in North Minneapolis. Hours earlier, Daunte Wright, a 20-year-old Black man, had been shot by the police 10 miles north. With the trial of the former officer Derek Chauvin, accused of killing George Floyd, heading into its third week, Mr. Mitchell didn’t want to take any chances.

headline: How the Capitol Riot Suspects Are Challenging the Charges
abstract: Defense lawyers have complained that some charges do not apply to what unfolded on Jan. 6, and one argues it will be impossible to get a fair trial in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Three months after the attack on the Capitol, the frantic federal effort to prosecute the members of the mob that stormed the building has started shifting gears.

headline: ‘We Have No Right to Destroy Them’

lead_paragraph: On Thursday, every Major League Baseball player will don a No. 42 jersey in honor of Jackie Robinson Day. The annual event, celebrated officially since 2004, marks the anniversary of Robinson’s major league debut in 1947, which broke baseball’s color line that stretched back to the 19th century.

lead_paragraph: President Biden formally announced his decision to end the 20-year, largely unsuccessful American effort to remake Afghanistan, declaring on Wednesday that he would withdraw the remaining few thousand United States troops in the country by Sept. 11.

headline: What the Coronavirus Variants Mean for Testing
abstract: Most tests should be able to detect the variants of concern, but test developers and health officials must remain vigilant, scientists say.
lead_paragraph: In January 2020, just weeks after the first Covid-19 cases emerged in China, the full genome of the new coronavirus was published online. Using this genomic sequence, scientists scrambled to design a large assortment of diagnostic tests for the virus.

headline: He Has Trained to Be Mayor for Decades. Will Voters Be Persuaded?
abstract: Scott Stringer’s deep experience in New York City politics has yet to translate into momentum in the mayor’s race. Could an endorsement from the Working Families Party help?
lead_paragraph: On a late February morning in TriBeCa, the most seasoned politician in the New York City mayor’s race was sitting outside, futzing with his fogging-up eyeglasses as he wrestled with an assessment of an election that appeared to be slipping from his grasp.

headline: What It’s Like to Fly Now
abstract: Here’s what a recent trip through Miami International Airport looked like for a New York Times reporter.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what a recent trip through Miami International Airport looked like for a New York Times reporter.
