headline: Biden’s Afghan Pullout Is a Victory for Pakistan. But at What Cost?
abstract: Pakistan’s military stayed allied to both the Americans and Taliban. But now the country may face intensified extremism at home as a result of a perceived Taliban victory.
lead_paragraph: Near the peak of the American war in Afghanistan, a former chief of neighboring Pakistan’s military intelligence — an institution allied both to the U.S. military and to its Taliban adversaries — appeared on a talk show called “Joke Night” in 2014. He put a bold prediction on the record.

headline: Lil Nas X? Not Sorry!
abstract: The celebrity apology has evolved, but it still isn’t good enough.
lead_paragraph: Social media apologies have become the standard celebrity response to internet outrage. But why do they feel so deeply inadequate? Jenna and Wesley dissect a new spate of public apologies from the last year. And they look to the activist and writer adrienne maree brown for an example of a “fully evolved” apology.

headline: France Lawmakers Pass Contentious Bill Extending Police Powers
abstract: The legislation was criticized by civil rights groups and political opponents, who intend to challenge its constitutionality.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French Parliament passed a contentious security bill on Thursday that extends police powers, despite criticism from political opponents and civil rights activists who have vowed to challenge the legislation before France’s Constitutional Council.

headline: 9 New Songs
abstract: Jon Pareles, our chief pop music critic since 1988, on the past month’s greatest hits, from Valerie June to joyful music from Africa.
lead_paragraph: Jon Pareles, our chief pop music critic since 1988, on the past month’s greatest hits, from Valerie June to joyful music from Africa.

headline: Prince Philip’s Funeral Will Include a Call to Battle
abstract: The prince approved plans for his own funeral and, despite coronavirus restrictions, the ceremony will reflect his wishes, officials say.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Toward the end of the carefully choreographed, 50-minute planned funeral service for Prince Philip, scheduled for Saturday, the “Last Post” will be played by musicians from Britain’s Royal Marines. But the military buglers will then have one further duty requested specifically by Prince Philip: sounding so-called Action Stations — a call used on naval warships to summon crew to battle readiness.

headline: Democrats’ Supreme Court Expansion Plan Draws Resistance
abstract: Lawmakers and activists say more justices are needed to rebalance the court, but a top Democrat said any action would have to await the work of a new presidential commission.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A group of House and Senate Democrats on Thursday introduced legislation to expand the Supreme Court to 13 members from nine, working to build momentum for rebalancing the court after an aggressive Republican drive to move it to the right.

headline: Vernon Jones, a Pro-Trump Republican, Will Challenge Kemp in Georgia
abstract: Vernon Jones, a Democrat-turned-Republican and former state representative who has called Georgia’s presidential election “fixed,” will oppose Gov. Brian Kemp, one of Donald Trump’s top targets.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Gov. Brian Kemp, the Georgia Republican who ranks high on former President Donald J. Trump’s list of enemies, will face a high-profile pro-Trump challenger in next year’s Republican primary: Vernon Jones, a former Democrat who, echoing the false claims of Mr. Trump, has called Georgia’s November presidential election “fixed” and “tainted.”

lead_paragraph: During a news conference on Thursday, Mayor Lori Lightfoot of Chicago said officials would release video of a police officer’s fatal shooting last month of 13-year-old Adam Toledo.

lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Eritrean troops continue to commit atrocities in the northern Ethiopian region of Tigray, despite assurances by Ethiopia’s prime minister, Abiy Ahmed, that they were leaving, a senior United Nations official said Thursday.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?

headline: Alan Vega Left a Robust Vault. The Excavation Begins With a New Album.
abstract: The Suicide singer died in 2016. Now his wife and musical partner, Liz Lamere, is releasing “Mutator,” an album the duo made in the mid-90s.
lead_paragraph: In 1978, the adversarial New York duo Suicide played a show in Boston, opening for the Cars, local heroes who’d crossed over into pop success. Suicide performed a set of assaultive and static electronic music, and the unhappy audience demonstrated its distaste by throwing ashtrays, some of which hit the singer Alan Vega. But Vega and his bandmate, Martin Rev, had recently finished European tours opening for the Clash and Elvis Costello during which they caused a literal riot in Belgium. (It was later documented on a live recording, “23 Minutes Over Brussels,” named for the length of Suicide’s set before the gendarmes were summoned.)

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today

lead_paragraph: Canada has gone through a few waves of the coronavirus, but compared with its neighbor to the south, the country has largely managed to keep its outbreak under control.

headline: John Williamson, 83, Dies; Economist Defined the ‘Washington Consensus’
abstract: A careful pragmatist, he regretted the way his term, aimed at developing countries, was misinterpreted by free-market ideologues and anti-globalization activists.
lead_paragraph: John Williamson, a British economist who in 1989 coined the phrase “Washington Consensus” to describe a set of policy reforms for developing economies, then spent the rest of his career trying to rescue it from misuse by both free-market ideologues and anti-globalization activists, died on Sunday at his home in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 83.

headline: Signs of Economic Hope Are Growing, Some With Superlatives

abstract: It’s more about listening than talking.
lead_paragraph: Morrie Schwartz was a Brandeis sociology professor who died of A.L.S. in 1995. While he was dying, he had a couple of conversations with Ted Koppel on “Nightline” and a bunch with his former student Mitch Albom, who wrote a book, “Tuesdays With Morrie,” which sold over 15 million copies. For a few years, Schwartz was the national epitome of the wise person, the gentle mentor we all long for.

Fauci said on Thursday that he hoped the nation would soon be able to resume use of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine, as a “pause” that now looks indefinite threatened to upend vaccination efforts overseas and in some of the most marginalized communities in the United States.

headline: Carol Prisant, Elegant Design Writer, Dies at 82
abstract: She was a 51-year old former antiques dealer with no experience as a writer when she wrote to the editor of The World of Interiors magazine about a job. She was hired.
lead_paragraph: Carol Prisant, an elegant design writer who was the New York editor of the idiosyncratic British magazine The World of Interiors, died on April 9 at a hospital in Manhattan. She was 82.

lead_paragraph: Charli Collier, a center from the University of Texas, was selected No. 1 over all by the Dallas Wings in the W.N.B.A.’s virtual draft on Thursday, fulfilling the dream of her late father that she be the top pick. lead_paragraph: Will Andrew Yang, the current front-runner, become New York City’s next mayor? If he wins, would he be any good at the job? I have no idea, although I’m skeptical about the latter.

headline: Why Spy Agencies Say the Future Is Bleak

lead_paragraph: Every four years, at the start of a new administration, American intelligence agencies put out “Global Trends,” a weighty assessment of where the world seems headed over the next two decades. In 2008, for example, the report warned about the potential emergence of a pandemic originating in East Asia and spreading rapidly around the world.

headline: Lack of Training Led Capitol Police to Temper Riot Response, Watchdog Says
abstract: The force’s inspector general testified that a top official ordered officers not to use their most powerful anti-riot tools on Jan. 6 because of concerns they did not know how.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The U.S. Capitol Police’s independent watchdog told Congress on Thursday that a senior official on the force had instructed officers not to use their most powerful crowd-control weapons on Jan. 6 because they had little training with the equipment and the official was afraid they would misuse it and potentially harm or kill people.

headline: Trump Is Gone, but Land Disputes Along Border Continue Under Biden

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After battling for years against the Trump administration’s plan to seize some of their family’s land in South Texas to build a border wall, the Cavazos siblings believed the inauguration of President Biden would bring a successful end to their fight.

headline: Biden’s approval rating rises, helped by the vaccine distribution push.
abstract: Americans don’t think the president deserves sole credit for the widespread availability of Covid vaccines, but they like the job he’s doing getting them distributed, a new poll found.
lead_paragraph: The American public doesn’t think President Biden deserves sole credit for the widespread availability of Covid-19 vaccines, but it overwhelmingly likes the job he’s doing getting them distributed — and it’s feeding a high job approval rating over all.

headline: I’m a Virus Expert Who Got the J&J Vaccine. I’m Not Losing Sleep.
abstract: Here’s how to think about the federal investigation into rare but severe blood clots associated with the vaccine.
lead_paragraph: About a week ago, I received the Johnson & Johnson Covid-19 vaccine. It was a joyous moment, after more than a year of fear of the coronavirus. Then, on Tuesday, I had a flurry of texts from concerned family members, friends and colleagues who had recently seen the news. Health authorities had requested a pause for the Johnson & Johnson vaccine to investigate six blood clotting cases among women who had been vaccinated.

headline: As protests against police violence surge, Florida passes a bill to combat ‘public disorder.’

headline: Corrections: April 16, 2021
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, April 16, 2021.

The article also may have implied incorrectly that Bitcoin is likely to shift to a proof-of-stake model. While some critics say Bitcoin will eventually need to make the switch, there are no plans to do so, and the idea is broadly unpopular within the Bitcoin community.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Feeding Hate With Video

headline: Sticking Point
abstract: Don’t skip this Friday challenge from Tom Pepper.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — There are so many action words in this Tom Pepper puzzle it’s like a comic strip — super fun to race or pick through but not easy by any means. We like to flyspeck this Friday/Saturday grid thing, and I’ll just note that when Mr. Pepper has a Saturday grid he will hit for the cycle, it’s the only day on which we haven’t solved him. I think this feels like a Friday but I’m willing to reconsider. Another Pepper trait is high-score scrabble words, and this grid is one letter short of a pangram (that letter is featured in a clue mentioned in the constructor notes, which you should read for a very cruciverbal chuckle).

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: U.S. sanctions on Russia.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration yesterday announced new sanctions on Russia over the hacking and election interference by its government. The measures aim to choke off lending to the Russian government as part of a broad effort to give more teeth to financial sanctions — though in the past, penalties have failed to deter Russian activity.

headline: I Tried to Filter Him Out
abstract: As a Pakistani Muslim, I knew that falling for a Hindu Indian would break me. And it did.
lead_paragraph: We started texting during the early months of the pandemic, going back and forth every day for hours. The stay-at-home order created a space for us to get to know each other because neither of us had any other plans.

headline: What to Know About the Police Shooting of Adam Toledo
abstract: Body camera footage showed that a Chicago officer fired a single shot into the boy’s chest after chasing him down a dark alley.
lead_paragraph: Officials in Chicago released body camera footage on Thursday of a police officer fatally shooting a 13-year-old boy last month, setting off protests over the use of deadly force by police in a city that has been beleaguered by violence.

headline: What We Know About the Shooting in Indianapolis
abstract: Eight people were killed at a FedEx warehouse, the police said.
lead_paragraph: At least eight people died in a shooting at a FedEx facility in Indianapolis late Thursday, and the gunman was believed to have taken his own life, the police said.

headline: Jimmy Kimmel Heckles ‘Future Former Florida Congressman’ Matt Gaetz
abstract: Kimmel poked fun at Gaetz and his friend Joel Greenberg for making their Venmo transactions public: “One of those ‘salads’ cost more than $1,000 — I guess they added avocado.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

abstract: This word has appeared in 11 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?

headline: Disappearing Slang and Cultural Variants: How Australian English Is Changing
abstract: Readers reflect on the country’s many different accents.
lead_paragraph: Last week, I wrote about whether an Asian-Australian accent existed and asked for your thoughts on how the Australian accent is changing. Dozens of readers wrote in about their experiences navigating regional, cultural and ethnic Australian accents, observing that the way we speak is becoming more homogenized, and to correct my own Australian linguistic error — yes, you’re right, we throw prawns, not shrimp, on the barbie.

headline: Paraguay’s ‘Life and Death’ Covid Crisis Gives China Diplomatic Opening
abstract: Paraguay desperately needs Covid-19 vaccines, which China could supply. That has led the South American nation to reconsider its relationship with Taiwan, which precludes it from dealing with Beijing.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Taiwan has built thousands of homes for the poor in Paraguay, upgraded the country’s health care system, awarded hundreds of scholarships and even helped fund the futuristic Congress building in the capital, spending generously over decades to nurture their diplomatic ties.

headline: Names of the eight victims were released by the authorities.
abstract: The gunman killed himself, according to authorities, after opening fire in the parking lot of a FedEx facility and storming the building.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — Officials with the Indianapolis Metropolitan Police Department identified the eight victims of the mass shooting at a FedEx warehouse in Indianapolis on Friday night, more than 20 hours after the gunman opened fire on Thursday.

abstract: In this lesson, students will learn about muons and why scientists are carefully tracking how they spin inside a magnetic field. Are physicists on the verge of discovering new subatomic particles?

abstract: Paul McCartney and the newspaper both make special appearances in Dominic Fike’s cover of “The Kiss of Venus.”
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Hong Kong Court Sentences Jimmy Lai and Other Pro-Democracy Leaders to Prison
abstract: The punishments for Mr. Lai, a media tycoon, and other leaders over an unauthorized peaceful protest point to what critics say is the shrinking space for dissent in Hong Kong.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Jimmy Lai has skewered the Chinese Communist Party for decades. The 73-year-old founder of a fiercely pro-democracy newspaper in Hong Kong, Mr. Lai helped give voice to critics of the city’s leaders and their bosses in Beijing, winning friends in Washington and other places along the way.

lead_paragraph: When I was 14, someone recorded a video of me naked without my knowledge or consent. It ended up on XVideos.

abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: New in Paperback: ‘Until the End of Time’ and ‘Warhol’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: SQUARE HAUNTING: Five Writers in London Between the Wars, by Francesca Wade. (Crown, 432 pp., $18.) Bloomsbury’s Mecklenburgh Square was home to five pioneering feminists across 25 years: the poet H.D., the novelist Dorothy Sayers, the medievalist Eileen Power, the classicist Jane Ellen Harrison and, famously, Virginia Woolf. Our reviewer, Blanche Wiesen Cook, called Wade’s portrait of the group “enchanting.”

headline: New Books on the Brain and What It Can and Can’t Do
abstract: From “Useful Delusions,” by Shankar Vedantam and Bill Mesler, about why lying to ourselves can be good, to Adam Grant’s “Think Again,” about how we can reset our preconceived notions.
lead_paragraph: USEFUL DELUSIONSThe Power and Paradox of the Self-Deceiving BrainBy Shankar Vedantam and Bill Mesler233 pp. Norton. $27.95.

headline: Why Adults Lose the ‘Beginner’s Mind’
abstract: The psychologist Alison Gopnik and Ezra Klein discuss what children can teach adults about learning, consciousness and play.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a sobering thought: The older we get, the harder it is for us to learn, to question, to reimagine. This isn’t just habit hardening into dogma. It’s encoded into the way our brains change as we age. And it’s worsened by an intellectual and economic culture that prizes efficiency and dismisses play.

headline: A High School Reunion for Two
abstract: After almost four decades, John Capshaw reconnected with his childhood crush, Courtneye Barrett, on the dating app Bumble.
lead_paragraph: After a long absence from the dating scene, Courtneye Barrett made her presence felt three years ago on Bumble, when she parked her cursor on the profile, “John C., 53’s,” which belonged to John Capshaw, a bearded, blue-eyed man.

headline: Rosie Could Be a Riveter Only Because of a Care Economy. Where Is Ours?
abstract: The men and women who went to work and war during World War II were backed by a care economy. We need one too.
lead_paragraph: I have spent the past two weeks reading about the infrastructure debate with mounting rage. When a reporter asked me recently why I felt so strongly, I sputtered, groping for the words. Ultimately, however, the answer is simple. Insisting that there is actually a fixed definition of what infrastructure is — bridges, but not baby care — perfectly encapsulates the ways in which the world is still shaped by men. Not just conservative men, but men across the political spectrum. Men today, that is: Three-quarters of a century ago, the Greatest Generation recognized that both forms of infrastructure were essential to the war effort.

headline: A Wedding Date They’ll Remember. No Joke.
abstract: When Carla Kitzmiller and John Porter’s April 1 wedding seemed impossible to pull off, Ms. Kitzmiller’s co-workers helped to make it happen at the car dealership where she works.
lead_paragraph: In early March, Carla Kitzmiller, a title clerk at the Indiana car dealership Thomas Kia of Highland, went to work with a problem. She and her fiancé, John Porter, wanted to be married April 1, but because of Covid regulations, their options seemed limited to eloping at a courthouse near their home in Munster, Ind. “The girls I work with started talking, and they were like, ‘No! You can’t have family at the courthouse,’” Ms. Kitzmiller said.

headline: How to Defeat Myanmar’s Military
abstract: Elected legislators deposed in the February coup have a plan for building a new federal democratic union. We need help.
lead_paragraph: The people of Myanmar have been fighting for the life of our nation since the military, or Tatmadaw, seized power on Feb. 1. We have been protesting peacefully, risking our lives to protect neighborhoods, cities and towns — fighting not for any one political party, ethnic group or leader, but for freedom and a genuine federal democracy.

headline: Weddings: He Followed His Heart to Memphis
abstract: Sarah Lockridge-Steckel moved to Memphis to start a nonprofit group. She was part of Kito Lord’s 10-year plan. So Memphis became part of his plan, too.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Kito Akin Obasi Lord likes to say he met Sarah Orcasita Lockridge-Steckel in January 2016 in Barcelona. Not the city in Spain, but a little restaurant-bar by that name near Yale in New Haven, Conn.

headline: The Blue Wall of Silence Is Starting to Crack
abstract: Police say, ‘This is not who we are.’ Prove it.
lead_paragraph: I was driving around the other day when I realized that the license tabs on my car had expired. I didn’t panic, because I didn’t have to. If the cops pulled me over, I could feel assured as a white male: My life would not be in danger.

headline: When Opposites Become Best Friends
abstract: Christian Hendry said Wynne Hamerman “taught me what it means to really care about people.” She says she learned from him “how to be patient.”
lead_paragraph: Christian Hendry said that Wynne Hamerman was a “social butterfly,” when they met at the University of Connecticut at the start of their sophomore years in September 2009.

headline: The Bride and Groom Met at a Wedding
abstract: Rachel Goldman and Christopher Ruiz, who grew up within two miles of each other, had never crossed paths until they met in 2016 at a wedding.
lead_paragraph: Cantor Rachel Goldman doesn’t often stay for the reception at the weddings she officiates, to “keep things professional,” as she put it.

headline: As N.Y. Courts Seek to Root Out Racism, a Clerk Is Heard Using a Slur
abstract: A lawyer for a teenager said he overheard racist comments directed at his client during a hearing in New York Family Court. The incident came months after a judge warned about racism in the courts.
lead_paragraph: At the end of an hourlong virtual hearing in Family Court in Manhattan on Thursday, Holden E. Thornhill’s 15-year-old client, who is Black, stood up to alert the authorities at his detention facility that the hearing had finished.

headline: He Flew From His Bike, and Later Fell Head Over Heels
abstract: Kaitlin Ruby Brinkerhoff met Ian McCann, a Canadian, on a mountain biking trip in her Utah hometown. They then maintained a challenging cross-border relationship through the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Kaitlin Ruby Brinkerhoff and Ian McCann consider the two weeks spent quarantining in a freezing recreational vehicle in Canada last fall — she knitting afghans and he playing the video game Call of Duty — among the highlights of their relationship. They realize this may not be everybody’s idea of a good time, but for the cross-border couple, togetherness under any conditions felt magical.

headline: She Works in a Homeless Shelter, and She Lives in One, Too
abstract: Many employees of New York’s homeless shelters are themselves in precarious economic situations, taking on multiple jobs, working overtime and struggling to find their own homes.
lead_paragraph: At the end of a 16-hour double shift at a homeless shelter in Queens, Amber Drummond, a security guard, was desperate to relax. But Ms. Drummond said she shared a room with a woman who was messy and constantly on her phone.

headline: The Lost Embryos
abstract: Elaine Meyer and Barry Prizant had given up on having more than one child. Then, in their 60s, they got a letter from the hospital where they’d long ago had IVF treatment.
lead_paragraph: When the first letter from Women & Infants Hospital arrived in the mail in July 2017, Elaine Meyer thought perhaps it was a fund-raising solicitation or clerical error. The letter, which included a billing invoice, addressed her as “Dear Patient,” but she had not been a patient at the hospital for nearly two decades. That’s when she and her husband, Barry Prizant, had completed their infertility treatment there.

headline: How Democrats Who Lost in Deep-Red Places Might Have Helped Biden
abstract: A study by a liberal group found a reverse coattails effect in 2020: Down-ballot candidates may have helped elect President Biden, rather than the other way around.
lead_paragraph: Ebony Carter faced an uphill climb when she decided to run for the Georgia State House last year. Her deeply Republican district south of Atlanta had not elected a Democrat since 2001, and a Democrat hadn’t even bothered campaigning for the seat since 2014.

headline: A Battle of Boos and Cheers at the Symphony
abstract: In the early 1980s, John Adams’s “Grand Pianola Music” defied the seriousness of classical music. Not everyone liked that.
lead_paragraph: It was 1970, and the composer John Adams was tripping on LSD.

headline: Why Do We Let Corporations Profit From Rape Videos?
abstract: With help from Google, XVideos lets people leer at the worst moment in a child’s life.
lead_paragraph: This article contains descriptions of sexual assaults.

headline: F.D.R. Didn’t Just Fix the Economy
abstract: He saved democracy itself.
lead_paragraph: The New Deal was more than a recovery program for the economy. It was, as the historian Eric Rauchway argues in his new book, “Why the New Deal Matters,” a recovery program for American democracy.

headline: Gauging the Prospects for International Travel
abstract: Roadblocks abound, but airlines, hotels and tour companies are trying to balance optimism with caution.
lead_paragraph: If 2020 was the summer of the pandemic-enforced road trip, many people seem to be hoping that 2021 will be the summer they can travel overseas. But that’s a big “if.” Roadblocks abound, among them, the rise of variant cases in popular destinations like Europe and confusion about the role that vaccine “passports” will play as people begin crossing borders. The recent pause on Johnson & Johnson’s coronavirus vaccine adds a new wrinkle.

headline: What Will Happen to All the Empty Office Buildings and Hotels?
abstract: Commercial real estate has been hit hard by the pandemic, but there are plans to convert some of the now-empty spaces into apartment buildings.
lead_paragraph: Dark windows. Quiet lobbies. Hushed halls.

headline: Unemployment Is High. Why Are Businesses Struggling to Hire?
abstract: Health concerns, expanded jobless benefits and still being needed at home are among the reasons would-be workers might be staying away.
lead_paragraph: There are two distinct, and completely opposite, ways of looking at the American job market.

headline: After Years of Wrangling, World War I Memorial Raises First Flag
abstract: As the United States withdraws from its longest war, a memorial that recognizes one of its most complicated ones officially opened in Washington, D.C., on Friday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Memorials to the war dead of the 20th century are among the central attractions in the nation’s capital. So it has always been notable that one of the most consequential American conflicts, World War I, lacked national recognition.

headline: Matthew Broderick Misses the Theater Very Much
abstract: Plus, Jerome LaMaar and RoseLee Goldberg on nurturing art in their studios.
lead_paragraph: With the New York charity circuit on hiatus, here is how some philanthropists and society figures are spending their time and resources during the pandemic.

headline: Art of the Dealer: Paula Cooper Shores Up Her Legacy
abstract: She opened the first gallery in SoHo and was a part of Chelsea’s initial wave. Now, at 83, the dean of ‘tough art’ will bring in new partners and start a year-round branch in Palm Beach.
lead_paragraph: In her first show at Paula Cooper Gallery in Chelsea, the painter Cecily Brown showed a large triptych, “A Day! Help! Help! Another Day!” (2016). The 33-foot-wide work, which draws its title from an Emily Dickinson poem, was an energetic field of colorful marks typical of Brown’s expressionistic style.

headline: Why Reopening Ceremonies Are So Important in New York Right Now
abstract: Movie theaters, hotels, restaurants and other businesses are putting a lot of thought into the process.
lead_paragraph: When Coney Island reopened this month after more than a year of sickness, death and unemployment, officials wanted to make sure the ceremony hit the right tone: one of joy, but also of respect and gratitude.

headline: How a Legendary New York Hotel Became a Battleground
abstract: Mark Twain and Bob Dylan slept at the Chelsea. Now, developers hope to lure tourists, but they have to soothe some frustrated tenants.
lead_paragraph: You can’t exactly roam carefree through the Chelsea Hotel these days, re-enacting its bohemian past, open wine bottle in hand, say, while taking a break from writing your generation-defining novel, song, or Netflix script. Even if you found the drilling and hammering, dust and debris, and exposed cables and pipes inspirational, the Chelsea has not booked a guest room since 2011.

headline: How George Hahn, Urban Raconteur, Spends His Sundays
abstract: He is devoted to his dogs, his tiny apartment and most of all these days, his city.
lead_paragraph: George Hahn loves New York. But in 2016, the writer, actor and sartorial pragmatist wrote an essay about how the city — his home for 22 years — had become unsustainable for his creative lifestyle. He decided to move home, to Cleveland, Ohio, where he marveled at his 1,000-square-foot apartment (with in-suite washer/dryer). But he grew to miss New York terribly. So when a Manhattan dermatologist offered him a full-time job, he returned — in January 2020.

headline: Covid-19 Pushes India’s Middle Class Toward Poverty
abstract: The pandemic sent 32 million people in India from the middle class last year. Now a second wave is threatening the dreams of millions more looking for a better life.
lead_paragraph: NOIDA, India — Ashish Anand had dreams of becoming a fashion designer. A former flight attendant, he borrowed from relatives and poured his $5,000 life savings into opening a clothing shop on the outskirts of Delhi selling custom-designed suits, shirts and pants.

headline: Gustavo Dudamel, Superstar Conductor, Will Lead Paris Opera
abstract: In a coup, the venerable company has hired as its next music director the rare classical artist to have crossed into pop-culture celebrity.
lead_paragraph: When Alexander Neef was named the next director of the mighty Paris Opera in 2019, he did not have a particular candidate in mind to succeed the company’s music director, who was leaving after a decade. “I felt I should consult with the musicians,” Neef said by phone recently, “and see who for them, what for them, how for them the future looked like.”

headline: Booster shots and re-vaccinations could be needed. Drug companies are planning for it.
abstract: Pfizer’s chief executive said a third dose of the company’s Covid-19 vaccine was “likely” to be needed within a year of the initial two-dose inoculation, followed by annual vaccinations.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have long said that giving people a single course of a Covid-19 vaccine might not be sufficient in the long term, and that booster shots and even annual vaccinations might prove necessary.

headline: Overwhelmed by the virus, Paraguay considers ditching Taiwan for China — and its vaccines.
abstract: In Paraguay, the government of Taiwan has built thousands of homes for the poor, upgraded the health care system, awarded hundreds of scholarships and helped fund a futuristic Congress building. But the alliance is facing an existential threat as Paraguay’s quest for Covid-19 vaccines becomes increasingly desperate.
lead_paragraph: In Paraguay, the government of Taiwan has built thousands of homes for the poor, upgraded the health care system, awarded hundreds of scholarships and helped fund a futuristic Congress building. lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — Families of people who work at the FedEx facility in Indianapolis continued to gather at a Holiday Inn Express & Suites on Friday, waiting in anguished suspense for news about their loved ones.

headline: The Success of Top-Down Simplicity
abstract: Blue states have pulled far ahead of red states in vaccinations. Why?
lead_paragraph: In the early weeks of Covid-19 vaccinations, the shining examples of success were all places with politically conservative leaders. Globally, the countries with the largest share of vaccinated people were Britain, Israel and the United Arab Emirates. In the U.S., the states that got off to the fastest starts were Alaska and West Virginia.

headline: ‘Arlo the Alligator Boy’ Review: Of Songs and Scales
abstract: This hyperactive animated Netflix musical for kids, with messages of empowerment and references to “Midnight Cowboy,” has a lot on its plate.
lead_paragraph: A tiger, a miniature Italian man, a girl with gigantism, a fish with legs, a pink hairball and a redheaded half-reptile walk into Manhattan. That’s the setup of “Arlo the Alligator Boy,” a hyperactive cartoon musical intended for kids on Netflix. The punchline is that the streaming service has already greenlighted a spinoff about this chipper green tyke for a 20-episode series.

headline: ‘Do I Really Belong Here?’: Korean Americans in the N.B.A. Wonder
abstract: A small network of Korean Americans working throughout basketball are helping one another grow professionally and feel understood personally, while hoping to add to their ranks.
lead_paragraph: Early this season, Evan Scott was officiating an N.B.A. game in Portland when a member of the Trail Blazers’ coaching staff approached him during a timeout.

headline: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love the Flute
abstract: It’s an instrument based on the most fundamental sign of life: breath. Ian Anderson, the leader of Jethro Tull, recommends a track featuring the flutist Andrea Griminelli.
lead_paragraph: It’s an instrument based on the most fundamental sign of life: breath. Ian Anderson, the leader of Jethro Tull, recommends a track featuring the flutist Andrea Griminelli.

headline: Goldman Sachs’s Top Image Maker Is Leaving
abstract: Jake Siewert led the firm’s post-financial crisis reputation makeover.
lead_paragraph: For nearly a decade, Jake Siewert led Goldman Sachs’s post-crisis efforts to shed its image as one of Wall Street’s most mysterious, and maligned, money machines. We’re the first to report that he plans to announce his departure later today.

headline: Mercedes unveils an electric version of its S-Class that goes farther than a Tesla.
abstract: The EQS has a range of 770 kilometers or about 480 miles, according to Mercedes. If that figure is confirmed, the EQS would dethrone the Tesla Model S Long Range Plus as the electric car with the longest range.
lead_paragraph: Mercedes-Benz unveiled an electric counterpart to its top-of-the-line S-Class sedan on Thursday, the latest in a series of moves by German automakers to defend their dominance of the high end of the car market against Tesla.

headline: Indianapolis recorded a steep rise in homicides in 2020.
abstract: Indianapolis, like several other cities across the United States, saw an increase in criminal homicides in 2020, a year already racked with death caused by the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Indianapolis, like several other cities across the United States, saw an increase in criminal homicides in 2020, a year already racked with death caused by the pandemic.

headline: Taiwan Charges Man With Causing Deadliest Rail Accident in Decades
abstract: The driver of a crane truck that slid down an embankment — into the path of an oncoming express train — faces up to 12 years in prison if convicted.
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Taiwanese prosecutors on Friday formally charged the operator of a crane truck that slid down an embankment into the path of an oncoming express train, resulting in the island’s deadliest rail disaster in decades.

headline: What Makes You Cringe?
abstract: An awkward conversation? A dad joke? An embarrassing photo?
lead_paragraph: What makes you cringe? An awkward conversation? A dad joke? Shameless self-promotion on social media? A trashy TV show? A Boomer trying to be young and hip? An old photo of yourself wearing an outdated fashion?

headline: Is Fashion Hacking the Future? Gucci Says Yes.
abstract: And demonstrates with Balenciaga. Whatever you do, don’t use the word “collaboration.” Celine goes into the light.
lead_paragraph: Gucci is singing a brand-new tune. (Emphasis on “brand.” Or maybe “branded.”)

headline: Dazzling Skies, U.F.O. Sightings and Real-Life Monsters: The Week in Narrated Articles
abstract: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote the story.

headline: The End of the United States’ Forever War
abstract: A new book about the Pech Valley in Afghanistan’s violent east offers poignant lessons as the Biden administration announces plans to withdraw all troops.
lead_paragraph: You’re reading this week’s At War newsletter. Sign up here to get it delivered to your inbox every Friday. Email us at atwar@nytimes.com.

headline: President Biden and the Japanese prime minister pledge new partnership to advance ‘shared democratic norms.’
abstract: President Biden welcomed Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga of Japan to the White House on Friday, using the first visit by a foreign leader during his presidency to underscore the importance of America’s allies as the United States confronts an increasingly aggressive China.
lead_paragraph: President Biden welcomed Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga of Japan to the White House on Friday, using the first visit by a foreign leader during his presidency to underscore the importance of America’s allies as the United States confronts an increasingly aggressive China.

headline: The Carpenter Who Built Tiny Homes for Toronto’s Homeless
abstract: Khaleel Seivwright built himself a wooden shanty while living on a West Coast commune. Then he started building similar lodgings for homeless people in Toronto to survive the winter.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — On his way to work on a construction site, Khaleel Seivwright surveyed the growing number of tents lining an intercity highway and in parks with increasing discomfort. How would these people survive Toronto’s damp, frigid winters, let alone the coronavirus, which had pushed so many out of overcrowded shelters?

abstract: Friday: Mayor Todd Gloria talks about the sheltering of young migrants at the city’s convention center.
lead_paragraph: (This article is part of the California Today newsletter. Sign up to get it delivered to your inbox.)

headline: Biden’s Supreme Court commission may weigh a range of potential changes beyond expanding seats.

lead_paragraph: President Biden’s commission to evaluate proposed overhauls to the Supreme Court is planning to tackle potential changes that range far beyond the hotly disputed proposal to expand the number of justices, according to people familiar with the matter.

headline: A Family Opens Up About Its Investing Mistakes
abstract: The family behind the Nathan Cummings Foundation agreed four years ago to invest more of the endowment in social justice causes. In a new report, it discusses how difficult that was.
lead_paragraph: Families routinely struggle to make simple decisions. But when their members come from three generations and the issue involves how to invest nearly half a billion dollars, the discussions can quickly get complicated, to say the least.

headline: Looking Back at the First Roaring Twenties
abstract: To understand where the stock market may be heading, a Nobel laureate examines the pop culture of one of the greatest bull markets in history.
lead_paragraph: We are in a second Roaring Twenties, or so you might think, from the countless comments suggesting that we are entering an exuberant decade that echoes the one of a century ago.

headline: That Popular S.U.V. Is Going to Cost You
abstract: Demand plus production delays have tightened the supply of new models. That means fewer deals. The only good news? Your trade-in may get a better price.
lead_paragraph: Car shoppers may find that bargains are scarce this year. But better prices on trade-ins may help ease the pain.

headline: Americans Have Discovered the Garden, and Celebrities Want In
abstract: Many of us turned to gardening for solace during the pandemic. Now Martha Stewart and Drew Barrymore want to guide us to green thumbs.
lead_paragraph: Last spring, as the world descended into a collective panic, Drew Barrymore planted her first lawn. “I did not think I could do this,” said Ms. Barrymore, 46, who until last year did not include gardening in her exhaustive list of achievements.

headline: The Tinder Hacker
abstract: When I asked Sean about his hobbies, I wasn’t prepared for what he said.
lead_paragraph: When I asked Sean about his hobbies, I wasn’t prepared for what he said.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Alison Gopnik
abstract: The April 16 episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Alison Gopnik. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Treasury Puts Taiwan on Notice in Currency Report but Strikes Measured Tone
abstract: The Biden administration removed Vietnam and Switzerland from the list of currency manipulators, but it will push all three countries to address its concerns.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury Department said on Friday that it was putting Taiwan, Vietnam and Switzerland on notice over their currency practices, but it struck a more conciliatory tone than the Trump administration by stopping short of labeling any of them a currency manipulator.

headline: Trump is gone, but land disputes along the border continue under Biden.

headline: ‘In the Heights’ Will Premiere at the Tribeca Festival
abstract: The movie musical is set to play the United Palace in Washington Heights, the neighborhood where the story is set. It will also screen outdoors in all five boroughs.
lead_paragraph: The Tribeca Festival announced Friday that it will open its 2021 edition this summer with the world premiere of “In the Heights,” the eagerly anticipated movie musical conceived by Lin-Manuel Miranda. The event adds a high-profile piece of arts programming to the statewide effort to bring the arts back after an entire year was upended by the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: The mayor of Indianapolis calls the shooting ‘horrific news.’

lead_paragraph: The mayor of Indianapolis on Friday described the deadly shooting at a FedEx warehouse near the city’s airport as “horrific news.” It was the latest time this year that the mayor has responded to a mass shooting that amplified gun violence in the city.

headline: A Partial List of Mass Shootings in the United States in 2021
abstract: The shootings never stopped during the coronavirus pandemic, they just became less public, researchers say.
lead_paragraph: To some, it might have seemed as if mass shootings all but halted during the coronavirus pandemic, with a year passing between large-scale shootings in public places.

headline: Iran Says It Began Enriching Uranium to 60 Percent. How Important Is That?
abstract: A highly purified form of uranium is needed to make an atomic bomb, but the main point of Tehran’s action may be to give it leverage in nuclear talks.
lead_paragraph: Iran has started enriching its uranium supply to 60 percent purity — the closest the country has ever come to the level needed for a weapon — in response to the sabotage of an Iranian nuclear site last weekend linked to Israel.

headline: Democrats running in down-ballot races helped Biden win votes in conservative areas, a study finds.
abstract: President Biden, who eked out a 12,000-vote victory in Georgia, received a small but potentially important boost from the state’s conservative areas if at least one local Democrat was running in a down-ballot race, according to a new study by Run for Something, an organization dedicated to recruiting and supporting liberal candidates. That finding extended even to the state’s reddest districts.
lead_paragraph: President Biden, who eked out a 12,000-vote victory in Georgia, received a small but potentially important boost from the state’s conservative areas if at least one local Democrat was running in a down-ballot race, according to a new study by Run for Something, an organization dedicated to recruiting and supporting liberal candidates. headline: Why I Fear Movies Won’t Be the Same Without the ArcLight
abstract: For the director Gina Prince-Bythewood, seeing her movie premiere there or just a poster for it on display was a sign that her work mattered. News of the closure hit hard.
lead_paragraph: As the rest of the film industry begins its tentative return to prepandemic normalcy, the announcement that Los Angeles’s ArcLight Cinemas, a chain that includes the Cinerama Dome, would close came as a shock to loyal moviegoers and filmmakers alike. Here, the director Gina Prince-Bythewood (“The Old Guard,” “Love & Basketball”) explains why the news was so devastating. These are edited excerpts.

headline: ‘Minari’ Haunted Me by What It Left Out
abstract: The drama dares to show sympathy for an emotionally distant patriarch and his relatively powerless wife — figures familiar to this child of immigrants.
lead_paragraph: Growing up, I never saw my Korean-American parents touch each other. No hugs or kisses, or even pats on the back. It wasn’t the byproduct of a loveless marriage, just the consequences of a life centered on survival — that endless list of unsexy chores. I’ve lived 30 years without acknowledging such biographical details, accepting that the nuances of my life could never make it into mainstream culture.

headline: When the World Feels Like a Disaster, ‘9-1-1’ Is on Call
abstract: The outlandish emergencies of “9-1-1” and “9-1-1: Lone Star” are oddly comforting in a terrifying time.

headline: Books About Racism and Police Violence Fill Out List of ‘Most Challenged’ Titles
abstract: After a year dominated by protests against police killings of Black Americans, the books on the list of the most frequently challenged titles of 2020 reflected the movement — and the backlash to it.
lead_paragraph: When the American Library Association released its list of the 10 most frequently banned or challenged books of 2020, it was no surprise to Angie Thomas that her debut novel, “The Hate U Give,” had made its return to the list for a third appearance.

headline: A New Line Inspired by Dancehall and Handicraft
abstract: The designer Rachel Scott has honed her skills at brands in Milan and New York, but when it came to creating her own label, Diotima, she looked homeward to Jamaica.
lead_paragraph: As a teen in 1990s Kingston, Jamaica, the fashion designer Rachel Scott was acutely aware of the tension between the decorum dictated by her Jesuit high school, where skirt lengths were checked on a regular basis, and the liberating dancehall scene she was swept up into at night. “There was this idea of being proper and having to present a certain way in the daytime — it was ridiculous,” says Scott, 37, speaking over Zoom from the lush green garden of her family’s house in Kingston, where she is visiting. But the soundtrack of her adolescence — the hip-swaying hits of local artists like Lady Saw, Shabba Ranks and Chaka Demus & Pliers that she heard at parties — left the more lasting impression. “Dancehall will forever be influential to me,” she says of the genre, which has roots in music of the African diaspora. “It’s like this explosion of exuberance.”

headline: Pasta Times Two
abstract: Sometimes, you just need a little more pasta: Pair it with garlicky spinach or feta and tomatoes.
lead_paragraph: Hi, everyone! Margaux Laskey here filling in for Emily this week. It’s a stunningly beautiful spring day where I am, like a Gerda Muller picture book come to life (except with sirens and aggressive pigeons). There’s a whisper of chill in the air, but the sun is bright, and I’m thinking this might be the weekend I plant pansies and begonias in my front porch pots. Maybe I won’t kill them this year. I am feeling hopeful about so many things. I wish that for you, too.

headline: He’s an Artist. His Medium? Wings, Tails, Scales, Beaks and Claws.
abstract: Our horror columnist looks at three new books, one of which is Polly Hall’s shudder-inducing debut, “The Taxidermist’s Lover.”
lead_paragraph: “Byrne Hall had a listening, whispering air.” This description of the Queen Anne-style mansion at the center of Elizabeth Brooks’s eerie and addictive Gothic novel THE WHISPERING HOUSE (Tin House, 378 pp., paper, $16.95) could also be applied to its heroine, the eavesdropping, willowy Freya Lyell, who becomes entangled with Byrne Hall and its inhabitants. Freya, bookish and sensible, has always lived in the shadow of her “frightening and beautiful” elder sister, Stella, and never more so since Stella’s body was discovered near the seaside village of Bligh. Five years later Freya, now 23, travels to Bligh from London for a wedding reception at Byrne Hall, only to discover a portrait of Stella hanging on a wall. This portrait, and the artist who painted it — Cory Byrne — launch Freya into the mystery of what really happened to Stella.

headline: Four Specials Take Outdoor Comedy in Unexpected Directions
abstract: Vir Das, Brian Regan, Erica Rhodes and Ester Steinberg each find new ways to make a virtue out of the necessity of performing al fresco in a pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Laughter doesn’t echo off clouds. That’s the first challenge of outdoor comedy. According to common wisdom, the ideal conditions for stand-up — small dark room, low ceiling — are pretty much the opposite of al fresco comedy. There was actually a history of such performing, before the pandemic, with its own street-comedy legends. But in the past year, a niche became mainstream, and now, there’s a new genre of special, tried by Chelsea Handler, Colin Quinn and others. Four more funny comedians have recently gotten laughs taking the special outside, and considering the loosening of rules for indoor performance, they could also be the last of their kind.

headline: Why the Vaccine Safety Numbers Are Still Fuzzy

headline: 10 Memorable Conversations From 15 Years of the Book Review’s Podcast

lead_paragraph: This month we’re celebrating the 15th anniversary of the Book Review’s podcast, the first podcast at The Times and still going strong. Pamela Paul, the show’s host and the editor of the Book Review, recently wrote about 15 of her favorite episodes from the eight years she has been at the helm. I thought I would expand the scope to the entire archive — Sam Tanenhaus, Paul’s predecessor, hosted for seven years — and share 10 more memorable conversations. (As an editor at The Times, I’ve had a hand in the podcast since 2011.) Below you’ll hear Toni Morrison discuss her vision for her novel “A Mercy”; Andre Agassi, Christopher Hitchens and Jeanette Winterson talk about their memoirs; Andrew Solomon on the profound lessons of death and dying; and more.
