headline: House Hunting in Germany: A Traditional Estate With Modern Taste
abstract: In and around Hamburg, demand for real estate has returned to prepandemic levels, but supply is still lagging, pushing prices upward.
lead_paragraph: This equestrian property of traditionally fired brick with a regionally distinctive reed-thatched roof was built in 2000 in the town of Fredenbeck, about 40 miles west of Hamburg, in northern Germany.

headline: ‘Great Gatsby’ Musical Sets Creative Team
abstract: The production will feature lyrics by Florence Welch of Florence + the Machine and a book by the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Martyna Majok.
lead_paragraph: After F. Scott Fitzgerald’s classic novel about America and aspiration entered the public domain in January, a glut of variations emerged that imagined the sentimental old sport, Jay Gatsby, as gay, a zombie or the hero of his own graphic novel.

headline: What We Know About the Killing of Andrew Brown Jr. in North Carolina
abstract: Police officers shot Mr. Brown in a confrontation as they tried to execute an arrest warrant
lead_paragraph: The killing of a 42-year-old Black man in coastal North Carolina by sheriff’s deputies is being scrutinized by state and federal authorities, and Gov. Roy Cooper has called for a special prosecutor to take over the case from a local district attorney.

headline: The Face of Solo Guitar Is Changing. It’s About Time.
abstract: Since the heyday of John Fahey, the genre has been seen as the province of white men. A new generation of diverse players is rapidly changing that.
lead_paragraph: Before Yasmin Williams became a teenager, she found her perfect sport: “Guitar Hero,” the dizzying video game where aging rock staples enjoyed an unlikely second life through players wielding plastic controllers fashioned after vintage Gibsons.

headline: When the Cellos Play, the Cows Come Home
abstract: A collaboration between a cattle farmer and a Danish music training program brings regular recitals to pampered livestock.
lead_paragraph: LUND, Denmark — During a recent performance of Tchaikovsky’s “Pezzo Capriccioso,” a handful of audience members leaned forward attentively, their eyes bright, a few encouraging snuffles escaping from the otherwise hushed parterre. Though relative newcomers to classical music, they seemed closely attuned to the eight cellists onstage, raising their heads abruptly as the piece’s languid strains gave way to rapid-fire bow strokes.

headline: South African President Appears Before Corruption Investigators
abstract: President Cyril Ramaphosa is testifying about graft during his predecessor’s tenure, in what analysts have characterized as a battle for the soul of the governing African National Congress.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — Three years ago, amid a flurry of corruption scandals that rocked South Africa, President Cyril Ramaphosa assumed power on promises to root out graft and restore public confidence in the governing party, the African National Congress.

headline: U.K.’s Johnson on the Defensive as Ethical Questions Mount
abstract: Britain’s Electoral Commission said it was opening an investigation into whether Prime Minister Boris Johnson used political donations to refurbish his apartment.
lead_paragraph: LONDON  — The ethical allegations swirling around Prime Minister Boris Johnson got more serious on Wednesday after Britain’s Electoral Commission announced it would open a formal investigation into whether Mr. Johnson secretly used political donations to refurbish his apartment in Downing Street.

headline: A Bet 20 Years Ago Made It the Exxon of Green Power
abstract: Iberdrola is a leader in wind and solar power, thanks largely to a bet its C.E.O. made 20 years ago.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — In the winter of 2015, three directors of a Connecticut electric company met with a potential acquirer: a determined Spanish utility executive named José Ignacio Sánchez Galán, who surprised them with a bold vision for America’s utility industry.

headline: Tastes of Spring
abstract: Eat well this season, whether you make a simple asparagus tart, creamy vegan tofu noodles, or crispy lamb with cumin.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Some store-bought puff pastry, goat cheese, crème fraîche, asparagus, fresh tarragon, plenty of Parmesan and a sprinkle of red-pepper flakes — you don’t need much more than that and an hour to make Melissa Clark’s fantastic springtime tart (above). And I hope you will make it, tonight or sometime soon.

headline: The Biden Plan for Free Community College Has a Big Challenge
abstract: A federal solution has to account for states that vary widely in how much they charge for tuition.
lead_paragraph: Coming up with a national policy for a college system that is decentralized is a lot tougher than it seems.

headline: How Does It Feel To Be Asian-American Right Now?
abstract: The pandemic and a rise in anti-Asian violence and rhetoric have brought renewed focus to this community. Tell us about your experience.
lead_paragraph: The pandemic and a rise in anti-Asian violence and rhetoric have brought renewed focus to this community. Tell us about your experience.

headline: How Long Can We Live?
abstract: New research is intensifying the debate — with profound implications for the future of the planet.
lead_paragraph: In 1990, not long after Jean-Marie Robine and Michel Allard began conducting a nationwide study of French centenarians, one of their software programs spat out an error message. An individual in the study was marked as 115 years old, a number outside the program’s range of acceptable age values. They called their collaborators in Arles, where the subject lived, and asked them to double-check the information they had provided, recalls Allard, who was then the director of the IPSEN Foundation, a nonprofit research organization. Perhaps they made a mistake when transcribing her birth date? Maybe this Jeanne Calment was actually born in 1885, not 1875? No, the collaborators said. We’ve seen her birth certificate. The data is correct.

headline: France Proposes More Surveillance to Hunt for Potential Terrorists
abstract: The new bill, which some fear will curtail civil liberties, comes after a series of attacks and as the far right is stoking feelings of insecurity.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French government, responding to several attacks over the past seven months, presented a new anti-terrorism bill on Wednesday that would allow intense algorithmic surveillance of phone and internet communications and tighten restrictions on convicted terrorists emerging from prison.

headline: Trading Stock Tips on TikTok, Newbies Are Deeply Invested in Learning
abstract: Self-taught and sharing what they’ve found out, a new generation of retail investors is taking the markets — and not memes — seriously.
lead_paragraph: In March last year, Kiersten Crum was a stock market novice. The pandemic had forced her college classes online, her father’s bar was temporarily closed, and she started working at a grocery store to earn extra cash. With $500, she bought shares of the Carnival cruise line, her first foray into stocks.

headline: The Debate Over a Tax Deduction
abstract: Readers react to an editorial calling for the elimination of the deduction for state and local taxes, and discuss how it affects the middle class and the wealthy.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Review: ‘Yasuke’ Reclaims a Black Samurai From History
abstract: Netflix’s new anime of ronin, race and robots is entrancing, if overstuffed with action-genre elements.
lead_paragraph: A partial list of the marvels in Netflix’s samurai anime series “Yasuke” includes sorcerers, a shape-shifting woman-bear, astral-plane duels and giant robots in feudal-era Japan. But the novelty that its characters are most surprised to encounter is a Black man who speaks Japanese.

headline: Theater to Stream: A Musical Throwback and ‘The Normal Heart’
abstract: Highlights include concerts by Melissa Errico and Sutton Foster, and an adaptation of Virginia Woolf’s “The Waves.”
lead_paragraph: In 2018, New Yorkers in the know were buzzing about a new musical at the tiny York Theater. That show, Mark Sonnenblick’s “Midnight at the Never Get,” was subtly daring and thought-provoking, underneath a conventional, even old-fashioned exterior. Thanks to a streaming production from the Signature Theater in Arlington, Va., it should reach the greater audience it richly deserves.

headline: New York will end its curfew on bars and restaurants next month.
abstract: The curfew, which currently requires establishments to stop serving customers at midnight, will end statewide on May 17 for outdoor dining areas and May 31 for indoor dining.
lead_paragraph: New York will end a longstanding curfew next month that forced bars and restaurants to close early in a bid to fight the spread of the coronavirus, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Wednesday.

headline: Here is a guide to Biden’s three big spending plans — worth about $6 trillion.
abstract: President Biden’s spending plans — one passed and two pending — reflect an ambition to restore the federal government to the role it played during the New Deal and Great Society.
lead_paragraph: President Biden is a man with a plan. Three plans, actually.

headline: Share Your Stories From India About the Pandemic
abstract: The New York Times wants to understand what you have endured, and we want to know what you’re doing to comfort one another until India can return to its bustle and vibrancy.
lead_paragraph: India is in crisis. Infections and deaths are soaring. Coronavirus vaccines are in short supply. In some cities, fear and uncertainty have settled over its hushed streets and shuttered storefronts, heavy with the knowledge that the pandemic may worsen before it gets better.

headline: An Inheritance Tax Bill You ‘Can’t Fathom’: $10.8 Billion
abstract: The Samsung family in South Korea will also donate billions of dollars’ worth of art, including Picasso and Monet.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL — Picasso, Monet and Dalí are among the assets South Korea’s richest family is parting with as it prepares to pay one of the largest inheritance tax bills in history.

headline: F.B.I. Searches Giuliani’s Home and Office, Seizing Phones and Computers
abstract: Prosecutors obtained the search warrants as part of an investigation into whether Rudy Giuliani broke lobbying laws when he was President Donald J. Trump’s personal lawyer.
lead_paragraph: Federal investigators on Wednesday seized cellphones and computers from Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former mayor of New York City who became President Donald J. Trump’s personal lawyer, stepping up a criminal investigation into Mr. Giuliani’s dealings in Ukraine, three people with knowledge of the investigation said.

headline: Wayne Peterson, Pulitzer Prize-Winning Composer, Dies at 93
abstract: His Pulitzer, in 1992, came amid controversy not of his making: A three-member jury had recommended a different work.
lead_paragraph: Wayne Peterson, a prolific composer whose fraught winning of the Pulitzer Prize in 1992 stirred debate about whether experts or average listeners were the best judges of music, died on April 7 in San Francisco. He was 93.

headline: Biden Administration Plans to Propose Banning Menthol Cigarettes
abstract: The move has been long sought by public health and civil rights groups, after decades of marketing aimed at Black smokers.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration is planning to propose a ban on menthol cigarettes, a long-sought public health goal of civil rights and anti-tobacco groups that has been beaten back by the tobacco industry for years, according to a federal health official.

headline: The Embers of a Long-Smoldering Revolution Are Stoked in France
abstract: The 150th anniversary of the Paris Commune of 1871 has struck a chord, reviving calls for better political representation and highlighting economic inequalities.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — On a recent chilly morning, a hundred people flocked to a tiny square near the Sacré-Coeur Basilica, at the top of the hill in Montmartre. They were not the usual tourists drawn by the breathtaking panoramic views over Paris, but left-wing demonstrators celebrating the 150th anniversary of a revolution that started right where they stood.

headline: 16 Grilling Recipes You’ll Want to Make All Summer Long
abstract: Cookouts are making a comeback, and these never-fail recipes will guarantee your best get-together yet.
lead_paragraph: No vacations, no picnics, no concerts: Last summer left much to be desired. This year, let’s make up for it by spending as much time outside as possible, grilling great foods with good friends. (Safely, of course.) These 16 tried and true recipes are easy and versatile, and there’s something here for every palate at the picnic table.

headline: A Missed Opportunity in India
abstract: Tech giants have so much power. They could do more to help Indians facing such a devastating crisis.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: Michael Collins, ‘Third Man’ of the Moon Landing, Dies at 90
abstract: Orbiting dozens of miles above the lunar surface, he kept solitary watch of the Apollo command module as Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin embarked for the moon.
lead_paragraph: Michael Collins, who piloted the Apollo 11 spacecraft Columbia in orbit 60 miles above the moon while his crewmates, Neil Armstrong and Col. Buzz Aldrin, became the first men to walk on the lunar surface, died on Wednesday at a hospice facility in Naples, Fla. He was 90.

headline: After the summit: Biden’s to-do list
abstract: The president set some lofty goals. Now, it’s all about money and politics.
lead_paragraph: So yes, that White House global summit happened.

headline: Scott Stringer, New York Mayoral Candidate, Is Accused of Sexual Assault
abstract: Jean Kim said Mr. Stringer assaulted her when she worked on his campaign 20 years ago and warned her not to tell anyone. He denied the allegation.
lead_paragraph: A woman who said she worked on a 2001 campaign for Scott M. Stringer, the New York City comptroller who is now running for mayor, has accused him of sexually assaulting her 20 years ago.

headline: The Pfizer and Moderna vaccines are 94 percent effective at preventing hospitalization in older adults, a study finds.
abstract: The findings, which are consistent with the clinical trial results, are the first real-world evidence from the United States that the vaccines protect against severe Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: The Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna coronavirus vaccines are 94 percent effective at preventing hospitalization in fully vaccinated adults 65 or older, according to a small study released by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Wednesday.

headline: Charles Strum, Versatile Editor for The Times, Dies at 73
abstract: Whether overseeing the paper’s night operations, a regional bureau or the obituaries, he was known for his calmness under deadline pressure.
lead_paragraph: Charles Strum, a longtime senior editor at The New York Times who earned a reputation for unflappability under deadline pressure in roles that included overseeing the paper’s nighttime news operations, its obituaries desk and its New Jersey bureau, died on Tuesday in Middlebury, Vt. He was 73.

headline: Prancer, the ‘Demonic Chihuahua,’ Finds a Home
abstract: An adoption ad said he was “literally the Chihuahua meme that describes them as being 50% hate and 50% tremble.” Undeterred, a Connecticut woman has adopted him.
lead_paragraph: It seemed hard to believe that a tiny Chihuahua described as a “man hating, animal hating, children hating” dog, a 13-pound “rage machine” and the “vessel for a traumatized Victorian child” could find a home.

headline: People of Color Breathe More Hazardous Air. The Sources Are Everywhere.
abstract: Researchers uncovered stark disparities between white people and minorities across thousands of categories of pollution, including trucks, industry, agriculture and even restaurants.
lead_paragraph: Over the years, a mountain of evidence has brought to light a stark injustice: Compared with white Americans, people of color in the United States suffer disproportionately from exposure to pollution.

headline: Fed Leaves Interest Rates Unchanged as Economy Begins to Heal
abstract: The Federal Reserve said the economy had “strengthened” but opted to continue providing support while playing down a rise in inflation.
lead_paragraph: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, made it clear on Wednesday that his central bank wants to see further healing in the American economy before officials will consider pulling back their support by slowing government-backed bond purchases and lifting interest rates.

headline: ‘Taxilandia’ Review: The Mouth is Running, but Not the Meter
abstract: Modesto Jimenez, known as Flako, has turned cab theater into a genre, and his latest show takes place on a ride through Bushwick, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Cruising down Knickerbocker Avenue in the back of a vintage Lincoln Town Car on a sunny Friday afternoon, I was thrilled when the driver, Modesto Jimenez, played the Fabolous track “Brooklyn,” loudly. The song, the Lincoln’s smooth ride, life passing by on the busy streets — the combination hit like theatrical umami.

headline: New Directors/New Films Turns 50 With a Bracingly Eclectic Lineup
abstract: For the showcase’s milestone anniversary, organizers have put together an eclectic program paired with a selection of films from past decades.
lead_paragraph: A wildly eclectic, cutting edge and globe-spanning lineup has always epitomized New Directors/New Films, the annual showcase of emerging filmmakers presented by Film at Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art. This year’s 50th anniversary edition is part of a citywide return to theaters, with in-person screenings taking place from Wednesday through to May 13. The program will also screen virtually (through May 8), along with an online retrospective of selections from decades past including early works by directors like Lee Chang-dong, Christopher Nolan and Charles Burnett.

headline: School Superintendents Are Superstressed
abstract: After this pandemic year, several superintendents across the country are leaving their jobs.
lead_paragraph: This year has been draining for pretty much everyone connected to schools: children stuck in Zoom classes, teachers worried about their health and their students, parents juggling their jobs while managing children learning from home. And for the district leaders responsible for managing it all, the pandemic has been a uniquely exhausting experience. Now some of them have decided to call it quits.

headline: Who Needs an Album? Just Keep Remaking the Song!
abstract: Recent hits by SpotemGottem and Lil Nas X show the power of extending the life of a single track, album be damned.
lead_paragraph: “Beat Box,” by the young Florida rapper SpotemGottem — a thunderous, pulsing sneer of a track — was released just over a year ago. It bubbled lightly throughout the summer and fall, and then in December came a remix, “Beat Box 2,” with the rising Memphis star Pooh Shiesty. Not long after, on Dec. 23, a dancer named Junebug posted a video doing an exaggeratedly comic shimmy dance step to the song. Called the #JunebugChallenge, it spread wildly on TikTok, replicated in oodles of videos.

headline: New York’s Spring of Optimism: Finally, the Second Virus Wave Is Ebbing
abstract: Virus cases and rates are plunging, and vaccination is rising, but one doctor cautioned, “We still have a long way to go.”
lead_paragraph: After months of persistently high coronavirus caseloads, New York City appears to have finally reached a turning point. The city’s second wave is ebbing, a half-year after it began, New York City’s health commissioner, Dr. Dave Chokshi, said.

headline: Fears About New Rules on Masks Outdoors
abstract: Readers worry about how the C.D.C. guidelines will play out. Also: Vaccines for India.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Citizen Kane’ Is No ‘Paddington 2,’ Says Rotten Tomatoes
abstract: After an 80-year-old pan resurfaced, the website Rotten Tomatoes recalculated and found that only 99 percent of critics had praised “Citizen Kane.”
lead_paragraph: There is perfect. And then there is almost perfect.

headline: Help! If There’s a Chance That I Could Endanger Others, Should I Still Travel?
abstract: Our Tripped Up columnist helps weigh the public health and ethical elements of traveling amid rising infection rates.
lead_paragraph: My husband and I are both fully vaccinated, and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says that we’re good to travel — with some modifications, of course.

headline: Cuomo Aides Spent Months Hiding Nursing Home Death Toll
abstract: Aides to the New York governor, Andrew M. Cuomo, repeatedly prevented state health officials from releasing the number of nursing home deaths in the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The effort by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s office to obscure the pandemic death toll in New York nursing homes was far greater than previously known, with aides repeatedly overruling state health officials over a span of at least five months, according to interviews and newly unearthed documents.

headline: Jack Ma Taunted China. Then Came His Fall.
abstract: Chinese regulators have a message for the finance sector: Tread carefully.
lead_paragraph: Ant Group, China’s biggest fintech conglomerate, was preparing last November for its initial public offering. Analysts projected it would raise $34 billion, the largest sale of shares in history. The company, founded by Jack Ma, had become synonymous with financial innovations, which are often risky.

headline: America’s Workplaces Are Still Too Dangerous
abstract: OSHA has saved many lives in its 50 years. But it can do more.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years ago today, when the Occupational Safety and Health Administration opened its doors, American workplaces were full of dangers. In 1970, an average of 38 workers were killed on the job every day, and many thousands more were injured or sickened by exposures to toxic chemicals. The law that created OSHA was revolutionary: It established, for the first time, the right to a safe workplace, free of serious hazards. Businesses had to comply with federal regulations and permit inspectors to examine their facilities.

headline: Valerie Cirillo-Bunch, a Child-Care Sage, Dies at 41
abstract: She worked with preschoolers, infants and their parents, “the mom that other moms looked up to.” She died of Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Vaccine Hesitancy Is as Old as Vaccines. I Take Comfort in That.
abstract: Vaccination campaigns have always, eventually, succeeded.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Almost 14 months into the coronavirus pandemic, vaccines are, for most of us, the key to getting out of lockdown and returning to lives that we recognize. And with more than a billion doses administered worldwide, there are reasons for hope — even if that hope is not spread evenly.

headline: Philadelphia Eagles G.M. Howie Roseman Talks Team’s Next Steps
abstract: Philadelphia’s general manager has come under fire in recent years for Carson Wentz’s contract, the team’s post-Super Bowl slide and reports of dysfunction in the front office.
lead_paragraph: Nick Foles. The Philly Special. The Lombardi Trophy parading down Broad Street.

headline: Chipotle Is Sued by New York City Over Scheduling Practices
abstract: The city seeks $150 million in relief for employees, accusing the fast-food giant of “complete disregard” of a law governing workweeks.
lead_paragraph: New York City on Wednesday sued the fast-food giant Chipotle Mexican Grill over what it says are hundreds of thousands of violations of a fair scheduling law at several dozen stores.

headline: Russian Spy Unit Investigated for Links to Bulgarian Explosions
abstract: The probe will look at whether Unit 29155, an elite group of Russian intelligence operatives, is connected to a series of blasts at ammunition depots over the past 10 years.
lead_paragraph: SOFIA, Bulgaria — The prosecutor general’s office in Bulgaria announced Wednesday that it was investigating a possible connection between a series of explosions at ammunition depots around the country and an elite group of Russian military intelligence operatives known as Unit 29155.

headline: New York Man Found Guilty of Threatening Democrats After Capitol Riot
abstract: Brendan Hunt said videos and social media posts calling for the slaughter of congressional Democrats were just jokes. Jurors were not convinced.
lead_paragraph: Brendan Hunt was struggling to find success as an actor in New York City when he discovered another way to become famous.

headline: France Arrests Leftist Militants Convicted of Terrorism Long Sought by Italy
abstract: The seven militants had been given refuge in France decades ago, a move which poisoned diplomatic ties between France and Italy. The arrests signal a strengthening of ties between the two governments.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French police on Wednesday arrested seven former members of Italian left-wing extremist groups who had been convicted of terrorism crimes in Italy decades ago, but were given refuge in France.

headline: Leaving Home, and Returning to It
abstract: New ways to fill the days.
lead_paragraph: Welcome. When the world opens up more, will we have less time? I was chatting with some of my colleagues about this last week, how the absence of a commute has led, some days, to a more spacious schedule, one with time to fold laundry between meetings, to walk the dog at lunch. Brian Hogan, a barber in suburban Des Moines, built a video store in his basement.

headline: 6 Art Gallery Shows to See Right Now
abstract: Gerald Jackson’s collages; Precious Okoyomon’s reimagined ecosystem; Damien Davis’s sculptures; Beverly Buchanan’s “shacks”; and more.
lead_paragraph: In its pairings of large and small shows, White Columns has come up with some extraordinary combinations, but its present one is especially excellent. The larger exhibition reintroduces the veteran artist and poet Gerald Jackson, now in his mid-80s, whose work was fearlessly multimedia long before it became the thing to do. The smaller show, “A Mountain Girl With Skyblue Teeth,” is the New York debut of a young painter, Daisy May Sheff, whose layered fantasies exude an overheated Fauvism of oranges, pinks, purples and greens populated by eccentric personages — all in a style best described as fluid-state Florine Stettheimer.

headline: Senate Begins Considering Diverse Slate of Biden Judicial Nominees
abstract: Democrats are hoping to remake the courts to counter the Trump administration’s conservative push.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Democrats on Wednesday began advancing President Biden’s first judicial nominees through the Senate Judiciary Committee, taking a significant step to counter the influence President Donald J. Trump had in steering the federal courts to the right.

headline: Facebook nearly doubles its profit and revenue rises 48 percent, as tech booms.
abstract: Nearly 3.5 billion people now use one of Facebook’s apps every month.
lead_paragraph: Facebook said on Wednesday that revenue rose 48 percent to $26.2 billion in the first three months of the year, while profits nearly doubled to $9.5 billion, underlining how the social network has continued to benefit during the pandemic.

headline: Court Could Consider Whether Trump Interfered in Cloud Computing Contract
abstract: The decision could be a win for Amazon, which said it was passed over for the $10 billion Pentagon contract because of his animosity toward its founder, Jeff Bezos.
lead_paragraph: A federal court said on Wednesday that it did not dismiss the possibility that former President Donald J. Trump interfered in the awarding of a military cloud-computing contract worth $10 billion, a decision that could result in the overhaul of a long-running effort to modernize technology at the Defense Department.

headline: N.Y.P.D. Robot Dog’s Run Is Cut Short After Fierce Backlash
abstract: The Police Department will return the device earlier than planned after critics seized on it as a dystopian example of overly aggressive policing.
lead_paragraph: When the Police Department acquired a robotic dog last year, officials heralded the four-legged device as a futuristic tool that could go places that were too dangerous to send officers.

headline: By Extending Emmert’s Deal, N.C.A.A. Shows Distance From College Sports’ Day-to-Day
abstract: Mark Emmert’s extension stunned conference commissioners and university athletic directors and reflected some stubbornness as the N.C.A.A. faces legacy-shaping reckonings.
lead_paragraph: Just over a month ago, when the N.C.A.A. was embroiled in another crisis of its own making, 21 board members joined a hastily called videoconference with Mark Emmert, the persistently embattled president of the governing body of college sports.

headline: German Intelligence Puts Coronavirus Deniers Under Surveillance
abstract: The country’s domestic intelligence agency says it will create a new department to deal with extremism among conspiracy theorists.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Germany’s domestic intelligence service said on Wednesday that it would surveil members of the increasingly aggressive coronavirus denier movement because they posed a risk of undermining the state.

headline: Global chip shortage will slash Ford’s production by about half in the second quarter.
abstract: Ford expects the shortage to lower its operating profit this year by $2.5 billion, to between $5.5 billion to $6.5 billion.
lead_paragraph: Ford Motor said on Wednesday that the global shortage of computer chips will take a greater toll on its business than previously expected and would likely cut its vehicle production in the second quarter by about half.

headline: What’s in Biden’s Spending Plan: Free Preschool and National Paid Leave
abstract: President Biden’s latest proposal is funded by raising taxes on wealthier Americans, and it is likely to encounter Republican resistance for that reason.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s $1.8 trillion spending and tax plan is aimed at bolstering the United States’ social safety net by expanding access to education, reducing the cost of child care and supporting women in the work force.

headline: Apple doubles its profits on soaring iPhone sales.
abstract: More people splurged on computers as they worked and learned from home, driving sales of Macs to grow by 70 percent.
lead_paragraph: Apple said on Wednesday that its profits more than doubled to $23.6 billion in the most recent quarter as people embraced its latest iPhones and bought more of its other products, striking results for what is already the world’s most valuable company.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: The variants feeding India’s outbreak.
lead_paragraph: Doctors, the public and the news media in India point to a so-called “double mutant” coronavirus variant — both more contagious and more resistant to vaccines — as the explanation for skyrocketing cases. Scientists say the data is too thin, and cite other possible reasons behind the country’s second wave.

headline: A Lively Supreme Court Argument Over a Cheerleader’s Vulgar Rant
abstract: The justices struggled to determine how the First Amendment applies to public schools’ power to punish students for social media posts and other off-campus speech.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a freewheeling two-hour argument on free speech in the age of social media, the Supreme Court seemed inclined to reject an appeals court’s sweeping ruling that the First Amendment does not allow public schools to punish students for what they say outside school grounds. Instead, the justices seemed to favor a modest decision that would leave many difficult questions unanswered.

headline: 25,000 Barrels Possibly Laced With DDT Are Found Off California Coast
abstract: One researcher said the number of discarded drums far exceeded his expectations. “It was hard to wrap my head around the density of targets,” he said.
lead_paragraph: In 2011, a curious marine scientist captured a series of photos of the ocean floor that left him disturbed. Using a sea drone, he documented dozens of corroding industrial barrels, scattered 12 miles off the coast of Los Angeles. Tests later showed that the sediment inside contained exceptionally high concentrations of DDT, a pesticide banned in the 1970s, and other chemical waste.

headline: Biden calls for a new era of government spending, saying, ‘We can’t stop now.’
abstract: The president urged lawmakers from both parties to embrace a sweeping new vision for public benefits, financed by higher taxes on the wealthiest Americans.
lead_paragraph: President Biden called for a broad reshaping of American society Wednesday night, using his first formal address to Congress to urge a vast expansion of safety net and educational programs while promising to harness the government to create jobs and opportunity for those often left behind.

headline: The G.O.P.-controlled Florida House passes an expansive bill of voting restrictions.
abstract: The legislation, which now heads back to the State Senate for a vote, would add strict new rules for drop boxes and new identification requirements for absentee ballots, among other measures.
lead_paragraph: A bill that would impose a raft of new restrictions on voting in Florida cleared the State House of Representatives on Wednesday after hours of contentious debate. Democrats denounced the legislation as overly stringent and unnecessary, and Republicans argued that it would install necessary “guardrails” for securing elections, despite their acknowledgment that the state’s election last year had been a “gold standard” without fraud.

headline: A Look at How We Gather Now
abstract: Eight photographers captured the joy and cautious optimism as people around the country emerged and came together now that spring is here and vaccination numbers have increased.
lead_paragraph: Eight photographers captured the joy and cautious optimism as people around the country emerged and came together now that spring is here and vaccination numbers have increased.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: Watch Pfizer make the vaccine.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times was recently given exclusive access inside the complex manufacturing process of the Pfizer vaccine, which takes 60 days to complete and spans three states.

headline: Is This the Oldest Bottle of American Whiskey? Is It Worth $40,000?
abstract: It was bottled after the Civil War, but tests show it was likely made in the late 18th century, offering a glimpse into early American distilling.
lead_paragraph: When Joseph Hyman, a rare spirits specialist for Skinner Auctioneers, first examined the brown-glass flask that his employer was preparing to sell, he already suspected it was one of the oldest bottles of American-made whiskey he’d ever seen.

headline: Senate confirms Samantha Power to be U.S.A.I.D. administrator.
abstract: Ms. Power said during her confirmation hearings that she will use the agency to combat China’s influence in regions including Africa, Eastern Europe and South America.

lead_paragraph: Gary Gensler’s tenure leading the Securities and Exchange Commission is off to a rocky start: Alex Oh, who he named just days ago to run the regulator’s enforcement division, has resigned following a federal court ruling in a case involving one of her corporate clients, ExxonMobil.

headline: Clara Lamore Walker, 94, Thwarted Olympian Redeemed in Her 50s, Dies
abstract: She gave up competitive swimming after the 1948 Games in London — until her doctor prescribed the pool for back pain. She staged an astonishing comeback.

headline: Biden’s $4 Trillion Economic Plan, in One Chart

headline: Hate Will Not Define My Life
abstract: A year of violence toward Asians and Asian-Americans forced me to grieve, then act.
lead_paragraph: On a gray morning, just before the first lockdown, I bundled up and went on a brisk walk in Central Park. As my friend and I rounded a bend along the path where tourists ride horse-drawn carriages, a hipster-looking white guy breezed by on his skateboard. He looked me straight in the eye and, enunciating clearly, uttered one word — a racial slur so insidious it won’t appear in this essay.

headline: How Do You Illustrate Resilience? These Graphic Novels Show the Way.
abstract: Among the books in her latest Graphic Content column, Hillary Chute looks at “A House Without Windows,” about the precarious lives and fighting spirits of children in the Central African Republic.
lead_paragraph: A HOUSE WITHOUT WINDOWS (Humanoids, 166 pp., $19.99) pulls off something difficult with a quiet beauty. It mixes photography and comics from page to page, marshaling the strengths of each in the service of a devastating topic: the precarious lives of children in the Central African Republic, the former French colony that is one of the poorest countries in the world.

headline: The Renaissance’s Most Influential Composer, 500 Years Later
abstract: Centuries after his death, Josquin des Prez’s achievements as a musical “magician-mathematician” remain stunning.
lead_paragraph: For the 250th anniversary of Beethoven’s birth, the classical music field pulled out all the stops last year, even in the midst of pandemic performance cancellations around the world. But while 2021 brings its own significant anniversary — in August it will be 500 years since the death of Josquin des Prez, the most influential composer of his age — few listeners will know it.

headline: If You Don’t Want to Go, Say No
abstract: Most social obligations would be best left in the Before Times.
lead_paragraph: When I was in my early 20s, my friends started calling me “The Bailer.” I was infamous for making plans and then canceling the day before. Even at the time, I knew this was irritating and ungenerous behavior. But I made the plans with the best intentions: I love my friends! I want to see their faces! That spoken-word event in a dank, low-ceilinged bar sounded like fun when you told me about it three weeks ago!

headline: For $800, You Too Can Sort of Be In On This Joke
abstract: Despite the fad, there’s little that’s fundamentally fresh in the NFT-art space.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, while browsing the internet, I came across a dark-blue rectangle for sale: “Monochrome Bleu Numérique.” I zoomed in, then out. I stared for long enough that I wondered whether it might have been a photograph of a photograph. A moment later it appeared to have a grainy texture, suggesting brush strokes on a canvas. But mostly it simply looked like a saturated, unnatural-seeming blue. This digital artwork, stored as a digital file, was for sale online when I first stumbled upon it for 0.3 Ether — the cryptocurrency for the blockchain platform Ethereum — worth more than $800, as of Tuesday night.

headline: The Math That Explains the End of the Pandemic

lead_paragraph: I intended to duly fulfill my duty as a political columnist and write about the first 100 days of Joe Biden’s presidency. My idea was to focus on the 50 Senate Democrats: They don’t have a single vote to spare, they have to broker deals that satisfy both Bernie Sanders and Joe Manchin — America does have a multiparty political system, it’s just tucked inside the Senate Democratic caucus — and yet they’ve held together pretty well, on a pretty ambitious agenda.

headline: They Survived Covid. Now They Need New Lungs.

lead_paragraph: BOSTON — He survived Covid-19, but his lungs were ravaged. After months of deep sedation, he is delirious, his muscles atrophied. And this 61-year-old still cannot breathe on his own.

headline: Why Is Perimenopause Still Such a Mystery?
abstract: Over 1 billion women around the world will have experienced perimenopause by 2025. But a culture that has spent years dismissing the process might explain why we don’t know more about it.
lead_paragraph: Angie McKaig calls it “peri brain” out loud, in meetings. That’s when the 49-year-old has moments of perimenopause-related brain fog so intense that she will forget the point she is trying to make in the middle of a sentence. Sometimes it will happen when she’s presenting to her colleagues in digital marketing at Canada’s largest bank in Toronto. But it can happen anywhere — she has forgotten her own address. Twice.

lead_paragraph: In a region where experts put the life expectancy for transgender women at only 30 to 35 years, Vicky Hernández didn’t make it even that long.

headline: ‘Dog Biting Dog’: China’s Online Fight Could Further Empower Beijing
abstract: Internet companies are using the threat of government action as a cudgel against rivals. That could make the Communist Party the ultimate arbiter over the industry.
lead_paragraph: Hours after the Chinese government imposed a record $2.8 billion fine on Alibaba, a veteran internet entrepreneur urged regulators to do something similar to his company’s biggest competitor.

headline: After Thoughts
abstract: 18 plans and proposals for when we emerge from the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Returning to public life happier in their trans body.

headline: At 100 Days, Biden Is Transforming What It Means to Be a Democrat
abstract: A lifelong centrist, President Biden has moved leftward with his party, and early in his tenure is driving the biggest expansion of American government in decades.
lead_paragraph: When Joseph R. Biden Jr. served as vice president in the Obama administration, he was known to preface his recommendations to other officials with a self-deprecating disclaimer. He may not have attended Harvard or Yale, Mr. Biden would say as he popped into an office or a meeting, but he was still a foreign policy expert, and he knew how to work Capitol Hill.

headline: We Know Where the Sheikh’s Horse Is. But Where Is His Daughter?
abstract: Essential Quality could win the Kentucky Derby. Activists concerned about Sheikha Latifa, the owner’s daughter, don’t think the horse should run at all.
lead_paragraph: LEXINGTON, Ky. — For nearly 40 years, Dubai’s ruler has spent vast sums here in central Kentucky. On thousands of acres of lush bluegrass with gently rolling hills mapped by limestone and plank fences. On horses — stallions and mares to populate his farms with foals and yearlings purchased in the sales ring.

headline: ‘Joy, Love, Grief’: How It Looks When Families Reunite
abstract: The pandemic kept nursing home residents and their loved ones apart for a year. Photographers for The New York Times were there when they finally reunited.
lead_paragraph: A daughter holding her mother’s hand. A son overcome that his 95-year-old mother survived the pandemic. A stoic family patriarch, suddenly in tears.

headline: How to Recognize and Treat Perimenopause and Menopause Symptoms
abstract: We break down the signs, causes and treatment options for five common symptoms.
lead_paragraph: Many women don’t know what to expect during perimenopause, which is the time period — often marked by distressing changes in the body — that leads up to menopause, or the end of a woman’s menstrual cycle and childbearing years. Those changes can come as a shock, so we broke down the signs, causes and treatment options for five common symptoms.

headline: A Candidate for N.Y.C. Mayor Is Accused of Sexual Assault
abstract: A woman who worked on a campaign decades ago with Scott M. Stringer, the comptroller, said she had feared retribution if she spoke out.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Airbus returns to profit but warns crisis is not over.
abstract: The company delivered 125 commercial aircraft to airlines in the three-month period, up from 122 a year earlier.
lead_paragraph: Airbus announced Thursday that it had returned to a profit in the first quarter following a 1.1 billion euro loss last year because of the coronavirus pandemic, but its top executive warned that the economic toll would continue.

headline: ‘We Have to Prove Democracy Still Works’
abstract: In his first address to Congress, President Biden made a case for vastly expanding the role of government — and taxing the wealthiest to pay for it.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday, President Biden gave his first address to a joint session of Congress.

headline: New David Hockney Billboards to Brighten 5 Cities in May
abstract: His chrysanthemum-like depictions of the sun will light up digital platforms in New York, Los Angeles, London, Tokyo and Seoul.
lead_paragraph: Two suns will appear in five cities during the month of May — the real sun in the sky, of course, but also the chrysanthemum-like depiction of it in a video by the British artist David Hockney. The 2½-minute animation will be broadcast on digital billboards in Times Square in New York and prominent locations in London, Los Angeles, Tokyo and Seoul.

headline: New York Times photographers capture families reuniting at nursing homes.
abstract: A daughter holding her mother’s hand. A son overcome that his 95-year-old mother had survived the pandemic. A stoic family patriarch, suddenly in tears.
lead_paragraph: A daughter holding her mother’s hand. A son overcome that his 95-year-old mother had survived the pandemic. A stoic family patriarch, suddenly in tears.

headline: Biden and the Vaccination Slowdown
abstract: President Biden speaks to the nation when much of the Covid news is good — but the pace of vaccination has slowed.
lead_paragraph: President Biden used the beginning of his speech to Congress last night to celebrate the speed of the country’s vaccination program. And he deserves a lot of credit for it.

headline: Navalny’s Network Crumbling Under Kremlin Pressure
abstract: As the jailed opposition leader made his first public appearance since a hunger strike, his associates said government pressure caused them to shut down regional offices.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Associates of Aleksei A. Navalny said they were shutting down their nationwide network of regional offices on Thursday even as the imprisoned Russian opposition leader vowed, in an online court appearance, to keep fighting the “emperor with no clothes” in the Kremlin.

headline: The Departed Could Soon Become Compost in Colorado
abstract: If the governor signs the bill, Colorado would be the second state to legalize the composting of human remains.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Food scraps and biodegradable utensils are common fodder for compost, but in Colorado, human remains could soon be transformed into soil too.

headline: ‘Limbo’ Review: A Musician in Exile Tunes Out
abstract: A Syrian refugee deposited on a remote Scottish isle seeks meaning in his isolated surroundings, with wryly funny results.
lead_paragraph: Most of the films we’ve seen about the migrant and refugee situation in Europe in recent years are gritty, often heartbreaking dramas and documentaries. “Limbo,” written and directed by a ferociously talented filmmaker, Ben Sharrock, takes an insinuating, poetic and often wryly funny approach. And it’s both heartbreaking and heartlifting.

headline: ‘Lucy, the Human Chimp’ Review: Far From Home
abstract: A domesticated chimpanzee is disastrously relocated to the wild in this deeply troubling documentary.
lead_paragraph: There’s a strange irony in the appalling trajectory of “Lucy the Human Chimp,” a documentary about an experiment that forced a chimp to live as a human, but resulted in requiring a human to live as a chimp.

headline: ‘Percy vs Goliath’ Review: Growing Pains
abstract: Christopher Walken plays a beleaguered farmer in this understated environmental drama.
lead_paragraph: “Percy vs Goliath” might be based on a 1998 Canadian legal battle and its fallout, but Clark Johnson’s ambling, warmhearted movie doesn’t lean on courtroom tension for drama. Addressing high stakes — the degree to which agribusiness controls our food supply — in an extremely low key, Johnson uses one family’s plight to illustrate the predicament of an entire industry.

headline: ‘The Outside Story’ Review: Brooklyn as No One Has Ever Known It
abstract: In this listless comedy by Casimir Nozkowski, a moping homebody locks himself out, but the resulting interaction with others helps to change his outlook.
lead_paragraph: The comedy “The Outside Story” takes a listless look at the life of Charles (Brian Tyree Henry), who is moping over his breakup with his unfaithful girlfriend, Isha (Sonequa Martin-Green). When Charles chases down a delivery person to offer a belated tip, he gets locked out of his Brooklyn apartment for a day and must set his self-pity aside.

headline: ‘Four Good Days’ Review: Repairing a Mother-Daughter Relationship
abstract: In this drama, Mila Kunis plays a heroin addict and Glenn Close the mother trying to help her get clean.
lead_paragraph: “Four Good Days” deals with the recoveries of two people: a heroin addict and her mother, who has given up on trusting her daughter.

headline: ‘Berlin Alexanderplatz’ Review: Reframing an Urban Classic
abstract: Burhan Qurbani’s film reinterprets a classic German novel into the story of a 21st-century immigrant from Guinea-Bissau surviving under the thumb of a brutal drug dealer.
lead_paragraph: Alfred Döblin’s masterpiece “Berlin Alexanderplatz” received its most famous dramatization not at the movies but on TV, with Rainer Werner Fassbinder’s 15-hour adaptation in 1980. Burhan Qurbani’s ambitious film by the same name re-centers the Weimar Era original on a 21st-century immigrant from Guinea-Bissau who seeks the straight and narrow but works for a psychopathic drug dealer.

headline: ‘Tom Clancy’s Without Remorse’ Review: A Routine Mission
abstract: Aside from a few set pieces, this action film, starring Michael B. Jordan, is a surprisingly dull adaptation of Clancy’s 1993 novel.
lead_paragraph: Situating the bulk of its action in 2019, “Tom Clancy’s Without Remorse” updates Clancy’s 1993 novel by opening with a prologue in Aleppo, Syria, and making reference to the Russian military presence in the country. But the geopolitics and relative lack of cyber-anything otherwise date the movie to a barely post-Cold War period, while the plot mechanics grind along like holdovers from Charles Bronson’s heyday.

headline: ‘Cliff Walkers’ Review: Double Crosses and Double Agents
abstract: Zhang Yimou turns his hand to a fast-paced spy thriller set during the Japanese occupation of Manchuria.
lead_paragraph: “Cliff Walkers,” the new picture from the protean Chinese director Zhang Yimou, arrives here after a hiccup in his filmography.

headline: ‘Eat Wheaties!’ Review: Chasing Ms. Banks
abstract: In this film, Tony Hale plays a man whose obsession with Elizabeth Banks almost ruins his life.
lead_paragraph: With his debut film, “Eat Wheaties!,” Scott Abramovitch has wrangled the kind of cast that most first-time directors dream of: a who’s-who of TV comedy that includes Tony Hale (“Arrested Development,” “Veep”), Elisha Cuthbert, Lamorne Morris, Sarah Chalke and Alan Tudyk. But what Abramovitch does with such a lineup is an unfortunate, unfunny mess.

headline: ‘About Endlessness’ Review: Heaven Knows I’m Miserable Now
abstract: Roy Andersson’s latest feature is a somber, exhilarating collection of self-defeating human specimens.
lead_paragraph: In his elegy for William Butler Yeats, W.H. Auden instructed poets to “sing of human unsuccess/in a rapture of distress.” The Swedish filmmaker Roy Andersson may be the great cinematic bard of failure and futility, though his version of rapture is a decidedly low-key affair. “About Endlessness,” his new feature, is at once gloomy and vivid, 76 minutes worth of vignettes that are individually somber and cumulatively exhilarating.

headline: ‘The Virtuoso’ Review: A Paid Killer, Hitting Bum Notes
abstract: Anson Mount plays the title character, who gets his assignments from Anthony Hopkins. But he keeps messing things up.
lead_paragraph: The existential anxiety of the paid assassin is a tricky theme — so tricky as to be potentially invalid, even. “The Virtuoso,” directed by Nick Stagliano from a script by James C. Wolf, misses its shot in a spectacular, and sometimes spectacularly pretentious, fashion.

headline: ‘Things Heard & Seen’ Review: Another Real Estate Nightmare
abstract: Amanda Seyfried and James Norton move into a haunted house in this busy, creaky Netflix thriller.
lead_paragraph: I’ll say this much for “Things Heard & Seen”: it absolutely lives up to its name. If, out of curiosity or inertia, you let your Netflix algorithm have its way for two hours, you will definitely hear and see some things, though you may have trouble afterward remembering just what those things were.

headline: Hong Kong eases some restrictions to encourage vaccinations, and other news from around the world.
abstract: Hong Kong eased restrictions on Thursday at restaurants and bars where staff and customers have begun receiving coronavirus vaccinations, part of an effort to help businesses hurt by the pandemic while attempting to boost an anemic inoculation drive.
lead_paragraph: Hong Kong eased restrictions on Thursday at restaurants and bars where staff and customers have begun receiving coronavirus vaccinations, part of an effort to help businesses hurt by the pandemic while attempting to boost an anemic inoculation drive.

headline: How Long Will These Children Live?
abstract: Tremendous gains on life expectancy have been made around the world, but huge gaps remain. We photographed scenes from the global fight for a more equal life span.
lead_paragraph: Tremendous gains on life expectancy have been made around the world, but huge gaps remain. We photographed scenes from the global fight for a more equal life span.

headline: What Grade Would You Give President Biden on His First 100 Days?
abstract: It’s report card time for the Biden administration. Have the president’s actions met your expectations?
lead_paragraph: When President Biden took office in January, we asked students what the new administration’s priorities should be. We heard from teenagers who wanted Mr. Biden to distribute coronavirus vaccines, support veterans, address police brutality, curb climate change and prioritize unity and bipartisanship.

headline: This ‘Angry’ Bird Is the Most Photogenic, Research Finds
abstract: Researchers in Germany reviewed more than 27,000 images to identify the world’s “most Instagrammable bird.” An odd-looking nocturnal species native to Australia and Southeast Asia stood out, they said.
lead_paragraph: With its broad, hooked beak and wide eyes, the frogmouth — a nocturnal bird that is sometimes mistaken for an owl — is a striking sight.

headline: Cows and Cellos
abstract: What story does this image inspire for you?

headline: The Lesson of Tony Blair’s Long Hair
abstract: The former British prime minister appeared in a recent television interview with a whole different look. It pushed a lot of buttons.
lead_paragraph: What is it with male politicians and their hair these days? After decades — centuries — of nondescript short cuts, their crowning glory has suddenly turned into a form of creative expression. And source of controversy.

headline: Biden’s Big Speech, by the Numbers
abstract: Here’s how he plans to spend $4 trillion.
lead_paragraph: Today is President Biden’s 100th day in office, and yesterday he delivered his first address to a joint session of Congress. In his speech, he laid out an agenda that, The Times’s Peter Baker writes, represents “a fundamental reorientation of the role of government not seen since the days of Lyndon B. Johnson’s Great Society and Roosevelt’s New Deal.” The centerpiece of his address was a plan for some $4 trillion in spending, split into two bills, on top of the $1.9 billion in economic aid already passed earlier in his term.

headline: Profits surge at Shell and Total, reflecting higher oil and gas prices.
abstract: Both companies are investing in renewable energy, but fossil fuels still drive their earnings.
lead_paragraph: Strong profit increases from two of Europe’s largest energy companies, Royal Dutch Shell and Total, demonstrated that what really matters for the financial performance of these companies remains the price of oil and natural gas.

headline: In a Dark Time, This Music Will Make You Smile
abstract: Four albums by young British composers from the label NMC show a wide-ranging, antic experimentalism.
lead_paragraph: Last fall, when the world was being told to expect a long, dark winter after what had already been a brutal year, I decided to search for some new, bracing orchestral music. It had been months since I’d been walloped by symphonic forces in a live setting. And if it was to be grim times ahead, I wanted at least some music that gestured toward that sense of scale.

headline: What to Expect in the First Round of the N.F.L. Draft
abstract: Five quarterbacks could go in the top 10 for the first time, according to mock drafts produced by several analysts, while the first round could pass without the selection of a running back.
lead_paragraph: Soon it will all be over — the guesses, the hunches, the smoke screens, the informed speculation, the uninformed speculation and, especially, the billions of mock drafts, which have elicited untold page views and paroxysms of internet rage but that as of around 8:15 p.m. Eastern time Thursday will be as relevant as the mock drafts released Friday for 2022.

headline: President Biden Gives a Pep Talk for Still-Unusual Times
abstract: This address was “just a little bit different” from last year, because of the pandemic — and the change of speaker.
lead_paragraph: “This gathering is just a little bit different,” President Joseph R. Biden Jr. said Wednesday night, opening his first address to a joint session of Congress.

headline: Comcast Earnings Spotlight the Media Industry’s Upheaval
abstract: As it takes the risk of transforming itself from a TV giant into a streaming start-up, the cable operator beat investors’ estimates in its first-quarter results.
lead_paragraph: If you want a clear picture of the state of the media industry in upheaval, Comcast offers a good snapshot.

headline: Biden is transforming what it means to be a Democrat.
abstract: Now 100 days into his presidency, President Biden is driving the biggest expansion of American government in decades, an effort to use $6 trillion in federal spending to address social and economic challenges at a scale not seen in a half-century. Aides say he has come into his own as a party leader in ways that his uneven political career didn’t always foretell, and that he is undeterred by matters that used to bother him, like having no Republican support for Democratic priorities.
lead_paragraph: Now 100 days into his presidency, President Biden is driving the biggest expansion of American government in decades, an effort to use $6 trillion in federal spending to address social and economic challenges at a scale not seen in a half-century. Aides say he has come into his own as a party leader in ways that his uneven political career didn’t always foretell, and that he is undeterred by matters that used to bother him, like having no Republican support for Democratic priorities.

headline: Sotheby’s and Phillips Announce Departures and Arrivals
abstract: The executive turnover in the auction world signals a market shift after the pandemic, an industry expert says.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, two of the three major auction houses announced shifts in the makeup of their leadership teams.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | May 5, 2021
abstract: How do Covid-19 infection rates in state prisons compare to rates in  state populations?

headline: Here’s How to Claim Your Stimulus Payments: File Your Tax Return
abstract: Thursday: In addition to three federal stimulus payments, some Californians also qualify for the Golden State Stimulus.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Microsoft plans to take a smaller cut from developers in its games store.
abstract: The fee will drop to 12 percent of revenue, from 30 percent, starting in August, the company said.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft will decrease the share of money it charges independent developers that publish PC games on its online store, starting in August, the company said on Thursday.

headline: ‘The Mitchells vs. the Machines’ Review: When Bots Attack
abstract: A family of lovable kooks are the last hope against a robot apocalypse in this hilarious animated Netflix film.
lead_paragraph: Nothing says “family bonding” like a road trip through a robot apocalypse. At least that’s the case for the Mitchells in the quirky and riotously funny Netflix animated film “The Mitchells vs. the Machines.”

headline: Do I Really Need to State My Pronouns?
abstract: A reader asks whether a workplace policy actually makes trans and nonbinary people feel more included.
lead_paragraph: My firm asked all employees to add our pronouns to our email signatures to promote inclusivity. So, I did: “He/him/his.” I am in sales and send out hundreds of outreach emails every week. Today, a potential customer replied: “Not interested.” He said he was “turned off by the unnecessary pronoun thing.” I support inclusivity. But this interaction made me wonder about the risks and rewards of my company’s policy. My email signature isn’t suddenly going to make anyone more welcoming to nonbinary people. But some may be turned off by it. And I don’t think leaving off my pronouns would offend anyone. Am I wrong?

headline: The Senate begins considering a diverse slate of Biden’s judicial nominees.
abstract: Democrats have begun advancing President Biden’s first judicial nominees through the Senate Judiciary Committee, taking a significant step to counter the influence President Donald J. Trump had in steering the federal courts to the right.
lead_paragraph: Democrats have begun advancing President Biden’s first judicial nominees through the Senate Judiciary Committee, taking a significant step to counter the influence President Donald J. Trump had in steering the federal courts to the right.

headline: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
abstract: Never-before-seen drawings by Kenny Rivero, a new tableware line from Yotam Ottolenghi — and more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we share things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

headline: She Bought a Truck on eBay, Then Forgot It. A Dementia Diagnosis Came Later.
abstract: Impulsive purchases, out-of-control spending: These behaviors can be early signs of Alzheimer’s disease or other cognitive decline.
lead_paragraph: After Maria Turner’s minivan was totaled in an accident a dozen years ago, she grew impatient waiting for the insurance company to process the claim.

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
abstract: This week’s properties are a four-bedroom house in Skillman, N.J., and a six-bedroom house in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are a four-bedroom house in Skillman, N.J., and a six-bedroom house in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.
