headline: Pope Francis Issues Law to Combat Corruption in the Vatican
abstract: Cardinals and other church officials will be required to make detailed financial disclosures and decline most gifts.
lead_paragraph: ROME — In an effort to fight corruption in the highest ranks of the Roman Catholic Church, Pope Francis issued a sweeping new decree on Thursday compelling top managers at the Vatican — including cardinals — to provide full financial disclosures and to refuse any gifts worth more than roughly $50.

headline: The S.E.C. delays a long-awaited decision on whether to allow a Bitcoin fund.
abstract: For many cryptocurrency supporters and investors, regulatory approval of a Bitcoin exchange-traded fund in the United States represents the holy grail. It would allow the crypto-curious to get exposure to Bitcoin without having to buy the tokens themselves, signifying that digital assets are really, truly mainstream.
lead_paragraph: For many cryptocurrency supporters and investors, regulatory approval of a Bitcoin exchange-traded fund in the United States represents the holy grail. It would allow the crypto-curious to get exposure to Bitcoin without having to buy the tokens themselves, signifying that digital assets are really, truly mainstream.

headline: Patti Harrison Wants to See What She Can Do
abstract: Known for scene-stealing side characters, the comedian and actress is pushing past her limits with her starring role in “Together Together.”
lead_paragraph: Patti Harrison, the actress and comedian, has taken one acting class in her life, an introductory course at Ohio University. “It was taught by a grad student and was very loose,” she said. “We mostly just did yoga.”

headline: When Are the Olympics? Here’s the Schedule for Tokyo.
abstract: The opening ceremony will be held July 23, with gymnastics, swimming and other sports beginning soon after.
lead_paragraph: The Tokyo Olympics, delayed for a year because of the coronavirus pandemic, are now scheduled for late July and early August. The time difference between Japan and the United States may make it tricky to figure out what will happen when, but we’re here to help.

headline: France sets a timeline to emerge from a third lockdown, and other news from around the world.
abstract: European governments are looking to ease restrictions as vaccinations ramp up and the number of new virus cases falls.
lead_paragraph: President Emmanuel Macron of France outlined plans on Thursday for the gradual reopening of the country, plotting a path out of the labyrinth of restrictions in place and fueling hope that life might finally return to normal after waves of infections forced the country into three national lockdowns.

headline: What drove the first-quarter economy: spending on goods.
abstract: Government payments made wallets fatter, and consumers took advantage.
lead_paragraph: The first-quarter economic recovery, when the economy expanded 1.6 percent, was powered by spending. Specifically, by spending on stuff.

headline: German High Court Hands Youth a Victory in Climate Change Fight
abstract: The government must expand its plan to reduce carbon emissions to zero by 2050, the country’s highest court ruled. The decision requires lawmakers to make long-term commitments.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Germany’s highest court ordered the government to expand a 2019 law aimed at bringing the country’s carbon emissions down to nearly zero by 2050, ruling on Thursday that the legislation did not go far enough to ensure that future generations would be protected.

headline: The Economy Is (Almost) Back. It Is Looking Different Than It Used To.
abstract: The recovery is profoundly unequal across sectors, unbalanced in ways that have big implications for businesses and workers.
lead_paragraph: There have been a lot of strange economic numbers over the last 14 months, as the world has been whipsawed by the pandemic. But one particular line of the first-quarter G.D.P. numbers released Thursday stands out even so.

headline: ‘Marighella’ Review: Battle for Brazil
abstract: Wagner Moura’s provocative feature debut chronicles the armed struggle led by Carlos Marighella against Brazil’s military dictatorship in the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: In 2018, the Brazilian president Jair Bolsonaro declared that he wanted “a Brazil similar to the one we had 40, 50 years ago”— referring to the era of the country’s military dictatorship, which saw violent censorship and the torture of dissidents.

headline: E.U. Says Americans Can Come, but Europeans Wonder How
abstract: In tourist-dependent countries, the announcement was called good news, but with lockdowns in place and vaccination slow, many wonder how realistic it is.
lead_paragraph: On March 31, President Emmanuel Macron of France announced the start of a third national lockdown in a bid to control the spread of a new deadly wave of the coronavirus. Domestic travel between regions is forbidden and restaurants, bars and cafes remain closed.

headline: Do I Have to Get the Covid Vaccine in My Arm?
abstract: Most people will roll up their sleeves for the injection, but some may want to consider an alternate body part.
lead_paragraph: By now most people are familiar with how the Covid-19 vaccine is typically administered: a quick jab to the upper arm. But there is a lesser known place on the body where the vaccine has also been approved for injection: the thigh.

headline: Biden Calls for U.S. to Enter a New Superpower Struggle
abstract: Competition with China and containment of Russia were the subtext of the president’s call for action. But casting the struggle as “democracy versus autocracy” oversimplifies what lies ahead.
lead_paragraph: President Biden has justified his broad vision to remake the American economy as the necessary step to survive long-run competition with China, a foot race in which the United States must prove not only that democracies can deliver, but that it can continue to out-innovate and outproduce the world’s most successful authoritarian state.

headline: The World Knows Her as ‘Disaster Girl.’ She Just Made $500,000 Off the Meme.
abstract: Zoë Roth, now a college senior in North Carolina, plans to use the proceeds from this month’s NFT auction to pay off student loans and donate to charity.
lead_paragraph: The name Zoë Roth might not ring any bells. But chances are you’ve seen her photo.

headline: McDonald’s says sales are back to prepandemic levels.
abstract: Chicken was one of the big drivers for growth in the U.S. The company’s new chicken sandwich is selling substantially better than its previous offering.
lead_paragraph: McDonald’s said Thursday that sales of Big Macs, chicken nuggets and french fries got back to prepandemic levels in the first part of the year.

headline: Mask On or Off? Life Is Getting Back to Normal, and We’re Rusty.
abstract: After the C.D.C. issued new guidelines, people are figuring out how to proceed. Some want to keep their face coverings on: “It saves me having to put on sunscreen.”
lead_paragraph: Mark Rasch hopped on his bike Tuesday in Bethesda, Md., pedaled off for an afternoon ride, and realized he forgot his mask. As he turned back for it, news came on the radio over his earbuds: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said masks were no longer required outdoors for fully vaccinated people unless they were in a crowd.

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: There are woods near my house where I sometimes head when I’m craving green shadows and stillness, a reminder that time and nature have very little to do with the human scale of things. Very little — but not nothing: As Scott Weidensaul points out in his new book about migratory birds, “A World on the Wing,” humans are deeply implicated in the recent decimation of aviation species. If you love the woods as I do, this book will make you more alert to the chirrups and whistles and flashes of movement in the canopy above you and give you new respect for birds’ incredible abilities. It’s one of our recommended titles this week.

headline: Joe Biden Has the Vision. Now Chuck Schumer Has to Bring It to Life.
abstract: The Senate majority leader, marking his own 100 days in charge, is responsible for turning sweeping Democratic plans into law. It’s a tall order.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden laid out his ambitious vision for a post-pandemic America on Wednesday night. Now it is up to Senator Chuck Schumer to make it a reality.

headline: What’s in Our Queue? ‘Survivor’ and More
abstract: I’m a reporter for the Culture Desk with a focus on music. Here are five ways I've been entertaining myself lately.
lead_paragraph: I’m a reporter for the Culture Desk with a focus on music. Here are five ways I've been entertaining myself lately.

headline: Senators announce proposed law removing commanders from military sexual assault cases.
abstract: Senator Kirsten Gillibrand, a Democrat from New York, has pushed for the legislation for years and finally has bipartisan support for the bill.
lead_paragraph: For nearly a decade, Senator Kirsten Gillibrand, Democrat of New York, has tried to pass legislation that would remove military commanders from their role in prosecuting service members for sexual assault.

headline: Don’t Ignore Ransomware. It’s Bad.
abstract: Ransomware attacks can bring down schools and hospitals. It’s time we took them more seriously.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: Rajan Mishra, Classical Indian Vocalist, Dies at 69
abstract: Part of a famous duet with his brother, he brought traditional ragas to generations of young musicians. He died of Covid 19-related complications.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Food Is Not a Prop for Senator Jessica Ramos. It’s a Platform.
abstract: The New York State lawmaker has made a name by leading food causes, speaking up for street vendors, farm workers and the many restaurants in her Queens district.
lead_paragraph: Last spring, when long lines at food pantries first began to form in Queens — where the coronavirus struck harder than almost anywhere else in the country — Jessica Ramos, a New York state senator, knew whom to call to feed her neighbors.

headline: How to Clean White Sneakers
abstract: Here’s how to get your well-worn shoes looking their best.
lead_paragraph: Here’s how to get your well-worn shoes looking their best.

headline: No, Other People’s Covid Vaccines Can’t Disrupt Your Menstrual Cycle
abstract: You can’t experience effects from being near someone who is vaccinated, because it is biologically impossible for the vaccine material to be transmitted from person to person.
lead_paragraph: In recent weeks, people who oppose Covid vaccinations have spread a claim that is not only false but defies the rules of biology: that being near someone who has received a vaccine can disrupt a woman’s menstrual cycle or cause a miscarriage.

headline: Review: A New ‘Mosquito Coast,’ This Time With Narcos
abstract: An Apple TV+ series radically reimagines the Paul Theroux novel, even though it stars his nephew Justin.
lead_paragraph: The television series called “The Mosquito Coast” that premieres Friday on Apple TV+ has so little in common with the best-selling 1981 novel of that name that comparison doesn’t get you far. This is true even though the novelist, Paul Theroux, is an executive producer of the show and his nephew Justin Theroux is the star.

headline: A Photographer Looks Deep Into America’s Past
abstract: Dawoud Bey’s images at the Whitney Museum expose rich histories hidden beneath the surface, how places evolve over time.
lead_paragraph: Before he became a photographer, Dawoud Bey trained as a jazz percussionist, looking to John Coltrane as a role model for melding craft with a commitment to social justice. As a teenager in the 1960s, Bey was finely attuned to the social and political upheavals of the civil rights movement, staging sit-ins and demonstrations with his high school classmates and joining the Black Panther Party, whose newspaper he sold on the weekends. By 1968, the struggle for racial equality was converging with demonstrations against the war in Vietnam and the early stages of women’s liberation, forming a pattern of transformation and upheaval that culminated with the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

headline: Facing Droughts, California Challenges Nestlé Over Water Use
abstract: A draft cease-and-desist letter sent to BlueTriton — known until this month as Nestlé Waters North America — is the latest development in a yearslong battle over water resources in the San Bernardino area.
lead_paragraph: After another dry winter that threatens to worsen water shortages across California, state officials have accused a water bottling company of diverting too much water from forests in the San Bernardino area.

headline: ‘Fat Ham’ Review: A Queer, Black ‘Hamlet’? Ay, There’s the Spice Rub.
abstract: Set at a Southern barbecue, James Ijames’s hilarious update on Shakespeare sees a recipe for liberation in the story of family disaster.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps the real tragedy of “Hamlet” is that it doesn’t end with a dance party; too many of its characters lie dead at the final curtain for anyone to shake a leg.

headline: Good Luck to Republicans if Biden’s Family Plan Becomes Law
abstract: Helping families will help create jobs.
lead_paragraph: Conservatives beware: If the main elements in Joe Biden’s American Family Plan become law, they’ll be very hard to repeal. Why? Because they’ll deliver huge, indeed transformational benefits to millions.

headline: A Sharp Divide at the Supreme Court Over a One-Letter Word
abstract: In an immigration ruling that scrambled the usual alliances, the justices differed over the significance of the article “a.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Thursday ruled that the government must comply strictly with a requirement that immigrants receive detailed notices about their deportation hearings.

headline: No Need to Take Risks to Prove Friendship
abstract: “Yes, we need to work at our friendships to maintain them, but is it fair to gauge a relationship by a willingness to take risks during a pandemic?” a reader asks.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Biden’s Ambitious Agenda for America
abstract: Readers mostly laud the president’s speech and sweeping plans. “I take back every bad thing that I said about Joe Biden during the primaries,” one reader says.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Pakistan warns of new strictures as its daily Covid death toll sets a record.
abstract: Dire reports from neighboring India are persuading more Pakistanis to seek vaccinations, though the country’s supply is limited so far.
lead_paragraph: With Covid-19 deaths surging to records in Pakistan this week, the government has sent troops to the streets to help enforce coronavirus precautions, and is warning it may turn to a lockdown if the spread is not controlled.

headline: 5 People, Including 2 Deputies, Are Killed in North Carolina Standoff
abstract: A 13-hour standoff with a gunman, who barricaded himself inside a house in Boone, N.C., ended at about 11 p.m. on Wednesday. Officials said the gunman was one of the dead.
lead_paragraph: Two sheriff’s deputies were among four people who were killed in a 13-hour standoff in Boone, N.C., that the authorities said started on Wednesday morning when they were called to the home of a man who had not shown up for work.

headline: Biden says he was not told the F.B.I. planned to search Giuliani’s office and home.
abstract: President Biden, who has vowed to restore the independence of the Justice Department, said in an interview with NBC that it was “not the role of the president to say who should be prosecuted.”
lead_paragraph: President Biden said on Thursday that he was not told in advance about the F.B.I.’s execution of search warrants at Rudolph W. Giuliani’s office and home, citing his pledge not to meddle in law enforcement matters.

headline: Turkey braces for its strictest lockdown yet, as the virus surges and vaccinations lag.
abstract: With an order about to take effect keeping people at home for three weeks except for essential errands and jobs, many Turks rushed to stock their pantries or flee crowded cities.
lead_paragraph: The streets of Istanbul were abuzz, the grocery stores packed, the seaside promenades crowded — but it was not the bustle of an ordinary spring Thursday. People were flocking to take advantage of the last day before a new lockdown takes hold, the strictest in Turkey since the pandemic began.

headline: Cuomo Loses Another Key Aide as Vaccine Czar Steps Down
abstract: Larry Schwartz resigned from his volunteer post after the State Legislature amended a law that would have subjected him to a two-year ban from lobbying the state.
lead_paragraph: Larry Schwartz, one of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s most trusted advisers, unexpectedly stepped down from his role as New York State’s vaccine czar, about five months after he was recruited by the governor to spearhead the state’s vaccine rollout.

headline: ‘The Traveling Zoo’: Life on the Road, With Pets at Their Side
abstract: Many truckers depend on the companionship of dogs, cats, birds, pigs — or even a hedgehog.
lead_paragraph: It can get lonely on the road, but Rebecca Washington, a long-distance trucker who is sometimes away from home for months on end, has Ziggy, Polly, Junior and Tucker along for the ride: her “rig dogs.”

headline: How to Breathe New Life Into Martha Graham’s Dances? Infuse Them With Art.
abstract: As part of GrahamFest95, the choreographer’s dance company celebrates its 95th anniversary with four films pairing dances with works by Hauser & Wirth artists.
lead_paragraph: If the pandemic has taught Janet Eilber anything, it’s this: “I’m always reminded how potent Martha’s work is,” she said, “when we mess with it.”

headline: Telemedicine Is a Tool. Not a Replacement for Your Doctor’s Touch.
abstract: Covid-19 made virtual medicine a popular investment. But patients should beware.
lead_paragraph: Earlier in the pandemic it was vital to see doctors over platforms like Zoom or FaceTime when in-person appointments posed risks of coronavirus exposure. Insurers were forced — often for the first time — to reimburse for all sorts of virtual medical visits and generally at the same price as in-person consultations.

headline: Only 8 Black Students Are Admitted to Stuyvesant High School
abstract: Once again, tiny numbers of Black and Latino students received offers to attend New York City’s elite public high schools.
lead_paragraph: After a year in which the pandemic shined a harsh spotlight on the stark inequities in New York City’s school system, the city announced Thursday that, once again, only tiny numbers of Black and Latino students had been admitted into top public high schools. The numbers represent the latest signal that efforts to desegregate those schools while maintaining an admissions exam are failing.

headline: The Vanished Glamour of Midcentury Print Media
abstract: Great examples of photography and editorial design abound at the Jewish Museum. (Catch the catalog, too.)
lead_paragraph: In a city whose news kiosks have become glorified chewing gum emporiums, where the Grand Central newsstand shelves are overtaken by chips and phone chargers, one of my few remaining happy places is Casa Magazines. It’s a hole of a shop on the corner of Eighth Avenue and 12th Street, and every wall and every inch of floor heaves with obscure, international fashion and design publications, for a dwindling class of print lovers. (I still remember, when I founded a magazine in 2015, the relief I felt when I saw my first issue piled on the floor of Casa; then it was real.) Once upon a time, before New York was swallowed into the smartphone screen, the city had dozens of shops like this. Now, if you care about fashion photography and print design, you probably belong in a museum.

headline: Be It a $10 Wine, or Much More, the Judgments Come Free
abstract: Inexpensive wines can be just fine. They also illuminate the harsh opinions that some people seem to cherish about the preferences of others.
lead_paragraph: Of all the undying clichés about wine, perhaps the one I hear most often is, “There’s no correlation between price and quality.”

headline: Txakolina for Good Cheer, Wherever You May Be
abstract: This slightly effervescent wine, from Spanish Basque Country, is easy to enjoy on seasides, with seafood and in the sunshine.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been craving outdoor time with friends whom I barely saw through the long pandemic winter. Here in New York City, I think we’ve finally seen the last of the cold.

headline: Does It Matter if I Skip My Second Covid Shot?
abstract: Your second dose of vaccine gives you more protection than you might think. Here’s why you should still get it, even if it’s later than planned.
lead_paragraph: Millions of people have missed their second dose of Covid-19 vaccine. But does it really matter?

headline: Cathy Park Hong
abstract: The Asian-American poet wants to help women and people of color find healing — and clarity — in their rage.
lead_paragraph: “Who is us? What is us? Is there even such a concept as an Asian-American consciousness?” The writer Cathy Park Hong searches for answers to these questions in her book of essays, “Minor Feelings: An Asian American Reckoning.” Hong’s book, which came out in February 2020, has taken on new urgency with the rise in anti-Asian violence and discrimination during the pandemic. Today, Hong joins Jenna and Wesley to discuss the usefulness of rage, and her experience of speaking for — and listening to — the Asian-American community.

headline: Twitter’s revenue jumps 28 percent in its first post-Trump quarter.
abstract: Twitter’s permanent ban of former President Donald J. Trump did not appear to hurt activity. The company saw a 20 percent jump in daily active users who see ads in the first three months of the year.
lead_paragraph: Twitter said on Thursday that its revenue in the first quarter of the year was $1.04 billion, a 28 percent increase from the same quarter the previous year that modestly exceeded analyst expectations. Net income for the quarter was $68 million, a turnaround from an $8.4 million loss in the same quarter a year ago.

headline: Central Asian Border Dispute Casts Shadow Over U.S. Afghan Departure
abstract: Fighting between Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan raised the specter of instability in the region as the United States prepares to leave Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Fighting broke out on Thursday between Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan over control of an irrigation canal and an access road to an ethnic enclave, raising the specter of instability in Central Asia as the United States prepares to withdraw from Afghanistan.

headline: The C.D.C. eases rules for cruises, making mid-July trips possible.
abstract: Cruise companies will be allowed to skip test voyages and won’t be required to file as much paperwork under the new guidelines.
lead_paragraph: Cruise ships that have been docked for more than a year could restart sailing in United States waters by mid-July, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said in a letter sent to the cruise industry late on Wednesday.

headline: Biden Is Giving Child Care ‘Prime-Time Attention.’ Can He Actually Transform It?
abstract: A turbulent pandemic, more women in Congress and decades of advocacy have set the stage for a complete overhaul of the child care system, experts said.
lead_paragraph: — Senator Patty Murray of Washington

headline: F.D.A. Announces Plan to Ban Menthol Cigarettes and Flavored Cigars
abstract: Agency leaders say the move is a science-based approach to curbing addiction and will save hundreds of thousands of lives over time.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday announced its long-awaited plan to ban the last flavor still allowed in cigarettes — menthol — and also said it would ban all flavors of mass-produced cigars, which are popular among youths. The ban would apply only to sales, manufacturing and imports — not personal possession.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Looking for something to watch? This weekend offers aliens, whales and the final season of “Pose.”
lead_paragraph: Every Monday and Friday, Margaret offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.

headline: Amazon’s profit soars 220 percent as pandemic drives shopping online.
abstract: The high volume of orders during the pandemic has let Amazon operate more efficiently.
lead_paragraph: With the pandemic shifting sales online and consumers flush with stimulus checks, Amazon on Thursday reported $108.5 billion in sales in the first three months of the year, up 44 percent from a year earlier. It also posted $8.1 billion in profit, an increase of 220 percent from the same period last year.

headline: After a Year of Loss, South America Suffers Worst Death Tolls Yet
abstract: If the world doesn’t stop the region’s surging caseload, it could cost us all that we’ve done to fight the pandemic, one health official said.
lead_paragraph: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — In the capital of Colombia, Bogotá, the mayor is warning residents to brace for “the worst two weeks of our lives.”

headline: What Is ‘Cheugy’? You Know It When You See It.
abstract: Out of touch? Basic? A new term to describe a certain aesthetic is gaining popularity on TikTok.
lead_paragraph: “OK TikTok, I have a new word for you that my friends and I use that you clearly are all in need of,” Hallie Cain, 24, a copywriter in Los Angeles says in a TikTok posted on March 30.

headline: Overlooked No More: Inji Efflatoun, Egyptian Artist of the People
abstract: She was born into the aristrocacy but became an activist for commoners while depicting social injustices in her paintings.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

headline: Auto sales helped get the American economy off to a good start in 2021.
abstract: Stimulus payments, pent-up demand and low interest rates lifted sales and prices.
lead_paragraph: In the first months of 2021, what was good for the auto industry was decidedly good for the American economy.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: A burst of growth in the U.S. economy.
lead_paragraph: In the first three months of 2021, the U.S. shook off some of the lingering effects of the pandemic on its economy. Consumer spending grew 2.6 percent and the first-quarter growth rate reached 6.4 percent. Economists predict overall economic activity could return to prepandemic levels in the current quarter.

headline: A 22-Million-Year Journey From the Asteroid Belt to Botswana
abstract: Astronomers reconstructed a space rock’s path before it exploded over southern Africa in 2018 and sprinkled the Kalahari with meteorites.
lead_paragraph: On the morning of June 2, 2018, an asteroid was seen careening toward us at 38,000 miles per hour. It was going to impact Earth, and there was nothing anyone could do to stop it. Astronomers were beside themselves with excitement.

headline: Anthony Powell, Oscar-Winning Costume Designer, Dies at 85
abstract: He was honored for “Travels With My Aunt,” “Death on the Nile” and “Tess.” He was also renowned for the outlandish outfits he created for Glenn Close as the evil Cruella de Vil.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Powell, an inventive British costume designer who won three Oscars but is perhaps best known for the outlandish clothing he conceived for Glenn Close as the fur-loving Cruella de Vil in “101 Dalmatians” and its sequel, died on April 16 in London. He was 85.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: Despite new federal guidelines, many Americans are finding it difficult to take off their masks.
lead_paragraph: The new mask guidance from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which says that vaccinated people can go barefaced in most outdoor settings, is a baby step back to normalcy. But after the trauma of the past year, many Americans are finding it difficult to uncover their faces so quickly — let alone return to their old ways.

headline: Star Polymers, Space Origami and Singing Finches: The Winners of Our 2nd Annual STEM Writing Contest
abstract: From snake venom and egg shells to Alzheimer’s and Covid-19, students explain concepts from the world of science, technology, engineering and math.
lead_paragraph: Where do scientists — and science writers — get their ideas? They pay close attention to the world around them and ask questions, then look for answers to the ones that fascinate them most.

headline: What Students Are Saying About ‘Learning Loss’ During the Pandemic
abstract: We invited teenagers to weigh in on a current debate in education. They supplied some important nuance.
lead_paragraph: In the article “Does It Hurt Children to Measure Pandemic Learning Loss?,” Dana Goldstein explores the debate among educators about how to measure learning gaps experienced during the pandemic — if we should measure them at all, that is.

headline: Sacrifice Fly Pushes Orioles Past Yankees in Extra Innings
abstract: Trey Mancini was Baltimore’s offensive star in the victory. Philadelphia’s Bryce Harper is OK after a scary hit-by-pitch.
lead_paragraph: Cedric Mullins delivered a winning sacrifice fly in the 10th inning, Trey Mancini had his first three-hit game since returning from colon cancer surgery, and the Baltimore Orioles beat the Yankees, 4-3, Thursday for a four-game series split.

headline: U.S. Economy, Menthol Cigarettes, N.F.L.: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: ‘A Perfect Positive Storm’: Bonkers Dollars for Big Tech
abstract: The dictionary doesn’t have enough superlatives to describe what’s happening to the five biggest technology companies, raising uncomfortable questions for their C.E.O.s.
lead_paragraph: In the Great Recession more than a decade ago, big tech companies hit a rough patch just like everyone else. Now they have become unquestioned winners of the pandemic economy.

headline: Five Charged in Shooting of Lady Gaga’s Dog Walker
abstract: The dog walker was critically injured and two of Lady Gaga’s French bulldogs were stolen in the violent robbery in Hollywood on Feb. 24, the police said.
lead_paragraph: Five people have been arrested and charged in connection with a violent attack in February in which a man who was walking Lady Gaga’s French bulldogs in Hollywood was shot and two of the dogs were stolen, the Los Angeles police said on Thursday.

headline: The Mayor Promises a Summer to Remember in New York. Can He Deliver?
abstract: A pledge from Mayor Bill de Blasio that New York City would fully reopen on July 1 brought hope. But his vision of a city reborn faces significant obstacles.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio declared on Thursday that New York City would fully reopen on July 1, conjuring up a tantalizing vision of a summer in which the nation’s largest city would throw open its doors and return to its prepandemic vibrancy.

headline: Firing of U.S. Ambassador Is at Center of Giuliani Investigation
abstract: Prosecutors want to scrutinize Rudolph W. Giuliani’s communications with Ukrainian officials about the ouster of the ambassador, Marie L. Yovanovitch.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, Rudolph W. Giuliani finally got one thing he had been seeking in Ukraine: The Trump administration removed the U.S. ambassador there, a woman Mr. Giuliani believed had been obstructing his efforts to dig up dirt on the Biden family.

headline: 8 Indicted in Fraternity Hazing Death of Bowling Green Student
abstract: Stone Foltz, a 20-year-old sophomore at the university in Ohio, died on March 7, three days after he had attended an off-campus Pi Kappa Alpha event.
lead_paragraph: Eight people have been indicted in connection with the death last month of a sophomore at Bowling Green State University in Ohio, days after he had attended an off-campus fraternity event where school officials have said “alleged hazing activity” took place, prosecutors said on Thursday.

headline: Jill Corey, 85, Coal Miner’s Daughter Turned Singing Sensation, Dies
abstract: The subject of a Life magazine cover story, she found early fame as a star of ’50s era television and drew comparisons to Judy Garland.
lead_paragraph: Jill Corey, a torch singer who soared to fame as a teenage television star in the early 1950s, at one point becoming one of Columbia Records’ top vocalists, died on April 3 at a hospital in Pittsburgh. She was 85.

headline: Biden, in Georgia to Promote Economic Agenda, Visits Carter
abstract: A day after his first address to Congress, President Biden met with former President Jimmy Carter and held a drive-in rally for his 100th day in office.
lead_paragraph: President Biden visited former President Jimmy Carter, an old friend, as he traveled to Georgia on Thursday to pitch his $4 trillion economic agenda.

headline: Michelle T. Boone Named President of Poetry Foundation
abstract: Boone, a former cultural commissioner for Chicago, will take the helm after tumult over racial justice at the foundation, one of the country’s wealthiest literary organizations.
lead_paragraph: Michelle T. Boone, a former commissioner of cultural affairs for the City of Chicago, has been named president of the Poetry Foundation, nearly a year after the previous president resigned amid an intense outcry over the Chicago-based organization’s perceived lack of commitment to social justice.

headline: Senate Passes $35 Billion Water Bill, but Bigger Infrastructure Fights Loom
abstract: The lopsided vote was a reminder that bipartisan cooperation on public works projects is possible, but lawmakers in both parties said the spirit of compromise could be fleeting.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Thursday overwhelmingly approved a $35 billion measure to clean up the nation’s water systems, offering a brief moment of bipartisan cooperation amid deep divisions between the two parties over President Biden’s much larger ambitions for a multitrillion-dollar infrastructure package.

headline: Give Power to the Parents!
abstract: Biden gets family policy half right.
lead_paragraph: We live in a diverse country, where people have a lot of different preferences about how to live. For example, a 2016 Pew Research Center survey found that 59 percent of Americans believed children with two parents were better off if one parent stayed at home, but 39 percent thought children were just as well off if both parents worked.

headline: President Biden’s first formal address drew nearly 27 million viewers.
abstract: His speech came later in his presidency than those delivered by his recent predecessors, which all took place in February.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 27 million people watched President Biden’s first formal address to a joint session of Congress on Wednesday night, a large audience for television these days but a much smaller audience than similar speeches by other presidents, according to data from Nielsen.

headline: Inside the Chauvin Jury Room: 11 of 12 Jurors Were Ready to Convict Right Away
abstract: One juror described the seven hours of closed-door deliberations that led to Derek Chauvin’s murder conviction.
lead_paragraph: Seated at tables six feet apart in a hotel conference room, 12 jurors scribbled letters on slips of paper to indicate how they were leaning on a murder charge against Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer on trial for killing George Floyd.

headline: Weekly Health Quiz: Alcohol, Covid Vaccine and Fat Fathers
abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Mass Vaccination, India’s Covid-19 Escape Route, Poses a Giant Challenge
abstract: Overwhelmed by the pandemic, the country that is a leading maker of vaccines is facing its own crisis at home — and that may be a problem for a world in need of vaccine.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — India is the world’s leading producer of vaccines, but over the past week it has also been the global leader in Covid-19 deaths, and it is not at all clear that the country can vaccinate itself out of the crisis.

headline: How Is the G.O.P. Angling to Attack Biden?
abstract: As Republicans search for a winning message, they’re trying out strategies both old and new.
lead_paragraph: As Senator Tim Scott delivered the Republican Party’s rebuttal to President Biden’s congressional address on Wednesday night, he had a big-picture question to confront: Where will the party go, in a time when it is split between two factions?

headline: Sexual Assault Allegation Against Stringer Upends N.Y.C. Mayor’s Race
abstract: All three major female Democratic candidates for mayor have called on Scott Stringer, who has denied the allegation, to drop out of the primary contest.
lead_paragraph: A bombshell sexual misconduct accusation against Scott M. Stringer pushed two major questions to the forefront of New York City’s mayoral race: Could the claim be corroborated, and how would Mr. Stringer’s campaign be affected by the allegation?

headline: Palestinian Vote Delayed, Prolonging Split for West Bank and Gaza
abstract: President Mahmoud Abbas said elections could not take place unless Israel allowed voting in East Jerusalem. But privately, he also fears a poor result for his party, officials said.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — When the Palestinian Authority called in January for parliamentary elections, many Palestinians hoped the vote — the first in the occupied territories since 2006 — would revive Palestinian discourse, re-energize the independence movement and end a 14-year division between Palestinian leaders in the occupied West Bank and Gaza.

headline: Stampede at Israel Religious Celebration Kills at Least 45
abstract: An estimated 100,000 people had gathered on Mount Meron to celebrate a religious holiday. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu called it a “terrible disaster.”
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A stampede early Friday at a mountainside religious celebration in Israel that drew tens of thousands of ultra-Orthodox Jews left at least 45 people dead and scores more injured.

headline: America Is Brutal to Parents. Biden Is Trying to Change That.
abstract: We're finally on the cusp of a humane family policy.
lead_paragraph: When Patty Murray joined the Senate in 1993, one of the first bills she worked on was the Family and Medical Leave Act, which guaranteed 12 weeks of unpaid family leave for people who worked at companies with 50 or more employees.

headline: N.F.L. draft order and picks: Here are the first round results.
abstract: Trevor Lawrence was taken with the first pick by the Jacksonville Jaguars.
lead_paragraph: 1. Jacksonville Jaguars — Trevor Lawrence (quarterback, Clemson)

headline: With Zach Wilson, the Jets hope to end their decades-long QB search.

headline: Pence, in his first speech since leaving office, speaks fondly of Trump.

lead_paragraph: In his first political speech since leaving office, former Vice President Mike Pence made clear that despite his grim falling out with former President Donald J. Trump, his days of trying to ingratiate himself to his former boss are far from over as he plots his political future.

headline: Film Club: ‘Sensations of Sound’
abstract: At age 20, Rachel Kolb received cochlear implants that gave her partial hearing. In virtual reality, experience how music felt for her, before and after. Then consider: What does music feel like to you?

headline: Shake-Up at Covid Vaccine Manufacturer That Tossed Millions of Doses
abstract: Emergent BioSolutions’ C.E.O. announced several executive changes but vigorously defended the company, which is on track for record revenues.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Executives of Emergent BioSolutions, the Covid-19 vaccine manufacturer that was forced to discard up to 15 million doses because of possible contamination, reported a shake-up in leadership on Thursday and offered the most fulsome defense yet of the company’s performance.

headline: Florida Republicans Pass Voting Limits in Broad Elections Bill
abstract: The bill, which Gov. Ron DeSantis is expected to sign, is the latest Republican effort to restrict voting after the 2020 election. It will make Florida the first major swing state won by Donald Trump to pass such a law.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Republicans in the Florida Legislature passed an election overhaul bill on Thursday that is set to usher in a host of voting restrictions in one of the most critical battleground states in the country, adding to the national push by G.O.P. state lawmakers to reduce voting access.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Hauling Loads, With Pets at Their Side

headline: Corrections: April 30, 2021
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, April 30, 2021.
lead_paragraph: An obituary on Sunday about Allon Schoener, the curator who organized the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s 1969 show “Harlem on My Mind,” referred imprecisely to the paintings damaged as part of a protest against that show. Although initial news reports said that one of them was a Rembrandt, subsequent scholarship suggests that it was not. And a picture caption with the obituary misstated the given name of one of the people shown with Mr. Schoener. She is A’Lelia Nelson, not Lelia.

headline: Biden will meet with South Korea’s president on May 21.

headline: Idaho Lawmaker Accused of Raping an Intern Resigns

lead_paragraph: An Idaho lawmaker who the police say is the focus of a criminal investigation into allegations that he raped a 19-year-old female legislative intern last month resigned on Thursday — the same day that an ethics committee recommended that he be suspended.

headline: Raiders take the fifth Alabama player drafted in the first round.
abstract: The Las Vegas Raiders, eager to replenish their offensive line, took Alex Leatherwood of Alabama at No. 17. Last year, Leatherwood (6-foot-5, 312 pounds) won the Outland Trophy, given to the best interior lineman in college football, after allowing just five sacks in 1,400 pass-block snaps. Yet the pick was something of a surprise, because higher-rated linemen were still available.

He is an elite tackle-breaker once he has the ball.

lead_paragraph: A 37-year-old man was fatally injured on Thursday evening when a car collided with his Yamaha motorbike and then crashed into an outdoor dining structure on a busy block of Astoria, Queens, the police said.

headline: What to Know About India’s Coronavirus Crisis
abstract: What is behind the explosion of new coronavirus cases that is overwhelming the South Asian country?
lead_paragraph: A deadly second wave of coronavirus infections is devastating India, leaving millions of people infected and putting stress on the country’s already overtaxed health care system.

headline: He Delivered for Me

lead_paragraph: For the first year of our relationship, I didn’t know his name and didn’t welcome his interruptions. I felt hassled by the unexpected knock on my window, which was necessary to get my attention because my apartment lacked a doorbell.

headline: ‘Triumph’ Review: Going to the Mat
abstract: The film tells the story of an aspiring high school wrestler with cerebral palsy.
lead_paragraph: “Triumph” tells the story of Mike (RJ Mitte), a high school senior in the 1980s who aspires to join the wrestling team. Because he has cerebral palsy, even adults who admire his resolve — like Coach Warren (Terrence Howard), who teaches Mike in a phys-ed class, and Mike’s single father (Johnathon Schaech) — don’t initially believe he can do it. Directed by Brett Leonard, the film was inspired by the experiences of its screenwriter, Michael D. Coffey.

headline: Expert Picks: Who Will Win the Kentucky Derby
abstract: Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert weigh in on the contenders for the 147th running of the Kentucky Derby.
lead_paragraph: The horses for the 147th running of the Kentucky Derby are listed in order of post position, with comments by Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert of The New York Times. The morning-line odds were set by Mike Battaglia of Churchill Downs.

headline: As Underclassmen Flood the N.F.L. Draft, Landing Places Dry Up
abstract: Since the league began allowing underclassmen to enter the draft in 1990, the number who do so has ballooned more than threefold. There are fewer options for those who go undrafted.
lead_paragraph: Clifton Duck may watch a bit of the N.F.L. draft this weekend, as he has in previous years. But he may not. “It’s everyone’s dream to go to the draft on TV,” he said. “But it’s a long, uncontrolled process, and you can’t determine what happens.”

lead_paragraph: Contrasting economic data released on both sides of the Atlantic this week conveys a simple but powerful message: It pays to unleash enormous quantities of public money and vaccines in the face of a lethal, livelihood-destroying pandemic.

headline: Frank Bowling’s New Paintings Are Family Affairs
abstract: With help from close relatives, the 87-year-old artist is still working, even if he doesn’t apply the paint himself.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — On a recent afternoon behind a scruffy door in South London, remarkable alchemical transformations were taking place under the watchful eye of the painter Frank Bowling. Wearing industrial masks, a team of assistants brushed and dolloped ammonia, gold powder, acrylic gel and water onto a dripping canvas hung onto Bowling’s studio wall.

headline: Would You Want to Live to 200?
abstract: Life expectancy doubled over the last century. Radically extending life is possible in this one. How long would you want to live?
lead_paragraph: From 1920 to 2020, the average human life span doubled. Medical and social advances such as the development of vaccines, germ theory and antibiotics, chlorinated water and pasteurized milk have reduced childhood deaths, mitigated diseases of old age and vastly prolonged life. The United Nations estimates that there were about 95,000 centenarians (people who live to 100) in 1990 and more than 450,000 in 2015.

headline: From Nigella Lawson to David Chang, Chefs Narrate the Stories Behind the Dishes
abstract: New audiobooks to queue up in or out of the kitchen.
lead_paragraph: Puttering around the kitchen, I’m almost always listening to an audiobook — often while consulting a recipe. But until recently, I had never listened to a cookbook, which seemed about as enticing as listening to someone read the phone book. Then I pressed play on COOK, EAT, REPEAT (HarperAudio, 11 hours, 42 minutes), by Nigella Lawson, narrated by the author in her plummy BBC English. I was transfixed.

headline: New in Paperback: ‘All Adults Here’ and ‘Fire in Paradise’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: DOWN THE HIGHWAY: The Life of Bob Dylan, by Howard Sounes. (Grove, 608 pp., $22.) This 20th-anniversary edition celebrating Dylan’s upcoming 80th birthday includes a new chapter by the author on the past 10 years of Dylan’s life. “No matter the time or place,” Perry Meisel wrote in his 2001 review of the book in these pages, “Dylan comes alive, strumming his guitar in a studio in Nashville or hurrying down Macdougal Street with the collar of his leather jacket turned up against the wind.”

From 2016 to 2019, the couple dated while separated by the Hudson River and three New Jersey counties.

lead_paragraph: The United States is in a muddle over how to tell our history, stuck between an aggressive  revisionism that would leave few commemorative statues standing, and a stubborn clinging to all the founding myths, no matter how odious or inaccurate.

lead_paragraph: In “The Aspern Papers,” the Henry James novella of literary obsession, a biographer becomes fixated on a stash of secret letters belonging to an elderly woman who was once his subject’s girlfriend. Abandoning all his moral scruples, he persuades her to take him in as her tenant and pretends to court her niece.

headline: Biden’s First 100 Days Would Make Trump Jealous
abstract: Is the president just finding wholesome-sounding reasons for doing what his predecessor  tried to do?
lead_paragraph: Joe Biden’s inauguration, with its camp authoritarian light displays and general atmosphere of praetorian menace, was exactly the sort of swearing-in that his predecessor might have relished. Roughly a hundred days into Mr. Biden’s presidency, it is hard to escape the feeling that his administration, too, could end up being one that Donald Trump will envy.

lead_paragraph: Gabrielle Alyse Neimand caught a glimpse of a tiger the length of Micah Lennon McEachen’s forearm as they shared a tray full of cupcakes at their friend’s cupcake tasting in Los Angeles on Feb. 13, 2015.

lead_paragraph: When Evie Ebert had her first child five years ago, she started noticing something interesting. Every Mother’s Day, her social media feeds would be full of perfectly styled picnics and cooing captions like, “Felt so celebrated today!” But later, when she logged on to the private mom groups she was part of, the same women were telling a different story.

headline: Surprise Family Reunion Videos Are Giving Us All the Feels

lead_paragraph: Josh Reynolds, who works in tech sales and lives in American Fork, Utah, got vaccinated without telling his extended family. Two weeks after his second shot, in the middle of April, Mr. Reynolds, 29, took his wife and younger brother, both also vaccinated, and 6-month-old daughter, to New Jersey. They rented a car at the airport and pulled up outside the house of his uncle, whom they hadn’t seen since before the pandemic.

He previewed a two-pronged economic package: the $2.25 trillion American Jobs Plan and the $1.8 trillion American Families Plan. He spoke about the need to pass universal background checks for firearms, comprehensive immigration reform, and the George Floyd Justice in Policing Act.

headline: Where Should You Buy Your Books?
abstract: Bookstore or Amazon? Curbside pickup or delivery? We answer common questions readers might have.
lead_paragraph: The last year has seen expanded options for buying books online, as more bookstores have developed websites, and e-commerce sites like Bookshop.org gain traction. But massive retailers like Amazon continue to dominate the bookselling business, and readers may be torn between the desire to support local bookstores and the convenience and price of online delivery giants. Here, booksellers and literary agents offer advice on how to evaluate your book buying options.

headline: Pro-Biden Group to Begin Ad Campaign Promoting His Agenda in Swing States
abstract: Building Back Together will highlight the president’s coronavirus response and his economic plan and will contrast his measured approach to his bombastic predecessor’s.

headline: Want to Move to Our Town? Here’s $10,000 and a Free Bike.
abstract: With offers of cash, housing and a budding talent pool, smaller cities and states hope to get in on the ground floor of a new era for remote workers.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Hill Booker has spent much of her professional life on the road. Ms. Booker, 45, a chef and entrepreneur, is the author of two cookbooks, and her travels on the lecture circuit have taken her around the country — but always back to Atlanta, where she lived with her two children. Then, last year, with her daughters off at college, she realized there was nothing keeping her there. “I am an empty nester looking for that next stage in my life,” she said.

lead_paragraph: As fall is to leaf-peeping, spring is to waterfall-watching, a seasonal pursuit now underway in the northern and higher regions of the United States.

headline: Alexia’s Lifelong Nurse Has to Leave Her. Here’s Why.

headline: Israel Mourns After a Religious Festival Turns Into Disaster
abstract: There were warnings for years that the venue on Mount Meron, where 45 people died in a stampede, could not handle tens of thousands of pilgrims.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — As Israelis mourned on Friday the 45 people trampled to death during a pilgrimage that drew tens of thousands of ultra-Orthodox Jews, questions were already arising about poor planning and possible negligence.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘As Covid-19 Devastates India, Deaths Go Undercounted’
abstract: In this lesson, students will learn about the crisis in India and explore ways to help.
lead_paragraph: Note to teachers: This lesson draws on Times resources that contain graphic images and descriptions of death and cremation. Please preview the featured article, “As Covid-19 Devastates India, Deaths Go Undercounted” by Jeffrey Gettleman, Sameer Yasir, Hari Kumar and Suhasini Raj, to make sure it is appropriate for your students.

headline: From dancing to business meetings, Britain tests how restriction-free events can happen safely.
abstract: Scientists hope that monitoring events will give them insights into how to reduce the risk of the virus spreading.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of people letting loose on a nightclub dance floor. Hundreds of suited-up people gathering for a business conference. And none of them wearing masks.

headline: Why Times Opinion Decided to Publish This Slur
abstract: On today’s guest essay by John McWhorter.
lead_paragraph: This article also appears in the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it in your inbox each weekday morning.

headline: Over 6 Years and 211 Spots, a British Man Conquers a Parking Lot
abstract: Gareth Wild made it his mission to park in every eligible spot of his local Sainsbury’s grocery store. No one tried to stop him.
lead_paragraph: Michelangelo spent four years painting the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel, Tolstoy devoted six to “War and Peace,” and the Mughal emperor Shah Jahan took more than twice that to erect the Taj Mahal.

headline: What We Learned in the 2021 N.F.L. Draft
abstract: Quarterbacks still come first, Alabama still produces talent and Aaron Rodgers is still unhappy.
lead_paragraph: The first round of the 2021 N.F.L. draft proceeded on Thursday night according to the league’s strict hierarchy: quarterbacks came first, followed by those who catch passes from them and protect them, with the defenders tasked with stopping them bringing up the rear.

headline: How the N-Word Became Unsayable
abstract: The evolution of the slur's use — and the taboo around it — tells a story about what our culture values.
lead_paragraph: This article contains obscenities and racial slurs, fully spelled out. Ezekiel Kweku, the Opinion politics editor, and Kathleen Kingsbury, the Opinion editor, wrote about how and why we came to the decision to publish these words in Friday’s edition of the Opinion Today newsletter.

headline: Renovating Your Kitchen This Summer? Proceed With Caution.
abstract: Supply chain problems and labor shortages have made home improvement projects even more complicated.
lead_paragraph: The salesman for the cabinets I was about to order stood in my kitchen a few weeks ago, looking worried. Normally, he would wait until after a contractor had gutted my kitchen to take final measurements, because these semi-custom cabinets ordinarily take three or four weeks to arrive. Now, because of pandemic-related delays, they would take 13 weeks, maybe more.

headline: A Refugee Who Fought Back Against the Hard Right
abstract: Alassa Mfouapon was falsely accused by a German tabloid and a far-right leader of starting a violent protest. So he sued them, and won.
lead_paragraph: GELSENKIRCHEN, Germany — The country’s largest-circulation tabloid called him the “scandal asylum seeker” and accused him (falsely) of entering the country illegally. People hacked his social media accounts and broadcast his location and personal information. A far-right political leader decried him as the “ringleader” of a violent protest, while another even suggested people like him would be a good reason to bring back the death penalty in Germany.

headline: Lawyer for Navalny Is Arrested in Moscow
abstract: Ivan Pavlov was defending the opposition leader’s organizations from accusations of extremism.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The lead lawyer defending the Russian opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny in an extremism case that could outlaw Mr. Navalny’s opposition movement was arrested on Friday, the latest instance of a remarkable escalation by the Kremlin in its long-running campaign to stifle dissent.

headline: Australian Politician Loses Court Fight Over Twisted Sister Song
abstract: Clive Palmer was ordered to pay more than $1 million for using “We’re Not Gonna Take It” in his party’s political advertising.
lead_paragraph: An Australian politician was ordered on Friday to pay Universal Music more than $1 million for using the Twisted Sister song “We’re Not Gonna Take It” in his party’s advertising.

headline: Exxon Mobil and Chevron report first quarterly profits after several losses.
abstract: Oil prices have climbed in recent months and are now roughly where they were before the pandemic’s full force was felt.
lead_paragraph: Exxon Mobil and Chevron, the two biggest oil companies in the United States, on Friday reported their first quarterly profits after several quarters of losses, signaling that the energy industry is rebounding from the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: The British Army’s Legacy in Iraq and Afghanistan
abstract: A new book looks at the changes the British Army has undergone and roles it has played as an almost volunteer sidekick to the American military in the war on terror.
lead_paragraph: You’re reading this week’s At War newsletter. Sign up here to get it delivered to your inbox every Friday. Email us at atwar@nytimes.com.

headline: Bust of Elie Wiesel Is Added to Washington National Cathedral
abstract: The stone carving of the Holocaust survivor and author took two years to create and is the first modern-day Jewish representation in the cathedral.
lead_paragraph: In the western section of the Washington National Cathedral, cathedral leaders have long commemorated human rights figures. Stone carvings of Rosa Parks, Mother Teresa and other celebrated leaders grace the walls of the so-called “human rights porch.”

headline: What to Know About California’s Drought
abstract: Friday: A primer on the state’s drought conditions — and what to expect this summer. Also: Disneyland reopens.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Volkswagen’s gag falls flat as the S.E.C. begins an inquiry.
abstract: The carmaker’s American unit was kidding when it said it was changing its name to “Voltswagen,” but publicly listed companies are not supposed to fool their shareholders.
lead_paragraph: Volkswagen’s American unit was only kidding when it put out the word late in March that it was changing its name to “Voltswagen” to show its commitment to electric vehicles. To say the April Fool’s joke didn’t land is an understatement. Now the misfired marketing gag has prompted an inquiry by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: The True Cost of Closing the Racial Wealth Gap
abstract: Policies like forgiving debt for all student loans and giving baby bonds to the whole population won’t be nearly enough to achieve racial wealth parity, an economist says.
lead_paragraph: Elimination of the wealth gap between Black and white Americans is a stated goal of President Biden and the Democratic Party. The gulf is enormous any way you look at it.

headline: It’s Not Just the Really Wealthy Who Face Tax Increases
abstract: Financial advisers say they have been flooded with calls from clients who are trying to predict which of President Biden’s tax proposals will become law.
lead_paragraph: President Biden this week proposed significant increases in taxes on the wealthy. And while the details are likely to change as the legislation makes its way through Congress, wealthy Americans were scrambling to lock in tax savings before they even knew what the proposal was.

headline: Banks Were Allowed to Give People More Access to Savings in the Pandemic
abstract: But the rule change by the Federal Reserve Board didn’t require banks to drop their limits, and some haven’t.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, as the economy shut down during the pandemic and millions lost their jobs, the Federal Reserve Board changed a banking rule to give people easier access to the money in their savings accounts.

headline: A Grudge Match in Japan: One Corner, Two 7-Elevens
abstract: Inside the war between a very powerful company and a very stubborn franchisee, complete with threats, spies and videotape.
lead_paragraph: HIGASHI-OSAKA, Japan — Across Japan, it can seem as if there’s a 7-Eleven on every corner.

headline: The Longtime Home of Gloria Gaynor Comes on the Market
abstract: The singer who assured us that, “I Will Survive,” is renovating another house in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: The singer who assured us that, “I Will Survive,” is renovating another house in New Jersey.

headline: Gloria Gaynor’s Contemporary House Back on the Market
abstract: Ms. Gaynor, best known for the disco hits “I Will Survive” and “Never Can Say Goodbye,” is listing the two-story home in Green Brook, N.J., for $1.249 million.
lead_paragraph: Gloria Gaynor’s longtime residence, a sprawling contemporary in Green Brook, N.J., with an enclosed heated pool, a home theater and lots of closets, is back on the market. The asking price is $1.249 million.

headline: ‘Death Is the Only Truth.’ Watching India’s Funeral Pyres Burn.
abstract: Graphic images of mass cremations cut through the Indian government’s wall of noise, misinformation and propaganda about its handling of the Covid-19 crisis.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The first 36 corpses were placed in the designated concrete cremation pits and set ablaze by 10 in the morning. After that, all the extra bodies went to the muddy parking lot, for a mass ceremony later.

headline: Why British Police Shows Are Better
abstract: When you take away guns and shootings, you have more time to explore grief, guilt, and the psychological complexity of crime.
lead_paragraph: When you take away guns and shootings, you have more time to explore grief, guilt, and the psychological complexity of crime.

headline: BAFTA Suspends Award for Actor Noel Clarke Amid Harassment Allegations
abstract: The British actor and director has been accused of sexual assault, harassment and bullying by 20 women in a published report.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The body that awards Britain’s equivalent of the Oscars has suspended a prominent actor and director weeks after he received one of its top awards, following accusations of sexual assault, sexual harassment and bullying from 20 women.

headline: True Romance: Janet Mock on the Final Season of ‘Pose’
abstract: As Mock says goodbye to the groundbreaking drama that changed her life, she is planning to make more television that shows people that they are not alone.
lead_paragraph: A year and a half ago, Janet Mock, a writer, director and executive producer on the FX drama “Pose,” began to plan a wedding. A big wedding. In a big ballroom. With music and flowers and a bride so heart-shatteringly beautiful that the groom would cry as soon as he glimpsed her at the top of the aisle.

headline: Germany Sets Out Plans to Return Benin Bronzes
abstract: The government, regional legislators and major museums said they would make “substantial” returns of the famous West African artifacts starting next year.
lead_paragraph: Germany will begin returning a “substantial” number of the priceless artifacts known as the Benin Bronzes from its museums to Nigeria next year, its culture ministry said on Thursday night.

headline: The Next Reconstruction
abstract: The devastation of the coronavirus, and the surge in support for Black Lives Matter that followed the killing of George Floyd, have presented the United States with its best opportunity in 150 years to remake American society and belatedly fulfill its promise as a multiracial democracy.
lead_paragraph: The devastation of the coronavirus, and the surge in support for Black Lives Matter that followed the killing of George Floyd, have presented the United States with its best opportunity in 150 years to remake American society and belatedly fulfill its promise as a multiracial democracy.

lead_paragraph: The director Stefano Sollima narrates a plane crash sequence in his action thriller starring Michael B. Jordan.

abstract: Stefano Sollima, the director of “Tom Clancy’s Without Remorse,” narrates a sequence from his action thriller.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: When the Goals Come Out of Nowhere
abstract: A Greek striker is one of the top scorers in Europe, and his play has caught the eye of big clubs. But are his goals a product of his talent, or his environment?
lead_paragraph: Giorgos Giakoumakis had never scored goals. Not in great numbers, anyway. He had played 22 games, spread across three seasons, before he finally managed a single one for his first club, a team of modest ambitions and close horizons called Platanias, based on his home island, Crete.

headline: The Last Creature You’d Expect Left Mysterious Trails on the Ocean Floor
abstract: Something with no legs, no feet and no skeleton is crawling around down there, scientists say.
lead_paragraph: Deep-sea sponges are not known for their mobility. After all, they lack muscles, nervous systems and organs. And forget about fins or feet for traveling the Arctic seafloor.

headline: Clotilda Douglas-Yakimchuk, Pioneering Nurse, Dies at 89
abstract: Breaking color barriers, she devoted herself to social justice, the education of Black youth and the well-being of older people. She died of Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Rossini at the Drive-In, as San Francisco Opera Returns
abstract: Honks instead of applause: An open-air “Barber of Seville” brought the company back after 16 months.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It feels almost too good to be true after a pandemic closure of Wagnerian scale: an audience watching a cast of singers enter the War Memorial Opera House here to rehearse and perform Rossini’s classic comedy “The Barber of Seville.”

headline: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
abstract: These new movies offer scares from around the world, including an Indonesian witch and an Irish vampire.
lead_paragraph: These new horror movies offer scares from a global perspective, including an Indonesian witch, an Irish vampire, Canadian home invaders and an American family nightmare.

headline: The New York Philharmonic Is Coming. In a Shipping Container.
abstract: Over four weekends in May, NY Phil Bandwagon 2 will visit parks around New York City for weekend-long residencies.
lead_paragraph: Late last summer, the august New York Philharmonic took a swerve toward scrappiness.

headline: Harvey Weinstein to Face Charges in Los Angeles as Early as May
abstract: The producer faces more than a dozen counts of sexual assault involving five different women.
lead_paragraph: For a year, Harvey Weinstein has been fighting attempts to extradite him from a prison near Buffalo, N.Y., to Los Angeles, a city where he was once feted as a visionary film producer and now faces multiple charges of rape and sexual assault.

headline: Gnocchi, Leeks, Soupy Greens: What Else Do You Need?
abstract: Wine-braised chard and those tender potato dumplings make a one-pot meal that’s perfect for the still-chilly nights of spring.
lead_paragraph: The blooming of farmers’ markets in New York happens a lot later in spring than I want it to. March and April pass, and warm days eventually catch up to the chilly ones. But the stalls remain mostly populated by overwintered leeks and spinach, and last season’s potatoes, onions and apples.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week 🌙

lead_paragraph: This week, the late-night hosts riffed on President Biden’s congressional address, the Oscars and Rudy Giuliani.

headline: Tomas Estes, Who Put Tequila on a Pedestal, Dies at 75
abstract: Starting with a popular Mexican restaurant in Amsterdam, he helped place the drink on the same shelf as fine cognac and single-malt Scotch.
lead_paragraph: Tomas Estes, who gave up a career teaching high school English to open Mexican bars and restaurants across Europe, in the process helping to transform the image of tequila from frat-house rotgut to a fine spirit that could sit on a shelf alongside cognac and single malt whisky, died on April 25 at his home in Ashland, Wash. He was 75.

headline: Maryland hotel mogul continues his quest for Tribune Publishing as time runs out.
abstract: Stewart Bainum is making a third try to keep the newspaper chain away from the hedge fund Alden Global Capital, which is poised to be the company’s next owner.
lead_paragraph: With time running out, Stewart W. Bainum Jr. is making a renewed effort to buy Tribune Publishing, the newspaper chain that agreed in February to sell itself to its largest shareholder, the hedge fund Alden Global Capital.

headline: A Sidewalk Clock Standing Proudly in Queens Gets a Restoration
abstract: Local leaders raised the funds, but mysteriously, there was no record of what the battered timepiece looked like when it was installed more than 100 years ago.
lead_paragraph: On a busy strip of Jamaica Avenue in Queens, where vendors hawk cellphone cases outside shops selling off-price wigs, tattoo services and fungal-nail care, stands one of downtown Jamaica’s most dignified residents. This street-corner denizen is an ornate cast-iron sidewalk clock, more than a century old, attired with archaic formality like a proud codger who still wears his threadbare suit every day, even as the world passes him by.

headline: The Bureaucrat From Buffalo Who Pushed Somalia to the Brink
abstract: His bid to stay in office an extra two years, without elections, has led to gunfights in the capital and fears that Somalia is backsliding into a disastrous conflict.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — During his years as an administrator at the Department of Transportation in upstate New York, the Somali refugee turned American citizen took classes in political science, imbibing democratic values he hoped to one day export back to his homeland.

headline: How Big Tech Won the Pandemic
abstract: A year ago even the tech giants were anxious. Now they have so much money it’s awkward.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: National-Security Surveillance Plummeted Amid Pandemic and Russia Inquiry Fallout
abstract: But the F.B.I. is still using residual authority to obtain business records under a partly expired Patriot Act provision, a new report showed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The number of people targeted by the F.B.I. for court-approved searches and surveillance in terrorism and espionage investigations dropped sharply in 2020, a report released Friday said, amid the pandemic and the continuing political and legal fallout from the F.B.I.’s botched use of its eavesdropping power in the Trump-Russia investigation.

headline: Faith, Freedom, Fear: Rural America’s Covid Vaccine Skeptics
abstract: Resistance is widespread in white, Republican communities like this one in Appalachia. But it’s far more complicated than just a partisan divide.
lead_paragraph: GREENEVILLE, Tenn.— “So have you gotten the vaccine yet?”

headline: Al Schmitt, Maestro of Recorded Sound, Is Dead at 91
abstract: The winner of multiple Grammys, he engineered or produced records by Frank Sinatra, Ray Charles, Paul McCartney, Bob Dylan, Jefferson Airplane and many others.
lead_paragraph: Al Schmitt, who as a boy watched Bing Crosby and the Andrews Sisters record music in his uncle’s studio, and who went on to become a Grammy Award-winning engineer for a long roster of artists including Paul McCartney, Bob Dylan, Frank Sinatra, Ray Charles and Diana Krall, died on Monday at his home in Bell Canyon, Calif. He was 91.

headline: What to Know About the Census Data
abstract: The count reflects the slowest population growth since the 1930s. It also offers a glimpse of the shifting centers of population and power in the United States.
lead_paragraph: The count reflects the slowest population growth since the 1930s. It also offers a glimpse of the shifting centers of population and power in the United States.

headline: The Giants Traded Back and, Some Say, Well
abstract: Some fans scratched their heads at Dave Gettleman’s decision to trade back in the draft for the first time. But scooping receiver Kadarius Toney at No. 20 and getting draft assets was no fleecing.
lead_paragraph: When the Giants finally chose Kadarius Toney, a wide receiver from the University of Florida, with the 20th pick in the N.F.L. draft, the team’s fans in Cleveland took a good 10 seconds to start a slow clap, mouthing undecipherable questions beneath their masks.

headline: After 500 Years, an Ancient Bronze Hand Is Rejoined to a Finger
abstract: Researchers still don’t know how a finger belonging to a colossal statue of Emperor Constantine went missing, but this week, it was finally reattached in Rome.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The Louvre Museum in Paris had a gigantic ancient bronze finger that had, at some point in time, been detached from its hand.

headline: Review: Trisha Brown’s Dances Find a Home at Judson Church
abstract: As part of a digital program presented by the Joyce, the Trisha Brown Dance Company focuses on early movement invention.
lead_paragraph: The first movement is of a hand drawing a square with the thick tip of a blue marker. As that same singular hand — it belongs to the choreographer and dancer Trisha Brown — turns the square into a three-dimensional structure, she says, “I imagined a cubicle form to begin with.”

headline: A Year of Cooking With My Mother
abstract: I’ve eaten her food my whole life. This pandemic made me realize how much I didn’t know about her process.
lead_paragraph: Let the record show that I make a terrible roommate. I can still hear my mother’s voice as she encountered the sink full of dishes, the counter spilling over with spices and syrups: “I can’t live like this!”

abstract: Real scalpels, artificial intelligence — what could go wrong?
lead_paragraph: Sitting on a stool several feet from a long-armed robot, Dr. Danyal Fer wrapped his fingers around two metal handles near his chest.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Chuck Schumer
abstract: The April 30 episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Chuck Schumer. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: You Want This Sauce
abstract: Yewande Komolafe uses guasacaca sauce, made with avocado, herbs and lime, alongside roasted carrots and chicken, but you’ll want to put it on everything.
lead_paragraph: After packing into New York City apartments for nearly 20 years, I finally have outdoor space, and so it follows that I am finally the owner of a grill. Grilling! What a fast and delightful way to make dinner on a Wednesday! I can’t say that we’re doing anything fancy with it, but it’s nice to just put some sausages or fish on there at twilight.

headline: Blinken Will Visit Ukraine in Show of Support Against Russia
abstract: The secretary of state will first meet with British officials and other American allies in London.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken will travel to Kyiv next week, a clear signal of the Biden administration’s support for Ukraine’s government against threats from Russia.

headline: Eww, That’s Gross. And We Like It That Way.
abstract: Why the tasteless humor of “Bad Trip,” starring Eric Andre, is a feat to be celebrated. Few can pull off transgression so skillfully.
lead_paragraph: If the comedy “Bad Trip” had premiered in theaters as intended until it moved to Netflix because of the pandemic, one already notorious scene would have surely sent crowds into a frenzy of groans and laughter. It involves an encounter between Eric Andre and a gorilla best not described in a family newspaper. Skillfully paced, preposterously tasteless, it’s a sequence that will alienate a portion of its audience, while cementing a cult reputation with another.

headline: Indoor dining in New York City will expand to 75 percent capacity next week, the governor says.
abstract: The moves comes a day after the city’s mayor said he wanted the city to fully reopen on July 1, a vision that still faces several obstacles.
lead_paragraph: Restaurants in New York City can broaden indoor dining to 75 percent capacity beginning on May 7, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said Friday, an expansion already available to restaurants in the rest of the state.
